Lunar Tug May Cause Magnetism Of the Earth
LEAD: TWO scientists at the University of Georgia have proposed that the Moon may be responsible for the Earth's magnetic field.
Lunar gravity, they say, tugs the solid inner core of the Earth away from the planet's center point, much as the Moon pulls the oceans, producing tides.

She was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

For U.S. Intervention In Haiti
LEAD: Once more the United States confronts a basic reality of international life: intervention in the affairs of another country.
The ethical and political question about Haiti is not whether to intervene but when and how.


Darkening Malaysian Democracy
LEAD: Malaysia has been a singular favorite of diplomats, travelers and investors, a stable and flourishing country with regular elections and lively public debate.
But corruption and ethnic tensions, manageable in boom times, are now festering and the Government has responded with drearily familiar steps: detention without trial, a ban on rallies, tightened secrecy.

Stains on Prehistoric Tool Are Human Blood
LEAD: DARK brown stains preserved on a 100,000-year-old stone cutting tool have been identified as the remains of human blood, the oldest human blood ever analyzed.
Scientists believe the discovery, though tainted by controversy, points to a new means of exploring early human life.


Calling All Sources
LEAD: One of the more prestigious and powerful labels one can wear in Washington is that of ''reliable source.'' Establishing oneself as an expert on a particular subject can mean guest spots on television, higher lecture fees and considerable propaganda value - promoting the party line, as it were, for political or ideological purposes.

Patterns
LEAD:  A Cautious Outlook


Ford Sales in France
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company led sales of foreign cars in France in the first 10 months of 1987, although its market share declined to 6.86 percent from 7.02 percent, the French Car Importers' Association said today.
Ford sold 116,540 cars, followed by Fiat S.p.A. of Italy with 111,135.
Fiat's market share rose to 6.54 percent, from 6.17 percent in the first 10 months of last year.

Music: The Goliard Chorale
LEAD: A PROGRAM devoted to only four works could hardly be more eclectic than that offered by the Goliard Chorale and Chamber Ensemble Sunday evening at Merkin Concert Hall.
It opened with a Psalm setting by Telemann, sung with light precision by the 23-voice ensemble and accompanied by violins with harpsichord continuo.

The U.N. Today: Dec. 1, 1987
LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY


Scholar's 40's Articles Debated
LEAD: In a finding that has stunned scholars, a Yale professor revered as one of the most brilliant intellectuals of his generation wrote for an anti-Semitic, pro-Nazi newspaper in Belgium during World War II, documents have disclosed.


Accounting Rule Plan For Banks
LEAD: The Financial Accounting Standards Board proposed yesterday that banks and other financial institutions be required to report to shareholders the market value of their assets and liabilities.


Sports People; Comings and Goings
LEAD: Kelly Ryan, the Yale quarterback, was named the Ivy League's top player yesterday, heading the all-star team selected by the league's coaches.
Ryan, a senior who led the Ivies in passing and in total offense, was voted the winner of the Asa S. Bushnell Cup. . . .
Randy Milligan, the first baseman for the Mets' Class AAA Tidewater farm team, was named the minor-league player of the year yesterday by The Sporting News.


West Berlin Strives for Its Old Glory in Science
LEAD: For half a century, ending in the 1930's, this city was the scientific capital of the world.
Here Max Planck and Albert Einstein helped lay the foundations of modern physics.
Otto Hahn, Lise Meitner and Fritz Strassmann split the atom.
Heinrich Hertz began the research that led to communication via radio waves.


Who Can Protect the Haitians?
LEAD: When Sunday's election in Haiti was voided, it shattered hopes for democracy and denied Haitians their first chance in 30 years to elect a President.
The culprits are Gen.
Henri Namphy's junta, and the murderous Tontons Macoute thugs whose rampages gave the junta the pretext it needed to call off the vote.

LEAD: A number of people were killed when a freight train crashed into a stationary passenger train on the Transcaucasian railway in Soviet Georgia, Tass said today Monday.

Norwegian Withdraws, Enabling German to Hold Top NATO Post
LEAD: Norway withdrew its candidate for the top political job in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization today, ending an embarrassing tussle within the alliance and clearing the way for Defense Minister Manfred Worner to become the first West German secretary general of NATO.


Stop the School 'Extortion'
LEAD: Can New York City's Board of Education do anything right?
It has a dismal record on counting dropouts.
It stands by while hundreds of homeless children also go school-less.
It has allowed the search for a chancellor to drag on for months.
The board badly needs a victory, and a prime opportunity now presents itself: contract negotiations with school custodians.


NATIONWIDE VOTE IN POLAND REJECTS A PARTY PROPOSAL
LEAD: The Polish Government today acknowledged defeat in Sunday's national referendum to obtain public approval for a severe economic austerity program that also promised some political changes.


FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
LEAD: The Reynolds Metals Company announced the signing of a $1.1 billion loan agreement yesterday to refinance two major term loans and to replace an undrawn revolving credit facility.
The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company acted as the agent, as well as co-manager with the Bank of Nova Scotia, as part of a consortium of 16 banks.

Brazilian Inflation Rises
LEAD: Double-digit monthly inflation returned to Brazil in November, and over the last 12 months inflation was a record 338 percent, the Government said today.
The consumer price index rose 12.84 percent in November, the most since a partial price freeze cut inflation from 26.06 percent in June to 3.05 percent in July.


Prices Paid to Farmers Rise by 3.1%
LEAD: Prices paid to farmers for raw products rose 3.1 percent in November spurred by higher prices for fresh fruits and vegetables, the Agriculture Department said today.

LEAD: Peter F. F. Kissel of Miami Beach, whose colt Pass Catcher won the Belmont Stakes in 1971, died Saturday at the Miami Heart Institute.
He was 61 years old.

LEAD: The violent disruption of Haiti's elections Sunday seemed to destroy a notion that some mysterious, uncontrollable force had been wreaking violence on the land.


Awaiting Dobrynin
LEAD: The guest list for the official Soviet delegation to the summit is not yet final, but one person the Russians will send is Anatoly F. Dobrynin, according to an official at the State Department.


Job Outlook Is Termed Good for Graduates
LEAD: The job outlook for college graduates is good despite the recent stock market collapse, according to a recruiting survey by Michigan State University.


U.S. to Take Steps to Protect Ozone
LEAD: New, legally binding restrictions on the use of chemicals now widely believed to be depleting the earth's ozone layer, which screens out harmful radiation from the sun, will be proposed Tuesday by the Federal Government.


Williams Took Some Giant Missteps
LEAD: In 1983, Perry Williams spent his rookie season on injured reserve.
Since 1984, while other members of the Giants' secondary have been burned by opponents' passes, Williams has quietly become a solid right cornerback who made few errors.


After Apology, Jersey Authority Votes to Raise Toll
LEAD: The New Jersey Highway Authority apologized to the public today and then voted a second time to increase tolls on the Garden State Parkway to 50 cents from 25 cents.


Sports People; Crum Resigns
LEAD: Dick Crum resigned yesterday as football coach at the University of North Carolina, which finished this season with a 5-6 record.
School officials said Crum would be paid an initial $400,000 and $100,000 per year over the four years remaining on his contract.
A statement was released jointly by Crum, Chancellor Christopher Fordham and Athletic Director John Swofford.


Japan Trade Surplus Off
LEAD: Japan reported today that its trade surplus for the first 20 days of November plunged almost 50 percent, to $2.09 billion, from $3.9 billion a year earlier.
Although the yen's increasing strength against the dollar did not inhibit Japanese exports from growing at a rate of 16.4 percent, to $12.16 billion, imports surged 53.7 percent, to $10.07 billion.


Hiring Burglars and 'Stealing' Buildings: Tales of Father Ritter
LEAD: In his early efforts to shelter run-away youths, the Rev.
Bruce Ritter admits that he forced several addicts out of their apartments by paying burglars to steal their clothes, furniture and plumbing.
Then he moved in homeless youngsters.


Sports People; White Re-Retires
LEAD: Jo Jo White's comeback at age 41 with the Topeka Sizzlers of the Continental Basketball League, ended yesterday, 26 days after it began.
White, a former star with the University of Kansas and the Boston Celtics, said he simply did not have the legs to keep up with younger players and felt it was best to retire.


'Hand' Bridges Communication Gap to Deaf-Blind
LEAD: FOR thousands of people, the educated hand of a friend, relative or professional interpreter is the only communication bridge with the outside world.
But an experimental device developed by four mechanical engineering students at Stanford University offers hope of enabling the deaf-blind to receive messages and even read on their own.

LEAD: There were more than enough crises on J. Michael Quinlan's agenda when he took over this summer as director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons.

LEAD: Andre Thornton, a power hitter who had the misfortune of spending many of his most productive years in the middle of a weak Cleveland Indians lineup, retired yesterday. ''I think it was understood that I was no longer in the plans of the ball club,'' Thornton said.

LEAD: Murder charges against Derrick Fenner, the former North Carolina football star, were dropped yesterday, but prosecutors in Upper Marlboro, Md., said they would go ahead with a separate drug and weapons case against him.
Fenner was arrested in June in connection with the fatal shooting in May of Marcellus Leach, 19, in what the police called a turf war between rival drug-dealing factions.

LEAD: Basil Brown, the senior member of the State Senate, pleaded guilty today to two felony drug charges.

LEAD: The Primerica Corporation has agreed to sell its direct marketing subsidiary, Looart Press Inc., to De Luxe Check Printers Inc. of St.
Paul.
Primerica said its proceeds from the sale would be about $150 million, resulting in an after-tax gain of about $35 million, or 65 cents a share.
It said the transaction was scheduled to be completed near year-end.

Marietta Contract
LEAD: The Martin Marietta Corporation said it had received a $608 million Air Force contract for continued production of the Lantirm electro-optical night navigation and targeting system.
The equipment is attached to Air Force fighter planes and enables pilots to fly beneath radar at speeds exceeding 500 miles an hour even in conditions of reduced visibility.


Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. How does a squirrel remember where it has buried a nut, particularly when the ground is snow-covered or frozen?
A.
Squirrels use their ''very acute sense of smell,'' said Skip Garrett, a spokesman for the New York City Parks Department. ''They can tell where the nuts are stored and that's where they go, even if it's not their own cache,'' he said.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders met today for the first time in four months and agreed to try to avoid convening a special session of the Legislature this year.

By Design; The New/Old Fur
LEAD: Be fearless with a fur coat that is no longer in its prime.
It probably cost plenty originally, and you clearly intend to amortize the investment by wearing it for many winters.
But in this season of above-the-knee chic, it is not frivolous to have the hemline of an old coat chopped fashionably short.

TRUE OR FALSE? THE ANATOMY OF A SMILE
LEAD: THE false smile, that ubiquitous social lubricant, has been unmasked by new research that has identified the different specific muscle patterns in smiles that reflect true delight and those that mask displeasure.

LEAD: ELECTRONIC thesauruses are popular programs with word processors in these days of greater built-in memory and fast-access, roomy hard disks.


Wife of Chinese Diplomat at U.N. Is Injured by a Hit-and-Run Driver
LEAD: The wife of China's deputy envoy to the United Nations was critically injured by a hit-and-run driver as she walked across upper Broadway Sunday night, and the police charged a Manhattan man in the case early yesterday.

LEAD: E.Thayer Bigelow Jr., Time Inc.'s chief financial officer, was named yesterday as president of Time's American Television and Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest operator of cable television systems.

LEAD: The Supreme Court agreed today to consider letting the Reagan Administration stop regulating some natural gas prices, a move Government lawyers say could save consumers as much as $100 million a year.

LEAD: Youngsters practicing their twists and turns near the pond in Central Park yesterday as the temperature climbed to 60 degrees.
Today is expected to be breezy and cooler and snow flurries (shiver!) are possible for tomorrow. (NYT/Barton Silverman)


Jackson Tramples Seahawks
LEAD: Bo Jackson, rushing for a team-record 221 yards and scoring three touchdowns, led the Los Angeles Raiders to a 37-14 victory over the Seattle Seahawks tonight.


Twins to Reopen Stadium Lease
LEAD: The Minnesota Twins, claiming net operating losses of $22.79 million over the last three seasons, are exercising their option to terminate the team's lease with the Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome, the Twins' president, Jerry Bell, said today.
The Twins, the 1987 World Series champions, want to negotiate a new lease for the 1989 season, Bell said.

LEAD: After years of hesitation in New York State's legal system, the courts in New York City and four upstate counties will step tentatively into the electronic age today when cameras are allowed for the first time in 50 years during sentencings, trials and testimony.

Careers; Nation's Nursing Shortage
LEAD: ONE profession that needs more people power is nursing.
The nation's 1.4 million registered nurses will have to increase 44 percent, to 2 million, by the year 2000, only 13 years away, the Bureau of Labor Statistics says.
And the 631,000 licensed practical nurses will have to increase 37 percent, to 869,000.

LEAD: A major offshore earthquake jolted south-central Alaska today, prompting thousands of people to flee low-lying coastal areas for the second time in two weeks.

LEAD: Imo Delaval Inc. said today that it had entered into a definitive agreement to acquire Ifint-Incom Inc., the holding company for Incom International Inc., for $166.6 million in cash and the assumption of about $34 million in debt.

LEAD: While the Mets steadfastly hold the contract line at one year for Dwight Gooden, the Yankees are on the verge of signing Don Mattingly to a three-year contract worth $6.7 million.

Transactions
LEAD:  BASEBALL


Edward Carter Ives, Real-Estate Agent, 81
LEAD: Edward Carter Ives, a former Connecticut real-estate agent, died Friday at his home in Kennebunkport, Me.
He was 81 years old.


WASHINGTON SEEMS CONTENT OVER FALL; Slide Began in Asia
LEAD: In Asian trading yesterday, the dollar fell to a new low of 132.45 Japanese yen in Tokyo, compared with Friday's 133.75 yen.
Later, in London, the dollar was quoted at 132.18 yen, and in New York the dollar brought 132.225 yen, compared with 133.55 on Friday.


Our Towns; Metamorphosis Of a Mayor, And Its Cost
LEAD: Angelo R. Martinelli, the dapper millionaire publisher who has presided over the turmoil of Yonkers politics for 12 years as Mayor, said the reports he had changed were true.
It was his transformation, he said with considerable pride, that cost him re-election last month.


Soccer Final At Clemson
LEAD: Clemson was chosen by the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday to be the host for the semifinals and final of the Division I soccer tournament this weekend.


Advertising; J. Walter Thompson Donates Its Archives
LEAD: The 123-year-old J. Walter Thompson Company has announced that it has donated its archives of more than three million items - advertising for all media as well as taped interviews - to Duke University.


Reebok-Ellesse
LEAD: Reebok International Ltd. said it would purchase only Ellesse USA and the Ellesse trademarks for the United States and Canada from Ellesse International S.p.A. for $25 million.
Previously, Reebok was to have purchased the entire Ellesse business worldwide for about $60 million.
The company did not say why the deal was altered.


Autolatina Sees Deficit
LEAD: Autolatina, South America's biggest auto maker, which has sued the Brazilian Government seeking eased price controls, said today that it expected widening losses in 1987 of $200 million to $300 million.
Last year Autolatina, which produces Ford and Volkswagen vehicles in Brazil and Argentina, lost $78 million.

LEAD: SHE needed to buy a computer but didn't know the first thing about them.
So she asked her husband.


Deficit at Corners Worries Walton
LEAD: When you're in a three-way tie for first place, your record is 6-5, and you have Dan Marino facing your depleted secondary, you don't have much time to gloat over a victory.


Eurotunnel Issue Weak
LEAD: Eurotunnel's offering of shares to the public is undersubscribed in Britain, with about 20 percent of the shares still in underwriters' hands, the company said today.


Rig Count Up in Week
LEAD: The number of oil and gas drilling rigs in use in the United States last week rose by nine, to 1,161, Baker Hughes Inc. announced today.
A year ago, the count totaled 954.
The Houston-based oil tool maker tallies the number of rigs exploring for oil, and not rigs producing oil.


Child Abuse Found High in New York Mental Centers
LEAD: Children in New York State mental hygiene facilities are abused and neglected more than twice as often as children in the state generally, a study by a state watchdog commission has found.


Rules Proposed to Curb Electrocutions on Job
LEAD: The Government proposed regulations today aimed at reducing by 40 percent the number of on-the-job electrocutions in certain industries.Electricians and farm and construction workers would be excluded from the regulations.


Women Discuss Striving For Status as Composers
LEAD: Clara Schumann surreptitiously used the name of her famous husband, Robert, to get her works performed before 19th-century audiences that thought women lacked the intellect to write music.


Woolridge Out 4 Weeks
LEAD: The Nets, who have lost their last five games, received some bad news yesterday.
Orlando Woolridge, New Jersey's leading scorer last season with an average of 20.7 points a game, has a broken toe.


Poll Finds Reagan Support Down But Democrats Still Lacking Fire
LEAD: President Reagan's popularity is sliding and so is support for the Republican Party, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.


X-Ray Lasers Expand Scientists' Vision
LEAD: ARMED with new techniques for producing and controlling X-rays, scientists are developing a family of research instruments that they expect will allow them to peer with unprecedented clarity into the mechanism of living cells.


Silent Film Trio
LEAD: A triple-bill of silent films, featuring Laurel and Hardy, Nazimova and Catherine Hessling, is to be shown on Dec. 9 at 7 and 9 P.M. at the Cathedral of St.
John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street.
The films are ''Big Business'' (1929) with Laurel and Hardy; ''Salome'' (1922) with Nazimova, and ''The Little Match Girl'' (1928), directed by Jean Renoir and featuring Catherine Hessling.


Exiled Duvalier Appeals for Calm
LEAD: Jean-Claude Duvalier, the deposed Haitian President, appealed today for calm in Haiti and for an end to the violence that caused the postponement of the first free presidential elections in 30 years.


J. Howard Pyle Dead; Ex-Arizona Governor
LEAD: J. Howard Pyle, Governor of Arizona from 1951 to 1955 and an aide to President Eisenhower, died here Sunday.
He was 81 years old.

Sports People; Imlach in Hospital
LEAD: George (Punch) Imlach, a member of the Hockey Hall of Fame who coached the Toronto Maple Leafs to the Stanley Cup championship four times in the 1960's, was in critical condition yesterday at Scarborough General Hospital in Toronto after suffering a heart attack at his home Sunday night.
A hospital spokesman said that the 69-year-old Imlach, who experienced heart problems that required a bypass operation in 1981, had no pulse on arrival at the hospital and was revived by emergency-room per-sonnel.

LEAD: The combatants in New York City's bitter tabloid newspaper war - The Daily News, The New York Post and New York Newsday - appear to be on the threshold of a final melee that could determine the city's newspaper landscape for many years to come.


Union Pacific Issue
LEAD: The Union Pacific Corporation is offering $150 million of 9.60 percent notes, due in 1994, at a price of 99.90 to yield 9.619 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.
Noncallable for five years, the notes are rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.&amp;P. and yield about eight-tenths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

LEAD: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov played routinely to an uneventful draw in the 18th game of their world championship chess match in Seville, Spain, on Monday.

LEAD: An attempt at a strong rally fizzled on Wall Street yesterday, although stock prices did manage to recoup some of their losses from Monday's big retreat.

Paul Companies to 20 percent from 8.4 percent.
Based on today's closing price of $67.50, up $2.50 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange, purchasing 5.37 million St.
Paul shares would cost Alleghany more than $351 million.

LEAD: After years of virtually full employment, some economists expect a labor shortage to crimp New England's growth next year and possibly for years to come.

That is the first clue that selecting the right college guide can be just as daunting as selecting the right college.

LEAD: To curb overzealousness in its internal security agency, the Canadian Government has ordered it to disband a countersubversion branch that until recently maintained files on 30,000 people, including some in labor and antiwar groups that have broad public backing.

LEAD: For London's wine crowd the week began Monday with a tasting at the Groucho (''I wouldn't want to belong to any club that would accept me as a member'') Club in Soho.
It ended Friday at the opening of Sir Terence Conran's long-awaited oyster and wine bar, Bibendum, in South Kensington.
It was a busy five days, but then, this is a vibrant wine city.

LEAD: Betty Ford, the wife of former President Gerald R. Ford, returned to her home in good condition after hospitalization for quadruple coronary bypass surgery, a spokeswoman says.
Mrs.
Ford was expected to be released from the Eisenhower Medical Center for Thanksgiving, but her doctor held her longer to make sure she had recuperated completely, the spokeswoman said.

LEAD: The United States Supreme Court refused today on procedural grounds to reinstate a 1982 New Jersey law requiring public schools to set aside one minute of silence daily ''for quiet and private contemplation and introspection.''


Golf to Benefit Special Olympics
LEAD: Proceeds from the 1988 United States Women's Open golf tournament will be donated to the Maryland Special Olympics, Ricki Baker, the tournament's executive director, said today at a news conference at the Baltimore Country Club, which will be the site of the event July 18-24.


Leading Indicators Down 0.2%
LEAD: Dragged down by the diving stock market, the Government index designed to predict the economy declined by two-tenths of 1 percent in October, the Commerce Department reported today.


Syria, Isolated at U.N., Drops Terrorism Plan
LEAD: The Soviet Union and third-world countries have joined Western nations at the General Assembly to defeat a move by Syria that many countries contended would confer legitimacy on international terrorism.


Parcells Insists He'll Return
LEAD: Bill Parcells has told his Giants that despite rumors to the contrary, he will return next year as coach.
He said the same thing during his weekly radio show for WNEW-AM.


Bonn Reappoints Pohl
LEAD: Karl Otto Pohl, 57-year-old president of West Germany's central bank, has been officially reappointed to a second eight-year term by the nation's President, Richard von Weizsaecker.


Charge of Attempted Murder Dropped in AIDS Blood Case
LEAD: A judge today dimissed two counts of attempted murder against a man who twice sold his AIDS-tainted blood, saying the prosecution could not prove the defendant had intended to kill anyone.


Down to a Handshake
LEAD: IVAN LENDL and Pat Cash were playing for the richest single prize in tennis history.
It was the final of the initial Stakes Match, seen on ABC-TV Sunday afternoon, and at one point, one of the announcers, Cliff Drysdale or Arthur Ashe, said, ''If Cash gets much further behind, he might be left with nothing but a handshake.


Decision Industries Gets Onset Offer
LEAD: The Onset Corporation has begun a friendly $8.75-a-share offer for the Decision Industries Corporation, which it said would cost $92 million, but a second company said that it would pay more for the computer concern based in Horsham, Pa.


2 Hunts Seek Chapter 11
LEAD: The personal trusts of Lamar and Nelson Bunker Hunt filed for protection from creditors today under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

A Senate Panel Votes to Ban Sale of Missiles to Bahrain
LEAD: The Senate Appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations approved a $12.2 billion foreign aid bill today that includes a ban on the Reagan Administration's plans to sell Stinger anti-aircraft missiles to Bahrain.


Building Outlays Down 0.5%
LEAD: Construction spending fell five-tenths of 1 percent in October, the first decline since March, the Commerce Department reported today.


House Approves Bill on Cherokee Removal
LEAD: The House passed legislation today to commemorate the forced removal of Cherokees from North Carolina to Oklahoma a century ago.


Sports World Is Taking Stock Plunge in Stride
LEAD: Six weeks after the stock market crash wiped out half a trillion dollars of the nation's wealth, those who work in the multibillion-dollar sports industry are in broad agreement that the immediate impact on athletes and athletics was limited, that the short-range fallout has been negligible and that even in the face of a possible recession the long-term outlook remains bright.


Russia Between The Coasts
LEAD: One dark night a long time ago in Provincetown, Mass., hearing sounds of desperation in the water that lapped our rental house, I waded in and retrieved a fully clothed female person, age about 18.


Killer Says He Helped In Chesimard's Escape
LEAD: An admitted killer testified yesterday that he and two defendants had helped carry out the dramatic prison escape of Joanne Chesimard, a Black Liberation Army leader, in 1979.


A Brave New World Emerging?
LEAD: In the days before the Reagan-Gorbachev meeting, a reporter from Washington finds a surprisingly hopeful mood in Western Europe about East-West relations.
It's not just anticipation of the first limited agreement to reduce the superpowers' nuclear arsenals.
One even hears thoughtful speculation about the beginning of the end of the cold war.


John P. Doswell, Pilot, 64
LEAD: John P. Doswell, a World War II combat pilot and the former director of operations for Flight Safety International, a pilot training school at La Guardia Airport, died of brain cancer Sunday at his home in Old Greenwich, Conn.
He was 64 years old.


Bhopal Case Charges Filed
LEAD: Investigators for the Government of India filed criminal charges today against the Union Carbide Corporation; Warren M. Anderson, its former chairman, and eight Indians stemming from the 1984 gas leak at a Carbide subsidiary's plant in Bhopal, India.


Black Cubans: Apart in Two Worlds
LEAD: The uprisings at two Federal prisons have focused attention on a dimension of the Cuban refugee exodus generally overlooked among the countless successes achieved by Cubans settling in Miami over the last three decades: the struggle of the black Cuban to share that success.


Gay Health Group Is Cleared in U.S. Inquiry
LEAD: An investigation by the Department of Health and Human Services has cleared officials of the Gay Men's Health Crisis of accusations that the Manhattan-based group used Federal money to produce sexually explicit educational comic books.


Using Heat in Treatment of Some Cancers
LEAD: MEDICAL historians trace the idea of fighting cancer tumors with heat to Hippocrates, who successfully treated his fellow Greeks in baths of hot sand 24 centuries ago.


CAPITALS STOP GRETZKY, 4-2
LEAD: Bengt Gustafsson scored two goals and assisted on another in Washington's four-goal second period tonight as the Capitals defeated Edmonton, 4-2, and became the second team this season to shut out Wayne Gretzky.


Picture of Death Squads Seen In Key Salvadoran Notebook
LEAD: If a former close aide to the rightist Salvadoran political leader Roberto d'Aubuisson ever comes to trial, a key piece of evidence could be a notebook that appears to show the inner workings of rightist death squads, according to American and Salvadoran officials.


Mother Pleads Guilty To Rape of Daughter
LEAD: A 20-year-old Bronx woman has pleaded guilty to holding her 6-year-old daughter while the child was sexually assaulted by two men, the authorities said yesterday.


Weed Trimmers Recalled
LEAD: Black &amp; Decker is recalling about 500,000 weed trimmers because of the potential for electric shock, the Consumer Product Safety Commission says.
Involved are Model 82209, Type 1 and 2, and Model 82210 Type 1 and 2, 9-and 10-inch bump-feed trimmers, the agency said Monday.
The wiring in some of them may be improperly located, allowing the handle tube to cut it, and lead to an electric shock hazard.


L.D. Hinshaw Is Dead; Presbyterian Minister
LEAD: Lillias Dulles Hinshaw, a Presbyterian minister and the daughter of the late Secretary of State John Foster Dulles, died after a long illness Monday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.
She was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Senior Democrats Look for Alternative Candidates
LEAD: Senior Democratic leaders, increasingly dismayed and frustrated by the performance of their party's six contenders for President, have started meeting privately to discuss ways of getting other candidates into the race.


Bridge: Dramatic Swiss Team Event Brings Fall Nationals to End
LEAD: There was a dramatic finale to the three-day North American Swiss Team Championship that ended here Sunday night as the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals concluded.


Mary Harmon Nason, Ex-Advertising Official
LEAD: Mary Harmon Nason, a former advertising executive and real-estate developer, died of cardiac arrest Nov. 14 at her home in Longboat Key, Fla.
She was 85 years old.
Mrs.
Nason was active for many years with her husband, James R. P. Nason, in developing properties in Connecticut, Nantucket Island, the Bahamas and Longboat Key.


Film: 'Blind,' Wiseman Documentary
LEAD: FREDERICK WISEMAN, the lawyer turned film maker, made his first feature in 1967, the tough, harrowing, litigation-plagued ''Titicut Follies,'' about life in the State Prison for the Criminally Insane at Bridgewater, Mass.
It seems he's scarcely taken a day off since.
In the last 20 years he's made 18 highly personal documentaries, most of them about institutions (hospitals, the police, the Army, meatpacking, among other subjects) that shape and define American life.


L.I.R.R. Halts 5 Trains as 25 Engineers Walk Out
LEAD: About 25 Long Island Rail Road engineers walked off the job briefly today in a dispute over vacation time, forcing the cancellation of five afternoon trains.


Soviet TV News
LEAD: American publications may not have much of an appetite for such news out of the Soviet Union as ''Volunteers Harvest Uzbekistan Cotton by Hand'' or ''Substandard Auto Services Plague Khabarovsk,'' but Soviet television's version of arms control talks in Geneva or a new flare-up in the Persian Gulf could be a different story - at least the owners of Worldview Inc.

LEAD: Jules Haimovitz, one of a group of managers who attempted a leveraged buyout of Viacom International Inc., yesterday was named president and chief operating officer of Aaron Spelling Productions Inc. in Los Angeles.


Hurdle Retires
LEAD: Clint Hurdle, one of the most highly rated rookies in baseball 10 years ago, ended his career as a player yesterday and began a new one as a manager in the Mets' farm system.


Primerica's Rating Studied
LEAD: The Standard &amp; Poor's Corporation said yesterday that it might reduce the Primerica Corporation's senior long-term debt to a speculative BB rating from BBB currently.


SENATE APPROVES SCHOOL PROGRAMS
LEAD: The Senate voted today overwhelmingly approved elementary and secondary education programs that could cost up to $7.4 billion, including programs for disadvantaged children and grants to states.


Music: Marianne Faithfull Returns
LEAD: MARIANNE FAITHFULL confessed to nervousness Monday at the Bottom Line, in the second of three nights in her first live show since 1983.
But a remarkable band, Ms.
Faithfull's singular voice and, perhaps, the tension of facing an audience again combined for one of the strongest performances in recent memory - complex, adult emotions conveyed with artful directness.


For R.S.V.P., Try D.B.
LEAD: Washingtonians have a way of dealing with invitations to parties they know will be either a crush of warm bodies or a crashing bore.


Jackson Proves He's At Home in the N.F.L.
LEAD: After Bo Jackson's team-record rushing performance and three touchdowns led the Los Angeles Raiders to a 37-14 victory over the Seattle Seahawks Monday night, the running back said that he had not given any thought to giving up his baseball career with the Kansas City Royals.


Topics of The Times; The Garlic Experience
LEAD: Some people wouldn't think twice about refusing garlic for the sake of a heavy date.
This is the kind of person made for Dr.
Saiki's Odorless Garlic, a triumph of Japanese know-how soon to be test-marketed on the East Coast.
But marketers of the product may have miscalculated.
True garlic lovers don't avoid garlic for the sake of human contact; instead, they limit their human contacts to other garlic lovers.


The One Who Got Away
LEAD: Brett Butler and the San Francisco Giants reached agreement on a two-year, $1.8 million contract yesterday, and Chili Davis, whom Butler will replace as the Giants' center fielder, accepted an offer from the California Angels believed to be for one year and an $850,000 salary.


Any Toaster Can Do Toast, But the Little Extras Count
LEAD: THE technology of home toasters has not changed fundamentally in 40 years.
Their function is simple and limited.
Of course, that hasn't stopped American manufacturers from fiddling with size, shape, color and special features to create diversity, real or imaginary, among brands - just as shoppers are led to believe that there is a difference among the half-dozen brands of canned peas on the market.


Real Estate; Rebuilding Pursued in Hempstead
LEAD: IN the 1940's and 1950's Hempstead served as the downtown for many of the new Long Island communities then emerging throughout Nassau County, but it began to slip into decline as the county evolved into a highly prosperous suburban area.


U.S. Seizes 5 Properties Seen as Drug Profits
LEAD: The Federal Government has seized five Florida properties worth $20 million as part of a campaign to confiscate investments made with profits from drug trafficking, estimated to exceed $300 million in Florida.

LEAD: Unworldly the Amish here in Lancaster County may be, but that doesn't mean they are impervious to the new, the modern and the secular.

LEAD: Stephen Zoll, an architecture writer and editor, died Nov. 24 of injuries suffered in an automobile accident near Cambridge, England.
He was 55 years old.


Picasso Work Brings $7.6 Million, a Record
LEAD: Picasso's ''Souvenir of Havre,'' an oval Cubist work depicting a bottle of rum, a glass, seashells, an anchor, ropes and a piece of fake wood, was auctioned at Sotheby's in London last night for $7.6 million, a record at auction for a painting by the artist.


2 Factors Help Dollar
LEAD: The dollar rallied from Monday's record lows in active interbank trading yesterday, helped by support from Asian and European central banks and by rumors that West Germany is about to cut its key interest rate.


Mother Sentenced in Death
LEAD: A mother convicted of criminal negligence after her 11-month-old son drowned in a mop bucket has been ordered to attend classes on how to rear children as part of her probation.
The baby, Justin Hoffman, drowned in a 5-gallon bucket after his mother left him and his 23-month-old brother alone to watch a soap opera.

LEAD: Supporters of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., who espouses theories of political conspiracy, have succeeded in placing an anti-AIDS referendum on the state ballot next June, California officials report.


Short-Term Rates Are Steady
LEAD: Short-term interest rates were little changed yesterday while Treasury bond yields rose slightly as traders kept one eye on fluctuations in the stock market and waited for more economic data to give a clearer picture of interest rate trends.

LEAD: When Lou Wacker arrived at Emory &amp; Henry College in 1982 to coach the football team, he said his goal was a national championship for the Division III school.
The statement sounded foolhardy, considering that the school's reputation had been made in the classroom, not on the field.
Before Wacker arrived at Emory &amp; Henry, the Wasps had had just one winning season in the previous 13.

LEAD: It's back to the bench for Doug Williams, the Washington Redskins quarterback, and he's a bit miffed about it.
Williams was the starter until he missed Sunday's game against the Giants due to a back injury.

Freshman Sparks Indiana to Victory COLLEGE BASKETBALL; Manhattan 84, Columbia 80    By The Associated Press - Billy Wheeler scored 22 of his career-high 35 points to power a second-half surge for Manhattan (2-1).   Wheeler, a senior guard who made 13 of 25 field-goal attempts, scored 6 consecutive points during an 11-4 spurt that brought Manhattan from a 66-59 deficit to a tie at 70 with 6:58 to play.   Peter Runge, who had 20 points for Manhattan, put the Jaspers ahead to stay on a free throw with 3:43 left. He gave Manhattan an 80-76 lead on a 3-point play.   Matt Shannon led Columbia (0-3) with a career-high 25 points. He hit all 5 of his 3-point tries in the first half, which ended tied at 38.  Marist 76, Southampton 49    POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. (AP) -Rik Smits scored 19 points and blocked 7 shots to lead Marist. Smits, a 7-4 senior center, became the fourth-leading scorer in Marist history. The first of his five slam dunks capped a 14-2 run for the Red Foxes to open the game.   Marist, which led by 39-18 at halftime, put the game out of reach with a 13-1 flurry midway through the second half.   Rudy Bourgarel added 12 points and a team-high 13 rebounds for Marist. Smits also had 10 rebounds.   Daryl Cambrelen of Southampton (0-5) was the game's leading scorer with 23 points.  Boston College 121 Harvard 80    CAMBRIDGE, Mass. (AP) - Dana Barros led Boston College (2-2) with 26 points. A full-court press throughout the game forced 25 Harvard (1-2) turnovers.   The Eagles received 19 points from Jamie Benton and 17 points from Corey Beasley, a freshman.   Harvard was paced by Ralph James with 16 points and Mike Gielen with 14.

Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about Paul de Man, a professor of humanities at Yale University, misstated the year of his death and his age.
He died on Dec. 21, 1983, at the age of 64.
In some copies, a colleague at Johns Hopkins University was misidentified.
He is Prof.
Neil Hertz.

LEAD: Two months after a major radiation accident shocked this Brazilian city, the threat of contamination, like an intangible plague, still reaches deep into the psyche of its inhabitants.

LEAD: The Federal Government spends $3.4 billion a year on guaranteed loans for college students, but $1.6 billion of that, or nearly half, helps no one pay for books and tuition.
It goes to cover the cost of defaulted loans.


Scotch and Silk; A Man of Spirit Shares His Life
LEAD: In good weather there used to be an old man and an ancient woman sharing a stoop on West 11th Street, the man singing and the woman tapping in time.
The man, dressed to the nines, would leave his rooming house and put his face to the sun, listening for the familiar sound of his companion's approach - the triple beat of a pair of feet and a cane coming down the walk.

Nectar of the White Roussillon Peach
LEAD: IN the French language, a pecher is a peach tree and a peche is a sin.
To these nearly sound-alike words add mignon, meaning cute, and the result is both a pun and the name of a new liqueur.

LEAD: Larry Davis, who is being tried for the murder of four suspected drug dealers, told the trial judge yesterday that his throat had been slashed by a fellow inmate at the Bronx House of Detention Monday while three officers from the Department of Correction watched and ''did nothing.''


Time to Be Serious About the Housing Crisis
LEAD: To the Editor:


Gorbachev, the Movie and the Reality
LEAD: The Soviet leader who will arrive next week in Washington will be less a stranger to Americans than any of his predecessors.
Just days before his summit visit, Mikhail Gorbachev was there for all to read in his new book, ''Perestroika,'' and for all to see in an interview on American television.
The reviews were quick and varied: canned and candid, belligerent and believable, inspirational and manipulative.

LEAD: A prime-time Soviet broadcast of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's interview on NBC News rolled along untouched for 55 minutes tonight, until the subject of Raisa Gorbachev came up - and with it, by implication, the ticklish question of her role in her husband's grand designs for Soviet society.

LEAD: Bishop Josef Vrana, one of only three Roman Catholic prelates in Czechoslovakia, has died at the age of 82, the official press agency reported today.


Robbins Plans Retrospective
LEAD: Jerome Robbins, absent from Broadway since 1964, plans to return next fall with a retrospective of his theater choreography that would include dances from the period between ''On the Town,'' in 1944, and ''Fiddler on the Roof,'' which opened two decades later and was his last work for the commercial stage.

LEAD: The latest round of buyer incentives is likely to do even less to stimulate the auto industry than the last round, which ended just two months ago, analysts and industry sources say.

LEAD: Chicago's City Council, in an emotional special session in chambers surrounded by chanting protesters, appeared late Tuesday night about to elect Eugene Sawyer, a black Alderman, as Acting Mayor.
However, opposition to his selection set off a round of wrangling that continued into the early morning hours today.


Funds' Assets Drop in Month
LEAD: Assets of the nation's mutual funds plunged $53.2 billion in October, the month of the stock market's spectacular dive, to $774.1 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

LEAD: Senate tax writers began piecing together a $9 billion package of tax increases today as top White House officials lobbied Republican senators to support the deficit-reduction agreement reached last month between the Administration and leaders of Congress.

LEAD: The pension funds of the General Motors Corporation and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company are investing substantially more than $100 million each in a $1.1 billion fund to finance friendly takeovers, officials close to the deal disclosed yesterday.

They never have.''

LEAD: A bid by the Scandinavian Airlines System for the ailing British Caledonian Airways is being considered by the British Trade and Industry Secretary, Lord Young, a spokeswoman said.
S.A.S., half-owned by the Swedish, Danish and Norwegian Governments and half privately owned, is interested in acquiring a 40 percent to 50 percent stake.

LEAD: The Duro-Test Corporation said that it had given confidential financial information to two companies, the American Magnetics Corporation and Ballantrae Partners L.P., that are interested in acquiring the light bulb manufacturer, based in North Bergen, N.J.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Duro-Test said the parties had agreed to purchase no additional Duro-Test shares for a year ''other than pursuant to a tender offer for all shares in which all shareholders are treated equally.

LEAD: It's a wonder how Charles Redman, the State Department spokesman, kept a straight face when he attacked France yesterday for dealing with Iran to obtain the release of French hostages in Lebanon.
Mr.
Redman's criticism implied that the virtuous United States would never stoop to rewarding hostage-takers.

LEAD: Justice David S. Ritter of State Supreme Court in Orange County was appointed today the administrative judge in the Ninth Judicial District, overseeing state courts in Westchester, Rockland, Orange, Putnam and Dutchess Counties.

Reductions At Dayton
LEAD: The Dayton-Hudson Corporation, which outspent all other retailers with capital allocations of about $2 billion in the last two years, said yesterday that it was cutting back to about $600 million next year for new stores and remodelings.
Kenneth A. Macke, Dayton-


Southland Proposal To Finance Buyout
LEAD: The Southland Corporation's on-again, off-again attempts to become a private company were on again yesterday as its investment bankers came up with a new plan to finance the $5.1 billion deal.


Saatchi &amp; Saatchi Wins Two $10 Million Billings
LEAD: Saatchi &amp; Saatchi DFS Compton, New York, won two pieces of business yesterday, each of which bills a healthy $10 million.
One is Fruit Corners from General Mills.
The other is Little Caesars Pizza, the largest pizza take-out chain in America.


Life in the 30's
LEAD: I HATE parent-teacher conferences.
I love the teacher.
I love the school.
I even kind of love the little chairs you have to sit in, that set your knees to knocking against your sternum.
I always bring a bribe: a bagel with butter and a cup of coffee.
It's unnecessary.
My elder child is the kind of kid about whom the teacher says everything you've waited all your life to hear: imaginative, generous, social, the proverbial ''pleasure to have in class.


The U.N. Today; Dec. 2, 1987
LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY


Holtzman, in Letter, Asserts Judge Degraded Woman in a Sex Case
LEAD: The Brooklyn District Attorney has asserted that a New York City judge ordered the complainant in a sexual misconduct trial to get on the floor on her hands and knees, as the defendant and others watched, to demonstrate her position when she was attacked.


Howard Bid Rejected
LEAD: Jim Marchiony, a spokesman for the National Collegiate Athletic Association, said yesterday that the Division I-AA football committee had rejected a proposal from Howard University to expand the playoff field from 16 teams to 20.
The university last week filed a $9 million suit against the N.C.A.A.


Sex Bias Ruling Against A.T.&amp;T. Subsidiary
LEAD: In a decision that could affect 20,000 women, a Federal district judge has ruled that a subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company discriminated against pregnant employees over a 12-year period in the 1960's and 1970's.


Mattingly Is Secure
LEAD: Don Mattingly, who is expected to sign a three-year contract worth $6.7 million ''anytime soon,'' is feeling about as secure as he ever has in his career with the Yankees these days.
But yesterday he was also feeling ''under the weather,'' and that, he explained, was why he did not make a blood donation, as planned, during an appearance to promote the Greater New York Blood Drive at the New York Health &amp; Racquet


INSIDE
LEAD:  Hostage Freed in Atlanta


Detroit Symphony Labor Negotiations Break Off
LEAD: The 11-week-old labor dispute between the Detroit Symphony Orchestra and its musicians worsened today as negotiations for a new contract broke down and the symphony canceled its Christmas concerts.


Shaker Cooking: Simplicity's Renewed Appeal
LEAD: SISTER FRANCES A. CARR is the kitchen deaconess, or head cook, of the little Shaker community of Sabbathday Lake near Poland Spring, Me., about 30 miles northwest of Portland.
She is one of the handful of remaining members of the sect, whose adherents once numbered in the thousands.
By the mid-19th century, their tidy settlements had spread from Sabbathday Lake in the hills of southern Maine across New Hampshire and upstate New York and into Ohio and


TV Reviews; 'A Conversation With Gorbachev'
LEAD: WHO'S the boss? That's easy; it's Mikhail S. Gorbachev.


WITNESS TESTIFIES HE WARNED DEAVER
LEAD: Repeated high-level warnings failed to deter Michael K. Deaver from contacting certain former White House associates and venturing broad hints that he could use their help as a private lobbyist, according to testimony today at his perjury trial.


Attackers From Egypt Wound Israeli Soldier
LEAD: An Israeli soldier was slightly wounded early today when two unidentified gunmen opened fire on an Israeli Army patrol after having cut a hole in the Egyptian-Israeli border fence, an Israeli Army spokesman said.


Canada Bank Seeks 75% of Brokerage
LEAD: The Royal Bank of Canada, the largest bank in the country, announced yesterday a complex plan to acquire 75 percent of Dominion Securities Ltd., Canada's largest full-service securities firm.
The deal is worth $385 million (Canadian), or $294 million in United States currency.


U.S. Rejects Claims in Mining of Harbor
LEAD: To the Editor:


PACT WITH PAN AM REPORTED BY PILOTS
LEAD: Pan American World Airways yesterday struck an 11th-hour deal with its pilots that could undermine a yearlong attempt by some of the airline's unions to find a buyer for the carrier and replace its current management.


Anti-Apartheid Parley Opens
LEAD: Julius K. Nyerere, the former Tanzanian President, said today that apartheid would leave a social and economic legacy that would last long beyond the transfer of political power to South Africa's black majority.


Colonial League: New Role Model
LEAD: The Colonial League, the six-team organization that just finished its second season with a flush of success, is delighted to serve as a model for intercollegiate football.
But it has no immediate plans for opening its doors to others, according to Peter Likins, the president of Lehigh University and one of the league's founders.


Bail Revoked in Bet Case
LEAD: A Federal judge Monday revoked bail for a son-in-law of former Mayor Frank L. Rizzo who was accused of continuing to take bets four months after his conviction on Federal bookmaking charges.
The convict, Joseph Mastronardo Jr., 35 years old, of Huntingdon Valley, was convicted in July of running a multimillion-dollar gambling operation that stretched from New York to Florida.


Supreme Court Roundup; Citizens' Suits in Pollution Cases Are Limited
LEAD: The Supreme Court today handed industrialists what appeared to be a partial victory over environmental groups in a complex decision limiting the ability of citizens to sue polluters for past violations of the Federal Clean Water Act.


Heir Guilty in Scheme to Defraud a Texas Charity
LEAD: A Galveston insurance heir was convicted today of defrauding his family's charitable foundation of nearly $1.5 million and faces up to 85 years in prison.


Tobacco Lawyer Said to Shift on Cancer
LEAD: A lawyer for the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company conceded in a September meeting with top Government health officials that cigarette smoking is related to cancer, heart disease and chronic lung disease, according to a memorandum written by one of the officials.


Ex-Head of Militia to Testify in Wedtech Trial
LEAD: The former head of New York's state militia will be the star prosecution witness at the first criminal trial in New York resulting from the sprawling investigations into the Wedtech Corporation, a South Bronx military contractor, lawyers in the case said yesterday.


EX-U.S. AGENTS GET PRISON IN A DEATH
LEAD: Two former agents of the United States Customs Service were sentenced today to 120 years in prison in the 1982 death of a Dominican currency courier who was robbed of nearly $700,000 in cash and checks.


Winter Drink: Pear Liqueur
LEAD: PEACH may be the most popular fruit to flavor wines and spirits these days, but now that winter is approaching it is a pleasure to turn to the seductively rich taste of pear.


NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1987
LEAD:  International A3-19


Corrections
LEAD: A chart in Business Day on Nov. 24 about third-quarter bank performance included incorrect figures provided by the First Bank System of Minneapolis and First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles for their common equity ratios.
The equity ratio for First Bank System should have been 4.64 percent, placing it third in the rankings behind J.


SUSPECTS IN CRASH TAKE SUICIDE PILLS
LEAD: A man and woman who had been passengers aboard a South Korean jetliner before it left the Middle East and disappeared over Burma took suicide pills today as they waited for the police to question them, the authorities said.


New Terms for Beirut M.P.'s
LEAD: Lebanese lawmakers, who have not faced election for 15 years because of strife, renewed their terms in Parliament today for two more years.


James Baldwin, Eloquent Writer In Behalf of Civil Rights, Is Dead
LEAD: James Baldwin, whose passionate, intensely personal essays in the 1950's and 60's on racial discrimination in America made him an eloquent voice of the civil-rights movement, died of stomach cancer early yesterday at his home in St.
Paul de Vence in southern France.
He was 63 years old.


Eating Well
LEAD: IT'S not just the nutritionists and doctors telling us to reduce the amount of fat in our diets.


Swiss Halt Production of Tainted Cheese
LEAD: Production of vacherin Mont d'Or, a soft-ripened cheese prized by connoisseurs, has been halted by the Swiss Government.
The cheese has been linked to outbreaks of listeriosis, a sometimes fatal bacterial infection, in the western part of Switzerland.


Transactions
LEAD:  BASEBALL


BONN PLAN TO SPUR ECONOMY REPORTED
LEAD: Facing pressure at home and abroad to do something about their sluggish economy, West Germany's Finance and Economics Ministers agreed today on a plan to encourage capital spending, Government officials said.


How the Music Slows as the Last Dance Nears
LEAD: Presidencies, like people, go through a natural aging process.
And with 14 months left in office, the two-term Reagan Administration has clearly passed through middle age and is approaching retirement.


A Little Church Made of Gingerbread, Fantasy and Patience
LEAD: WHEN you close your eyes and think of Christmas, do you see snow-covered cottages decorated with gumdrops, cinnamon candies and candy canes?


60- Minute Gourmet
LEAD: IF I were to catalogue the foods that best lend themselves to hasty cooking or cooking within 60 minutes, scallops - whether sea scallops or bay scallops - would rank high.
If they are overcooked, however, they tend to dry out or become chewy.
In prolonged cooking, they also tend to lose their moist succulence and even their sweetness.


2 Say Officials Withhold Data
LEAD: Two organizations of journalists today accused the Justice Department of refusing to enforce the Freedom of Information Act.
Officials of the two groups urged Congress to create an independent agency to resolve disputes over access to Government files.


Paine Webber Seeks Acquisitions
LEAD: The Paine Webber Group Inc., the latest Wall Street beneficiary of Japan's financial power, said it would use some of its $300 million from the Yasuda Mutual Life Insurance Company for acquisitions. ''We're looking at brokerages and asset-management firms,'' said Donald B. Marron, Paine Webber's chairman and chief executive.


Texaco Creditors Back Plan
LEAD: The committee of general creditors of Texaco Inc. yesterday approved an interim settlement proposal in the oil company's three-year battle with the Pennzoil Company, but it declined to disclose its terms until a crucial showdown in bankruptcy court today.


Milk Deliverers Strike As Talks Break Down
LEAD: The milk deliverers' union, angry because management refused to continue contract talks through the night, struck at 12:01 A.M. today, halting all deliveries to New York City, Long Island and most of Westchester County, union officials said.

NEW YORK, IN POLICY SHIFT, WITHHOLDS RENT FROM WELFARE HOTEL
LEAD: The Koch administration has for the first time begun withholding rent payments from an uncooperative welfare hotel in an effort to force it to correct dangerous health and safety code violations, city officials said yesterday.


Stage: One-Acts by Lanford Wilson
LEAD: LIKE the apparently mismatched pair in ''Burn This,'' the people in the three one-act plays by Lanford Wilson that opened last night at the Sanford Meisner Theater are on edge.
The reconciliations made as the lights go down tend to be soft, but Mr.
Wilson's steady humor and his smart dialogue offer pleasures along the way.

LEAD: In the upper ranks of academe, there are two kinds of creatures, those who hold a Ph.D. and the wretched novitiates who are chasing one.


4 COMPANIES WIN NASA'S CONTRACTS FOR SPACE STATION
LEAD: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration awarded contracts yesterday to four companies to begin building the nation's first permanent outpost in space, an undertaking that would cost at least $14 billion and would be the last manned space program of this century for the United States.


Stock-Index Contracts Delayed by C.F.T.C.
LEAD: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has delayed approval of new stock-index futures contracts until it can complete its investigation into the Oct. 19 market collapse, commission officials said today.


Scott Paper Will Cut Its Headquarters Staff
LEAD: The Scott Paper Company said yesterday that it would significantly reduce the number of employees in its Philadelphia headquarters by early next year.
The company would not say how many of the 1,400 workers at the office would be furloughed.

Among those expected to participate are Alicia Alonso, Dame Margot Fonteyn, Mike Nichols and Jerome Robbins, with an introduction by John Taras.

Alleco Dispute
LEAD: Salomon Brothers Inc. disclosed that it might sell its stake in Alleco Inc., formerly the Allegheny Beverage Corporation, because of a disagreement with Alleco over terms of the $18.5 million in senior subordinated debentures controlled by the New York investment firm.
Alleco shareholders approved a transaction today in which a management group agreed to acquire Alleco's food service business, the Service America Corporation, for $345 million in cash and the assumption of the debentures.

2 Pottery Exhibitions, Midtown and SoHo
LEAD: Albert Green says his life was changed when he walked into an exhibition by the Japanese potter Shoji Hamada in Rockefeller Center.
That was 41 years ago, when Mr.
Green, now 73 years old, was a landscape painter. ''I haven't touched a canvas since I touched glazes,'' he said.


Cherished Plants That Recall Friends
LEAD: NOT all the plants in my garden come from nurseries or seed firms, although many do.
At the beginning of every gardening year, when the catalogues arrive, I pore over them in search of the rare, the unusual and the foolproof.
Not all of what I know about gardening comes from books, although my volumes on horticulture fill several shelves.


New Club, Same Coffey Flair
LEAD: WHEN the question is asked, Paul Coffey looks away momentarily, ruminatively rubbing the jaw his trademark beard once occupied.
When he finally turns back, there is softness in his dark eyes.
There are no tears. ''My seven years in Edmonton were fantastic,'' Coffey said in response to a query regarding regrets about the defenseman's recent transfer from the Oilers to the Penguins.


Shot In the Foot
LEAD: The Reagan Administration is engaged in a novel effort to restrict the right of Americans to speak freely and receive information on an acute issue of public policy.
In that effort it has the support of Senators Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, and others who are usually sensitive to constitutional rights.


Airbus Subsidy Talks Continue
LEAD: United States and European trade officials failed to reach a final agreement today in talks about the long-running dispute about government subsidies for the Airbus aircraft consortium.

LEAD: Jay Schulman, a sociologist who advised lawyers in the selection of jurors, died yesterday in his apartment on Central Park West.
He was 60 years old.


Manila Is Split Over Order To Oust Australian Reporter
LEAD: The Philippine Government ordered the expulsion of an Australian reporter today, revoked the order, then reinstated it in a bureaucratic tug of war.

In adolescence we might experience it when a rival wins the affections of our current heartthrob.

LEAD: The TLC Group, a New York-based investment concern headed by Reginald F. Lewis, said that its $985 million purchase of the Beatrice International Food Company had been completed.

LEAD: Time magazine, which recently introduced a Max Plan on advertising sales and greatly upset its competitors, has now announced that it will not increase its ad rates next year, the first year it has not raised them since 1963.

INSIDE
LEAD:  Battling Dishonest Bills


DECOY UNIT HALTED BY TRANSIT POLICE IN ARRESTS DISPUTE
LEAD: The New York City Transit Police Department suspended the operations of its Decoy Unit yesterday amid accusations that officers in the squad had made dubious arrests on subway trains and platforms earlier this year.

Giuliani Weighs Private Post as Step to Senate Race
LEAD: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney for New York's Southern District, says he has talked in detail to two law firms about joining them, an important step to his imminent decision on challenging Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan next year.


Court Order for Blinder
LEAD: A Federal judge has ordered Blinder, Robinson &amp; Company to comply by Monday with a Securities and Exchange Commission subpoena for records sought in an investigation of purported stock manipulation.
In an opinion issued Nov. 24 but not released until this week, United States District Judge Harold H.


Cuts at Ciba-Geigy
LEAD: The Ciba-Geigy Corporation announced that 27 research positions would be eliminated from its pharmaceuticals division in Summit, N.J., in an attempt to streamline operations.
The drug company, based in Basel, Switzerland, hopes to place the researchers in other jobs within the company, a spokesman said.


In the Capital, a Battle of the 'Brifinks'
LEAD: In a city where ''spin control'' is an art form, the Soviet Government presented reporters today with four senior officials to field questions about everything from Afghanistan to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's wife, Raisa.

Shearson Reported To Acquire Hutton In a $1 Billion Deal
LEAD: In one of the largest consolidation moves in modern Wall Street history, E. F. Hutton &amp; Company, the 83-year-old brokerage house, has agreed to be bought by Shearson Lehman Brothers for almost $1 billion, executives close to the negotiations said last night.

Ethiopia's Wars Foil Aid to Hungry
LEAD: Just beyond this oasis of tree-lined streets, cosmopolitan boutiques and southern European ambiance, the ravages of armed conflict and hunger paint a different reality.


Dance: 'Fresh Tracks'
LEAD: SEVEN dances were offered on ''Fresh Tracks,'' the program of works by young choreographers that was presented Tuesday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater.
All were interesting in one way or another.
And, through a sheer fluke of scheduling, six proved surprisingly similar.


In Salvador, 'Dream' Ends For a Rebel
LEAD: Ruben Zamora, a Salvadoran rebel official, seemed pensive today as he boarded a plane after finishing an 11-day visit to his country that ended seven years in exile.


Sports People; Richardson's Admission
LEAD: Michael Ray Richardson, the former Nets star, has admitted stealing $9,700 from an insurance company by cashing an insurance check intended to pay for repairs on his wife's car.


A Holiday Bounty of Plain and Fancy Gifts for the Home
LEAD: CHRISTMAS is a time most of us like to stay close to home.
But presents for the approaching holiday season, like those here and on page C6, can come from far afield - like a tribal stool from Africa or a contemporary Japanese tool set.
If you prefer the traditional, a shiny samovar from West Germany serves 50 -enough for any seasonal gathering.


A Calm Voice For Chicago: Eugene Sawyer Jr.
LEAD: In the tumult of Chicago politics, Eugene Sawyer has been considered the calm voice of reason that could appeal to the city's many opposing factions.


'Sherlock' Is Closing
LEAD: ''Sherlock's Last Case,'' a mystery thriller by Charles Marowitz, is to close after the matinee performance on Sunday at the Nederlander Theater, 208 West 41st Street.
Directed by A. J. Antoon and co-starring Frank Langella and Donal Donnelly, the play will have run for 13 previews and 124 performances.


Edwin W. Ebel, Executive, 86
LEAD: Edwin W. Ebel, a former vice president of the General Foods Corporation, died Monday at a nursing home in Chappaqua, N.Y.
He was 86 years old and lived in Chappaqua.


Dollar Drops Late in Day Amid German Uncertainty
LEAD: After closing higher in relation to the West German mark in European trading yesterday, the dollar weakened in later New York trading amid uncertainty about whether the Bundesbank would cut its main lending rate.


Watercolor Attributed To Hitler Brings $8,300
LEAD: A watercolor attributed to Hitler has been sold for about $8,300 at an auction.


MORE DESIGNING WOMEN
LEAD: ''DESIGNING WOMEN'' may not only be the name of a hit television series.
Dennie Pimenthal, former president of Hickory Business Furniture, now of Schafer Inc. of California, is enlisting a group of women to design office furniture.


Nets Are No Match for Bird
LEAD: Larry Bird had just scored his 31st and 32d points on a jump shot tonight to give the Boston Celtics a 79-59 advantage with five minutes remaining in the third quarter.
As the 18-foot turnaround shot off a pass from Danny Ainge cleared the net, Gary St.
Jean, the Nets' assistant coach, gave a deep sigh and said, ''Here's a kid who played center in college, and in his third pro game he's guarding Bird, one of the great scorers in pro basketball.


Polish Vote: Easier Path; Strict Austerity Plan Can Now Be Softened
LEAD: The Polish Government's unexpected defeat in a national referendum Sunday is not likely to alter the direction of its drive for change, but will force it to tread lightly in imposing drastic austerity on an already strained economy.


Deaver Trial Hears Tape of Grand Jury Testimony
LEAD: The prosecution in the trial of Michael K. Deaver, having called all its witnesses, today began playing for the jury more than five hours of tape recordings of the grand jury testimony that led to Mr.
Deaver's indictment on five counts of perjury.


More Funds for Argentina
LEAD: The International Monetary Fund has approved modifications in the economic program for Argentina, allowing the debtor country to get additional money to overhaul its economy, the agency said today.


Transactions
LEAD:  BASEBALL


Reagan on Networks For Interview Tonight
LEAD: President Reagan will appear on the major commercial television networks Thursday night in an interview to be conducted by the network anchors.


Grace to Split Sale of Assets
LEAD: The W. R. Grace Company said today that it had decided to sell its agricultural and chemical businesses in separate transactions instead of together.
The new direction was disclosed by a Grace executive at a meeting with financial analysts in San Diego.


Japan Pushed On Quotas
LEAD: Japan, reacting to a complaint of unfair trade brought by the United States, said today that it could not accept in full a report by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade urging Tokyo to remove import quotas on 10 agricultural products.


Rebuff to Palestinians Is Upheld
LEAD: A Federal District Court judge today upheld a State Department order closing an information office connected to the Palestine Liberation Organization, rejecting claims that shutting it down was unconstitutional.


Time for Somebody to Defend Herbert Hoover
LEAD: To the Editor:


Dr. George D. Ruggieri, Director Of Aquarium and a Jesuit, Dies
LEAD: Dr.
George D. Ruggieri, director of the New York Aquarium and Osborn Laboratories of Marine Sciences in Coney Island, died of cancer Tuesday at the home of a sister in Moorestown, N.J.
He was 62 years old and lived in Brooklyn.


Treasury Official Backs Brokerage-Bank Links
LEAD: George D. Gould, the Treasury's Under Secretary for finance, endorsed a proposal today that would allow commercial banks to participate in investment banking activities for the first time in 50 years, but he stopped short of endorsing a related measure that calls for further changes in the nation's financial system.

The Stage: 'Tamara'
LEAD: AS a play, ''Tamara'' exists on three levels - upstairs, downstairs and in Gabriele d'Annunzio's chamber.
Opening last night at the Seventh Regiment Armory, it is an entertaining party game and murder mystery theme park.
Whatever it is - and ''Tamara'' is self-defining - it is unlike any other show currently in New York.

LEAD: ''Orpheus in the 20th Century,'' a musical program devoted to works based upon the Orpheus myth, will begin the Brooklyn Philharmonic's Meet the Moderns series on Jan. 29 at 8 P.M., at Cooper Union, Cooper Square and Seventh Street.

Pirates Tap Westinghouse
LEAD: The chairman of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Douglas D. Danforth, embarked on a new career yesterday.
He was named chairman and chief executive of the Pittsburgh Pirates baseball club.

CHICAGO IN TURMOIL AS MAYOR IS CHOSEN
LEAD: Chicago got a new Acting Mayor today, Eugene Sawyer, a black alderman chosen by the City Council in a raucous predawn vote after 12 hours of street demonstrations, scuffles, chants and angry debate, with at least one Council member donning a bulletproof vest.

Caterpillar Notes
LEAD: Caterpillar Inc. is offering $100 million of 9 3/8 percent notes due in 1993 at a price of 99.70, to yield 9.441 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company.
Rated A-3 by Moody's and A- by S.&amp;P., the noncallable notes yield about eight-tenths of a percentage point more than the average of the most recently issued five- and seven-year Treasury notes.

Iran Gamble For Chirac; At Home and Abroad, Issue Poses Problems
LEAD: In reviving the idea of ''normalizing'' relations with Iran, Prime Minister Jacques Chirac has taken a major political gamble at home and provoked accusations abroad that France has reverted to a policy of appeasing terrorists.


Good Fortune Provides Gifts For Neediest
LEAD: Some people like to share good fortune by contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

Sony Unit Sets Price Increase
LEAD: The Sony Corporation of America said yesterday that it planned to increase prices of its consumer and professional products, effective Jan. 4, to offset the decline in the United States dollar.


Gannett TV Deal
LEAD: The Gannett Company said it had reached agreement in principle to buy television stations in Greensboro, N.C., and Jacksonville, Fla., from Harte-Hanks Communications Inc.
The stations are WFMY-TV, the CBS affiliate in Greensboro, and WTLV-TV, the ABC affiliate in Jacksonville.
The purchase price of both stations is $155 million, the company said.


Jury Convicts Brokerage
LEAD: A Federal jury has convicted a brokerage, its three officers and a customer in a plan to launder up to $2.5 million - some of which was invested by drug dealers, income-tax evaders and a bookmaker, a United States Attorney said today.


Yugoslav Flights to Israel
LEAD: Adria Airways, a Yugoslav charter company, today began flights to Israel every two weeks.
El Al Israel Airlines will begin flights to Yugoslavia early next year. ''We hope this will also bring about the resumption of diplomatic relations between the countries,'' the Israeli Transport Minister, Haim Corfu, said.


Items Dropped in Senate Tax Plan
LEAD: The Senate Finance Committee focused its attention today on a new compromise plan for raising $9 billion in taxes.
It drops several proposals the Reagan Administration had objected to.

LEAD: INSTALLING adjustable hanging shelves - the kind that are attached to a wall with brackets and vertical metal channels called standards - is one of the easiest, least expensive ways to gain added space for storage and display.

News Seems Held Hostage At Prison Site
LEAD: Shortly before noon on the third day of the uprising at the Federal prison here, a dozen reporters signed a handwritten note.
It was a request for a briefing on 25 hostages who had been taken captive the night before and five others who had been freed.


Kidnapped Colonel in Chile Reported Released in Brazil
LEAD: Authorities said tonight that a Chilean army officer kidnapped three months ago by guerrillas had been freed in Brazil.


Most Treasury Rates Hold Steady
LEAD: Interest rates were little changed yesterday for most Treasury issues.


Brooklyn Haitians Anxiously Seek News
LEAD: Pierre Jean Baptiste came to a small Brooklyn storefront Tuesday morning hoping for news about his mother and brother, who were chased from the polls in a Haitian town Sunday morning.

U.S. Looks to Haitian Military to Restore Election
LEAD: Despite evidence that elements of Haiti's armed forces were involved in violence that forced the cancellation of presidential elections, the United States is still looking to the military to get the elections back on track, Administration officials and foreign diplomats say.


Seoul Suspects North in Jet Crash
LEAD: South Korea strongly implied today that it suspected North Korea was responsible for the disappearance and presumed destruction on Sunday of a South Korean airliner carrying 115 people.


Advertising; Wells, Rich, Greene Names a New President
LEAD: People in the news today include Richard Macedo of Los Angeles and David Lubars of Providence, R.I., and formerly of Los Angeles.


Washington Talk: The Pentagon; There's No Place Like This Hometown
LEAD: ''Interested in plants, flowers and fun? . . .
Join the Department of Defense Garden Club!'' This unwarlike sign greets Government workers as they arrive each day at the Pentagon and is but one of dozens of solicitations by social groups posted around the building.


Last Gimbels to Close
LEAD: The last Gimbels store will close by Jan. 31 because it has lost its lease at a suburban Pittsburgh mall, store officials said today.
The Gimbels chain was anchored by the Herald Square store in New York City.
The 36 stores were sold individually by their corporate parent, Batus Inc.


The Talk of the Pequot Reservation; Business Sense and Bingo: An Indian Tribe Prospers
LEAD: The tepee jokes elicit only strained smiles from most residents here on the Mashantucket Pequot Indian Reservation.
Tribe members hear them often from tourists and out-of-towners.
They say it's a common misconception.

COMEDY: THE KIDS IN THE HALL
LEAD: THE Kids in the Hall, a promising five-man comedy troupe from Toronto, exude the fresh-scrubbed youthfulness and puppyish charm of a bunch of bright college kids doing skits in a dormitory lounge.


U.N. Chief in Talks With Iranian
LEAD: A senior Iranian official gave no significant indication today that Iran is prepared to move to end the seven-year-old Persian Gulf war during a new round of peace talks with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, according to diplomats and officials.


Vote Delayed At First City
LEAD: The First City Bancorporation of Texas said today that it would delay until early 1988 a shareholders' vote on the bank's proposed $1.5 billion restructuring plan.


Advertising; Saatchi's Pretax Profits Up 77% in Fiscal Year
LEAD: For the year ending Sept. 30, Britain's Saatchi &amp; Saatchi Company, the world's largest advertising concern, reported that it had pretax profits of $193.5 million a gain of 77 percent from the previous year.
Much of that increase can be attributed to the acquisition of Ted Bates Worldwide last year.


Highway Snipers Fire On Drivers in Midwest
LEAD: A bus driver told the police that somebody shot at him today in the fourth highway shooting in two days in neighboring sections of Missouri and Illinois.


Independent Counsel Wins House Approval
LEAD: The House gave final Congressional approval today to a five-year extension of the law on independent prosecutors and sent the bill to President Reagan, where its fate is uncertain.


Justice Dept. Denies Querying Views of Nominee
LEAD: The Justice Department said today that Judge Anthony M. Kennedy, President Reagan's nominee for the Supreme Court, was not questioned in advance about how he would vote on issues likely to come before the Court.

LEAD: Northeastern University's policy of mandatory drug testing for athletes was struck down today by a Superior Court judge who ruled that the practice violated state protections of privacy and civil rights.

LEAD: Sean Miller, a reserve freshman point guard, made all 6 of his 3-point field-goal attempts and scored 20 points tonight to lead Pitt to an 88-70 victory over St.

LEAD: IT'S de-lightful, it's de-bunking, it's . . . ''De-Architecture,'' the world according to James Wines, the founder of SITE, an avant-garde design and architecture firm in New York.

Its current lineup brings together musicians who made their reputations in 1960's free jazz - Dave Burrell on piano and James Spaulding on flute and alto saxophone - with Mr.


Karpov Up A Pawn in End Game
LEAD: The 19th game in the world chess championship was adjourned today with the challenger, Anatoly Karpov, a pawn ahead in an endgame.
Karpov, who was playing White, sealed his 41st move.

Bass-Macmillan
LEAD: A group led by the Texas investor Robert M. Bass has raised its stake in Macmillan Inc. to 8.8 percent, from 7.5 percent.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr.
Bass did not amend his previous statement that he was acquiring the shares of the New York-based publishing company for investment purposes only.
