Piano: Artis Wodehouse In Gershwin
LEAD: ARTIS WODEHOUSE, a pianist who has been something of a pioneer in research on early sound recordings, came to Merkin Concert Hall Monday night with the fruits of her work on George Gershwin.
She has transcribed some of the song improvisations recorded by the composer for Columbia in the 1920's.
Gershwin himself published 18 such arrangements in 1932 as ''George Gershwin's Song Book''; Miss Wodehouse's work (published by Warner Brothers


Hialeah Journal; The City Eclipsed by a Race Track
LEAD: Hialeah has always been more blue collar than bluenose.


Nuclear Weapon Test Held
LEAD: A nuclear weapon test that had been delayed because of a strike at the Nevada Test Site was detonated today, the second test announced by the Department of Energy in two days.
Today's test, code-named Mission Cyber, was conducted 900 feet beneath the surface of Rainier Mesa, about 90 miles northwest of Las Vegas.The test, which had an explosive force of less than 20,000 tons of TNT, was termed successful by a spokesman for the department.


Gilbert Winner Over Connors
LEAD: Sometimes it seems that the day Jimmy Connors retires will also be the day when all those street corner prophecies about the end of the world or California sliding into the Pacific Ocean will be fulfilled.
The open era of tennis is 20 years old and Connors has been round for most of them, still playing at a level others aspire to.


BOOKS OF THE TIMES
LEAD: THERE were surprisingly few gimmicks among the children's picture books I saw this year - very few pop-up books, or books that collapse into picture puzzles, or books with wheels on them, holes through them, or sound tracks in them, or books with parts the reader can feel, smell, hear or taste.
The only noticeable departure from convention was a small outburst of didactic works that reached its nadir in a line of books called ''Disney's Classic Value Stories,'' with the title ''Walt Disney's Dumbo and the Magic Feather: A Tale About Confidence.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. Dirt and old polish have accumulated on the surfaces of a teak table and a teak buffet that are about 20 years old.
What is the best way to thoroughly clean this grime off and give the finish new life?
A.
One cleaning method is to scrub with a pad of very fine steel wool dipped in mineral spirits (paint thinner).

Wood Gundy Cuts
LEAD: The investment firm Wood Gundy Inc. said it was laying off 150 employees in Canada and overseas because of a slowdown in business since October's stock market collapse.
Before the layoffs, the firm had about 2,100 employees worldwide, about 1,100 of whom were in Toronto, a spokesman, John Wegener, said.

LEAD: The heated question of aid to Pakistan will soon hit the floor of the House of Representatives.
The vote will be close, for principle seems to vie with principle - helping Pakistan for itself and for its help to the Afghan rebels versus trying to pressure Pakistan to stop building nuclear weapons.


Tunnel Stock in France
LEAD: Private investors have subscribed to only 60 percent of the French portion of the stock offering for the $1.38 billion tunnel project under the English Channel.
The French-based Banque Indosuez, an adviser for the stock offering, said the French public bought stock valued at $357 million out of $625 million offered.

LEAD: Albert Einstein's earliest and longest known manuscript on relativity -an unpublished 72-page work probably written in 1911 or 1912 - was auctioned yesterday at Sotheby's.
The hand-written paper spelling out the famous formula, E-mc#2, brought $1.2 million.

Lord Young, the Trade and Industry Secretary, is expected to decide this week whether the Scandinavian carrier can proceed with plans to bid for a significant stake in British Caledonian, which is looking for a buyer and is talking with Britain's largest airline, British Airways.

27 Hurt as 2 Buses Collide
LEAD: Twenty-seven people received minor injuries last night when two private buses collided at 41st Street and 11th Avenue.
The police said the accident occurred at 6:20 P.M. when a Trailways bus returning to its garage at 525 11th Avenue collided with a Delaware-bound tour bus.
The Trailways bus was traveling west on 41st Street, and the tour bus, owned by Gregg's Bus Service of Yorklyn, Del., was southbound on 11th Avenue en route to the Lincoln Tunnel.

LEAD: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar told member countries today that the United Nations must start borrowing in financial markets for the first time to avoid the threat of insolvency next year, largely as a result of the failure of the United States to pay its dues.


Erik Hamrin, Public-Relations Representative, 57
LEAD: Erik Hamrin, a public-relations representative who represented many well-known classical musicians, died of cardiac arrest on Sunday in Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan.

Optimism at Ford
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company remains optimistic about the 1988 market because the lower stock market has not forced November car sales below levels a year earlier and truck sales have actually risen, the company's chairman, Donald E. Petersen, said.
Mr.
Petersen told reporters that he expected overall industry vehicle sales of about 15 million in 1988, with trucks making up one-third of the market.


Two California Hikers Found
LEAD: A Thanksgiving outing that became an icy ordeal ended today when two hikers were found three days after they were scheduled to return from the San Gabriel Mountains.
The hikers, Stephen Thomas Parker, 31 years old, of La Verne, and Kip Brook Pennington, 24, of Upland, were found by rescue teams and flown out by helicopter.

LEAD: HIS eyes narrowed and his skin became flushed until he took on the appearance of a three-foot-high Genghis Khan.
Then came the wide-mouthed scream - a cry that combined defiance, frustration and the decibel level of an boom box.
He was a little more than 3 years old, and he was throwing a tantrum in the checkout line of the supermarket.

LEAD: Although the violence that shook Haiti over the last week has not spilled over into the neighboring Dominican Republic, the border between the two countries remained closed today and Dominican troops in the area were on alert.


Whirlpool Plan Off
LEAD: Philips N.V. of the Netherlands and the Whirlpool Corporation have failed to agree on a long-running plan for a joint venture to produce appliances because of falls in stock prices and the dollar, Philips said.
The companies had announced the venture in September 1986.
Philips's businesses include consumer electronics, small household appliances and lighting.

Now they emerge from trials by fire, electronic fire, chosen by the public.
NBC's two-hour program Tuesday night carried on-screen screening to a new level by including each candidate of both parties.
In principle, it's part of a welcome, historic shift to primary election campaigns.


Korean Trade Gain
LEAD: South Korea's trade surplus widened to $5.52 billion in the first 11 months of the year from $2.93 billion a year earlier, the Trade and Industry Ministry reported today.
Officials said that Korean exports during the period rose 34.3 percent, to $41.91 billion, while imports rose 28.7 percent, to $36.39 billion.


Hijacking Suspect Implicates a Beirut Official
LEAD: A Lebanese charged with hijacking a Royal Jordanian airliner in 1985 has told the Federal Bureau of Investigation that the Lebanese Justice Minister, Nabih Berri, recruited him for the mission, according to court papers filed today by prosecutors.


Bridge: 2 Against 2 for an Evening: A Life Master in a Set Game
LEAD: A rare event in clubs but a common one in domestic bridge is the ''set game'': two against two for a complete evening.
This is the normal choice when one or two married couples are involved, since there is no profit in winning a few dollars from one's spouse.


Donn F. Eisele, 57; One of 3 Crewmen On Apollo 7 Mission
LEAD: Donn F. Eisele, one of three astronauts who in 1968 flew the first manned flight of the Apollo spacecraft that eventually took man to the moon, died yesterday of a heart attack while on a business trip in Tokyo.
He was 57 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.


Savings Unit Gets New Chief
LEAD: The American Continental Corporation has named William D. Hinz chairman and chief executive of its main operation, the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, based in Irvine, Calif.

LEAD: WHEN a foreign-based advertising agency opens a branch in New York, it can't really be too hopeful of attracting local clients, what with the great selection of American agencies available.


Farthest Space Objects Yet Are Found
LEAD: A team of British and American astronomers has discovered two celestial objects much farther away from Earth than any previously known.
The discovery of the two quasars, one 12 billion light years away, reinforces a growing belief that the outer limits of the observable universe have yet to be glimpsed.


NASA WILL LAUNCH UNMANNED CRAFT TO JUPITER IN 1989
LEAD: NASA announced today that its long-delayed mission to Jupiter would be launched in 1989, and would include an audacious rerouting of the spacecraft to use the gravitational force of Venus and Earth to fling the craft like a stone in a slingshot toward Jupiter.

School Earring Ban Upheld
LEAD: A school district has the right to ban male students from wearing earrings while attending classes, a Federal district judge has ruled.
The judge, Paul E. Plunkett, released an opinion Tuesday denying a request for a temporary injunction against the Bremen Community High School District by attorneys for 17-year-old Darryl Olesen of Midlothian, who contended that the ban violated his constitutional rights.

Salvador Rebels Kill Cattle
LEAD: Leftist guerrillas herded about 200 head of prize cattle valued at $1.5 million into a corral and slaughtered them with machine guns at a ranch in eastern El Salvador, according to local press and rebel reports.
Newspapers said about 80 guerrillas of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front attacked the Hacienda Monte Grande just south of San Miguel on Sunday night.

Money Fund Assets Fall
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 411 money market mutual funds decreased $237.2 million, to $261.85 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 111 institutional funds were down $643.2 million, to $73.53 billion.
Assets of the 207 general purpose funds were up $741.9 million, to $79.60 billion.

LEAD: An article on Monday about parishioners' efforts at St.
Luke's Church in the South Bronx to help homeless people described a church shelter program incorrectly.
The Partnership for the Homeless, a private multidenominational coalition, provides food and operating assistance.
New York City government provides beds, linen and transportation.

Robert Bork, whose fight lasted four months, and Douglas Ginsburg, who withdrew a few days after being chosen, are judges on the prestigious United States Court of Appeals in Washington, only one step below.

LEAD: The chairman of the Democratic National Committee is urging his party to write a short 1988 platform instead of a long one filled with promises to special interest groups.


Fire Sprinkler System Bill
LEAD: A bill was introduced in the House today that would require all hotels and motels to install fire sprinkler systems in rooms and public areas.
The bill was inspired by the fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel in Puerto Rico last New Year's Eve in which 96 people died.
The hotel did not have a sprinkler system.


Addendum
LEAD: *
Working Woman magazine will increase its circulation rate base by 5.9 percent, to 900,000, and its rates by more than 11 percent, beginning with the March issue.


Standard Register Shift
LEAD: Standard Register, the Dayton, Ohio, maker of business forms and systems, has decided to move its advertising to the Martin Agency in Richmond.
The business-to-business account is in the $1 million to $2 million range.
For the last 25 years, the advertising was handled by Griswold, a Cleveland-based Ross Roy subsidiary.


LOW-LEVEL FLIGHTS OF B-1 ARE HALTED
LEAD: The Strategic Air Command has suspended low-level flights for the new B-1 bomber, limiting the training of crews for their main mission of low-level bombing, according to officers at the command's headquarters in Omaha.


O'Neill Found Free of Cancer
LEAD: A large section of prostate gland removed from former Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. showed no signs of cancer, a hospital spokeswoman said today.
Surgeons at Brigham and Women's Hospital removed 90 percent of the enlarged prostate of the former Speaker of the House of Representatives on Monday and tests were performed on tissue samples.


Union Pacific Has 16.4% of Beard
LEAD: The Union Pacific Corporation said it holds 16.4 percent of the Beard Company and may seek control of the Oklahoma City-based oil and gas concern.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Union Pacific said it might acquire Beard to obtain the company's 28 percent stake in USPCI Inc.


Drug Tests for Racers
LEAD: Nascar stock-car drivers will be involved in a drug-testing program in 1988, according to an announcement yesterday by Bill France Jr., the organization's president.


U.S. MAY BE EASING ARMS TALKS STAND
LEAD: The United States may drop its demand that an overall limit be placed on warheads on Soviet land-based missiles as part of a larger compromise on reducing long-range nuclear arms, senior Administration officials said today.


Caledonian Set To Sell Stake
LEAD: Britain cleared the way today for the Scandanavian Airlines System to buy a minority stake in British Caledonian Airlines, but announced steps to insure the carrier would remain under British control.


Soviet Series Not Firm
LEAD: John Ziegler, the president of the National Hockey League, said yesterday that no specific agreements had been reached to permit Soviet teams to play in the league.
Ziegler met with Soviet hockey officials in Moscow this week.
According to a report earlier this week in The Toronto Globe and Mail, a tentative agreement had been reached to allow four Soviet teams to play in the N.H.L.

LEAD: The general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board has authorized a complaint saying that some National Football League players were illegally barred from the first weekend of games after the strike.

LEAD: The nation's non-farm businesses increased their efficiency in producing goods and services by 3.6 percent from July through September, the best improvement since the first quarter of 1986, the Labor Department said today.

TIGER MOSQUITOES FOUND IN 17 STATES
LEAD: The hardy Asian tiger mosquito, an aggressive biter and a carrier of disease, has spread to 17 states since arriving in Houston aboard used tire casings two years ago, prompting new Federal inspections of used tire imports, health officials said today.

LEAD: Panama has ordered the United States to close the operations of the Agency for International Development in Panama and is expelling the agency's American employees and their dependents, the State Department said today.

Safeway to Sell 172 Stores to Vons
LEAD: The Vons Companies said it had agreed to buy 172 grocery stores from Safeway Stores Inc. in a cash and stock deal valued at about $408.2 million.
Vons, based in El Monte, Calif., operates 193 stores in Southern California that generated $3 billion in sales last year.
The Safeway stores that Vons intends to buy had sales of $1.6 billion last year and would extend Vons's reach into Central


Bonds End Day Slightly Higher
LEAD: Bond prices ended moderately higher yesterday after seven European countries lowered their interest rates.


Relics of Carthage in New Exhibition
LEAD: THIRTEEN centuries have elapsed since the Islamic invasion of North Africa obliterated ancient Carthage.
But reminders of the striking blend of artistic genius and institutional cruelty that characterized the Carthaginians have survived, and a new exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History brings both the beauty and the horror of Carthage into sharp focus.

LEAD: In an unusual, concerted effort to stabilize the dollar and promote economic growth, West Germany's central bank cut its most important lending rate today, and hours later six other European central banks cut their rates.

LEAD: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation was the volume leader on the New York Stock Exchange today with more than 44 million shares traded, one of the busiest days ever for a single stock.

LEAD: A lawyer was sentenced yesterday to a year and a day in prison for helping arrange sham marriages for Haitian aliens so they could gain permanent resident status.

Restaurants
LEAD: WHEN I spent a winter seven years ago in the ancient university city of Salamanca, Spain, I passed many evenings in a cluttered and boisterous little taverna called Covechuela.
My affection for this place had little to do with the food, which was satisfying but hardly memorable.
What attracted me were the warmth and ebullience of the place and the puckish owner, whose nightly performance included picking up coins left as tips, flipping them ceiling high, then catching them in his shirt pocket.

Watersons, Folk Singers From Britain
LEAD: FORTY years ago, Norma, Lal and Mike Waterson would spend their evenings in their parlor in Yorkshire, England, singing along with their grandmother - reprising ballads, hunting songs, hymns and carols that their grandmother probably sang with her parents.
One family member would take up the tune; the rest would join in, and if the melody reached too high or too low, they'd choose a harmony note instead.

Showing Off New York City To Visitors From Out of Town; Let There Be Lights
LEAD: The thing to do in New York at Christmas is to walk, anywhere in Manhattan where you can see the lights.
This is the truly extraordinary thing about the city now - the way in which the energy of New York becomes, suddenly, frozen in millions of tiny points of perfect light.
The light of Christmas in New York is different from the light of any other time, or of any other place; it is more precise, more delicate, at once overpowering in its sweep and gentle in the way it touches the eye.

LEAD: The offices and a warehouse of a man who has been Santa Claus for many underpriviledged children were looted of about $500 in merchandise Wednesday. ''I think anybody would have to be pretty bad off to steal from the poor,'' said Dorcas Drake, whose annual toy drive serves 50,000 children.
Mr.
Drake, a retired justice of the peace, has served as Santa Claus for 30 years.

U.N. Aid for Drought Area
LEAD: The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization said today that it would give $23.5 million in emergency aid next year to help feed refugees and drought victims in four African countries, Botswana, Malawi, the Sudan and Somalia.


SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
LEAD:  Chango at City College


Chess Game a Draw
LEAD: The 19th game of the world championship chess match ended in a draw yesterday in Seville, Spain, after determined efforts by the 36-year-old challenger, Anatoly Karpov, failed to budge the 24-year-old titleholder, Gary Kasparov.


INSIDE
LEAD:  U.N. Effort on Gulf Falters


New Lab Tests In Case of Nurse Show No Drug
LEAD: New tests on the urine of a 73-year-old hospital patient revealed no signs of the paralyzing drug that a 25-year-old nurse is accused of injecting into him, the Suffolk County District Attorney's office said today.
The nurse, Richard J. Angelo, is suspected of killing at least 10 people.


Cubans End 11-Day Prison Siege In Atlanta, Freeing All Hostages
LEAD: Rebellious Cuban prisoners ended an 11-day uprising at the Federal penitentiary here early this morning and began freeing their 89 hostages.


States That Require AIDS Education in School Triple in Six Months
LEAD: The number of states mandating education about AIDS in the public schools has tripled in the last six months, with 17 states and the District of Columbia now requiring such instruction, the National Association of State Boards of Education said today.


Buckeye Wins Award
LEAD: Chris Spielman, the Ohio State All-America linebacker and a finalist for the Lombardi Award in 1986, won that 40-pound granite trophy last night as the nation's outstanding collegiate lineman of 1987, but the victory was bittersweet.


Court Record In Sex Case Is Examined
LEAD: The administrative judge for the New York City criminal courts, beginning an inquiry into allegations that a judge humiliated the complainant in a sexual misconduct trial, examined the record of the trial yesterday.


Art: Legendary Influence Of Black Mountain College
LEAD: IN the history of the postwar avant-garde, the name Black Mountain College crops up repeatedly, framed in the golden glow of legend.
The list of artists and writers who as students and teachers entered into the school's short, experimental existence is studded with impressive names.
Founded in 1933 in the hills outside Asheville, N.C., by a group of disenchanted faculty members from Rollins College in Florida, Black Mountain placed the arts and, in its first years, especially the visual arts, at the center of its curriculum.


Katherine R. Erskine Wed to Dale Aubrey Jenkins
LEAD: Katherine Ruth Erskine, a freelance writer, and Dale Aubrey Jenkins, an executive vice president of the Urban Group, a New York real-estate development company, were married last evening at the Beekman Tower in New York by Judge Elaine Slobod of the Family Court of Orange County.


RESULTS
LEAD:  N.B.A.
Hawks 102, Bullets 94: Kevin Willis scored 23 points and Cliff Levingston had 21 to lead visiting Atlanta to a victory over Washington last night.
Levingston, starting in place of the injured Dominique Wilkins, had 13 points in the first half, during which the Hawks opened a 45-30 lead.


TV Weekend; 'Blunt - the Fourth Man,' on A&amp;E
LEAD: ON Nov. 15, 1979, Margaret Thatcher publicly named Anthony Blunt as the ''fourth man'' in a notorious spy ring that included Guy Burgess, Kim Philby and Donald Maclean, all three of whom had defected to the Soviet Union in 1951.
Actually, Blunt had been confronted 15 years earlier by M.I.5, the British security agency, about his longtime role as a Soviet agent.

LEAD: The Government ordered an investigation yesterday into an incident earlier in the week in which a Delta Air Lines jet taxied onto a runway at Los Angeles International Airport as a United Airlines jumbo jet was taking off from the runway.

LEAD: The Museum of Modern Art and some 200 of its curatorial and administrative employees reached agreement on a new three-year contract this week.


900 Evacuated After a Leak Of Chemical in Derailment
LEAD: Up to 31 railroad cars overturned near here, and a leak of a chemical from a derailed tanker prompted the evacuation of 900 residents, officials said today.
No injuries were reported.


Gephardt Urges a Law For Health Insurance
LEAD: Representative Richard A. Gephardt has called for legislation forcing businesses to offer health insurance to their employees, ''just as they must now provide a minimum wage.''

LEAD: To the Editor:


Construction Shortcuts Caused Fatal Bridge Collapse, Panel Says
LEAD: Construction shortcuts contributed to the bridge collapse on the Gov.
Thomas E. Dewey Thruway that killed 10 people last April, New York State's final report on the disaster stated today.
The report confirmed earlier findings that erosion around the base of one of the bridge's piers had led to the collapse.

LEAD: Jay Kriegel, a longtime associate of CBS Inc.'s chief executive, Laurence A. Tisch, has been named senior vice president in charge of external relations and governmental affairs.
He will report directly to Mr.
Tisch.
Mr.
Kriegel had been acting as a consultant to CBS.
From 1966 to 1973, Mr.
Kriegel served as chief of staff and special counsel to John V.

LEAD: A toy that simulates war sounds and is intended to allow motorists to vent their frustrations is the latest novelty sensation, retailers in New York and California say.


Kraft Says It Will Sell Its Duracell Division
LEAD: Kraft Inc., said yesterday that it planned to sell its Duracell Inc. battery division in order to focus more heavily on its core food businesses.

The U.N.Today; Dec. 4, 1987
LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY


Correcitons
LEAD: A list of college guidebooks on the Education page on Wednesday omitted three books in some editions.


Santa Fe Railway Plans Cutbacks
LEAD: The Santa Fe Railway, continuing a cost-cutting drive begun last year, said it would consolidate its operating divisions and repair yards by 1990.
The move will result in the immediate layoff of 170 workers and is expected to result in further layoffs.


One Killed, 2 Injured In Queens House Fire
LEAD: One person was killed and two others were seriously injured in a fire that swept through a three-story house in Queens late last night, the authorities said.


Seoul's Growing Exports
LEAD: South Korea's rapidly growing electronics industry has become the country's second business sector to exceed $10 billion in annual exports, the Trade and Industry Ministry reported today.
Ministry officials said that exports of Korean electronic products since January reached $10.02 billion on Wednesday and were expected to climb to $11 billion by year-end.


Bridge: Sometimes, Even an Expert Thinks Twice on First Trick
LEAD: If someone sat behind a player and recorded the length of time he took to play each card, a graph of the results would provide a good indication of his level of ability.


Suit by Hispanic Groups Assails Texas Colleges
LEAD: Three influential Hispanic organizations, backed by the Mexican-American political leadership in Texas, have filed a wide-ranging lawsuit against the state university system, charging that it discriminates against the state's growing Mexican-American population.


THE ENORMOUSLY RISKY ROAD TO A DEAL
LEAD: The road to Shearson Lehman Brothers' acquisition of the E. F. Hutton Group was surprisingly risky, according to a number of people close to the marathon negotiations.
Some senior Hutton officials feared at one point that, if no bidder succeeded, the firm could face a possible exodus of employees, according to the sources.


Steinbrenner Talks With Angels' Witt
LEAD: George Steinbrenner, once the prime pursuer of star free agents, passed up the chance to sign Jack Morris a year ago, but the Yankees' owner may have different thoughts about another free-agent pitcher this year.


TALKS ON GULF WAR FALTERING AT U.N.
LEAD: Efforts to negotiate a cease-fire between Iran and Iraq appeared near collapse today after officials said Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar had made no progress in talks with a senior Iranian official.


Settling Out of Court: Gamble or Skill?
LEAD: Consider a pair of riverboat gamblers.
The cards have been dealt, the bets have mounted, the combatants, well-matched in skill, face an all-or-nothing decision.
Rightly or wrongly, such an image forms easily in the minds of the public when talk of out-of-court settlement enters the picture in high-stakes lawsuits.


About Real Estate; Housing on 89th St. Built in the Old West Side Style
LEAD: In the last few years, residents of the Upper West Side have become accustomed to seeing many of the neighborhood's old town houses restored to their original 19th-century and early 20th-century elegance.
That is what seems to have happened to two adjoining buildings at 103 and 105 West 89th Street near the corner of Columbus Avenue.


Slow Sales for Retailers in November
LEAD: Disappointing retail sales in November raised concern yesterday over how retailers will fare this Christmas season.


House Approves Spending Bill; Veto Threatened
LEAD: The House of Representatives approved a $587 billion spending bill for 1988 today that requires $7.6 billion in cuts agreed to in the deficit-reducing plan reached last month by Congress and the White House.


SOVIET ECONOMISTS SEE A NEW ORDER
LEAD: Two leading Soviet economists held out prospects today of a new international economic order inspired by Soviet economic reforms and the impending arms control pacts.


Livestock and Meat Fall; Energy Contracts Are Up
LEAD: Livestock and meat futures prices plunged sharply yesterday, with many contracts losing the limit allowed for daily trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.


Serving America's Interests
LEAD: A serious battle is building here on arms control agreements with Moscow, but it won't really be about what appears on the surface.


Derailed Chemical Cars Force Evacuation in Tennessee
LEAD: Overturned cars lay in a heap after train derailed Wednesday near Charleston.
About 900 people within a one-mile radius had to leave their homes because a chemical, acetic anhydride, a combustible corrosive, was leaking from an tanker car.
No injuries were reported. (AP)

SNAPSHOTS TAKEN AS CHEMICALS BOND
LEAD: Using pulses of light lasting only one-millionth of one-billionth of a second, scientists at the California Institute of Technology have invented an instrument to detect the subtle sequences of events that occur in some ultra-fast chemical reactions.


Film: Soviet Drama
LEAD: THE skill with which ''Repentance'' has been made is sure to be eclipsed in importance by the very fact that it was made at all.
The level of political self-criticism to be found in this Soviet film is so high, and the satire so scathing, that ''Repentance'' has been greeted as a phenomenon at home.


At the Movies
LEAD:  The Origins of 'Walker'


Marathon Misconduct
LEAD: Fred Lebow, the race director of the New York Marathon, announced yesterday that six runners in the race this year had been disqualified for cheating.
Last year, 25 disqualifications were made, including one in which the men's second-place finisher, Antoni Niemczak of Poland, tested positive for use of steroids.


New Charges Raise Old Question
LEAD: In the dangerous world of the decoy police officer -in which officers, seeking to attract muggers, disguise themselves as helpless old ladies or derelicts sleeping in the subway - there have been heroes and heroines.
And there have also been casualties.


For Bush, a Strong Pat From the Chief
LEAD: President Reagan, who has not given a formal endorsement to Vice President Bush's campaign for the White House, today gave him a firm political pat on the back.


State Legal Panel Suspends A Former Treasury Secretary
LEAD: Robert B. Anderson, Secretary of the Treasury in the second Eisenhower Administration, was suspended yesterday by a state Supreme Court panel from practicing law in New York state.

60 to 75 Soviet Citizens Get Permission to Leave Country
LEAD: In a pre-summit human rights gesture of unusual scope, Soviet officials told Western diplomats today that they were approving the emigration requests of 60 to 75 Soviet citizens, the diplomats said.


A COMMISSION FROM THE NEW WORLD RETURNS TO THE OLD
LEAD: Matilda Cuomo, wife of the Governor, shaking hands with President Francesco Cossigna of Italy yesterday in Rome.
At left was John Guode, president of the Christopher Columbus Quincentenary Jubilee Commission.
Theyt were attending a reception for members of the commission, which is in Rome to plan for the celebrations marking the 500th anniversary of the discovery of the New World.


Rare Respighi Opera at Carnegie
LEAD: Tonight at Carnegie Hall, New York will have one of its infrequent opportunities to assess Ottorino Respighi (1879-1936) as a composer of opera, a sphere in which his relative obscurity is a matter of some irony.

C.I.A. Aids Harvard Study on Intelligence Policy
LEAD: The John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard Univesity announced today that the Central Intelligence Agency had provided $400,000 for a three-year program of research and training on intelligence assessment and policy.


Nets Sign Moore For Help at Guard
LEAD: The bruised and battered Nets, losers of 7 consecutive games by a total of 111 points and in need of help at several positions, yesterday signed Johnny Moore, a free-agent guard.

LEAD: A strong reservations today about efforts by the army-dominated Government to speed through a reorganization of the disbanded electoral council and hold new elections by early February.


Ruder Resisting Glass-Steagall Repeal Effort
LEAD: David S. Ruder, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, today became the only head of a major financial regulatory agency to withhold support from efforts in Congress to repeal the Glass-Steagall Act.

Uncertainty of Administration Dollar Goals
LEAD: The coordinated cuts in European interest rates today could dissuade the markets from pushing the dollar down for a while.
Beyond that, the cuts fulfill a major condition that the Reagan Administration had set for doing more on its own to stabilize the dollar.

7-YEAR TERM FOR IMPERSONATOR
LEAD: For her 38th swindle in 35 years, Rowena Riggs Powell - also known as Christina Onassis - was sentenced to seven years in state prison today.


Canada's Jobless Rate
LEAD: Canada's unemployment rate fell to 8.2 percent in November, its lowest level in more than six years, the Government's statistical agency reported today.
In October, the jobless rate was 8.4 percent after adjustments for seasonal variations.
The number of unemployed stood at 1,081,000 in November, down 30,000 from the previous month, Statistics Canada said.

LEAD: Welcome to Friday the 13th at Madison Square Garden.

Correction
LEAD: A Washington article yesterday about the B-1 bomber misstated the circumstances of a recent cruise missile firing.
It was the first such firing from a B-1; several cruise missiles were fired previously from B-52's.


South Shore's Star Leads Despite Injury
LEAD: His sturdy forehead makes you wonder whether he needs a helmet to play football.
The thickness of his neck is equally impressive for an 18-year-old, and the rest of his body is even more robust.
Everything about Arthur Davis is menacing, until his huge smile appears and wipes all that toughness away.

Pact Would Limit Drug Tests
LEAD: Officials of Stanford University and the National Collegiate Athletic Association, meeting with a judge today, reached an agreement that would sharply limit drug tests on the school's athletes.


Home Loan Limits to Rise
LEAD: The nation's two largest providers of money for home mortgages announced today that they were increasing their loan limits by 10 percent for 1988 to reflect rising home prices.


November Operating Profit Is Reported by Salomon Inc.
LEAD: Salomon Inc., the huge securities firm that suffered a $75 million after-tax loss in October, was profitable on an operating basis in November, John H. Gutfreund, the chairman and chief executive, said yesterday.

LEAD: Colgate stayed within its football family in selecting its new coach yesterday.
Mike Foley was named to the position to succeed Fred Dunlap, who had resigned but will continue as the athletic director.

Treaty Critics Lash Back at Reagan
LEAD: A wide range of Republicans assailed President Reagan today for his criticism of opponents of his arms control accord with the Soviet Union, as a group of hard-line conservatives announced what they conceded would be a near-futile campaign to block Senate approval of the treaty.


100,000 Subway Commuters Delayed by a Fire in Queens
LEAD: About 100,000 rush-hour subway commuters were delayed last night when service on three lines between Manhattan and Queens was halted for almost two hours after railroad ties stored at the Queens Plaza Station caught on fire.
No injuries were reported.


No Clear Favorite in Soccer's Final Four
LEAD: Harvard will meet San Diego State and Clemson will clash with North Carolina here Saturday afternoon in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I soccer tournament.
The winners will meet for the title Sunday.

First Interstate
LEAD: The First Interstate Bancorporation of Los Angeles said it was reducing slightly its bid for the Allied Bank of Texas.
Rather than offering 0.12 of a share of its series B preferred stock for each Allied share, First Interstate will offer 0.1 of a share, thus cutting its cost by about $41 million.


AWARD BY POETS ACADEMY
LEAD: Alfred Corn, the author of four books of poetry, has won the Academy of American Poets $10,000 fellowship for ''distinguished poetic achievement,'' it was announced this week.
Mr.
Corn's most recent book is ''The Metamorphoses of Metaphor: Essays in Poetry and Fiction'' (Viking, 1987).
Mr.
Corn, who was born in Georgia in 1943, earned degrees at Emory and Columbia Universities and lives in New York City.


Senate Votes $4 Billion for Farm Credit
LEAD: The Senate today overwhelmingly approved a $4 billion federally guaranteed bailout of the Farm Credit System.


3 Relatives Killed, 4 Injured, In Long Island Car Accident
LEAD: Three people - members of the same family - were killed and four others were injured yesterday when two cars collided on the Southern State Parkway in Nassau County, state police said.

U.S. Students Die in Britain
LEAD: A minibus carrying 13 American college students collided with a car on an expressway today, killing 2 students and injuring 11 people, the police said.
The victims' names and their college were not immediately given.
The police said the students were traveling west on the M-4 expressway when the accident occurred between Swindon and Newbury, in southern England.

Despite Soviet Move, Jews Will Protest in Capital
LEAD: Calling the Soviet Union's announcement that it would approve the emigration requests of 60 to 75 people only a good-will gesture, leaders of American Jewish organizations said yesterday that they would not be deterred from going ahead with a rally tomorrow in Washington on behalf of Soviet Jews.


Bonn Halts Sub Sale to North Korea

Violin: Joseph Fuchs In Carnegie Hall Recital
LEAD: Joseph Fuchs, the American violinist, who appeared Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall, is now 87 years old.
He has had a career of distinction, not just as a technician and interpreter of the standard repertory, but also as a champion of new music and an organizer within the musical profession.
His playing betrayed the inevitable depredations of age.

The Senate Fakery Committee's Bill
LEAD: The Senate Finance Committee has been working to cut the budget deficit, but not very hard.
Its new tax bill would make corporations pay $1.6 billion next summer that wouldn't otherwise be collected until fall.
That's not a tax increase, just a speedup.
But it accounts for almost one-fifth of the committee's $9 billion package to reduce this year's budget deficit: pure fakery.


IS HE JUST A TENNIS PLAYER?
LEAD: WHY did you play in South Africa?
The question was posed to Brad Gilbert, a Californian, and one of the tennis players participating in the Nabisco Masters round-robin tournament of eight now at Madison Square Garden.

LEAD: Despite the withdrawl of his financial partner and prime tenant, the developer of a huge project on the site of the New York Coliseum said yesterday that he would proceed with plans for offices and apartments there.

When Santa And Scrooge Are the Same
LEAD: The two characters couldn't be less alike: the notorious skinflint of the Christmas season, Scrooge, and his polar opposite, Santa Claus.


The Two Truman Capotes on Display
LEAD: When Truman Capote wrote ''In Cold Blood'' 22 years ago, readers were told that the book fell somewhere between fiction and fact.
It was called a report of a murder, a fictionalized story, a courtroom drama.
Finally, the book about the killing in 1959 of a farm family in a small town in Kansas and the capture, trial and execution of the two young murderers was labeled and promoted as something new in literature: a ''nonfiction novel.

IN 1871 A ROYAL U.S. GREETING
LEAD: Earlier reports (premature, it now appears) that Mikhail S. Gorbachev, might be willing to extend his visit to the United States beyond three days brings to mind a sojourn by one of his countrymen more than a century ago.
And what a happening that was!

Deaver's Bids for Dismissals Are Rejected by Federal Judge
LEAD: The Federal district judge trying the perjury case of Michael K. Deaver, the former White House deputy chief of staff, today denied the first series of defense motions for acquittal.


RECITAL: LEONA MITCHELL SINGS
LEAD: Leona Mitchell is the sort of singer who considers, with sometimes almost too much care, every sound her supple voice produces.
For the inaugural concert in the N.A.A.C.P.'s Great Artists Award series, the soprano sang on Tuesday evening in Alice Tully Hall.
Lawrence J. Wong was the pianist.
Ms.
Mitchell seemed to come into her own as the recital progressed, ending with several spirituals that she delivered in unusually suave, shapely renditions.


Artist-Studio Tours
LEAD: Twenty-six artists will open their studios to the public from 1 to 6 P.M. today and tomorrow at 430 West 14th Street.
The multi-media exhibition, housed in the heart of the meatpacking district, will display works in progress and finished projects in film, animation, jewelry, sculpture and painting.


The Usual Crowd at Heisman Time
LEAD: The five leading contenders to win the Heisman Trophy as college football's outstanding player this season are, as usual, players whose offensive ability got them there.


SOVIET TO PUBLISH PASTERNAK BIOGRAPHY
LEAD: A biography of Boris Pasternak written by his son will be published soon in the Soviet Union, the news agency Tass said today.

Savard Dismissed
LEAD: The Quebec Nordiques dismissed Coach Andre Savard yesterday, 24 games into his first National Hockey League season, and replaced him with Ron Lapointe, the coach of their top farm team.
Savard, 34 years old, was named June 19 to succeed Michel Bergeron, who left to become coach of the Rangers.
Savard, who lasted less than two months, was dismissed a day after the Nordiques lost, 6-3, in Buffalo for their eighth defeat in nine games.

U.S. Links Waldheim to Persecution
LEAD: The Justice Department has told an international panel investigating war crimes charges against President Kurt Waldheim of Austria that it barred Mr.
Waldheim from the United States because it found sufficient evidence to implicate him ''personally'' in wartime persecutions, according to those who have seen the material.

LEAD: Bob Froese's little piece of National Hockey League history - the goal that the goaltender was credited with scoring against the Islanders last Sunday at Madison Square Garden -vanished yesterday when the league decided to take away his credit for the score.

LEAD: Plainclothes police officers, one with a pistol, confronting protesters at European Community meeting in Copenhagen.
Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and her Foreign Minister, Sir Geoffrey Howe, were among leaders of the 12 nations debating changes in financing and agricultural subsidies.

Jets' Glenn Out for Year
LEAD: Less than a week after the Jets' latest surgical-knee patients were able to start for the first time in almost a year, another key player has been sidelined with a serious knee injury.


Off-Duty Officer Wounds 2
LEAD: Two men were shot and wounded last night by an off-duty transit police officer in Brooklyn after the men tried to rob the officer, the police said.
The officer, Martin Jordan, 32 years old, was approached about 9:27 P.M. by two men who demanded his coat, said Sgt.
John Venetucci, a police spokesman.


CORRECTION
LEAD: Excerpts in some copies yesterday from an Associated Press transcript of President Reagan's interview with four network correspondents misattributed a quotation that formed part of a question.
The reporter's question should have begun, ''Mr.
President, Winston Churchill once said that 'trying to maintain a good relationship with the Communists was not unlike trying to woo a crocodile and when it opened its mouth you never could be quite certain whether it was trying to smile or eat you up.

''We believe that the long-term value of USPCI stock is substantially in excess of $25 a share,'' said Gerald J. Gagner, the president and chief executive of the Oklahoma City-based hazardous waste company.

CORRECTION
LEAD: In the bridge column that appeared Thursday the final statement was incorrect.
In six spades the declarer can survive a club lead by taking all his winners except the diamond ace and end-playing East.


Embryos Are to Be Used
LEAD: Frozen embryos of a wealthy Chilean couple killed in a plane crash will be thawed and implanted in an Australian woman next year, doctors said.
They said Thursday that the decision was made by the state government of Victoria in light of a California court ruling settling the estate of the couple, Elsa and Mario Rios, who lived in Los Angeles and died in a plane crash in Chile in 1983.

LEAD: The third reactor at the Chernobyl nuclear power station, damaged in an explosion and fire in April 1986, has been repaired and put back in operation, the press agency Tass said today.
The fourth reactor at the Ukrainian plant was damaged beyond repair in the accident, which killed at least 31 people.

Braves Seeking Horner
LEAD: Bob Horner rejected a three-year, $4.5 million contract offer from the Atlanta Braves last season and chose instead to play for Yakult of the Japananese Central League for about $2 million.
But the general manager of the Braves, Bobby Cox, believes that at a meeting next week in Dallas he can persuade Horner to return to the Braves with a one-year contract worth $900,000, including incentives and a provision for daily weight checks.


Recital: Dawn Upshaw, In Settings of Dickinson
LEAD: Dawn Upshaw began her song recital at the 92d Street Y Wednesday night with a group of Emily Dickinson settings that proved more intriguing in prospect than in realization.
And though her singing was - as New York audiences have already learned to expect - very, very fine, something of the same impression hung over the recital as a whole.


Poland's Democratic Surprise
LEAD: Democracy is unpredictable, as Gen.
Wojciech Jaruzelski of Poland discovered last week.
Poland conducted a remarkable popular referendum - and received an unexpected result: the Government's reform proposals lost.
General Jaruzelski, making the best of a difficult situation, vows to go on with modified reforms.

LEAD: Talks between warring Nicaraguan factions broke down today when representatives of the Sandinista Government refused to accept a cease-fire proposal from the mediator, Nicaragua's Roman Catholic Primate.


Guidepost; Tips on Tipping
LEAD: Whom do you tip and how much?
For many, this is the big question of the holiday season, followed by many others.
Did your doorman often go out of his way for you?
At your favorite restaurant, did the maitre d'hotel, whom you do not regularly tip, consistently give you extra service?
Do you enjoy a special relationship with the people who work for you?

Music: Faure's Requiem, With Slatkin Conducting
LEAD: Gabriel Faure's Requiem is a comforting contemplation on the sweetness of death, a gentlemanly view of a hereafter in which a loud trump on the last day might be an intrusion on the peace calling for intervention by a kindly gendarme.
Unlike the more vivid funerary masses of Verdi, Berlioz and Mozart, Faure's disdains to summon up distasteful images of apocalyptic violence or hellish horrors.

THE AMBIVALENT AMERICAN BACHELOR
LEAD: Trip Gabriel writes of men's ambivalence about marriage as though it were something new.
The icon of American culture is the lonesome cowboy, epitomized by Shane.
These single men do the heroic deeds that married men cannot.
How could any man be a product of this culture and not be ambivalent about marriage?

ARCHIVES OF BUSINESS: The Toy Industry; Under the Tree, in Christmases Past
LEAD: CHRISTMAS was a lot easier on parents before toys came along.
When children played with wooden spoons or pots, their parents not only didn't have to spend any money but, more important, didn't have to make any choices. (They also didn't have to squirm around under couches and beneath dish washers, days later, rooting for mislaid pieces from the Erector set.) By the late 1800's, the toy business was in full swing.


Koreans Vie for the 'Undecided' Vote
LEAD: South Korea's presidential candidates fanned out across the country today, drawing vast crowds wherever they went as they tried to win over a substantial number of voters who seem unable to make up their minds.

BARE KNUCKLES ON MADISON AVENUE
LEAD: I must say I find all this negativism concerning the advertising business these days quite extraordinary.
Every time I read an article about the megamergers, etc., I read the lines ''A lot of the fun has gone out of the business.'' The irony is that the quote usually comes from those who have become wealthy (thanks to the advertising business) and have sold out in one way or another.

Columbia and Football: An Issue Strikes a Nerve;  School's Athletes Belong There
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


Question Of the Week; Is Larry Holmes Too Old To Fight?
LEAD: Larry Holmes, at 38 years of age, is not too old to fight.
Like most older athletes, he can compensate for that lost step, that slower trigger in his reflexes.
Put him in with most of the heavyweights of today and he'll have his way.
However, he is too old - and worse yet, has been inactive too long - to fight a young ogre like Mike Tyson.


PROGRAM HELPS INMATES FIND WAYS TO FORGO VIOLENCE
LEAD: SEVENTEEN Sing Sing inmates, convicted of everything from murder to drug trafficking, recently played musical chairs, made up new names for themselves and talked about the temptation to violence.


West Rebuffs East on Pact on Europe Troop Cuts
LEAD: While Washington geared up for the drama of summitry and a major arms pact, negotiators in Vienna wound up another fruitless round of the 14-year-old talks on troop reductions in Central Europe with Western delegations rejecting Eastern efforts to end the talks with a ''symbolic'' agreement.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Ramsey Suspended
LEAD: THE National Hockey League announced yesterday that Mike Ramsey, a Buffalo Sabres defenseman, had been suspended for eight games for incurring a match penalty in a stick-swinging incident in a game Dec. 3 against Quebec.
Ramsey injured the Nordiques' Paul Gillis.


Art
LEAD: This is the last week of an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of which little was known in advance and not a great deal was expected in terms of audience response.

SIMON SPIVACK, M.D.
Worcester, Mass.


TV: 'Northanger Abbey,' Austen Satire
LEAD: PUBLIC television's ''Masterpiece Theater'' ventures into predictable territory tonight - on Channel 13 at 9 P.M. - with Jane Austen's ''Northanger Abbey.'' Here, in a one-part, 90-minute adaptation, is still another excuse for a British period piece, exquisitely costumed and expertly acted.
But fans of the series are likely to be perplexed by this particular adaptation.

THE AMBIVALENT AMERICAN BACHELOR
LEAD: I was reading Trip Gabriel's article alone in the kitchen, while my husband (of 29 years) was in the adjacent TV room, watching his sixth hour of football.
I wonder why those bachelors who were interviewed believe they must relinquish their cherished adolescence the moment they say ''I do.'' Any of them in need of reassurance is welcome to spend a Sunday at our house from now until the Super Bowl.


The Stage: 'Cabinet of Dr. Caligari'
LEAD: WHY mount a stage adaptation of a screen classic that owed its nightmare quality to startling backdrops, ominous lighting and crafty camera angles?
Susan Mosakowski's 50-minute version of ''The Cabinet of Dr.
Caligari,'' the 1919 spooker about the malevolent hypnotist and the somnambulist he sends forth from his coffin to murder townsfolk, affords no satisfying explanation.

THE AMBIVALENT AMERICAN BACHELOR
LEAD: The assertion that singles may face greater difficulty and loneliness in later life is more an expression of a fear common to the middle-aged, regardless of marital status, than a reality of old age.
One recent study suggests that singles may, in fact, have an advantage in adjusting to the conditions of aging over those who lose their lifelong mates and are left to develop new personal and social skills on their own.

NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1987
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL/3-31


Question Of the Week; Is Larry Holmes Too Old To Fight?
LEAD: Unfortunately, especially among heavyweights, those who fought one fight too many are numerous.
Joe Louis, arguably the best ever, being slaughtered in the eighth round by a young Rocky Marciano, most closely parallels Larry Holmes's current sad journey and its probable sad ending.
LARRY WOLFSON

LEAD:  RARE ARTHUR MILLER

LEAD: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., Jane Elizabeth Blinder, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Seton Laurence Blinder of Woodmere, L.I., was married last evening to Robert I. Barocas, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Max Barocas of Great Neck, L.I.
Rabbis Joel Y. Zion and Gerald Davidson officiated.


Thai Vasectomy Record
LEAD: Yearlong celebrations of King Bhumibol Adulyadej's 60th birthday culminated in Thailand today with Buddhist rites, colorful processions and a claim of a world record for voluntary vasectomies.
A spokesman for the Population and Community Development Association said 1,214 men were vasectomized free of charge in an annual event held on the King's birthday.


CHOOSING FILES FOR WOOD AND METAL
LEAD: FILES for smoothing and shaping metal and wood are useful and inexpensive additions to any do-it-yourselfer's tool kit.
However, files are categorized by an obscure terminology that can make choosing one perplexing.

Kenneth B. Becker of New City, N.Y.

Lessons for Skiers, Old and New
LEAD: THE advice from seasoned skiers is that lessons are the most important investment skiers can make in their career on the slopes.
Beginners, obviously, need good teaching from trained instructors, but wherever there are ski classes you'll find intermediates and experts trying to smooth out trouble spots, everything from progressing from stem to parallel turns and planting poles correctly to racing.


Opera: 'Fledermaus,' In Old World and New
LEAD: AMERICAN culture bears the burdens of tradition lightly if at all.
It is both our joy and our calamity and a source of constant confusion.
Perhaps it is this kind of rootlessness and free-floating liberty that creates such bewildering events as Friday night's ''Fledermaus'' at the Metropolitan Opera.

A Proud People Seeks U.S. Respect
LEAD: WHEN visiting Americans tour a Russian factory, farm, school or hospital, they are sure to be politely interrogated about how it stacks up against a comparable facility in the United States.
After this questioning, they may be startled to hear their host declare, contradicting the immediate evidence and the apparent rules of glasnost, ''Yes, we have all that, too.


Rio Rancho's Tangled Legacy
LEAD: IN THE early to mid-70's, residents of New York and other cities were flooded with invitations to free dinners, courtesy of the Amrep Corporation.
Those who went were treated to something else as well: a high-pressure sales pitch about the natural beauty and investment potential of land in Rio Rancho Estates, a sprawling new subdivision that Amrep was developing 15 miles northwest of Albuquerque, N.M.


AT 91 YEARS, HANGING IN FOR THE LONG PULL
LEAD: HISTORY not only repeats itself, but as I head into my 92d year, I am beginning to suffer from acute deja vu.
I have seen Halley's comet twice, lived through two World Wars, and experienced two stock market crashes, one in October 1929, the other October 1987.
The two crashes had much in common.
The advice given by the experts in 1929 is very much like that being given now.

Pop Music
LEAD: The voice reigns in South African popular music.
Voices join in ringing harmonies, overlap in syncopations, swoop into falsetto or glide through melodies; the clicks that are part of the Zulu language turn into percussion.

What the Dollar's Drop Won't Do
LEAD: THESE should be glory days for America's industrial exporters.
Their products bristle with state-of-the-art technology.
They are lean and hungry after responding to an onslaught of foreign competition during the early 1980's.
And most are using the pricing advantage created by the dollar's steep decline against major industrial nations to regain old markets or establish new ones.

Sometimes it resembles the dilemma of a rat in a maze.

TWISTING THE TALE AT THE END: A SYMPOSIUM

If only the Three Sisters had moved to Moscow and gone dancing with the Brothers Karamazov.
What if Ahab married Hester Prynne and gave up the seafaring life?
When The Book Review asked a number of writers what literary endings they would change, heroines were saved from death and despair, underdogs turned into heroes.


GORBACHEV'S SHREWD SUMMITRY
LEAD: The second summit meeting between President Reagan and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev ends in icy collapse without any agreement, not even on a date for the next summit.
Gorbachev accuses Reagan of scuttling the summit.
Reagan coldly tells the Soviet leader, ''I think you didn't want a summit,'' and then rides off cursing in his limousine.

Most recently, Book-of-the-Month Records issued a four-LP set (two cassettes or three CD's) and a few years ago CBS issued a clutch of some of the most famous cuts in a series of LP's.

Deer Disappears
LEAD: Most deer run away.
Jeff Humphreys says his eight-point buck was carried away.
Mr.
Humphreys, of Ligonier, Pa., told the police that someone stole his freshly killed deer from the back of his pickup truck Tuesday night as the truck was parked at an inn. ''He had shot himself a nice eight-point,'' said Jim Steel, a state trooper, ''and he was at a watering hole for a beer and to talk about his deer, and he came out to find the deer was taken.

ART
LEAD: ONE of the paradoxical things about art book publishing is that within a book that is almost too heavy to lift, let alone to carry, a slender pamphlet of exceptional distinction may be hiding.
Equally well, what looks at first sight like a routine enlargement of an exhibition catalogue that dates back to 1976 may turn out to be full of new facts and new insights and in every way an indispensable addition to knowledge.

Q AND A
LEAD: Airport Codes  Question: For a research project, I would like to know who regulates the coding system for baggage ticketing at airports.
If Kennedy Airport in New York is JFK, why should Key West be EYW?
Where can I get information? - I. P. A., Brooklyn  Answer: Those three-letter codes used for labeling airline passengers' baggage are determined by the International Air Transport Association, the trade organization of most of the world's airlines.

THE PRIVATE PAIN OF INFERTILITY
LEAD: THE SMALL OFFICE IS CROWDED: 9 OR 10 women wait for their names to be called.
After signing in, I stand by the desk and wait like the rest.
The silence is communal - not uneasy. ''What stage of your cycle are you at?'' I ask a woman about 35 - my age.
Under other conditions this question would have prompted her to move away from me shaking her head, certain I was one of the many odd characters a large metropolitan city regularly serves up.

Baby Killed by Terrier
LEAD: A mixed boxer-pit bull terrier mauled a sleeping 2-week-old baby to death early Friday, officers said.
The infant, Brian Lillis, was asleep in a car seat on a sofa when he was pulled to the floor and attacked by the 40-pound dog, the police said.
The police killed the dog at the request of a deputy medical examiner.

LEAD: THE New Zealand challenge for the America's Cup - in boats twice the size of the traditional 12-Meter yachts - has caused an uproar among many traditionalists, but it may have come just in time to rescue the world's leading sailing event from the trash heap of sports history.

Shearson-Hutton: The Deal Is Done
LEAD: Shearson bought Hutton for $962 million in a deal that will, by some measures, create the securities industry's largest firm.
For example, the combined sales forces will number 12,300, about 800 more than at Merrill Lynch, the industry leader.
The Hutton brokers' jobs were believed to be largely secure but there will undoubtedly be layoffs elsewhere to eliminate duplication.


WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
LEAD: BLACK DAHLIA by James Ellroy.
Mysterious Press. 325 pages. $16.95.
In January 1947 a beautiful young woman was murdered and dismembered in Los Angeles, and despite the greatest manhunt in California history, the case was never solved.

A NEW LOOK INTO THE ABYSS OF CALIGARI'S CABINET
LEAD: THE 1919 GERMAN FILM CLASSIC ''The Cabinet of Dr.
Caligari'' has been a favorite of Film 101 courses for a variety of reasons.
Although its validity as a harbinger of the moral climate that permitted Hitler's rise to power has been debated, its significance for the cinema as a bold stylistic departure into a realm of fantasy and expression has remained indisputable.

Tenderfoot in the Wilds of Wyoming
LEAD: THE magnolia was getting ready to bloom back in my Philadelphia garden and I was questioning my sanity.
Why was I was trekking into subarctic conditions to spend a week skiing in the highest and most remote private guest ranch in the Wyoming Rockies?
I and my intrepid party of seven knew we would be cut off from civilization, deep-frozen, virtually snowbound.

LEAD: ERICK HAWKINS choreographed ''Black Lake'' in 1969 but for some reason this translucent ceremonial suite has not been danced since 1978.
On Friday night it was revived again at the Joyce Theater, 19th Street and Eighth Avenue, as part of the Erick Hawkins Dance Company season ending tonight.

NEW CHINESE ARRIVAL IN WANTAGH
LEAD: IT'S deja vu time; a new Chinese restaurant, Peking Dynasty, has opened on Merrick Road in Wantagh.
This restaurant, like other recent Chinese arrivals, is in the mold, with the standard color scheme of pink, rose, plum, burgundy, mauve and gray.
In bygone days, Chinese restaurants were red and gold and sported dragons and lanterns.

LEAD: To the Editor:


When Planning Can Be Too Much of a Good Thing
LEAD: TO A CRITIC OF THE EXCESSES of development that have plagued most American downtowns, San Francisco would appear to be the promised land.
Here, the planners and the voters, not the real-estate developers, hold the power.
The process of getting approval to put up a high-rise office building in the downtown business district here is so complex it must make the hardiest developer yearn for the simplicities of doing business in New York.


Critic Charles Spurs Debate By Londoners
LEAD: Britain's best-known architecture critic, Prince Charles, has touched off a spirited public debate about modern buildings and royal privilege with a stinging attack this week on property development.


Austerity And Unrest On Rise in Eastern Bloc
LEAD: IN one country, plans are afoot to close unprofitable steel mills and eliminate thousands of jobs.
In another, a Government-decreed belt-tightening drove thousands of workers into the streets, where they ransacked a city hall.
In a third, voters rejected an economic austerity program.


Cross Country In Canada
LEAD: SAVE for the purist who insists on skiing the 16 miles, most wintertime visitors to Mount Assiniboine Lodge in the Canadian Rockies are whisked in by helicopter, as we were.
The 15-minute ride from the muddy Mount Shark Heliport above Bryant Creek and over Assiniboine Pass was exhilarating.
Suddenly there was a new world below with white snow interspersed with dark patches of larch, spruce and fir.

LEAD: If life expectancy is said to be 70-80 years, why give up your freedom by marrying at age 25?
Yes, I'll admit I am one of the ''self-indulgent'' generation; I cannot see myself getting married until I find someone I ''cannot live without.'' Until then, I know I will be content not having to report to someone daily or having to ask what that $100 check was spent on.

THE AMBIVALENT AMERICAN BACHELOR
LEAD: Trip Gabriel points out that American men show less inclination to marry than they did formerly.
I would like to suggest that our Government is actively encouraging the change.
Current tax laws impose a substantial tax burden on two-income couples who choose to marry.
Thus, a significant economic penalty is imposed.

I would clean up, I told them, not knowing exactly where to begin. ''Have a good day,'' my son said, averting his glance from the mess. ''You must be kidding!'' I cried. ''Well, have a better day,'' he offered.

LEAD:  'CHRISTMAS CAROL' TOUR  Three touring companies of ''A Christmas Carol,'' a production that originated in Omaha, Neb., in 1976, are going across the country this year.

Large Atom Plant Dedicated
LEAD: The largest commercial nuclear power plant in the United States was dedicated Friday by Energy Secretary John S. Herrington.
Construction began in 1976 on the three-unit, 3,810-megawatt plant, and commercial generation began in January 1986.
When the third unit comes on line next year, only the Paluel nuclear power plant in France and a plant near Leningrad in the Soviet Union will be capable of generating more power.

MODERN CONVENIENCES
LEAD: THE MORE EXPENSIVE THE antique, the faster its sale.
Such has been the supply-and-demand rule of home furnishings in recent years.
Indeed, the lust for a set of graceful Regency chairs, a beautifully inlaid cabinet or a breakfront crafted by an 18th-century furniture maker became as much a status symbol as a silver Porsche or a gold-faced Rolex watch.

He was 88 years old.
Dr.
Powell, who was born in Warrenton, N.C., and had a doctorate in biology, founded the Carolina Biological Supply Company in 1927 and headed its operation from 1936 until his death.

Schnabel and Stella: Art, Myth and Ego
LEAD: THE COINCIDENCE THAT LARGE surveys of the art of Frank Stella and Julian Schnabel are taking up a lot of prime exhibition space in New York City at the moment has an air of perfect timing about it.
The exhibitions, Stella's at the Museum of Modern Art, Schnabel's at the Whitney, are both by the enfants terribles of their respective artistic generations, and come toward the end of a tumultuous decade in art.


THREE DECORATIONS TO MAKE
LEAD: Holiday time often brings out creative talents.
With each year, the traditions become more firmly rooted and the family looks forward to to a display of seasonaltrimmings.
The three designs shown here are easy to duplicate and are made from live plant materials.
Two of them are based on influences from Victorian England and are enriched by embellishments from this country.

Catholic Charities Aids Those in the Shadows
LEAD: For 70 years, the poor, the hungry, the homeless, the troubled, the abandoned and the sick have come to the agencies and offices of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York looking for assistance.
We have responded by offering food, shelter, clothing, medical care and services to meet immediate and long-term needs of individuals and families unable to cope on their own with the crisis of survival in the urban setting.

STAR WARS IS COMING, BUT WHERE IS IT GOING?
LEAD: IT SEEMS CLEAR THAT STAR Wars has become both impossible and inevitable.
The best evidence indicates that, given the current size of the Soviet arsenal of long-range ballistic missiles aimed at the United States, some 10,000 warheads strong, a space-based defense has no chance of working as envisioned by President Reagan.

If the Turkey Had Been the National Bird; Consider the Rattler
LEAD: To the Editor:


From Track to Track in Ireland
LEAD: BY early afternoon, some of the stores on Shop Street, Galway's aptly named main commercial thoroughfare, are starting to close their doors.
Bumper to bumper, long lines of cars thread their way along Shop and the other narrow streets that lead out of town.
The buskers, strolling street musicians, have put aside their fiddles and tin whistles; they, too, are leaving.


Record Price Is Paid For Antique Brooch
LEAD: A fifth-century gold brooch of a standing eagle - an Ostrogothic Dark Ages ornament - was auctioned last night in Monte Carlo, Monaco, by Sotheby's for $2.6 million, a record price at auction for an antiquity.


Vandal Throws Cobblestone Through Window on Liberty
LEAD: A jagged hole and splintered shards of glass greeted park rangers Friday at the building that houses the Liberty Bell, the work of a vandal who threw a cobblestone through an inch-thick pane of glass, officials said.

NEW YORK FARMERS POST EARNINGS RISE
LEAD: New York farmers received a record net income of $598 million in 1986, up 33 percent from the year before, and the highest profit ever reported in the nearly 50 years that records have been kept, according to agricultural statistics issued this week here and in Washington.

LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 17 food establishments cited for violating the health code.


Piano: Michael Blum at Alice Tully Hall
LEAD: MICHAEL BLUM, a 31-year-old New York-born pianist who has studied at the Juilliard School, began his recital on Thursday evening in Merkin Concert Hall with his best work - four of Mendelssohn's ''Songs Without Words'' shaped in limpid, supple phrases and colored by a soft, shimmery tone.


Question Of the Week; Is Larry Holmes Too Old To Fight?
LEAD: A great deal of scientific evidence suggests that the normal central nervous system is significantly less functional at 40 than it is at 20.
This dysfunction is perhaps most evident in an area with great implications for a boxer's well being, hand-eye speed and coordination.
Holmes, after an amateur career, 50 professional fights, and countless rounds of sparring, does not possess a normal central nervous system.

Will Trade Follow the Summit Talks?
LEAD: While Soviet-American trade has never been large in volume - it will total only about $2 billion in 1987 - it has been controversial and highly political.
In the early 1970's, during the era of detente, American companies began to move into the Soviet Union in a big way.
In 1971, Mack Truck designed and built a large part of the Soviet Union's $1.4 billion Kama River truck manufacturing plant.

Playhouse Video. 122 minutes. $59.98.
For a tale that pits Clark Gable against Robert Ryan, ''The Tall Men'' makes a mighty mild movie.
The weather is heavier than the plot of this Western, which takes place mostly on a big cattle drive from Texas to Montana - 5,000 head herded by a batch of Mexican hombres from ethnic casting plus a tribe of Sioux to be shot down along the way.

The Editors Grimm
LEAD: To the Editor:


The Thirsty State Drinks
LEAD: ''WE HOPE TO HAVE WATER TO Tucson by early 1991,'' says Bob Towles, project manager for the Central Arizona Project (CAP), the United States Bureau of Reclamation's $3.5 billion effort on behalf of the nation's thirstiest state.
From its source, at Lake Havasu on the California border, the 335-mile system of concrete-lined canals, tunnels, pumping plants and pipelines will provide much of southern and central Arizona with the bounty of the Colorado River.

COOKBOOKS
LEAD: COOKBOOKS tend to cluster.
Several along similar themes are published each season, either reflecting current tastes or predicting a trend.
This year the cooking of countries bordering the Mediterranean seems to dominate the lists.

GIFTS THE MAGI NEVER BROUGHT: A LITERARY QUIZ

The gift may please, or it may rebound on the giver.
It may also expose one or both parties, may express aggression as well as affection.

LANDSCAPES SHOW AT U. OF BRIDGEPORT
LEAD: THE mass filling the picture is one of those Southwestern mesas that look like fossilized architecture.
A reproduction of a 1978 black-and-white photograph by Michael Smith, it could be an Abstract Expressionist image, and, in a way, owes its existence to that movement in art. ''Toroweap, Arizona,'' as it's called, is one of the 67 landscapes by 56 photographers that make up ''Views and Visions,'' the present attraction at the Carlson Gallery at the University of Bridgeport.

Not-So-Great Debates
LEAD: 'Those great debates of the middle and early 1800's, the Clay and Calhoun and Webster debates - some of what they did at least put off the Civil War for another decade, some of what they did opened up the opportunity for new states and new territories to be created. . . .
I have a suspicion that on some of those big and closely fought issues, the debate itself may well have tipped the balance - but you can't tip the balance today if everybody is so heavily positioned before the debate starts that you can't change or modify your position.

LEAD: THE FIRST TIME I HEARD THE WORD ''glasnost'' from a Soviet official was last October, on a flight from Reykjavik to New York after the Reagan-Gorbachev summit meeting.

LEAD: IN July 1842 an unhappy 22-year-old jumped ship in the South Pacific.

23 Seamen Killed in Fire on Ship Off Spain
LEAD: At least 23 seamen died today after fire broke out aboard a freighter in rough seas off Spain and forced the crew to abandon ship, the Spanish National Radio reported.


HOCKNEY CASTS A NEW LIGHT ON 'TRISTAN'
LEAD: THREE WEEKENDS AGO, IN A large rambling house high up in the Hollywood Hills, a party of three sat before a model theater.
Built to a scale of 1 to 12, it mimicked exactly the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles, complete with proscenium, flies and a keyboard for the lights.
The house was the home of David Hockney - painter, draftsman, printmaker, photographer and stage designer - and the party of three had driven up from Santa Monica for a run-through in miniature of a new production of Wagner's ''Tristan and Isolde,'' which has its premiere this evening at the Dorothy Chandler


The Beaux Arts' New Boy
LEAD: ''YOU CAN ONLY GET TO know a musician during a concert,'' asserted the Beaux Arts Trio's pianist, Menahem Pressler, a few days after the group's first performance with Peter Wiley, its new cellist. ''You can find out a lot about someone offstage, or in rehearsal, but it is only when you are playing for an audience - when the chips are really down - that you get a true insight into what your colleagues are about.


Rouben Mamoulian, Broadway Director, Is Dead
LEAD: Rouben Mamoulian, the director of such benchmark musical shows as ''Porgy and Bess'' and ''Oklahoma!'' and more than a dozen innovative and distinctive movies, died Friday night.
He was 90 years old.
Mr.
Mamoulian died at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital in Los Angeles, where he had been hospitalized a short time, a hospital spokeswoman said.

FIG TREE BEARS A CROP OF MEMORIES
LEAD: THE fig tree grew in the backyard of the acre property deeded to us with the purchase of our present home.
Embedded in the ground by the gardener, the tree was nurtured by and brought joy to the old man and woman from whom we bought the house.
It might have received no more attention from us than any other shrub or tree, except that the old man always asked about it.

Bateman's
LEAD: To the Editor: My traveling companion and I enjoyed the article on Bateman's, Rudyard Kipling's home (Travel, Aug. 23).
Having seen the house and gardens, we must say the article is very accurate.
We especially enjoyed the motor car in the adjacent building.
Kipling was somewhat of a hot-rodder with his auto, and we could just picture him whizzing down the narrow country lanes we had driven to get to the house.

LEAD: THE recent construction of a 100-foot microwave tranmission tower by the Long Island Rail Road has taken the community of Woodbury by surprise, causing anger and concern in residents who said they had no knowledge of its planning or execution.


Sound: Plus Ca Change. . .
LEAD: PEOPLE CONVINCED that there can't be too much of a good thing prefer their music nonstop, and technology has caught up with them at last.
It isn't just that the playing time of records has increased steadily over the years, growing from 4 1/2 minutes a side in the days of 78-rpm disks to about 30 minutes in the LP era and reaching an uninterrupted 70 minutes or thereabouts on CD's.

LEAD: More than 31,000 men in three countries have been bilked of millions of dollars by a scheme that promised they could retire to a paradise tended by nude angels, Federal prosecutors say.

Keeping on Top of All Those Details
LEAD: HERE at Mission Control we use a Rolodex file to keep track of sources and telephone numbers.
We use a small pocket diary and a larger desk calendar to keep track of appointments and meetings.
We keep track of expenses on slips of paper that we stuff into pockets or desk drawers, to be gathered and added up later with a pocket calculator.

THE AMBIVALENT AMERICAN BACHELOR
LEAD: Commentators on the marriage patterns of baby boomers persistently return to the single, comfortingly familiar assertion (revamped for the 1980's) that women want marriage, men avoid it.
In fact, however, the rueful and somewhat bewildered discourse on this subject cuts across gender lines.
Single women and men of this generation are saying remarkably similar things about the absence of marriage in their lives.

VOLCKER ON THE CRASH
LEAD: Attempting to put the ''crash'' in perspective, Paul Volcker states that ''the market went up 30 percent this year and it's gone back down 30 percent, to where it was at the beginning of the year.'' Unfortunately, as millions of investors will attest, a 30 percent gain followed by a 30 percent loss doesn't bring you back to where you started.

Jim Dinerstein, a sculptor, and Suyapa Quinn, a painter, will be among those exhibiting their work.

Now It's Chirac Who Decides He Can Deal for Hostages
LEAD: POLITICIANS habitually have problems squaring high moral principles with reality - most painfully when they have to deal with fellow citizens who have been kidnaped by terrorists.
In an age dominated by the televised image, the hostage becomes compellingly human in his helplessness, generating pressure for action.


FAREWELL TO WIT, HELLO VULGARITY
LEAD: COMMERCIAL TELEVISION ENTERTAINMENT is tumbling into a Vulgarity Sweepstakes.
Today's viewers will find language and situations on their weekly series that would never have got past the ''program practices'' guards just five years ago.
One major reason for the change is the expanding presence of cable television, where more permissive rules about content allow operators to carry uncensored theatrical-release films and stand-up comedy acts that revel in aggressive coarseness.

LEAD: The Scott Paper Company has agreed to pay the Federal Government fines totaling $475,000 to settle charges that it deliberately violated Federal health and safety regulations at its paper mill in Winslow, Me.

How to Make Mammography Affordable
LEAD: Nancy Reagan's breast cancer surgery in October prompted a national surge of interest in mammography, the procedure for detecting such cancers long before they can be felt.
But when such cases fade from the news, demand for the procedure recedes.
Only 11 percent of American women undergo mammography on a regular basis.

A Legacy of Ruin
LEAD: When I was a boy, I sometimes visited a house in upstate New York that was just across a fence from an old, overgrown, hillside cemetery.
This graveyard was a beautiful place, shady on hot days, and I used to love playing there.
Cemeteries are often intriguing to children, I think.
They are sometimes our first brush with the mystery of death, and also with the power of memory.
