But they do have a kind of secret weapon, and it's aimed at increasing everybody's home-run swing.


Youth Faces Charges In Crash Fatal to 4
LEAD: A 16-year-old Bethany youth was charged yesterday with four counts of misconduct with a motor vehicle in connection with the deaths of four of his friends in a car crash in October, the police said.


Europeans Deregulate Air Travel
LEAD: The European Community's transport ministers approved a long-awaited airline deregulation package today that community officials said would lower ticket costs by creating more competition on flights within Europe.


When Will the Shackling Stop?
LEAD: On Nov. 11 the New York City Department of Correction declared it would put an end to the barbaric practice of shackling ailing prisoners to beds in city hospitals.
Shackling of women prisoners was to end immediately, which it did.
Male prisoners were to be freed of their shackles a week later.
As of yesterday about two dozen men, including some suffering from AIDS, remained in chains, manacled to bed rails and posts at Bellevue


Steel Output Off 3.8%
LEAD: Steel production fell to 1.798 million tons in the week ended Saturday, a decrease of 3.8 percent from the previous week's 1.869 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 83.3 percent of capacity, compared with 86.6 percent in the previous week.

Senator Burdick in Hospital
LEAD: Senator Quentin N. Burdick, the 79-year-old Democrat who is seeking re-election, was hospitalized for observation today after he fell on ice at the airport and hurt his head, said the Senator's Washington press secretary, Jean Brodshaug.


Marietta Contract
LEAD: The Martin Marietta Corporation has been awarded a $1.56 billion military contract for work on 13 big Titan 4 space rockets, the Air Force said.
The effort is another step by the Pentagon to increase its ability to launch heavy spy and other satellites into space in the wake of setbacks in America's space program in the last two years.


At the Talks, A Barometer In a Uniform
LEAD: When Secretary of State George P. Shultz was on his way to Geneva two weeks ago for talks with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, he told reporters he was confident that the two sides would resolve the key differences over the new missile treaty at those meetings.


Sallie Mae Sets Sale of Notes
LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering to the public $250 million of short-term floating-rate notes due on June 9, 1988, through various securities dealers.


C. George Willard, 58, Broadway Press Agent
LEAD: C. George Willard, a Broadway press representative and former theatrical company manager, died Sunday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center.
He was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: THE distinguishing feature of the $9 billion package of tax increases that the Senate is scheduled to consider today is that few people are likely to remember what was in it.
In fact, few people are likely to understand most of what is in it.
And that is exactly what tax writers on the Senate Finance


Pension Fund Group Links Specialists to Stock Plunge
LEAD: An industry group representing some of the country's largest corporate pension funds, with more than $400 billion in assets, has singled out the New York Stock Exchange specialist system for contributing to the mid-October stock market collapse.

2 Executive Recruiters Altering Management
LEAD: Two of the major executive recruiting companies, Russell Reynolds Associates and Spencer Stuart, have announced shifts in top management.
At Spencer Stuart, Dayton Ogden has been named managing director and chief executive, while at Russell Reynolds, Hobson Brown Jr. was selected as president and chief operating officer.


Music: The Cosmopolitan
LEAD: THE Cosmopolitan Symphony Orchestra is one of New York's many pickup ensembles, pulling its members from the city's deep pool of young, talented players.
The roughly 50-member orchestra gave the first concert of its season in Town Hall on Saturday afternoon.
Presenting a program of palatable Romantic fare, it displayed not only the vigor one expects from a youthful ensemble, but also a relatively high degree of style and coordination.


Northeast U.S. Mussels Are Banned by Ontario
LEAD: The Province of Ontario today banned the sale of mussels from Canada's Atlantic provinces and the northeastern United States after 37 cases of food poisoning in Canada were attributed to shellfish.

U.S. Farmland Values Are Making Comeback
LEAD: Farmland values are rebounding after six years of decline, a modest turnaround that Agriculture Department economists say is nonetheless significant.


CATHOLIC TAX CASE TO GET A HEARING
LEAD: The Supreme Court agreed today to consider whether to kill, on jurisdictional grounds, a lawsuit seeking to revoke the Federal tax exemption of the Roman Catholic Church.


About Education; The Uses of Technology
LEAD: UNLESS the schools are radically transformed and become part of the age of technology, the United States will spend decades catching up with more enterprising countries, according to an educational consultant.
At the present pace of change, a small number of privileged children in a few pioneering public school systems will benefit from high-technology learning tools.

Confusion, Secrecy Shroud Experiments
LEAD: Clinical trials of experimental treatments in this country have long been shrouded in secrecy, their locations and often their very existence hidden from scientists and frustrated patients, some of whom are desperately seeking a life-saving cure.


Governing Party Is Set Back In Bolivian Municipal Voting
LEAD: Bolivia's governing party was set back in municipal elections as leftist and conservative opposition parties were leading in eight provincial capitals, including La Paz, according to initial results reported today.


Polar Explorers Announce New Expeditions
LEAD: WILL Steger, an Arctic explorer who last year led the first dogsled expedition to the North Pole since 1909, now plans to make the first non-mechanized journey to the first non-mechanized journey to the South Pole and across the entire continent of Antarctica.


The Summit: Ready to Raise the Curtain; Power Trade: El Greco for Titian
LEAD: The Soviet Union and the United States have announced an exchange of art masterpieces timed for the summit meeting, a Titian being lent to the National Gallery here and an El Greco to be lent to the Hermitage Museum in Leningrad.

Witness Discloses Bigamy  A major witness in a Wedtech bribery trial told a jury he had two wives and had offered loans to associates at annual rates above 50 percent.


Stingless Bee Of Dinosaur Age Lies in Amber
LEAD: EIGHTY million years ago, when dinosaurs were about and tropical breezes warmed the land that is now New Jersey, a stingless honey bee there got itself caught in the sticky resin of a conifer.
The resin hardened into a piece of amber, preserving the bee in lifelike fossilization.

LEAD: For Mikhail S. Gorbachev, this week's talks with President Reagan hold the key to an audacious but still fragile effort to alter the international order and revitalize the Soviet Union.


2 Top Correction Officials Demoted After 3 Inmates Escape
LEAD: Calling several recent escapes from city jails ''an embarrassment,'' Richard J. Koehler, the New York City Correction Commissioner, yesterday demoted two top penal officials.

LEAD: Vice President Bush made important headway today in his effort to gain a majority of Michigan's 77 delegates to the Republican National Convention when several top officials of Representative Jack F. Kemp's campaign gave up an acriminous procedural battle.

Yanks Are Still Dealing
LEAD: The Yankees, refusing to give up Al Leiter, their highly promising pitcher, missed out on a chance to get Zane Smith, a left-handed pitcher, from the Atlanta Braves today.
But they continued their pursuit of Dave Parker, a left-handed hitter they covet.


17 Arrested by U.S. in Heroin Ring in Puerto Rico
LEAD: Federal officials said today that 17 people, including one person in New York, had been arrested in connection with the operation of a family-run heroin ring here.
The officials said they believed it to be one of the biggest drug rings in Puerto Rico.

LEAD: The Deputy Secretary of Defense, William Howard Taft 4th, said today that military budgets being planned for the five years beginning in 1990 would be 11 percent or 12 percent less than those drafted a year ago, and that the armed forces would be cut by 100,000 people.

3-0 PITT COASTS TO VICTORY

Books: Setting Stages Books: Setting Stages
LEAD: THE THEATER ART OF BORIS ARONSON.
By Frank Rich with Lisa Aronson. 322 pages.
Knopf. $75.
BORIS ARONSON (1900-1980) was an artist who, having chosen set design as his metier, enjoyed the boon of early recognition both in his native Kiev and in New York City.
Luckily for him (though he is unlikely to have thought so at the time), this recognition fell short of that premature elevation to fame and fortune that has tainted the lives of so many other young artists in our era.

Opera: 'Tristan Und Isolde'
LEAD: The new production of ''Tristan und Isolde'' that the Los Angeles Music Center Opera put forward this evening was something of an oddity for our times, but a welcome one.
It had about it a tone of antic freshness, of fairy-tale legend filtered through adult (and adulterous) fantasy, while nonetheless managing to resemble the naturalistic stagings familiar to previous generations of Wagnerians.


Expatriate Looks Homeward
LEAD: When 30 young South Africans arrived in New York earlier this fall to introduce ''Sarafina,'' Mbongeni Ngema's fiercely passionate South African musical, their wide-eyed wonder reflected their first visit outside their own troubled country.

Jonathon Chase, Law School Dean, 48
LEAD: Jonathon Chase, who was dean of the Vermont Law School in South Royalton from 1982 to July 1987, died of cancer Saturday at his home here.
He was 48 years old.


Chiles of Florida Is Retiring, Saying Zeal for Senate Lags
LEAD: Senator Lawton Chiles, citing a loss of enthusiasm for the Senate, today surprised his colleagues here and his supporters in Florida by pulling out of his race for re-election next year.


Dollar Posts Broad Gains In a Light Trading Session
LEAD: The dollar strengthened in light trading yesterday, amid continuing signs that for the time being at least the Federal Reserve Board is prepared to prevent the currency from falling further.


France Expelling Iranian Opponents of Khomeini
LEAD: France began a roundup of several dozen members of a leftist Iranian opposition group today in what appeared to be part of an agreement to improve relations with Iran.


Barry Blau &amp; Partners Gets New President
LEAD: Dennis Eastham, who had been executive vice president and general manager of the Chicago office of Barry Blau &amp; Partners, was named president of the Fairfield, Conn. company.
His predecessor, Barry Blau, who just turned 60 years old , was named chairman.

LEAD: Many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ask not to be identified, a request that is always honored.

The Summit: Ready to Raise the Curtain; In Stopover to See Thatcher, Celebration Rules the Air
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, stopping here briefly today on his journey to Washington, said the treaty that he and President Reagan are to sign on Tuesday is an expression of a yearning everywhere for a ''nonnuclear world.''


Ex-Teammates Meet
LEAD: A narcotics officer who played high school baseball with LaMarr Hoyt, a 1983 Cy Young Award winner, crossed paths with Hoyt again - during a drug arrest.
Hoyt, 32 years old, was arrested Saturday at his Columbia, S.C., apartment.
Narcotics investigators from the Richland County Sheriff's Department reported finding about two grams of cocaine and several plastic bags containing marijuana.


French Court Blocks Sale of Zola Manuscript
LEAD: The French Court of Appeals in Paris yesterday ordered Sotheby's to halt the sale of the original manuscript of ''J'Accuse,'' the tract by Emile Zola that defended Capt.
Alfred Dreyfus against charges of treason.
The court move followed a dispute among the French author's heirs.

Editors' Note
LEAD: An article yesterday from Cambridge, Mass., reported that a study of Swedish women concluded that couples who live together before marriage have a divorce rate nearly 80 percent higher than those who do not.
The headline in some editions said, ''Divorce May Be the Price of Living Together First.'' That went beyond the conclusions of the authors of the report.

California Plane Crash Kills 44; Gunshots Are Reported in Cabin
LEAD: A Pacific Southwest Airlines commuter jet carrying 44 people crashed in central California this afternoon minutes after the pilot reported gunfire on board, Federal officials said.
The officials and the airline said they believe no one survived.


States Offering Safety Courses to Keep Hunters Out of the Line of Fire
LEAD: It is as much a part of the fall hunting season as a white-tailed deer bounding away through a hickory forest or a pheasant rising fast from a corn row.


Keep Fit the Way the Old-Timers Do
LEAD: To the Editor:


Monk Is Out
LEAD: The Washington Redskins will probably be without one of their wide receivers, Art Monk, until the playoffs.
The Redskins clinched the National Football Conference East title Sunday with a 34-17 victory over the St.
Louis Cardinals.
But their second-half comeback was marred by the loss of Monk, who suffered a partial tear of a ligament in his right knee.

It Takes Two to Make a Cold War
LEAD: To the Editor:


Victims and Suspects
LEAD: To the Editor:


Nicaragua Reports Downing and Capture of American Pilot
LEAD: A small plane was shot down Sunday afternoon over southeastern Nicaragua, and its pilot, an American, was captured by Sandinista troops, an army spokeswoman said early today.


Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q. Do Eskimos get scurvy?
A.Scurvy, a condition marked by weakness, anemia and bleeding from the gums and elsewhere, is caused by a lack of Vitamin C in the diet.
But according to Dr.
Douglas A. Shedden, a medical officer in Canada's Indian and Northern Health Services, the traditional diet of the native Inuit people contains surprising amounts of Vitamin C.


The Summit: The Stakes Are Momentous; Soviet Assails U.S. Plan On Conventional Arms
LEAD: A senior Soviet military official has sharply criticized the new American approach for reducing conventional arms.


CUBAN PRISONERS SEEK MIDDLE PATH
LEAD: Between the two extremes of deportation and indefinite detention, some Cubans who have served time in American prisons have been paroled into rehabilitation programs in preparation for integration into society.


Indians Seek Burial of Smithsonian Skeletons
LEAD: The Smithsonian Institution's collection of skeletal remains of native Americans is a sore point with Indians who want their ancestors' remains buried properly and treated with dignity.


Canada, U.S. Agree On Trade
LEAD: Canada and the United States today completed the final details of a free-trade agreement that had been threatened by last-minute efforts on both sides to tighten loopholes and limit concessions in an outline document that the two Governments approved two months ago.


By Design; 'Informal' Evenings
LEAD: It's always easy for men.
If the invitation to a swell dinner party reads ''black tie,'' they get out the dinner jacket.
If it says ''informal,'' they wear a dark business suit and a white shirt.
But for women, informal can be a quagmire.


U.N. and Arabs Protesting a Move In Congress to Shut P.L.O. Mission
LEAD: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar joined angry Arab representatives today in protesting a Congressional move to close the Palestine Liberation Organization's observer mission here.


Breast Milk Can Transfer Cocaine, Study Says
LEAD: Researchers have confirmed that a baby can ingest cocaine through breast milk, a Northwestern University pediatrician said Sunday.


Official in Kemp's Campaign Quits After Report on Books
LEAD: The Rev.
Tim LaHaye, a leader in the fundamentalist Christian movement, resigned today as an honorary national co-chairman of Representative Jack F. Kemp's Presidential campaign after reports that the minister had made anti-Catholic and anti-Jewish statements in published writings.


Vote in the Seychelles Elects 3d Assembly Since '77 Coup
LEAD: Voters in the Indian Ocean nation of the Seychelles elected a new four-year Parliament on Sunday.
It was the third general election since France Albert Rene seized power in a coup in 1977 and established one-party rule.


Advertising; Experts See Strength in Ad Spending
LEAD: IF the feared recession does indeed develop by 1990, worldwide advertising will probably not be badly hurt, according to an international agency media executive.


German Is Given Coma Therapy in Kansas
LEAD: Every day, Ilias Markfort hears the tape-recorded voice of his mother gently explaining why he is in a hospital bed in Kansas, thousands of miles away from his family and friends in West Germany.

MOLLY O'DAY, SINGER OF COUNTRY MUSIC IN ROUGHHEWN STYLE
LEAD: Molly O'Day, who never became a major national star but who was prized by aficionados as one of the finest country-and-western singers ever, died of cancer of the colon Saturday at Cabell Huntington Hospital in Huntington, W.Va.
She was 64 years old.


New York City to Pay Jersey Town $1 Million Over Shore Pollution
LEAD: A Federal judge today approved an agreement intended to halt the pollution of New York Harbor and the Jersey Shore by garbage from the city's Fresh Kills Landfill on Staten Island.


Boesky Said to Aid Homeless
LEAD: Ivan F. Boesky has been working with homeless men under an assumed name at the Cathedral of St.
John the Divine in Manhattan, his lawyer said in a court appearance last week.

LEAD: Long before the scheduling of this week's summit meeting between the Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Reagan, the PEN American Center had been negotiating with the Soviet Writers' Union to bring Soviet authors to this country for a series of public readings.

Market Plunge Aids Savings Units
LEAD: Many savings institutions are doing a roaring business, and their profits should increase sharply in the wake of the stock market collapse, experts on the savings industry said yesterday.


Lipton Acquisition
LEAD: Thomas J. Lipton Inc. said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the herbal tea maker Celestial Seasonings from Kraft Inc.
Terms of the deal, which is scheduled for completion next year, were not disclosed.
Lipton said that Kraft was selling Celestial Seasons as part of its move away from the beverage industry.


Peers Seeking Allis-Chalmers
LEAD: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation, which filed for bankruptcy protection last June, said it had received a proposal from Peers &amp; Company to purchase substantially all of its operating assets and properties for $385 million in cash.

LEAD: The Organization of American States was too timid yesterday in backing free elections in Haiti without endorsing an inter-American force to guarantee the process.
Only the most compelling circumstances can justify armed infringements of national sovereignty.
Those circumstances prevail in Haiti today:


L.F. Rothschild to Cut Jobs and Part of a Unit
LEAD: L. F. Rothschild Holdings Inc. announced yesterday that it would dissolve a large part of one of its divisions and lay off about 700 workers throughout the company within the next three to six months.


Florida Tax Faces Repeal
LEAD: The Florida Legislature is expected to repeal the state's controversial new tax on advertising and other services at a special session to begin Tuesday.


Correction
LEAD: A picture grouping in Business Day on Nov. 30, with an article about Drexel Burnham Lambert, incorrectly described the status of several insider-trading cases.
Robert M. Wilkis and Ilan K. Reich are serving the rest of their sentences in halfway houses in Manhattan, not in the Federal prison in Danbury, Conn.


James Royal Case, 92, Retired Army Officer
LEAD: James Royal Case, a Masonic historian and retired United States Army colonel who served in both World Wars, died Nov. 26 while on a Thanksgiving visit to his daughter in North Granville, N.Y.
He was 92 years old and lived in Wallingford, Conn.


Signet Bank Offer
LEAD: Signet Bank of Virginia, a subsidiary of the Signet Banking Corporation, a holding company, is offering $100 million of 9 1/4 percent deposit notes due in 1991 at a price of 99.93 to yield 9.27 percent through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Capital Funding.
Rated Aa-3 by Moody's and A by S.&amp;P, the noncallable issue yields about 95-hundredths of a percentage point more than four-year Treasury bills.

Why doesn't someone just take Bud Rinehart out back and kick him in the heart 100 times?

Military Supplier Sued For Equipment Defects
LEAD: The Government is accusing an Ohio military contractor in a civil suit of fraudulently supplying the Army with defective drive shaft assemblies for M48 and M60 tanks, the Justice Department announced today.


Delay Is Seen for Three Mile Island Cleanup
LEAD: Difficulties in extracting debris from the damaged nuclear reactor at the Three Mile Island power plant have led officials to extend the date for completing the cleanup into 1989, a spokesman said today.

LEAD: Baseball's rules committee officially shrunk the strike zone today but said it actually enlarged it.

Kennedy Statue to Be Chosen for Boston Memorial
LEAD: Dave Powers, a former aide to John F. Kennedy and curator of the Kennedy Museum in Boston, looking at models of proposed statues of the former President that went on display yesterday.
A committee will decide on one of the five designs for a memorial outside the Boston Statehouse.
The statue is to be in place by May 1989 for what would have been President Kennedy's 72d birthday.

LEAD: Iranian forces fired a Silkworm missile at Kuwait today, but it exploded harmlessly in waters off the main oil loading terminal, the Defense Ministry said.

LEAD: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday that an inquiry into allegations of scores of false arrests by four transit police officers would be widened to include five other officers cited as having made an unusually high number of sexual-abuse arrests in 1983 and 1984.

Tornadoes Strike in Texas
LEAD: Tornadoes destroyed homes and uprooted trees and power lines in at least two East Texas counties Sunday, but no injuries were reported, the authorities said.
The Anderson County Sheriff's Department here, 110 miles southeast of Dallas, said the damage was farther south in the county and in Polk County, 75 miles to the southeast.

LEAD: Amid growing public concern that San Francisco's neighborhoods are losing their distinctive character to ugly apartment buildings, the Board of Supervisors today imposed a 120-day freeze on demolition of houses throughout the city and on major additions to existing homes.

LEAD: THE most striking visual images in ''Forest of Women,'' a multimedia dream play involving mime, puppetry and ''homemade'' music, are its masks, puppets, and sculptures inspired by the work of Alberto Giacometti.

LEAD:  George P. Shultz: Secretary of State, 66; was in Geneva last month to resolve the final details on the intermediate-range missile treaty; a former Secretary of Labor, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, and Secretary of the Treasury.

Art: Hockney's Design for 'Tristan und Isolde' in Los Angeles
LEAD: ''Tristan and Isolde,'' as designed by David Hockney, had to be set up and engineered in a fast five days on unfamiliar ground and engineered with elaborate new technologies that had never been used in such a context.
Necessarily the result was not quite the polychromatic utopia, responsive to Wagner's every nuance, that had been dreamed of.

Fall in Starts Of Housing
LEAD: The number of housing units started in the third quarter dropped by 13 percent from the period a year earlier, mostly because of changes induced by the new tax law, a construction research firm said yesterday.


Credit Rise Is Slower
LEAD: Consumers took out $3.7 billion more in credit than they paid off in October, substantially less than credit growth in the previous two months, the Government said today.


Woman, 78, Is Struck And Killed by a Bus
LEAD: An elderly woman was struck and killed by a tourist bus last night as she crossed a street in midtown Manhattan, the police said.


Reagan and History
LEAD: President Reagan, always the optimist, is concerned but not fearful about his role in history.
In an appearance at the National Archives last Friday, he cited three critical moments in American history.
His first two dates were 1787, when the Constitution was drafted, and 1861, when Abraham Lincoln came to Washington to face civil war.


Some Missile Crews to Pair Men and Women
LEAD: For the first time, the Air Force plans to assign officer crews made up of a man and a woman to the deep underground stations that control intercontinental nuclear missiles.clear missiles.

LEAD: The E. &amp; J. Gallo Winery responded yesterday to last Thursday's resignation by its ad agency, Hal Riney &amp; Partners.


Sony-Ford Tape Deal
LEAD: The Sony Corporation will supply the Ford Motor Company with digital audio tape players for sale under Ford's name, a Sony spokesman said today.
The playback-only units will be available as an option in 1988 Lincoln Continental cars, he said.


4 Men Seized Trying To Rob Token Booth; One Is Shot by Police
LEAD: Transit police officers arrested a group attacking a subway token booth in Queens with a pickax early yesterday and shot and critically wounded one of the men trying to escape, a transit police spokesman said.


New Clues to Complex Biology of Dyslexia
LEAD: DYSLEXIA, the catch-all term for reading disability, is yielding to the probes of neuroscientists.

LEAD: A New York State appellate court panel ruled last night that television and newspaper cameras would not be allowed to cover the closing arguments at the Howard Beach murder trial in Queens.


A 'Heroic Act' Wins A Mailman a Chiding
LEAD: A mail carrier who jumped into a rolling car and kept it from hitting an elderly woman and a pair of gasoline pumps has been reprimanded by his bosses for participating in an ''unsafe act'' that injured him.


In AIDS, Virus Forces Choice Between Longer Life or Eyesight
LEAD: SOME AIDS patients are being forced to make a wrenching choice: they can take a drug that may save their eyesight, but only if they forgo indefinitely a drug that could prolong their lives.


Children Working on Farms Are Found at Risk for Injury
LEAD: zard financial times on the farm may mean that children must share in the work, but they run the risk of injury from old farm machinery or lack of supervision, a Mayo Clinic researcher says.


Seoul Seeks Suspect's Extradition
LEAD: A South Korean official flew to Bahrain late today to negotiate the extradition of a woman linked to the suspected bombing of a Korean Air jet that disappeared with 115 people on board.

FANCY LINGERIE: THE FRILL OF IT ALL
LEAD: Women are wearing frilly lingerie again.
Underneath the board-room suit and professional uniforms are feminine camisoles, ruffled teddies, lacy bras, stretch-lace bodysuits or silk panties.
Instead of the ubiquitous T-shirt, secretaries and stockbrokers alike are sleeping in satin shorts and embroidered tops or short nightgowns, which they wear with short robes instead of blue jeans when lounging around the house.

Recital: O'Riley, Pianist
LEAD: WHAT Christopher O'Riley does well he does very well, but it was not quite enough to sustain interest through the course of his recital in Alice Tully Hall on Sunday evening.
The pianist began with Bach's B flat Partita, which immediately brought out his strong suit - a gentle, small-scale, unpretentious approach to the music that included judicious use of the pedal and a scrupulous concern for detail.

LEAD: The United States had the lowest voter turnout rate, 53.58 percent of citizens of voting age in Presidential elections, among 28 democratic countries from 1969 to 1986, according to a Congressional study.

This would be unfortunate.
Cuba's influence in Latin America is growing while ours is diminishing.

Illustrated.

Kabul Journal; The Dogs (and the Camels) Are Fighters, Naturally
LEAD: The champ shook out his massive shoulder muscles as the handlers stepped back.
He glared at his opponent, bounding toward him from the far side of the ring, his breathing already heavy.
Barking, he went for the throat.
There was a hush as more than a thousand men, Afghans with hard, lined faces, leaned forward intently to watch the two battling dogs.


Emanuel Saxe, 88, Former College Dean
LEAD: Emanuel Saxe, dean emeritus of the School of Business and Administration of the Bernard M. Baruch College of the City University of New York, died Saturday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.
He was 88 years old.


Atlantic Research Accepts Sequa Bid
LEAD: The Atlantic Research Corporation, a maker of rocket propulsion systems, has accepted a sweetened takeover bid totaling $316 million for the whole company from the Sequa Corporation, a diversified company with interests in aerospace and military electronics based in New York.
The new bid raised the offer to $31 a share, from $30.


6-Block Swim Fails To Help Suspect Flee
LEAD: A 20-year-old narcotics suspect trying to escape the police yesterday was pulled from the East River near 103d Street after he had bolted from the arresting officers at a hospital, the police said.


A SURPRISE MOVE BY DEAVER DEFENSE
LEAD: In a surprise move, the defense rested its case today without calling any witnesses in the perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver.

LEAD:  International A3-17


Comings and Goings
LEAD: The Rangers assigned Gordie Walker, a rookie forward, to their Colorado farm club in the International Hockey League yesterday. . . .
Brent Fullwood, the Green Bay Packers' rookie running back, underwent arthroscopic knee surgery yesterday.


Army Awards Most Medals, Survey Finds
LEAD: If you're joining the military and want some medals on your uniform, the Army is the place for you, according to a survey made public today.


Greater and Greater
LEAD: Even by Wayne Gretzky's standards, it was an extraordinary week.
On Sunday, against Los Angeles, the Edmonton Oilers' star had the fourth five-goal performance of his career, which led to his being named the National Hockey League's player of the week.
Gretzky had nine points in four games during the weekly voting period.

Harold M. Barrett, Executive, 80
LEAD: Harold M. Barrett, retired president of the Uniroyal Tire Company, died Friday at his home in Newtown, Conn.
He was 80 years old.
Mr.
Barrett, a native of New Haven, was also president of the Uniroyal Consumer Products Company in the 1960's.
He was a graduate of Northeastern University.

LEAD: Mayor Koch yesterday named Stanley E. Grayson, Commissioner of the city's Office of Financial Services, to be Finance Commissioner.

Decision Industries
LEAD: A Massachusetts-based investment partnership, CBC Associates, said it plans to make a bid for Decision Industries Inc. that would be ''substantially higher'' than the friendly $8.75-a-share tender offer begun by the Onset Corporation.
The disclosure of the possible new bid, made in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, increases the number of suitors for Decision Industries to three.


Robertson and History
LEAD: In an attack on Mr.
Reagan's policy toward the Soviet Union, Pat Robertson is comparing the President to Neville Chamberlain, the British leader who was the architect of the policy of appeasement toward Nazi Germany.
The Republican Presidential contender made the comparison in a statement to the American Political Campaign Hotline.

Correction Chief Opposes Transfer of Larry Davis to Federal Prison
LEAD: A New York State Supreme Court judge cleared the way yesterday for Larry Davis to be transferred from a city detention center in the Bronx to a Federal prison in Manhattan, but the city's top correction official said he would ''vigorously'' oppose such a move.


Kodak and Fuqua Plan Photofinishing Merger
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company and Fuqua Industries said yesterday that they would combine their photofinishing operations, putting the final touch on acquisition campaigns that had left them as the dominant players in a fragmented industry.

Crashes of Small Planes Kill 9 in Three States
LEAD: Nine people were killed in weekend plane crashes in three states, including a man who died early yesterday from injuries suffered when a small plane in which he was riding slammed into a house shortly after takeoff, the authorities said.

LEAD: Trans World Airlines Inc., led by Carl C. Icahn, said yesterday that it would seek Government permission to buy more than a fourth of the outstanding stock of Texaco Inc.

LEAD: Mikhail Gorbachev has arrived in Washington to sign one arms treaty, to prepare for another and to pursue his search for a prize and achievement even greater.

Irwin Schiff Case Turns To Contractor Payments
LEAD: Before Irwin Schiff was shot to death last August in a Manhattan restaurant, he received at least $10 million in questionable payments from an electrical contractor, according to law-enforcement authorities.
They say they believed Mr.
Schiff was a middleman who transferred payoffs from construction companies to organized-crime figures in the city.


Profit Posted By Navistar
LEAD: The Navistar International Corporation, which makes trucks and engines, today reported a fourth-quarter profit of $54 million, or 18 cents a share, after a loss of $50 million in last year's quarter because of an increase in sales and lower interest costs.

Theater: 'The Gingerbread Lady'
LEAD: NEIL SIMON'S strange 1970 play, ''The Gingerbread Lady,'' seems to strain mightily to fly into pieces, and part of the fascination of seeing it lies in watching director and cast struggle to hold it together.
The challenge of keeping it coherent, in fact, must be one reason it continues to appeal to producers.

LEAD: ''LIKELY SUITE'' was the fitting name of a piece Sally Silvers presented on Sunday at the Middle Collegiate Church.

HOW TO DESTROY THE 2,611 MISSILES
LEAD: The text of the treaty signed today by President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev spells out how hundreds of American and Soviet inspectors will insure that 2,611 American and Soviet missiles are smashed, exploded, crushed, burned or launched to be destroyed.


Upjohn Swine Vaccine
LEAD: A new bioengineered vaccine against pseudo-rabies, a swine disease, won approval for marketing today from the Agriculture Department, the Upjohn Company said.
The Tolvid vaccine, developed by Upjohn, is produced by Diamond Scientific.
Pseudo-rabies is a contagious virus that affects about 6.4 million, or 8 percent, of the nation's 80 million hogs.

LEAD: Concern for the plight of New York City's hungry and homeless has motivated people from all over the country to send donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.


Broadnax Moving On
LEAD: Marcus Broadnax, a sophomore reserve guard at St.
John's, said yesterday that he would leave the university after this semester, which ends Dec. 23. ''I'm through practicing,'' he said. ''Next semester I'll be in another school.
I spoke with Coach Carnesecca and he said that he understood.'' Broadnax, who averaged 38.9 points a game in his senior year at Fort Walton Beach (Fla.) High School, said he had been misled during the recruiting process by Coach Lou Carnesecca and his assistants, Ron Rutledge and Brian Mahoney.

THE FAMILY ALBUM: DIVINING THE RIGHT GIFT
LEAD: YOU can, without a doubt, have too many ties.
You can even have too many books, records, scarves, gloves and all the other perennials of the gift-giving season.
Food, though, is another matter.
You might be given the wrong food: chocolate when you can't bear the sight of it; mustard when you have two dozen jars; Julia Child's opus when you haven't mastered tuna fish sandwiches.

LEAD: The government of British Columbia has announced a $1 billion (Canadian) pulp and paper project with a Japanese forest products company.

Letters; Live and Learn
LEAD: To The Living Section:


Donors Support Bruce
LEAD: Fifty-seven donors who had pledged a total of $408,030 to an Ohio State University fund-raising drive canceled their promises after the school dismissed Earle Bruce as football coach last month, according to Thomas L. Tobin, the university's vice president for communcations and development.
By far, the largest gift was to have come from John McConnell of Worthington Industries in Columbus, who made a corporate pledge of $400,000 to a fund supporting the university's indoor athletic complex.

LEAD: A car-bombing this evening at Manila International Airport added to the worries of Philippine officials as they prepare for a regional summit meeting next week.


Koreans Find New Freedom For Vote Talk
LEAD: One flight up from the dusty side street, the clacking of plastic discs could barely be heard over the chatter of politics in Chun Woo Wang's baduk parlor.

LEAD:  ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.


BABY TO BE BORN AS AN ORGAN DONOR
LEAD: A hospital has agreed to deliver a baby expected to be born with most of its brain missing and to accept other such babies as organ donors, a hospital spokeswoman says.


Winfield-Gibson: Trade Talks End
LEAD: The Yankees, seeking a productive left-handed-hitting outfielder, talked to the Detroit Tigers about a Dave Winfield-for-Kirk Gibson trade, but the Tigers terminated the talks today.


EMERGENCY REPAIR UNIT FAULTED
LEAD: The chairman of the New York State Senate Investigations Committee charged yesterday that the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development had ineptly handled the thousands of emergency repair calls placed to its complaint number each year.


Olympic Coach Backed
LEAD: Joe Vigil, the men's distance-running coach for the United States Olympic team, received a vote of confidence yesterday.
He was recently involved in a controversy over racist statements attributed to him in a magazine article.
The International Competition Committee of The Athletics Congress, the national governing body for track and field, unanimously approved a motion ''reaffirming his status as Olympic coach.


Meldrum &amp; Fewsmith Chosen by Mr. Coffee
LEAD: Mr.
Coffee came under new management in July as a result of a leveraged buyout and then decided to get an ad agency to replace its in-house facility.


Phnom Penh Journal; Meditation Among the Ashes of a Wondrous Past
LEAD: Every afternoon at Wat Sambuor Meas, a once glorious temple a few miles south of here, a silent drama begins.
Nuns deep in prayer and meditation pace ruined porches, passing twisted fences and the rubble of Khmer Buddhist art strewn over grass and garden.


Use of Real Names in Novels Upheld
LEAD: In a ruling that upholds the historical practice of authors using the names of living people in works of fiction, a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan has denied an attempt by Archbishop Paul Marcinkus, a former head of the Vatican bank, to suppress a novel by A. J. Quinnell in which the Roman Catholic Archbishop figures as a character.

LEAD: FOR most families, the good cheer of the holiday season is punctuated by alcohol.

LEAD: Eleven finalists have been named for the 10th Susan Smith Blackburn Prize, an award given annually to an English-speaking playwright who is a woman.

Dick Williams, Theatrical Agent and Editor, 72
LEAD: Dick Williams, a former theatrical press agent and editor, died Sunday in a boating accident in Gulf Breeze, Fla.
He was 72 years old.
Mr.
Williams, who was born in Farmingdale, L.I., served in the Army during World War II and became the editor of Theater Arts magazine in the late 1940's.
He spent more than 20 years with Bill Doll Associates, a Broadway public-relations concern, before opening a merchandising firm in Stamford,

She was 90 years old.

CHRISTMAS SHOPPING IS PICKING UP, STORES SAY
LEAD: After a sluggish start, sales for the Christmas shopping season's first 10 days picked up in many stores, according to telephone interviews with nationwide and local retailers that cater to consumers with a broad spectrum of incomes.


JUDGE PUTS LIMIT ON DEAVER DEFENSE
LEAD: Michael K. Deaver's defense lawyers were told today that they could not argue before the jury that the former Presidential aide's memory was impaired by alcoholism when he was questioned about his lobbying business.


4TH GRADERS WATCH AND LEARN AT TRIAL
LEAD: Thirty-seven fourth graders made the 90-minute trip via two subway lines from Public School 304 in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn to State Supreme Court in Kew Gardens, Queens, for the Howard Beach trial.


What Is the Reality?
LEAD: Sverdlovsk, a Soviet industrial center in the Urals, has long been closed to foreigners.
The U-2 spy plane piloted by Francis Gary Powers was shot down near Sverdlovsk in 1960: the incident that wrecked that year's summit meeting between President Eisenhower and Nikita Khrushchev.


Accountant Is Chosen As President of Pennzoil
LEAD: Randal B. McDonald, a top executive of Arthur Andersen &amp; Company, the accounting firm, yesterday was named president and chief operating officer of the Pennzoil Company, the first executive post he has held in an energy company.

LEAD: Mike Caltibiano, an assistant to the warden of the Federal penitentiary, showing an assortment of weapons found after Cuban inmates surrendered.

Night of Hatred by Whites Is Depicted at Racial Trial
LEAD: The chief prosecutor in the Howard Beach murder case declared last night that a gang of white teen-agers, yelling racial epithets in a ''night of fists, fear, terror and hatred,'' chased a black man into a ''chasm of death'' during an attack on him and two other black men in Howard Beach, Queens.


Seabrook Utility Told To Pay by Jersey Bank
LEAD: A New Jersey bank demanded yesterday that the Public Service Company of New Hampshire immediately repay a $425 million debenture issue that is due in 2004, because the utility had defaulted on a $37 million interest payment that was due Oct. 15.
The effect on the company, which is already on the brink of bankruptcy, is not clear.

The Hotel Poll
LEAD: The Hotel Washington, only a block from the White House, is naturally concerned about who will be the new occupant in 1989.
So it began exploring the Presidential preferences of its guests last February, distributing a ballot listing 11 possible Republican candidates, 19 Democrats and a space for write-ins.


The Summit; From Chinese, Tempered Praise
LEAD: China reacted with tempered praise today to the signing of a Soviet-American treaty to eliminate intermediate-range nuclear missiles.


Pennsylvanian's Case Seen As Big Test for Ethics Unit
LEAD: Nearly 10 years have passed since Congress enacted the Ethics in Government Act, an outgrowth of the Watergate scandal that, among other things, requires members of Congress to disclose their personal finances and income.


Motive Is Discounted at Krishna Arson Trial
LEAD: The nation's biggest Hare Krishna community grossed $3.9 million in 1983 and it would have been absurd for its leader to burn a building that year to collect $40,000 in insurance, a defense lawyer said Tuesday at the start of the leader's trial here on arson charges.


Moscow Grain Estimate
LEAD: A Soviet official said today that his country stood by its earlier estimate that 210 million metric tons of grain was produced in 1987.
Valeriy Biryukov, head of the raw materials department of the Soviet trade delegation in London, said, ''Though we had bad weather, it was the same size as last year's crop.


Atelier International Has New Owner
LEAD: Atelier International, a 20-year-old company in Long Island City, Queens, known for its modern furniture and lighting designs, has been sold to Steelcase, an office-furniture company in Grand Rapids, Mich., it was announced Tuesday.


Israeli Troops Kill Arab in Gaza
LEAD: Israeli troops shot and killed a Palestinian and wounded 16 others today after teen-agers threw gasoline bombs at an army patrol car in the occupied Gaza Strip, an army spokesman said.


Advertising; Transition For Levine And Schmidt
LEAD: HAROLD LEVINE and Robert H. Schmidt, the disparate pair that have been running Levine, Huntley, Schmidt &amp; Beaver since it began with $1.5 million in billings in 1972, have now completed a sort-of second-generation management transition.


Air-India to Add Planes
LEAD: Air-India will spend 15 billion rupees, or about $1.15 billion, in the next three years to buy new planes and expand its routes, the state-run carrier's managing director, Rajan Jetley, said today.
At a news conference, he said two Boeing 747's and two Airbus 310's would be added by early 1988.

Home Improvement
LEAD: DRIPPING or leaking faucets are among the most exasperating household annoyances.
Not only is the dripping sound a nuisance, but the amount of water that flows uselessly (and expensively) down the drain can be appalling.
In porcelain sinks, basins and bathtubs, constant contact with water also causes stains.

LEAD: ABOARD U.S.S.
FEARLESS, in the Persian Gulf, Dec. 9 - United States Navy vessels searching for mines in the Persian Gulf will soon be equipped with underwater robots that will vastly enhance their ability to find mines, officials on one of the wooden-hulled minesweepers said today.

Metro Matters; Hailing a Taxi Is Even Harder If You're Black
LEAD: ''Taxi!'' the middle-aged black woman on Central Park West shouted into the night. ''Taxi!'' she repeated three times.
Finally, one stopped.
But just as the woman opened the door, the cabby spotted another fare down the block and sped off . . . to pick up a man dressed like a gorilla.


Libel Finding Is Issued
LEAD: A New York State judge has ruled that the writer Shana Alexander and her publisher, Doubleday &amp; Company, libeled a Manhattan psychologist in Ms.
Alexander's book ''Nutcracker.''


Soviet Airline to Sell Seats on Pan Am Trips
LEAD: A Soviet-American agreement was signed today that will permit Aeroflot, the Soviet airline, to sell some seats on Pan American World Airways jumbo jets that will make nonstop flights between New York and Moscow.


Baseball Expansion Won't Come Soon
LEAD: The expansion of the big leagues was turned over to a joint committee of the American and National Leagues today.
Commissioner Peter Ueberroth made it clear, however, that nothing concrete could be done until baseball had cleared two ''hurdles'' in the next two years: negotiations for new contracts with the players' union and the television networks.


Bond Prices Post Slight Advance
LEAD: Bond prices rose modestly in light trading yesterday, as investors and traders continued to wait on the sidelines until there are enough economic data to clarify the welter of year-end economic forecasts now being published.


Tougher Rules Sought On Disposal of PCB's
LEAD: House members asserted today that the Reagan Administration had failed to keep a three-year-old pledge to tighten control over the handling and disposing of polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's.

Yankees Eyeing Santana
LEAD: With Wayne Tolleson possibly needing shoulder surgery, the Yankees have resumed their search for a shortstop and one of the shortstops they have asked about is Rafael Santana of the Mets.


Experts Err On Carracci
LEAD: A painting valued by auctioneers at Sotheby's at just $720 has sold for more than 2,000 times that amount at the rival Phillips auction house here.


The Dance: Maria Benitez Spanish Company
LEAD: THE Maria Benitez Spanish Dance Company presented a compelling program on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue.
But there was one moment that stood out.
It came with a farruca performed by Eduardo Montero.
Choreographed by Jose Luis Ayuste to traditional music, the solo gave Mr.
Montero, a guest artist with the company, a chance to let loose with steely, lacy fusillades of foot beats of such exquisitely precise timing and dynamic range that one watched breathlessly.


Ratings of Salomon's Debt Reduced a Notch by S.&amp;P.
LEAD: The short-term and long-term debt ratings of Salomon Brothers Inc. were reduced a notch yesterday by the Standard &amp; Poor's Corporation.


Devils Edge Kings
LEAD: Although they are last in the National Hockey League point standings, the Los Angeles Kings have a high-powered offense.
But the Devils thwarted that offense tonight for a 2-1 victory at Byrne Meadowlands Arena that spoiled Robbie Ftorek's coaching debut.


Boy Who Nearly Drowned Continues to Improve
LEAD: Roberta Young, a nurse in Fargo, N.D., examining Alvaro Garza Jr.
Tuesday after he was taken off a respirator.
The 11-year-old boy was considered clinically dead Friday after being under water for about 45 minutes in an ice-covered river.
When the respirator was removed, he delighted the staff by asking for a hamburger, fries and a Coke.


LEADERS IN ALBANY COOL TO KOCH BID ON SCHOOL BOARD
LEAD: Despite strong public pressure from Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch to give the Mayor more control over the New York City school system, all the leading state legislators whose support is essential for the plan said yesterday that they opposed it.

LEAD: A United States polar exploration airplane crashed and burned in Antarctica yesterday, killing two Navy crew members and injuring nine others.

Trust But Verify
LEAD: The Euromissile treaty signed Tuesday is hailed as the first to eliminate an entire class of nuclear weapons.
Perhaps of greater significance, the treaty includes verification provisions of unprecedented sweep and detail.
Properly managed, these could soften the core of mistrust that has so dominated arms control and U.S.-Soviet relations.


Wohl Dismissed as Coach of Nets
LEAD: The Nets, struggling with injuries, a 2-13 record and a streak in which they have lost nine straight games by an average of 18.7 points, dismissed Dave Wohl as their coach today.
Bob MacKinnon, the assistant general manager, was named interim coach.


Maryland's Yields Range Up to 6.90%
LEAD: Maryland is offering $80 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns &amp; Company.
It won the issue in competitive bidding.


Stage: Wilson's 'Piano Lesson'
LEAD: August Wilson has vowed to write one play about each decade of black American life in this century.
But this writer, whose fecund career is creating its own patch of history in the American theater of the 1980's, knows history is not a serial, to be ladled out event by event according to the artificial dictates of a textbook time line.


Thompson Is Chosen
LEAD: J. Walter Thompson's Los Angeles office has been tapped by the Standard Brands Paint Company, a West Coast chain of home decorating stores with 150 outlets concentrated in 16 cities.
According to trade sources, the billings will be more than $5 million.
The previous agency was Admarketing Inc., Los Angeles.


For Pet Adoptions, an Unusual Holiday Setting
LEAD: Elaborate Christmas windows are a tradition at the specialty store Gump's, but this year the windows are filled with dogs and cats.


Nobel Laureate's Work Is Published in Soviet
LEAD: Six poems by Joseph Brodsky, the 1987 recipient of the Nobel Prize in Literature, who was once sent to a Soviet labor camp because of his writing, appeared in the December issue of the Soviet monthly Novy Mir.

Swarms of Tiny Comets May Travel Solar System
LEAD: A host of miniature comets so small that they have eluded detection are probably swarming through the inner solar system and their bombardment over several billion years could account for many of the craters on the Moon, Earth, Mercury and Mars, space scientists reported yesterday.


Marketing of Andy Warhol
LEAD: The estate of Andy Warhol has signed an agreement with the marketing company responsible for the phenomenal success of Cabbage Patch Kids dolls, giving the company exclusive rights to use the artist's name and works in products possibly ranging from sweaters and scarves to watches, calendars, datebooks and gift wrapping paper, a spokesman for the estate said yesterday.


Cleveland St. Penalized
LEAD: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has banned Cleveland State's basketball team from postseason play for two years because of violations in the 1983-84 season.
The violations included an attempt to recruit Manute Bol, the 7-foot-6-inch center from the Sudan, who now plays for the Washington Bullets.


Van Brunt to Handle Caramba Restaurants
LEAD: Caramba, a seven-year-old New York restaurant chain hoping to go national, has retained its first ad agency, Van Brunt &amp; Company.


Abrams Testifies at Iran-Contra Grand Jury
LEAD: Assistant Secretary of State Elliott Abrams testified today before a Federal grand jury investigating the Iran-contra affair, officials said.


Japanese Jet Warns Soviet Plane
LEAD: A jet fighter fired warning shots at a Soviet bomber today after the plane violated Japanese airspace, the Defense Agency said.
It was the first time in at least 33 years that a Japanese plane had fired on a Soviet aircraft.


Nixon Saves Widow From Being Evicted

LEAD: Bill Goodstein, the agent for Dave Righetti, said tonight that the relief pitcher had received an offer from a Japanese team that would make him the ''highest-paid athlete in team sports history.'' Hers
LEAD: IN these latter days the shop talk of university professors tends to anecdotes about our laughable undergraduates.
My contribution includes the story of a student from an Eastern liberal arts college whom, for cause, I advised against taking my course in creative writing.
The student complained that there was nothing else that satisfied her time slot and humanities requirement except a course in 17th-century poetry, and how, she asked, did she know she was going to like it?

LEAD: Q. The rainwater from the gutters around my house drains into a dry well, but I don't know exactly where this dry well is.

I believe the dry well is clogged and not draining properly.

Opera: Berg's 'Lulu' By the Lyric in Chicago
LEAD: In composing ''Lulu,'' Alban Berg made a fascinating attempt to reconcile chaos and order under one operatic roof, setting a harrowing tale of moral anarchy to a 12-tone score that is rigorously organized down to the smallest staging detail.
Most productions of the work, some of them highly acclaimed, have ignored or played down Berg's intricately interlocking scheme of music and stage action.

Why Nixon Shouldn't Pass Up 'Nixon in China'
LEAD: SITTING the other night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's production of ''Nixon in China,'' I found myself hoping that Richard M. Nixon would overcome whatever reservations he may have and go to see it.
Before one had seen the opera, one could understand his doubts.
He had every reason to fear that he would be made to look foolish, or that his attendance might become a silly celebrity event, full of reporters and flashbulbs and television cameras.

Currents; Homage To an Early Modernist, Adolf Loos
LEAD: ''ORNAMENT is crime,'' said Adolf Loos, the Austrian pioneer of modern architecture who was born in 1870 and died in 1933.
His early 20th-century houses were stark white stucco cubes.
Some of his designs will be shown in the form of models, photographs, furniture and drawings in an exhibition at Cooper Union beginning next Wednesday and running through Jan.


Gun Is Found at Site of Jetliner Crash
LEAD: Investigators said today that they had found a gun in the wreckage of a jetliner that crashed in central California on Monday and that a cockpit voice recording indicated someone had barged into the cockpit just before the crash.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Sports Pages yesterday about the Jets' loss to the Miami Dolphins incorrectly described the injury to Dwight Stephenson, the Dolphins' center.
He suffered damage to ligaments in his left knee when he was blocked by Marty Lyons of the Jets.

A Reverse on Winter Woes
LEAD: Researchers studying people who become depressed in winter and manic in summer have discovered that the syndrome has a mirror image: some people become depressed every summer and excitable in winter.
Those with the newly identified seasonal syndrome report that their depression typically starts in the March-June period and ends in August or


Bus Stops Are Spread Out
LEAD: Bus stops along 20 blocks of lower Madison Avenue have been spread out in an effort to ease congestion and speed bus service, the New York City Transportation Department announced yesterday.
The new pattern, from 23d Street to 42d Street, affects five local routes and 14 express routes.
Beginning Tuesday, stops for local buses were set every three blocks instead of every two and express bus intervals increased from five blocks to seven, the department said.


Paramount Names New Head of Production
LEAD: Paramount Pictures yesterday named Gary Lucchesi as head of its motion picture production division.


Speaking for, and Speaking to, the Russians
LEAD: WHO speaks for the Soviet Union?
On television, Mikhail S. Gorbachev gets help.
The other night, John Chancellor wondered about the Soviet leader's ''blow dried, horn rimmed and well dressed'' surrogates.
The NBC commentator was not alarmed, but he did seem skeptical.
The surrogates have been on television all week.


Worry Grows That Korean Army Might Intervene in the Elections
LEAD: Serious concern has been raised here that South Korea's military might step in to cancel next week's presidential election or to nullify its results if the opposition wins.

Audio and Video Gifts for the Holidays
LEAD: DEVICES to create diversions and spectacles through sight and sound have always been among the most cherished gifts of the season.
Once it was the music box and the magic lantern.
Today it's audio and video equipment.
Here are suggestions for holiday giving, ranging from a complete desk-top video system to a simple Walkman for children.


Transactions
LEAD:  BASEBALL


Restructuring Plan At Cleveland-Cliffs
LEAD: Cleveland-Cliffs Inc., an iron ore mining company under siege from dissident shareholders, said it had proposed a recapitalization and restructuring plan.
The company also said it was seeking a buyer.


HAITI SETS A DATE FOR NEW ELECTION
LEAD: Eleven days after the violent disruption of Haiti's first effort at a presidential election in 30 years, the army-dominated provisional Government announced tonight that it was planning another attempt at elections on Jan. 17.


Colorado Bank Bailout Plan
LEAD: Citing concerns about Colorado's image, Gov.
Roy Romer today proposed a $5 million bailout for thousands of depositors in 15 industrial banks where deposits are frozen.


TO OUR READERS
LEAD: Because of Nasdaq computer problems, the high and low prices for some O-T-C stocks, as well as some volume figures, may be incorrect.


Mets and Dodgers Go Back and Forth
LEAD: The Mets' prize project in the trading market collapsed today when the Los Angeles Dodgers refused to send Bob Welch to New York for Mookie Wilson, Jesse Orosco and Rafael Santana.


Music: Temirkanov and Philadelphians
LEAD: YURI TEMIRKANOV is a noted conductor in the Soviet Union, and the first to appear with the New York Philharmonic after the melting of the long cultural freeze between his country and the United States.
So it was symbolically fitting for him to reappear here during a summit meeting, as he did Tuesday night with the Philadelphia Orchestra in Carnegie


New Data Reduce Russian Missile Force
LEAD: The Soviet Union has fewer operational medium-range missiles than previous American Government estimates have stated, according to a confidential annex to the new missile treaty.


President Is Said to Threaten a Veto of Deficit Bill
LEAD: Senate Republicans said today that President Reagan would veto deficit-reducing legislation unless the Democrats removed provisions unrelated to cutting the deficit.


Suicide Exposes British Church Rift
LEAD: What the newspapers called ''The Crockford's Mystery'' did not last long.
But in the space of a few days, it forced into public view the angry divisions within the Church of England over theology and clerical promotions.


Panel Backs McLaughlin
LEAD: The Senate Labor Committee today unanimously approved the nomination of Ann Dore McLaughlin to be Secretary of Labor.
The panel voted to send the nomination to the Senate floor with no debate.


Wall Street Reviews 'Wall Street'
LEAD: For many investment banking luminaries at a private screening of ''Wall Street'' on Monday night, watching the new film was like watching home movies.


Energy Prices End Higher In a Wild Trading Session
LEAD: Prices of energy futures rose in skittish trading yesterday as traders shrugged off a day of bickering by OPEC ministers seemingly unwilling to agree on production cuts.


New Role for Fleming
LEAD: Peter Fleming, the longtime doubles partner of John McEnroe, will soon be taking on a new assignment.
Early next year, he will become McEnroe's manager in an attempt to help the volatile left-hander regain the No. 1 position in international men's singles rankings.
Speaking in London yesterday at the Masters Doubles championships, Fleming said his aim was to remove ''negative aspects'' of McEnroe's game, which should enable him to challenge Ivan Lendl for the top ranking.

LEAD: To the Editor:


A.T.&amp;T. Acts to End Delay on Contract Rift
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company will try to convince a Federal judge today to allow its protest to proceed against the General Services Administration and the manner in which it awarded $55 million in telecommunications contracts.


Stage: ''Mlle. Colombe,'' Musical of Anouilh Play
LEAD: HAROLD CLURMAN, who directed Jean Anouilh's ''Mlle.
Colombe'' in its original 1954 Broadway production, regarded the play as ''a tragic harlequinade,'' in which the world of the theater is filled with dreams and possibilities and real life is stultifying.
The first is represented by the title character, a repressed young woman who blossoms as an actress on stage, the second by her rigid husband, Julien.

LEAD: Aspects of Rina Dokshinsky's New York recital debut, presented by Young Concert Artists at the 92nd Street Y on Tuesday evening, seemed oddly contradictory. her program was impressively ambitious, though also curious, for after having staked her claim as high-minded by programming Back's C. minor sonata (Op.


Chrysler Plans TC by Maserati
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation plans to introduce a two-seat luxury sports car in March that will sell for about $35,000, despite the disappointing sales of Cadillac's Allante sports car this year.


Currents; Ever More Antiques at the Armory
LEAD: THE drafty main room of the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue has become one of the hottest spots for antiques shows. ''It's considered the prime place in town because of its location,'' said Sanford Smith, who organizes two of the eight shows held there each year.


THE TOP GUN WEARS SHOULDER PADS
LEAD: THE finest untrumpeted college football player in the nation did not seem to know how to react to this situation.
In the tradition of the United States Air Force, Chad Hennings understands that a considerable amount of time and energy must be spent before a senior at the Air Force Academy can achieve the status of Top Gun.


Influenza Season Opens With Scattered Cases
LEAD: Heralding another flu season, the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta have begun to document isolated discoveries of influenza viruses throughout the country.

LEAD: Next week, the South Korean Government of Chun Doo Hwan faces the great test of its democratic bona fides: the first direct presidential election in more than 15 years.

LEAD: To the Editor:


DONOR, AGE 8, GIVES TWICE TO NEEDIEST
LEAD: Meg D. Holzer, 8 years old, of Rye, N.Y., has sent her contributions to the 76th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
They were her sketch of a girl making a donation and a check for $3.


Prosecutor in Park Killing to Link Suspect to Possible Marijuana Use
LEAD: The prosecutor in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. intends to argue that Mr.
Chambers may have been under the influence of marijuana at the time of Jennifer Levin's death in Central Park, according to court documents obtained yesterday.


IRAN AND ARABS CLASH IN OPEC ON OIL POLICY
LEAD: Iran threatened today to double its oil output and start an oil price war as the seven-year war in the Persian Gulf moved to center stage at the meeting here of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.


Sitting in the Park, Even on Wednesday
LEAD: A couple enjoying sunny skies and a high temperatures that reached 60 degrees as they staked out a bench in Central Park.
Morning clouds are expected to give way today to sunny skies in the afternoon. (NYT/Keith Meyers)


Dole's Friends See Aversion to Bush
LEAD: The contest between Vice President Bush and Senator Bob Dole involves not only a rivalry for the White House but also an undercurrent of personal antipathy on the part of Mr.
Dole, according to Republican Party consultants who are longtime friends of Mr.
Dole.


The Summit; Questions Rise in Soviet On Dissent and the Press
LEAD: While Mikhail S. Gorbachev pitches glasnost to America, the battle over how to practice his policy of ''openness'' has flared up anew at home.


San Francisco Elects Ex-Social Worker
LEAD: A contentious era has ended and a new one has begun in San Francisco.
After nearly a decade in which the city stressed the effort to build up its commercial downtown, its neighborhoods have risen in revolt.

In the effort, Mr.

Political Lot of Reagan And Gorbachev Linked
LEAD: Two days of summit talks have demonstrated how closely President Reagan has tied his political fortunes to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the leader of the nation that Mr.
Reagan has spent his entire career denouncing, according to political experts inside and outside the White House.


Icahn Shifts Texaco Stock
LEAD: Trans World Airlines Inc. said yesterday that it was selling half its holdings in Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company to ACF Industries at a $30 million profit.
The move represents a shuffling of assets between two companies controlled by T.W.A.'s chairman, Carl C. Icahn.


New Luster for a Once-Ignored Architect
LEAD: EILEEN GRAY, the first woman to achieve recognition as an architect, was born surrounded by Victorian splendor in County Wexford, Ireland, but made her fame as a modern designer and architect in Paris.


A Dual Financing By Texas Eastern
LEAD: The Texas Eastern Corporation is offering $200 million of senior unsecured notes with maturities of 5 years and 10 years through underwriters led by Dillon, Read &amp; Company.

LEAD: Mayor Koch erred badly in losing control of ethnic politics to the extent that he had to dismiss Richard Beattie from New York City's Board of Education.
Mr.
Koch had promised to appoint a Hispanic and could not conveniently remove anyone else.
Now he has made up some of the loss with the appointment of a superb replacement, Amalia


I.B.M. Renaming Unit
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation is renaming the Rolm Corporation, the maker of telephone switching systems it acquired in 1984.
At year-end it will become the Rolm Systems division.


L.I. Employers Join to Build New Housing
LEAD: More than two dozen Long Island employers today announced a partnership to build middle-income housing in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, saying the Island's economic growth was threatened by a lack of affordable housing.


Redmen Top Rams In 2 Overtimes, 76-71
LEAD: Fordham, at a great height and weight disadvantage, nearly beat St.
John's last night for the first time in 17 years.
But the Rams fell short in double overtime, 76-71, at their Rose Hill gymnasium in the Bronx.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: Dick Crum, who resigned as the football coach at North Carolina on Nov. 30, after compiling a 72-41-3 record in 10 years, said yesterday that he wanted to remain in coaching and would not rule out reports that he could be considered for the job at Southern Methodist University. . . .
Davey Lopes, who spent more than 15 years in the major leagues, was named a coach for the Texas Rangers.


Arts Academy Elects Dickey and Styron
LEAD: The poet James Dickey, the novelist William Styron and the late Joseph Campbell, an anthropologist who wrote about myth and religion, have been elected to the American Academy of Arts and Letters, Stanley Kunitz, the academy secretary, has announced.


U.S. Policy Is Said to Leave Dollar Value to the Markets
LEAD: Despite last week's cuts in European interest rates and other actions abroad to stabilize currencies, the Reagan Administration is sticking to its new policy of leaving the value of the dollar largely to the judgment of the financial markets, according to Administration officials and Wall Street currency experts.


SAC Journal; On Watch for Nuclear Armageddon
LEAD: If ever there is a time for watch standers in the Strategic Air Command's underground center to relax here, it is probably a week when the Soviet leader is in this country.

LEAD: John Anzalone, one of three inmates who escaped from a hospital ward on Rikers Island early last Saturday, was recaptured last night at a Brooklyn apartment without incident, the police said.

LEAD: Funeral procession for John Toomey, a 38-year-old firefighter, at Sackett and Hoyt Streets in Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn after Mass yesterday at St.
Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.
Mr.
Toomey died last Sunday after suffering a heart attack while battling a blaze on the roof of a building in Brooklyn.

LEAD: Jack Schwartz Shoes has assigned the creation of advertising for its British Knights athletic shoe division to Tim Love Advertising.
The New York-based Schwartz nationally distributes its athletic line to Foot Locker and Lady Foot Locker retail stores.

Pan Am And Braniff Set Deal
LEAD: The Pan Am Corporation announced last night that it had reached a tentative deal with Braniff Inc. that could result in the merger of Pan American World Airways and Braniff if certain conditions are met.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Tennis Edberg and Jarryd Defeated: Stefan Edberg and Anders Jarryd of Sweden, the defending champions, squandered two match points and a 5-3 lead in the final set yesterday and went on to lose to Czechoslovakia's Miloslav Mecir and Tomas Smid in the $200,000 Masters Doubles championship in London.


Leader of Uprising Captured in Manila
LEAD: The colonel who led an August coup attempt was captured today in a raid on a Manila townhouse and will face ''due process of law,'' the military said.


Chrysler Recalls 14,000 Cars
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation said Tuesday that it was recalling 14,000 1988 Chrysler Fifth Avenue, Plymouth Gran Fury and Dodge Diplomat models because of a wiring defect that could cause an engine fire.
A fire occurred in a car at the assembly plant, but no fires have been reported by motorists, the company said.

The leaders of the two most powerful nations join for a historic meeting.

LEAD: The dollar slipped lower yesterday in thin trading as dealers in the foreign exchange markets awaited the trade deficit figures scheduled for release today.

LEAD: Several people who lost hundreds of dollars each in telemarketing scams have told Congress that the public needs more protection against disreputable companies.

The Best Linebacker
LEAD: After disproving scouting reports that said he was too small and too slow to become a competent college football player, Paul McGowan of Florida State University capped his collegiate career yesterday by winning the 1987 Butkus Award as the nation's best collegiate linebacker.
McGowan, who totaled four first-place votes and 25 points from a panel of 11 sportswriters and broadcasters, won by a point over Chris Spielman of Ohio State, who had five first-place votes.


Frederic V. Grunfeld Dies at 58; Author Wrote a Rodin Biography
LEAD: Frederic V. Grunfeld, an author and journalist whose biography of the French sculptor Auguste Rodin was published last month, died of a heart attack Wednesday in Barcelona, Spain.
He was 58 years old and lived near Deya, Majorca.


Mayor Reportedly Set to Appoint New Investigation Commissioner
LEAD: Mayor Koch has chosen the city's Criminal Justice Coordinator, Kevin Frawley, to be Commissioner of Investigation, the chief mayoral watchdog over corruption and other abuses by city employees, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.


Corrections
LEAD: An article from San Francisco on Nov. 19, about a California Poll citing the preferences of state Democrats for the party's Presidential nomination, included individual percentages that totaled more than 100.
The article omitted a sentence stating that respondents to the poll were allowed to choose more than one candidate.


Western Union
LEAD: The Western Union Corporation closed the polls on a thrice-delayed shareholder vote on a vital part of the telecommunications concern's restructuring plan.
A shareholder meeting for balloting also was adjourned for the corporation's chief subsidiary, the Western Union Telegraph Company.
A spokesman said the shareholder meeting would be reconvened on Monday to announce the results of the balloting.


Estate of Warhol Sues Hospital and Doctors
LEAD: The estate of Andy Warhol filed a malpractice and wrongful death suit yesterday seeking an unspecified amount of money from New York Hospital and 11 doctors and nurses.


Pan Am Board Differs on Bid
LEAD: The board of directors of the Pan Am Corporation has major reservations about some of the terms proposed by Jay A. Pritzker for the takeover of Pan American World Airways that will have to be resolved before he can gain control, a source close to the board said yesterday.

LEAD: Five Caribbean Prime Ministers held talks today with the head of Haiti's army-dominated provisional Government, Lieut.
Gen.
Henri Namphy, over the cancellation of the Nov. 29 election and his plans to hold a new vote.

LEAD: Senator Juan Ponce Enrile said today that his law firm would defend Col.
Gregorio Honasan, who will be court-martialed on charges of leading the fierce revolt in August.

LEAD: LaMarr Hoyt, the American League Cy Young Award winner in 1983 when he pitched for the Chicago White Sox, yesterday denied an allegation in United States District Court in San Diego that he had violated terms of Federal probation by testing positive for cocaine use.

James Dobson, Actor, 67
LEAD: James Dobson, who appeared with President Reagan in ''Hellcats of the Navy,'' died of a heart attack on Sunday.
He was 67 years old.


Royals Get Bannister
LEAD: The Kansas City Royals, and not the Yankees, got Floyd Bannister tonight when the Chicago White Sox sent Bannister to the Royals for four young pitchers.
The trade ended a months-long scramble for the left-handed pitcher.


Trade Data Send Dow Down 47.08
LEAD: Ending Wall Street's three-day rally, stock prices fell sharply late yesterday after a seesaw session that reflected unexpectedly bad news on the trade front.


There's No Room In Neighborhood For Mentally Ill

LEAD: Armour Pharmaceutical is recalling 208 lots of a blood clotting agent distributed for hemophilia patients because of the possibility it could contain the AIDS virus, the Food and Drug Administration said today.

LEAD: The dollar plummeted yesterday to its lowest levels since the 1940's amid heavy trading, as dealers sold the currency in the wake of the unexpectedly bad report on the nation's trade deficit in October.

LEAD: Dave Righetti can defect to Japanese baseball for at least $8 million over two years, but the mammoth offer has left him ''confused'' and has prompted George Steinbrenner to say that the development could seriously damage United States-Japanese baseballl relations.


Fire Damages Interior of the Biltmore Theater
LEAD: The interior of the Biltmore Theater in Manhattan, which recently received landmark designation, was damaged by fire early yesterday in a blaze that officials say was deliberately set.


Eurotunnel Shares Drop
LEAD: Eurotunnel shares sank 29 percent today, the first day they were traded, underscoring the risky nature of investing in the Anglo-French consortium that is building a rail tunnel under the English Channel.

American Brands To Sell Pinkerton's
LEAD: American Brands Inc. said it had agreed to sell its Pinkerton's Inc. security services unit to CPP Security Service Inc. of Van Nuys, Calif.
Terms were not disclosed.
Pinkerton's is the nation's oldest provider of security services.
American Brands, based in Old Greenwich, Conn., had announced in October that it planned to divest the company as part of its strategy of concentrating on its core businesses: tobacco, distilled spirits, financial services and office products.

Drop in New Housing
LEAD: The Commerce Department said today that completions of new homes fell 2.4 percent in October to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1,536,000 from 1,574,000 in September.


Japan Given Apology by Soviet
LEAD: The Soviet Union apologized today for the intrusion of a Soviet TU-16 Badger bomber into Japanese airspace over the island of Okinawa, saying the incident was unpremeditated and was caused by poor weather.

LEAD: The Senate early this morning approved a $26 billion deficit-reducing package, including $9 billion in tax increases, that is needed to carry out a major part of the budget compromise reached between Congress and the White House last month.

LEAD: Senator Paul Simon, one of the Democratic Presidential candidates, on Wednesday named Charles T. Manatt, former Democratic national chairman, as his national campaign chairman.


Fire Hits Rangoon Suburb
LEAD: A wind-swept fire raced through a suburb of Rangoon, killing a five-year-old boy and leaving 2,500 people homeless, it was reported today.
A primary school was among the 180 buildings and shanties destroyed in the two-hour blaze Wednesday, which started in a kitchen.


OPERA: CHICAGO'S LYRIC IN 'MARRIAGE OF FIGARO'
LEAD: Metropolitan Opera audiences who know Peter Hall only as the director of two famously lackluster productions, ''Macbeth'' and ''Carmen,'' must have a seriously distorted view of his talents.
As often happens, the right man was hired for the wrong jobs.
The prolific Englishman's work is more justly represented by his stagings of Mozart operas, particularly for the Glyndebourne Festival, of which he has been artistic director since 1984.

About Historians Who Can't Write
LEAD: In 17th century France, there lived an unusual woman, Ninon de Lenclos.
She was the most famous of courtesans, lover, friend, adviser and companion of the great and near-great: monarchs, statesmen, authors, philosophers, generals.
Her lawyer, Francois Arouet, was a former peasant who served her with diligence, and she was quite taken with the lawyer's precocious 10-year-old son.
