Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 410 money market mutual funds increased $522.6 million, to $262.41 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 111 institutional funds decreased $361.1 million, to $73.20 billion.
Assets of the 206 general-purpose funds increased $294 million, to $79.89 billion.

BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1987
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  The U.S. trade deficit jumped to a record $17.6 billion in October as Christmas goods and other imports rose more than five times as much as exports.
The result was far worse than analysts had expected and caused turmoil in the financial markets.
The dollar fell to record lows against the yen and the mark, bond prices rose steeply and stocks fell.

Griffin dead in the parking lot of a police station, victim of a police bullet in the forehead.
Much less could he have known that this would become a landmark in the troubled history of one of Quebec's forgotten minorities.


New York Is Losing Just the Shops That Make a Neighborhood
LEAD: To the Editor:


IT PAYS TO DEFER INCOME UNTIL JAN. 1
LEAD: With income tax rates dropping on Jan. 1, taxpayers can benefit by finding ways to defer income until next year.


Art: 'Fictions,' Views of the Future and the Past
LEAD: ''FICTIONS,'' the work of a critic, Douglas Blau, is one of the better curatorial performances of the season.
A double-gallery exhibition of more than 40 paintings, drawings and photographs, at both the Curt Marcus Gallery and Kent Fine Art, ''Fictions'' reaches across the past three centuries to compare and contrast a variety of equally romantic realisms and world views.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Democratic Hopefuls Raise Issue of Tax Climb
LEAD: The Democratic Presidential candidates raised the possibility of higher taxes to reduce the nation's budget deficit last night in their first joint appearance before a New York audience.

LEAD: Henry Threadgill's ''Run Silent, Run Deep, Run Loud, Run High'' - a work for 28 musicians and singers -is to receive its world premiere tonight and tomorrow at 8 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, in the Fort Greene section (718) 636-4100). Tickets are $15 to $20.

LEAD: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar told the Security Council today that its authority was being undermined by Iran's refusal to accept its cease-fire call and indicated he felt it was time to impose an arms embargo.

LEAD: Giving to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has become a tradition closely linked to the holiday season, according to many donors.

LEAD: The man who swallowed poison and died before he could be questioned about the disappearance of a South Korean airliner was probably a former North Korean diplomat, Japanese officials said today.

Single Gene Deficiency Linked to Lung Cancer
LEAD: Scientists have reported evidence that a single genetic defect appears in all major types of lung cancer and say it appears to play a key role in the nation's biggest cancer killer.

LEAD: British Airways raised its bid for all of British Caledonian Airways to more than $360 million today in a fierce battle with the Scandinavian Airlines System, which Wednesday night offered $200 million for 26 percent of British Caledonian.

A Federal Land Bank Is Insolvent
LEAD: After years of losses throughout the Farm Credit System from depressed land values, a Federal land bank declared itself insolvent today, the first ever to do so.

NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1987
LEAD:  International A3-26


Stage: 'Only You,' By Timothy Mason
LEAD: WHIMSY rides high at the Circle Repertory Company with the opening last night of Timothy Mason's ''Only You,'' a short evening of small talk.
Ostensibly this comedy concerns the compartmentalization of prospective young lovers, each of whom never seems to know when he has found a rightful romantic partner.


Dr. Louis Gray, Physician, 98
LEAD: Dr.
Louis Gray, a retired physician from New York City, died Wednesday at the National Orthopaedic Hospital in Arlington, Va.
He was 98 years old and lived in Rockville, Md.


Israeli Soldiers Kill a Palestinian and Wound 15
LEAD: Israeli troops shot and killed a West Bank resident and wounded at least 15 other Palestinians today as violent unrest continued for the second day and spread throughout the occupied territories.


Bear Stearns Sues Jardine
LEAD: The Bear Stearns Companies has filed suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan against the brokerage house of Jardine Strategic Holdings Inc. of Hong Kong for withdrawing from an agreement to acquire a stake in the company.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article from Washington on Wednesday about Senator Paul Simon's candidacy for President gave an erroneous date for an article he wrote for Harper's Magazine.
It appeared in 1964.


WASHINGTON TALK: Political Image-Making; In the Land of George, Abe, Ike and Jack: Mikhail
LEAD: He is masterly in his use of television, good at the small gesture, quick in repartee.
He appeals directly to the people over the heads of the political establishment.
He seems to enjoy a close relationship with an attractive wife, always a political asset, and he appears open to new ideas and to change.


Good Big Buildings Need Friends
LEAD: The Shadow Trend is apparent coast to coast, from San Francisco to New York: a newly energized movement that opposes big buildings in cities because they cast shadows, threaten views, crowd facilities and offend somebody's taste.
But the virtuous opponents rarely explain how, without big new buildings, cities can end housing shortages, expand job opportunities and collect tax revenues.


Cuomo Meeting Fails to Agree on Restructuring School Board
LEAD: Political and education leaders, summoned by Governor Cuomo yesterday to discuss the New York City schools, failed to agree on the Governor's main goal: restructuring the Board of Education.

LEAD: A picture caption in The Home Section yesterday about home improvement in Greenwich Village apartment misidentified two people.
The man seated in the center was William F. Miller, a general contractor; the other man was Tom Brashares, a Manhattan architect.


Trade Gap Sets Monthly Record At $17.6 Billion
LEAD: The nation's deficit in foreign trade leaped to a record $17.6 billion in October as Christmas goods and other imports rose more than five times as much as exports, the Government said today.

LEAD: Bond prices were battered yesterday as the dollar plunged to new lows in the wake of the record $17.6 billion trade deficit reported for October.
The losses were most pronounced among the longer-term Treasury maturities as institutions struggled to sell bonds to uninterested buyers.

'Asinamali!' and 'Foxfire' Explore Pain of Survival
LEAD: TWO plays newly adapted for television explore, in very different ways and contexts, the subject of survival.
The South African ''Asinamali,'' on Channel 13's ''Great Performances'' tonight at 9, describes the brutality of living under the oppressive policy of apartheid. ''Foxfire,'' a Hallmark Hall of Fame presentation on CBS Sunday at 9 P.M., deals with the unavoidable pressures of simply growing old.

LEAD: A Congressional subcommittee charged today that politically motivated officials at the Office of Management and Budget improperly pressured health experts into adopting a regulation easing food labeling requirements and ''undercut the credibility'' of the Food and Drug Administration.


Hugh R. Williams, 65, Maryland Psychiatrist
LEAD: Dr.
Hugh Roberts Williams, director of the Talbot County Mental Health Clinic in Easton, Md., from 1977 to 1985 and the in-patient psychiatrist at Franklin Square Hospital in Baltimore from 1985 until early this year, died Wednesday of prostatic cancer at his home in Royal Oak, Md.
He was 65 years old.

LEAD: A United Nations envoy has opened negotiations with the exiled King of Afghanistan and guerrilla leaders on a transitional government to take power if the Soviet Union withdraws its forces, diplomats and officials say.

LEAD: The New York bridge scene lost one of its great veterans when Herman Horowitz of Rego Park, Queens, died in August just short of his 90th birthday.
Only two weeks earlier he was the big winner in a six-hour rubber bridge session that would have tested many a younger man.


Time for New York to Turn Up the Candlepower
LEAD: Ever illuminated, New York becomes even more incandescently lustrous in the weeks before Christmas as holiday lights flicker on, building tops are bathed in red-and-green spotlights and even familiar street lamps acquire a cool, wintry glow.
From the malls of Park Avenue to the poinsettia-encircled ''trees from different lands'' at the New York Botanical Garden, evergreens of every description are already festooned with millions of lights.

LEAD: The third Reagan-Gorbachev summit conference brought no major breakthroughs beyond the treaty banning medium-range missiles.

LEAD: The education summit meeting called yesterday by Governor Cuomo marks an important first step toward reform of New York City's troubled school system.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A picture caption on Wednesday about CBS News film of a Soviet missile carrier misidentified its cargo.
CBS later reported that it was not an SS-20 missile, only a canister used for one.

LEAD: Joseph Clark, a high school principal here who has won national acclaim as a disciplinarian, has been ordered to reinstate 50 students he had ejected because they were disciplinary problems and were not doing their school work.


Locations of Sites Named in Arms Agreement
LEAD: A memorandum of understanding to the Soviet-American agreement on medium- and shorter-range weapons pinpointing basing, production and support sites for the arms was released yesterday.
Missile production installations in Magna, Utah, and Votkinsk, U.S.S.R., are open to 13-year inspections.
All other sites listed here are open to one type of inspection or another, with the exception of all remaining missile production installations and all research and development launch sites.

LEAD: Despite the heavy snows of early October that damaged hundreds of thousands of trees in the Hudson Valley, cultivated Christmas trees weathered the storm in good shape and are now ready for harvest.

LEAD: N.H.L.

Bobby Carpenter and Paul Fenton gave visiting Los Angeles a 2-1 lead in the first period, but the Kings couldn't hold it and were defeated for the sixth time in the past six games.


A New Warning on the Trade Deficit
LEAD: Bad news on the October trade deficit came right in the middle of the Washington summit conference.
Even as President Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev explored arms control, there it was -stark confirmation that the Soviet Union is not the only superpower with economic problems.
America's economy is also out of kilter, and the experts aren't sure how to fix it.

LEAD: President Reagan said tonight that his three-day summit meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev had placed Soviet-American relations ''on a far more candid, and far more realistic footing.''


Allis Rejects Bid
LEAD: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation, the struggling equipment maker on the block since November, said it had rejected a $385 million offer by a New York investment firm for most of its assets and property.
Allis-Chalmers, which filed for bankruptcy protection from its creditors more than a year ago, rejected the offer by Peers &amp; Company as too low and because of its plans to sell two major units.


Thruway Unit Suspends Plans For Interchange
LEAD: In a surprise announcement, the New York State Thruway Authority said yesterday that it was halting preparations to build a Thruway interchange at the edge of Sterling Forest, a 30-square-mile tract of private timberland less than an hour's drive northwest of Manhattan.


Diner's Journal
LEAD: A FESTIVE spot in midtown for a self-indulgent snack is Petrossian, the caviar and champagne palace on Seventh Avenue at 58th Street.
The menu has been greatly expanded to offer a wide range of refined finger foods that can be tasted in the plush Art Deco dining room or at the marble-topped bar.
Options include tasty little roulades of smoked sturgeon with wild mushrooms, truffled foie gras en croute, smoked salmon wrapped around avocado and Russian salmon roe, and fillets of smoked eel encasing shiitake mushrooms (all $12 each).

BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1987
LEAD:  Companies


Comings and Goings
LEAD: The Philadelphia 76ers, already weakened in the frontcourt by injuries to Tim McCormick, a 7-foot center, and Roy Hinson, a 6-9 forward, suffered another setback yesterday.
Chris Welp, a rookie 7-foot center from the University of Washington, was told after undergoing arthroscopic surgery that he would be sidelined for a year because of ligament and cartilage damage in his knee.

U.S. to Reduce Shelter Funds For Homeless
LEAD: The Federal Government plans to curtail sharply the contributions it makes toward sheltering homeless families in New York and other cities.


Jury Starts Deliberations in Deaver Case
LEAD: The perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver went to the jury today, and the jurors deliberated for six hours before recessing for the weekend after a Federal district judge instructed them to disregard defense contentions that alcoholism had impaired Mr.
Deaver's memory.

U.S.-Canada Trade Pact's Details Listed
LEAD: The United States will continue to protect its maritime industry, and Canada its publishing and film industries, under an agreement aimed at eliminating most restrictions on their bilateral trade by the year 2000.


German Coal Output Cut
LEAD: West Germany's troubled coal industry will cut annual production by 16 to 18 percent, costing 30,000 jobs, under a pact reached today by Government, industry and union officials.
Economics Minister Martin Bangemann, who led the Government delegation in the latest round of talks on restructuring the industry, said coal output would be cut back by between 13 million metric tons and 15 million tons.


Walter Anderson, 69, Investigator in Queens
LEAD: Walter Anderson, an investigator in the office of the Queens District Attorney for 25 years, died Wednesday at the Huntington (L.I.) Hospital.
He was 69 years old and lived in Lloyd Harbor, L.I.


Yanks, Mets Will Play
LEAD: The general managers of the Mets and the Yankees disclosed today that the teams would resume playing exhibition games against each other in 1989.


South Africa Restricts a Freed Dissident
LEAD: The South African police imposed harsh restrictions today on Govan A. Mbeki, the former national chairman of the outlawed African National Congress, who was released from prison last month after serving 23 years of a life sentence for plotting to overthrow the Government.


Four Haiti Candidates Unite And Demand Regime Resign
LEAD: The four leading presidential candidates united today in opposition to the army-dominated provisional Government and, in a hardening of their position, demanded that the Government step down.


Devils Burned by the Flames
LEAD: Alain Chevrier, Devils' goalie, blocking shot in first period last night at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.
Flames went on to win, 5-1.
Page 57. (The New York Times/Angel Franco)


SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
LEAD: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week.
Answers appear on page 21.


No Sign of Medical Ailment Found In Blood Test of Homeless Woman
LEAD: An independent blood test on Joyce Brown, the first street person involuntarily hospitalized under a new Koch administration program, found that she was not suffering from a medical ailment suggested by city doctors.
Her lawyers immediately renewed their pleas for her release.


FILM: IN 'THE WILD PAIR,' GOOD GUYS VS. BAD GUYS
LEAD: ''The Wild Pair,'' which sneaked into the Criterion and other theaters yesterday, is about an F.B.I. man (white) and a big cop (black) who join together to bring down a big drug pusher (black) and a sadistic ex-Marine colonel (white) who is on a private mission to save America from lesser races.
The good guys are played by Bubba Smith and Beau Bridges, who also directed.


Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the New York State Thruway Authority misstated the amount needed by the authority to repair and maintain all roads and bridges by 1996.
It is $1.71 billion.


Transactions
LEAD:  BASEBALL


Lakers Top Celtics On Johnson's Shot
LEAD: Magic Johnson's off-balance 20-foot jump shot at the buzzer gave the Los Angeles Lakers a 115-114 victory over the Celtics tonight at Boston Garden.


In the Private Talks, Humor And a Deep Disagreement
LEAD: On Tuesday morning, after the elaborate pageantry of the arrival ceremony for Mikhail S. Gorbachev on the South Lawn of the White House, President Reagan escorted his guest to the Oval Office and promptly committed a minor and intentional breach of etiquette.


A.T.&amp;T. Profits Called on Upswing
LEAD: The chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, James Olson, said A.T.&amp; T.'s profits were on the upswing and should continue to grow in 1988. ''We're convinced we've turned a very important corner financially,'' Mr.
Olson told a meeting of securities analysts in New York.
A.T.&amp; T.'s stock rose 25 cents yesterday, to $27.375, in consolidated trading on the New York Stock Exchange.


Sotheby Defers Stock Offering
LEAD: Sotheby's Holdings Inc., the auction house, said yesterday that it would postpone its plan to sell shares to the public because of the recent volatility of American and British stock markets.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''I don't think just because he wears Gucci shoes and smiles occasionally and acknowledges that he's got a wife before his funeral means that the Soviet Union has changed its basic doctrines.'' - Caspar W. Weinberger.  [ 1:5. ]


Mullin Suspended
LEAD: Chris Mullin was suspended for last night's game by the Golden State Warriors, a day after he missed a practice for the second time this season.
Mullin failed to show up for practice on Thursday and was barred from practice and the game against the Atlanta Hawks.
Coach George Karl, who met with team officials Thursday night to discuss the situation, said the starting guard would be fined.


Families Give Found Money To Neediest
LEAD: For the last four years, the Oerlemans family has been picking up pennies, nickels and dimes as well as foreign coins from the streets of New York City, and this week they gave it all back.


G.M.-Toyota Australia Deal
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation confirmed today that it would establish a joint venture in Australia with the Toyota Motor Corporation in 1988.


Dr. Sidney Yudin, Psychologist
LEAD: Dr.
Sidney Yudin, a New York City psychologist, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.
He was 66 years old.


Panels to Decide Fate of Cuban Inmates
LEAD: The Reagan Administration established a new process today to decide whether Cubans held in American prisons should be sent back to Cuba, but lawyers for the inmates said the procedures were inadequate.


Dollar at New Lows After Tokyo Selloff
LEAD: The dollar sagged to new lows in fairly light trading yesterday.
Dealers said that support from the Japanese and West German central banks, as well as profit taking following Thursday's huge declines, helped to prevent a deeper drop.


Bond Prices Fall in Slow Trading
LEAD: Treasury bond prices continued to decline yesterday in what dealers termed one of the slowest trading days of the year.
Most of the losses were unrealized, however, because they consisted more of dealer price-cutting than actual sales.
Despite price cuts of up to three-quarters of a point on the longest maturity, buyers were rare, dealers said.


AIDS Patients In Dire Need Finding Solace
LEAD: A dozen slips of lavender paper hang over Gregory Broyles's desk in a homey Harlem office.
On each one is the name of someone hospitalized with AIDS, a telephone number and a notation of the patient's special needs: clothing, cigarettes, daily calls, child care, help in paying the rent.


Oil Pollutes Lithuania River
LEAD: More than 60 miles of river in the Soviet Baltic republic of Lithuania have been polluted by an oil leak from a power station, the trade union daily Trud said today.


Texaco Stockholder Group Agrees With Pennzoil on $3 Billion Pact
LEAD: Frustrated by an impasse in the discussions between Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company over a $10.3 billion judgment, a group of Texaco's shareholders yesterday bypassed the company's management and agreed with Pennzoil on a $3 billion plan to end the dispute.


Majority Vote for National Book Award Novel
LEAD: To the Editor:


F.D.A. Warns Against Eating Some Shellfish From Canada
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration told Americans today to avoid eating mussels, oysters and clams from the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Canada.

Louis Symphony is conducting the New York Philharmonic for three weeks this month.

A Duo at Bradley's
LEAD: The duo of Ronnie Mathews, pianist, and Ray Drummond, bassist, perform tonight at Bradley's, 70 University Place (228-6440).
Music begins at 9:45 P.M.; there is no cover charge or minimum.


Woman Withdraws Complaint on Judge Pressed by Holtzman
LEAD: The complainant in a sexual-misconduct trial retracted her accusation yesterday that a judge had humiliated her by ordering her on her hands and knees to re-enact a rape.
She said the Brooklyn District Attorney's office had coerced her into making the false accusation, according to her lawyer.


The Even Sadder New York Police Saga
LEAD: The recent revelation that Transit Police officers made scores of illegal arrests for alleged sex abuse and other crimes in 1983 and 1984 is only the beginning of what promises to be a long and sorry story.
It is fast becoming clear that the ill-advised practice of measuring police productivity by arrest quotas is responsible for a far more extensive pattern of false arrests and for undermining the credibility of an entire police agency.


Uspci Takes Steps To Block Takeover
LEAD: Uspci Inc., trying to ward off a $25-a-share takeover proposal from the Union Pacific Corporation, disclosed that it had entered negotiations to acquire ''a business which complements the company's operations.'' Uspci, the hazardous waste management concern based in Oklahoma City, has previously said that an acquisition might be used as a defense against Union


Sale of Edinburgh Brokerage Is Set
LEAD: County Natwest Ltd. announced today that it would acquire Wood Mackenzie &amp; Company, an Edinburgh-based brokerage house, in the most significant consolidation move in the British securities industry since the worldwide stock market plunge in October.


Some Say Frontier Is Still There, and Still Different
LEAD: Nearly a century after experts pronounced the death of the American frontier, a loosely knit group of academics and public officials are arguing that the death sentence was premature.
The frontier is still out there in all its harshness, they say, even if its borders are harder to define.





FEARS OF VIOLENCE DOMINATE KOREA CAMPAIGN'S LAST DAYS
LEAD: South Korea's presidential campaign entered a climactic phase today in a swirl of warnings about violence and charges that brutality and fraud were being used to win votes.

LEAD: Questions appear on page 18.


Fond Trip Down 'Knish Alley'
LEAD: That generation gap so often the inspiration for lamentations has been bridged by two men in their middle-30's who find it no wider than their leg span.
The sector of the gap under discussion here consists of the immigrant Yiddish theater on one side and the Yankee grandchildren - great-grandchildren, even - of those early audiences.


On Selling Peronism With No Peron and Little Ism
LEAD: Four decades ago, Antonio Cafiero was part of the feverish multitude that swept Juan Domingo Peron to power and set Argentina on a path of social and industrial change.


Big Board Fills Security Post
LEAD: David Doherty, who has worked with the Central Intelligence Agency and the Securities and Exchange Commission, is joining the New York Stock Exchange as senior vice president for enforcement.


Consumer Spending Found Cautious
LEAD: Evidence mounted today that consumers have slowed their spending in recent months, but the cutback does not appear severe enough to shove the economy into early recession.





Jury Is Denied Visit to Site Of Howard Beach Incident
LEAD: The judge in the Howard Beach trial yesterday refused the request of a jury deliberating the fate of four white teen-agers charged with murder or manslaughter to visit the scene of an attack on three black men a year ago.

LEAD: Tom G. Kessinger, a scholar on South Asia who heads the Ford Foundation's office in New Delhi, has been named president of Haverford College.

LEAD: Recently, the news from New York City jails has seldom been good.

Olympic Summit
LEAD: As he promised Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska, President Reagan raised the issue of support of the Olympic Games by the United States and the Soviet Union at the summit meeting this week in Washington, an aide to the Republican Senator said.
But even though Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, acknowledged general support for the Olympic movement, the aide said, he would not promise that a team from his country would attend the Summer Games next September in Seoul, South Korea.

Saving More Than Turtles
LEAD: Several mischievous amendments are waiting as the House gets ready to vote next week on reauthorization of the Endangered Species Act, one of the most effective environmental laws ever enacted.
The most troubling, offered by Solomon Ortiz of Texas, would delay new regulations requiring shrimp fishermen to use excluder devices that permit sea turtles to escape their nets.

LEAD: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, with the guest artists Joshua Bell, violinist, and Jean-Yves Thibaudet, pianist, will perform works by Ives, Mozart and Chausson at 5 P.M. tomorrow in Alice Tully Hall.
Tickets are $18.

3 Suspects Are Seized In Brooklyn Shootings
LEAD: Three young men were arrested yesterday on charges of participating in a shooting spree at a packed Brooklyn catering hall in which two people were killed and 13 were wounded, the police said.


10 Years of Schubert Starts Jan. 26 at the Y
LEAD: Beginning Jan. 26, nearly a decade of performances devoted to the music of Franz Schubert will be offered at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.
The tribute, called ''the Schubertiade,'' is to include appearances by a number of noted musicians and will end in 1997, the bicentennial anniversary of the composer's birth.


Gorbachev Stops in Berlin; Gets a Triumphal Welcome
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev stopped here today on his way home from the Washington summit meeting and was given a triumphal welcome by other Warsaw Pact leaders and thousands of East Berliners who cheered him along the motorcade route.

Save John Jay's Westchester Site
LEAD: Since the birthdays of George Washington and Abraham Lincoln are national holidays, at least for this year let's look at today as a holiday, too.
John Jay, probably the most unheralded of the Founding Fathers, was born 242 years ago.


Cutting This Year's Taxes: Retirement Plans a Big Help YOUR TAXES: TIPS FOR YEAR-END; Third of five articles.
LEAD: Depositing money in a personal retirement account or in a company-sponsored plan is one of the most lucrative ways still left for individuals to trim their 1987 income tax bill.


Heavy Thai Rains Kill 24
LEAD: Heavy monsoon rains and storms have killed 24 people and destroyed several thousand acres of farmland in southern Thailand, an Interior Ministry official said today.


Harvard Endowment
LEAD: Harvard University's multibillion-dollar endowment dropped 7.2 percent in value when the stock market plunged in October, the university said today.
The endowment's decline of $290 million was far smaller on a percentage basis than the overall market, which by various measures was down more than 20 percent in October.


Discord in OPEC Deepens on 3d Day of Meeting
LEAD: Divisions within OPEC widened significantly today and the group of 13 oil producers appeared unable to reach an agreement that would prevent oil prices from dropping further.

LEAD: Pope John Paul II cleared the way today for the beatification of the Rev.
Junipero Serra, the founder of nine Spanish missions in California.

Coping: With 401-K's and the Market
LEAD: If you are a participant in a company-sponsored savings or profit-sharing plan like a 401-K and you directed your contributions into equity mutual funds, you may be more exposed than you had thought to the stock market's plunge.


Church's Chicken Stake Purchased
LEAD: An investment group led by three members of the wealthy Bass family of Texas said it held an 8.2 percent stake in Church's Fried Chicken Inc.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bass group said it had purchased the shares as an investment.
Earlier this year, Church's, the nation's second-largest fast-food chicken operation, rejected a $469 million offer from a group of former company executives.


Nicu Haas, Anthropologist, Dies
LEAD: Dr.
Nicu Haas, an Israeli scientist who helped in the discovery of the only known remains of a man crucified in the time of Jesus, died last week after 13 years in a coma, colleagues said today.
He was 60 years old.


Yanks and Mets End Eight-Year Freeze
LEAD: The last time the Yankees and the Mets engaged in a transaction was Aug. 2, 1979, when the Mets purchased Ray Burris, a pitcher, from the Yankees.


PTL Owes $61 Million in Taxes, Court Is Told
LEAD: The Internal Revenue Service contends that the PTL television ministry owes at least $61 million in taxes, which is $1 million more than the ministry said it had in total debts when it sought protection under the Federal bankruptcy law.


NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1987
LEAD:  International 3-11  After the U.S.-Soviet summit, President Reagan said he and Mikhail S. Gorbachev had established ''an entirely different relationship.'' The White House mood was a combination of exhaustion and exhilaration.
Page 1  Strong differences on'Star Wars' remain between the United States and the Soviet Union despite President Reagan's assertion that the discussion about the issue was a victory for his position, officials said.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Wife of Spy Hospitalized
LEAD: The jailed wife of convicted spy Jonathan Jay Pollard today was transferred from a prison hospital in Kentucky to one affiliated with the Mayo Clinic for treatment of a digestive disorder, Government officials and family members said.
A Justice Department official said Anne Henderson Pollard, who was given a five-year term in March after pleading guilty to charges related to her husband's sale of state secrets to Israel, was checked into Methodist Hospital in Rochester, Minn.


Koch Picks Investigation Aide To Be Criminal Justice Chief
LEAD: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would appoint the first deputy investigation commissioner, Peter J. Benitez, the Criminal Justice Coordinator.


West German Films on TV
LEAD: Beginning tomorrow and continuing for the next five weekends, contemporary films from West Germany will be shown on CUNY-TV, the cable channel of the City University of New York.
The films, most of which have English subtitles, were produced by Das Kleine Fernsehspiel, a program of the Second German TV Network.

LEAD: The Soviet flag flew high at the Reagan White House.
Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, pressed the flesh on Connecticut Avenue and beguiled members of Congress.
And both he and President Reagan pronounced their summit meeting a solid success.
Whether or not that assessment seems justified after close examination of their labors, it surely succeeded in the largest sense.

Mr.

This one turned out to be the afternoon of the Chinese massage.

Paul Ekman, an expert in the muscles of emotional expression, has added a new weapon.
He and his colleagues, Wallace Friesen and Maureen O'Sullivan, have found a sure way to detect the crocodile smile.

Higher Sales Tax To Replace Florida Services Tax
LEAD: Gov.
Bob Martinez of Florida signing a bill passed by the Legislature that repeals the state's tax of services.
The tax, which was opposed by businesses, will die Jan. 1 and the state sales tax will climb from 5 percent to 6 percent on Feb. 1 to make up lost revenue.
The additional sales tax is expected to cost the average Florida family $185 a year.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.H.L.
Gretzky Passes Esposito: Wayne Gretzky reached another scoring plateau, and Grant Fuhr stood out in goal in leading the Oilers to a 2-1 triumph last night over the Vancouver Canucks at Edmonton.
Gretzky moved into sole possession of third place on the league's career scoring list with 1,591 points.


British Inflation Understated
LEAD: A British Government computer program error understated the annual inflation rate by around a tenth of a percent for more than 18 months, the Department of Employment announced today.
It said the mistake in the retail price index, the main inflation barometer, went undetected from February 1986 until October of this year.


Reduced Bid Taken By McLeod Young
LEAD: Bank of Nova Scotia, one of Canada's leading banks, cut its takeover offer for the McLeod Young Weir Corporation, the brokerage firm, in a reaction to the stock market decline, and the bid was accepted.
Bank of Nova Scotia reduced its offer to $52 (Canadian) a share, or a total of $419 million, from $60 a share, or $483 million.


TV: 'Mystery!' Opens Agatha Christie Series
LEAD: Public television's ''Mystery!'', packaged by WGBH of Boston and underwritten by Mobil, is on a nifty winning streak these days.
Having just finished a splendid trio of Dorothy L. Sayers adaptations, with Edward Petherbridge as Lord Peter Wimsey, the series is now returning to Agatha Christie's Miss Marple stories, once again starring Joan Hickson as the venerable but dogged sleuth.


Iran Sees Oil Accord With Paris
LEAD: Iranian oil officials said today that France and Iran had agreed in principle to end a French ban on the purchase of Iranian oil that had been imposed in the summer.

Peruvian Guerrillas Kill 4
LEAD: Peruvian Maoist guerrillas killed four workers and wounded two in an attack Thursday on the headquarters of the region's major water project, the police said today.
They said three guerrillas entered the office and sprayed seven workers with gunfire, killing the executive director and two other engineers and a guard.


Record Mexico Inflation
LEAD: Consumer prices rose 7.9 percent in November, bringing inflation for the first 11 months of 1987 to a record 125.8 percent, the central bank has announced.
November's rate was down from October's 8.3 percent rise, according to figures released by the Bank of Mexico.
Private analysts have predicted that inflation for the year could go as high as 140 percent, well above the previous annual record of 105.7 percent, reached in 1986.

Men notice.

Pop: David Frishberg Songs
LEAD: David Frishberg, the Los Angeles-based songwriter and performer, is a consummate craftsman of pop-jazz songs whose lyrics have the cutting precision of the best light verse.
In the refinement of his language, he is equaled only by Stephen Sondheim among contemporary American songwriters.
But instead of theater songs, he writes jazz tunes filtered through the climate of Hollywood movie music.

Accident Kills Police Trainee
LEAD: A police cadet was killed Thursday when a training officer, carrying a pistol with live ammunition that he had forgotten to remove, fired once into the cadet's chest in a mock apartment raid, the police said today.
The victim was identified as Omega Graham Jr., 25 years old, of the Fort Wayne (Ind.) Police Academy, one of several cadets taking part in a weeklong exercise at a training facility here.

Treasury?

By going along, Senate conferees would strike a blow for fiscal responsibility.

John Huston's Last Legacy
LEAD: ''IT HAD BEGUN TO SNOW again.
He watched sleepily the flakes, silver and dark, falling obliquely against the lamplight.
The time had come for him to set out on his journey westward.
Yes, the newspapers were right: snow was general all over Ireland.
It was falling on every part of the dark central plain, on the treeless hills, falling softly upon the Bog of Allen and, farther westward, softly falling into the dark mutinous Shannon waves.

SHOULD THE METS KEEP MOOKIE WILSON?
LEAD: No.
Mookie and Len Dykstra are both aggressive base runners, good fielders and switch-hitters to boot.
But the leadoff hitter should make contact or walk.
Dykstra will lead the Mets in plate appearances and runs scored.
RICHARD H. MARX  Stamford, Conn.


ILLUSTRATED BOOKS FOR CHRISTMAS: GIVE THE BIG PICTURE
LEAD:  THE NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC SOCIETY: 100 Years of Adventure and Discovery.
By C. D. B. Bryan. (Abrams, $45.) If any American institution merits a five-and-a-half-pound $45-birthday card celebrating its centennial, it is the National Geographic Society.
The society's superbly produced flagship magazine has guided generations of Americans from the benthos to the cosmos and is, I warrant, the only periodical regarded as impossible (if not downright illegal) to throw away; tons of issues are passed down like family heirlooms.

Construction began in the summer and is scheduled for completion at the end of next year.

LEAD: Corazon C. Aquino, who has had a trying tenure as president of the Philippines, found something to be ''really overjoyed'' about last week.

Gregorio Honasan, the army officer who in August led an attempt to topple the Aquino Government.

SHOULD THE METS KEEP MOOKIE WILSON?
LEAD: Of course, the Mets should keep Mookie.
Not only because he's an igniter, a clutch hitter, a class citizen and the Met responsible for The Grounder to Buckner, but, most importantly, because my 3 1/2-year-old son - who frequently calls himself Mookie (his name is Alex) - is too young to learn the harsh realities of the baseball business.

IT'S TIME FOR TRIMMING
LEAD: BE sure to use approved outdoor wiring when attaching lights to shrubs and trees.
Check coldframe sashes; they should be secure for future windstorms.
The soil of bulbs potted for forcing into bloom after the holidays should be moist, not dry.
Spray anti-desiccants on broadleaved evergreens and young conifers.

Q AND A
LEAD:  Sled-Dog Race  Question: I have always wanted to see the winner of the Iditarod Trail Sled-Dog Race in Alaska.
Once in Nome, will it be easy to learn when the winner will arrive and get a front-row look? - E. S., New York, N.Y.
Answer: It is not easy, one of the race officials explains, to estimate accurately when the winner and his or her dogs will cross the finish line until the leaders are about 200 miles from Nome.

The Dance: An Evening at Ailey Works at City Center
LEAD: GLITTER, love and pain were the main ingredients in the ''All Ailey Evening'' presented by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater on Friday at City Center.
Mr.
Ailey is an eclectic.
That the evening proved.
But there is a unifying humanity in all his work.
And it was danced here in the penetratingly expressive way that is so distinctive a feature of the Ailey dancers and their repertory.

A TRADITIONAL ENGLISH CHRISTMAS FEAST
LEAD: FOR me, Christmas dinner has to be traditional.
That means a serious roast - goose, turkey or suckling pig - and plum pudding brought flaming to the table.
Being British, I am used to dishes that might seem unusual to an American, but they are very much part of our repertoire and date back to long before the Revolution.

WHAT HAPPENED TO THE MARKET?
LEAD: It is curious that when the market experiences a decline, members of the securities industry and the Administration refer to the phenomenon as a ''correction'' (On Language: ''What Happened to the Market?'' by William Safire, Nov. 8).
However, when the market goes up, the term ''correction'' is never applied.

From the Particular to the Sublime
LEAD: THERE IS SOMETHING REALLY rather peculiar about the virtual unanimity with which Anselm Kiefer, now 42, has been accepted in the United States as the most important artist to have emerged from Europe in the last quarter of this century.
Kiefer's work is like nobody else's.
Often daunting in size and undeniably bizarre in its physical structure, it is predicated upon myths and magics, both private and public, that are quite unfamiliar in this country.

He was 79 years old and lived in Princeton.

THE PROPER CARE OF CERAMIC TILE
LEAD: CERAMIC tile, used to cover bathroom walls and floors as well as kitchen backsplashes, enjoys a reputation for moisture resistance and durability, not to mention beauty.
It is so hard that it seldom suffers damage from impact.
However, tiles sometimes loosen or develop cracks, and maintenance is necessary to prevent the filler, called grout, between them from deteriorating.


SEDUCED BY THE GLOW OF MEMORY
LEAD: SOME YEARS AGO, AFTER HAVING WRITTEN what must have been an especially effusive review of an Arthur Rubinstein recital, I received a long, remarkably detailed letter of disapproval from a young pianist.
In particular, he wanted to chide me for being so bedazzled by the Rubinstein reputation that I could not recognize what was clearly an ''abominably imprecise, slovenly'' performance of the final movement of Chopin's ''Funeral March'' Sonata.


Leaderless Conservatives Approach '88 in Splinters
LEAD: A WEEK in which the hammer and sickle was flying in front of the White House is not a bad time to contemplate the dismay and disarray that grips much of the American conservative movement.
Leaving aside the arms-control agreement with the Soviet Union - and for many conservatives that's bad enough - the movement is in a decidedly bad humor.

They were protective of the petite 81-year-old, whom they called Sandy.

MOVIES
LEAD:  Beyond Therapy  Starring Julie Hagerty, Jeff Goldblum, Glenda Jackson, Tom Conti, Christopher Guest.
Directed by Robert Altman. 1986.
New World Video. 93 minutes. $69.95.
This surreal romance is strictly for Robert Altman addicts.
Christopher Durang's play has been Altmanized, which is to say that characters have been transported to the director's alternative universe, making ''Beyond Therapy'' a disorienting experience indeed.

The Bosporus
LEAD: To the Editor: Alan Cowell's account of his trip to the Bosporus via zig-zag ferry (Travel, Nov. 8) stirs pleasant memories.

That article directed us to Pier 1 near the Galata Bridge in Istanbul as the launch site.

LEAD: To the Editor: I thought that the article on the Weissensee cemetery gave an excellent description of the cemetery and the history surrounding it.

On my most recent visit to East Berlin, I was taken to the Weissensee cemetery one Sunday afternoon.


New &amp; Noteworthy
LEAD:  MAMA, by Terry McMillan. (Washington Square Press/ Pocket Books, $5.95.) Mildred Peacock, the protagonist of this novel about a poor black family in a decaying suburb of Detroit, finds many ways to transcend poverty -alcohol, prostitution and plain, hard work. ''In its inexorable movement toward economic doom, 'Mama'  [ proves ]  that dignity can't be carried in a wallet,'' Will Blythe said here earlier this year.

In and Out of Storyville: Jazz and Fiction
LEAD: ONE morning in New Orleans I went to a jazz funeral.
The deceased was Thomas Jefferson, a trumpet player, gone now at 65.
His own band was going to play.
It was cool and cloudy when my wife and I, with the baby in his stroller, joined a crowd gathered on the sidewalk and street outside the funeral home.

Gorbachev emerged variously as a charming, steely and unpredictable Soviet leader - a man who, alternately, ''blew up'' at tough questions, who startled guests with his awareness of American culture, who seemed ''very controlled'' and curiously mysterious.

Bargains in Closed-End Funds
LEAD: THIS year has brought another deluge of stock offerings in new closed-end investment funds; a total of 34 issues raised about $9 billion, according to one estimate.
But even before the plunge in stock prices in October, investors in many of the equity-oriented funds shared a common experience: They were a bit poorer for having bought at the initial offerings.


ABOUT ALARM SYSTEMS AND THE REAL WORLD
LEAD: I could not read ''Closed Windows, Good Neighbors''  [ Nov. 22 ]  without being grateful that I am not one of Sara Jasper Cook's next-door neighbors.
Does she think that the people who have alarm systems are any happier about them than she is?
We, too, have to listen to them when they go off, have to worry that someone may be breaking into our homes, and feel like we live in a cage.

SIMMS ACCEPTING INCOMPLETE SEASON
LEAD: After all those years with all those injuries, everything seemed to turn round for Phil Simms.
In 1984, he passed for 4,044 yards, a Giant record.
In 1985, he passed for 3,829 yards and was voted the most valuable player in the Pro Bowl.

ANSWERING THE MAIL
LEAD: Q. I am having a problem removing nonskid bathtub decals I put down five years ago.
I had taken up the old ones and put new ones in their place without ever getting all the old adhesive off.
Now I would like to remove these decals and the sticky residue left.
I have tried benzine, nail-polish remover and Spray 'N' Wash (which was recommended by the manufacturer of these decals), but I have only been able to remove the top layer, not the adhesive.

THE PROPER CARE OF CERAMIC TILE
LEAD: CERAMIC tile, used to cover bathroom walls and floors as well as kitchen backsplashes, enjoys a reputation for moisture resistance and durability, not to mention beauty.
It is so hard that it seldom suffers damage from impact.
However, tiles sometimes loosen or develop cracks, and maintenance is necessary to prevent the filler, called grout, between them from deteriorating.

Art
LEAD: Outside the mainstream, contemporary art sometimes seems to be turning into a menagerie.
So many animals have been invented, depicted and unleashed in painting that they almost seem to be taking over.
This need for nature is something of a reaction against the amount of theory in art now.
Animals also make it possible for artists to express an affection for living creatures in a way that the human figure, as problematical as it has been in 20th-century art, does not.

SHOULD THE METS KEEP MOOKIE WILSON?
LEAD: Yes, the Mets should keep Mookie Wilson.

ILLUSTRATED BOOKS FOR CHRISTMAS: GIVE THE BIG PICTURE
LEAD:  DANCE AND PHOTOGRAPHY.
By William A. Ewing. (Holt, $50.) William Ewing's primary interest in photographs of dance lies neither in performance preservation nor in star adulation but in something more profound: the craft, sensuality and intelligence framed within each individual image.
The author presents more than 200 full-page exquisitely reproduced images by such artists as Brassai, Genthe, Steichen, Man Ray, Degas, Nadar and Walker Evans, all of them connected by the subject of dance - primitive, avant-garde, spontaneous, classical.

Should the Beatles have kept Ringo Starr, even though there were better drummers around?
Do thousands at Shea call ''Moo-kie, Moo-kie'' instead of ''Lenny'' or some other name?
Would this Englishman have taken so happily to baseball if Mookie hadn't been there?


THREE-GENERATION PERSPECTIVE OF HUNTING AND KILLING
LEAD: BIG HERB, my father, never lost the thrill of killing.
For him, there was no greater excitement than to be among a covey of quail, on an autumn morning, and to bring down one of their thundering forms with each barrel of his double-barreled Winchester.
Or to stand in a blind at sunset, as the mallards lanced in from the exposed waters of the lake, and send one of their speeding bodies plunging into the marsh.

BIG MAN IN THE KITCHEN
LEAD: EVEN IN HIS APRON, Charles Palmer looks like a fullback.
The 28-year-old chef is 6 feet 3 inches, 236 pounds, and is clearly more than a match for the sea bass on the cutting board in front of him.
Palmer runs a meaty left forefinger along the scales, then, with a few strokes of the knife in his right hand, bones the fish and splits it into two fillets.

A VOTE FOR VOLCKER
LEAD: As Leonard Silk's article ''Volcker on the Crash'' (Nov. 8) demonstrated, Paul Volcker is one of the most respected men in this country and throughout the world.
I applaud and agree with his statement: ''We can control events if we do the right things.'' And there is, as he believes, time to deal with the underlying problems threatening the American and world economies.

In the Cities: Replacing the Downtown Mall With Traffic
LEAD: IN the early 1970's, officials in this Chicago suburb closed their two main shopping streets to traffic, planted trees and grass and flowers where there had been concrete, and turned the whole area into a landscaped pedestrian mall.
The hope was to revitalize a fading downtown, and lure back shoppers and retailers from those other malls, the large regional shopping centers that had stolen them away.

LEAD: WITH HER SOARING VOICE and sometimes fiery abandon, Aretha Franklin has had a long, variable but frequently incandescent career.

Her ''Amazing Grace'' double album of 1972 (now on a double CD set, Atlantic 2-906-2) counts among her finest achievements.

LONG ISLAND GUIDE
LEAD:  HAPPY HANUKKAH  Hanukkah, the Jewish Feast of Lights, lasts for eight days.
This year, the first candle will be lighted at sundown Tuesday, the last on Dec. 22.
But actually the celebrating starts a bit earlier.
For example, today at the Elmont Jewish Center, 500 Elmont Road, in a pre-Hanukkah Adult Education Breakfast at 10:45 A.M., the folk singer Oscar Brand performs his ''Welcome to America'' program.

SHOULD THE METS KEEP MOOKIE WILSON?
LEAD: Should India keep the Taj Mahal?
Should Egypt keep the pyramids?
Of course the Mets should keep Mookie Wilson!
At least, until somebody perfects a time machine that would render Willie Mays young again.
BOB MURRAY  Mt.
Kisco, N.Y.


King Hussein Visits Kuwait
LEAD: King Hussein of Jordan flew to Kuwait today at the start of a Persian Gulf tour to follow up the Arab summit meeting in Amman last month, officials said.
They said the King, accompanied by Prime Minister Zaid al-Rifai, was also expected to visit Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar and Oman during his three-day trip.


Jersey Casino Group Protests Ban on Politicking
LEAD: The 10-member Atlantic City Casino Association has voted unanimously to support a casino official's challenge to New Jersey restrictions on casino participation in the political process.


'Maquiladoras' Cost American Jobs
LEAD: OVER the past decade, the term maquiladora has entered the business lexicon.
Maquiladoras are American-owned plants along the United States-Mexican border operating under special United States tax treatment and Mexican foreign investment regulations.
American-made components are shipped to Mexico and used to assemble products that are sent back to the United States.

Secretary of Energy, on
oil prices and OPEC impasse.  [ 1:5. ]

Is South Korea Ripe for Democracy - or More Repression?
LEAD: POLITICAL parties in South Korea last about as long as the fashionable width of men's lapels.
By custom, they exist only to serve the immediate needs of national politicians, and no party has outlasted the ambitions of its founder.

COOL STORIES, INFLAMED POETS
LEAD: A TRULY capitalist country is one that can afford not one but several annual collections of ''best'' short stories.
While short story collections used to be notoriously poor sellers, they are proliferating - which means either that the market for them has improved, or that American literature has, in some improbable way, transcended the question of sales.

Music: St. Cecilia Chorus, in 'King David'
LEAD: HAVING heard the St.
Cecilia Chorus and Orchestra's performance of Honegger's ''King David'' on Friday evening at Carnegie Hall, it is not difficult to understand why the work was greeted so favorably at its premiere in 1921.
The oratorio tells the grandiose, impassioned story of the Old Testament figure's passage from shepherd to king in music that is both ingratiating and light.

Divining the Legacy of Jackson Pollock
LEAD: NOW, AS MUCH AS EVER, PEOPLE cannot stop talking about Jackson Pollock.
He and Abstract Expressionism, for which he is a symbol, remain so vivid that he seems to be still alive, still dancing over his canvas, still trying to lead art to places it has never been.
There is a sense that no one, not even post-modernists who reject everything he stands for, knows how to cut him down to size.

A Solitary Voyage
LEAD: WELL into the second day of a severe storm in mid-Atlantic the young navigator of the Polish freighter Stefan Starzynski contemplated a course change.
The storm had forced the ship south of the great circle route to its destination, Le Havre, France.
A tight schedule necessitated a change that would put the ship into the troughs of 30-foot waves.

The Trade Deficit Comes in a Shocker
LEAD: The trade deficit jumped to a record $17.6 billion in October, with imports rising by 12.3 percent while exports edged up only 3 percent.
The gap was much worse than had been predicted by the experts, most of whom were expecting it to be no worse than $15 billion.
October is a big month for importing Christmas goods, but there were signs that the report could not be dismissed as a seasonal quirk.

Streetscapes: The Elks Club; An Endangered Species on 43d
LEAD: IT seems like a typical, seedy West Side hotel, no different than a score of other aging buildings in the West 40's.
But if you look up you can still make out the letters ''BPOE'' on the 1911 ''Mother Lodge'' of the Elks, at 108 West 43d Street.
Now the Hotel Diplomat, the building sits on one of the largest assemblages in midtown, and a recent court ruling has removed the last legal obstacle to its demolition.


ANSWERING THE MAIL
LEAD: Q. I am having a problem removing nonskid bathtub decals I put down five years ago.
I had taken up the old ones and put new ones in their place without ever getting all the old adhesive off.
Now I would like to remove these decals and the sticky residue left.
I have tried benzine, nail-polish remover and Spray 'N' Wash (which was recommended by the manufacturer of these decals), but I have only been able to remove the top layer, not the adhesive.


Correction
LEAD: An article from Cambridge, Mass., last Sunday about a dispute between M.I.T. and the City Council incorrectly described the eviction of squatters from a lot owned by the university.
Two police dogs that were coincidentally driven past the scene of the disturbance belonged to the city police and were not involved in the eviction.


Lake Titicaca
LEAD: To the Editor: In 1974 we took the hydrofoil, just as Edwin McDowell did in ''The Lake Atop Bolivia'' (Travel, Nov. 29), from the Crillon Company's dock on Lake Titicaca.
It was an April day, gray and drizzly.
We were going to Copacabana with a stop along the way, to see the Aymaras' reed boats.
There had been an unusual amount of rain that year.

Hip Graphics
LEAD: THE COMPUTER-GENERATED images above represent a human hip.
Reading left to right, two rows at a time (the white images illustrate bone structure; the surrounding musculature is in red), the hip appears to be rotating on a vertical axis.
It's stop-action photography.
Imagine the rotation performed before your eyes on a screen, the illusion of three dimensions, and you envision the accomplishment of innovative hardware and software now being readied for market by Pixar, a computer firm based in San Rafael, Calif.

LEAD: To the Editor:


THE PROPER CARE OF CERAMIC TILE
LEAD: CERAMIC tile, used to cover bathroom walls and floors as well as kitchen backsplashes, enjoys a reputation for moisture resistance and durability, not to mention beauty.
It is so hard that it seldom suffers damage from impact.
However, tiles sometimes loosen or develop cracks, and maintenance is necessary to prevent the filler, called grout, between them from deteriorating.

Leaving Home for Christmas
LEAD: I STILL remember the artful phrase that first enticed us to leave home for Christmas, a habit we have kept up for 25 years.
Earlier that year, my father had died suddenly.
Bereft of this central figure, how were we - my mother especially -to endure our usual rituals?
In the want ad section of the Saturday Review, a wellspring of intriguing possibilities in those days, I found our refuge: ''Tiki, Your Tropic Island Home.

Correction
LEAD: An article last Sunday about community orchestras misstated the origin of the all-professional Nassau Symphony Orchestra and the status of the Merrick Symphony.
The Nassau Symphony is a descendant of the Massapequa Symphony, which has been replaced by the Massapequa Philharmonic, a community orchestra.

LEAD: SOME houses on a tree-lined street in Katonah have had a hard life.
First, in about 1895, they were lifted from their foundations and hauled a mile south on horse-drawn rollers.
Then, after sitting there for a peaceful half century they were rattled and shaken for years by truck traffic.

SHOULD THE METS KEEP MOOKIE WILSON?
LEAD: The Mets should keep Mookie Wilson.
Not only is he a fine fine ballplayer but Len Dykstra has become unreliable, homer-happy, and is not the fielder Wilson is.
He should also be kept in an attempt to show that the Mets do not have a racial quota system.
THOMAS E. HILTON  Brooklyn

Comings and Goings
LEAD: JOE PATERNO was honored last night at the Waldorf-Astoria as the 80th recipient of the Pennsylvania Society's Gold Medal for Distinguished Achievement.

Paterno donated $150,000 to launch the fund in May 1986.

ANSWERING THE MAIL
LEAD: Q. I am having a problem removing nonskid bathtub decals I put down five years ago.
I had taken up the old ones and put new ones in their place without ever getting all the old adhesive off.
Now I would like to remove these decals and the sticky residue left.
I have tried benzine, nail-polish remover and Spray 'N' Wash (which was recommended by the manufacturer of these decals), but I have only been able to remove the top layer, not the adhesive.

True, the dramatic renovation of Portsmouth's once-crumbling downtown proceeds apace, giving the city a spruced-up colonial look and expanding its tax base.

Value Investing
LEAD: To the Editor:


Temples and Tortillas On a Mexican Tour
LEAD: ONE thing that you will find out, as we did, when you travel in the Yucatan, is that climbing down those Mayan pyramids is completely terrifying.
Unfortunately, you are not going to find this out (and even if you are warned, you won't really believe it) until you are standing on top of one.
So there we were at Chichen Itza, and Larry was up on top of the biggest pyramid, and Perri was down at the bottom reading to Benjamin from a favorite book, ''The Cow Who Fell in the Canal,'' and after she had read it through for the seventh time she realized that Larry was not down yet.

LEAD: An 18-month investigation by Federal agents, chemists and local detectives has succeeded in cracking a drug tampering case here that led to the poisoning deaths of two people and caused widespread fear.


EDITOR'S NOTE
LEAD: A picture on the cover of The Times Magazine on Sept. 29, 1985, with an article about the character of Australia, showed a cowboy on horseback against a rugged landscape.
The caption said, ''A cowboy rides past Ayers Rock in Australia's vast Outback.''


'It Shouldn't Be This Way,' But Trade Deficit Expands
LEAD: THE roller coaster that the financial markets boarded in the middle of October just won't stop.
Stocks went up 100 points last week, their best performance since August, but the dollar was battered.
It now will buy less than half as many German marks and Japanese yen as it did at its peak in early 1985.


Employee Parties With Less Pizazz
LEAD: THERE will be no company Christmas parties at Bear Stearns, Shearson Lehman and some other Wall Street houses this year.

HOW-TO
LEAD:  Design With Plants  Morris Video. 57 minutes. $14.95.
Ed Hume likes toothpicks.
This knowledgeable host, who is an author and radio-TV commentator, uses toothpicks to test whether the soil in a pot is dry and needs water.
He also likes to lift a pot to determine its weight; if it is too light, he says the soil is probably dry.


Jersey Denies Sports Authority More Money
LEAD: The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, which saw its proposal to build a $185 million baseball stadium turned down by voters last month, suffered a second setback this week when its request for $60 million in state money was denied.


THE DON: GOING STRONG AT 200
LEAD: THE GREATEST OPERA - SO a surprising number of people who dare to nominate one have called it - is 200 years old this season.
Whatever its absolute standing among the great, ''Don Giovanni,'' first heard on Oct. 29, 1787, in Prague, can claim one primacy without question.
It did something no other opera before it had ever done - it survived its epoch.

JAMES BROOKS LAUNCHES A STAR
LEAD: IN JAMES L. BROOKS'S NEW FILM, ''Broadcast News,'' a handsome new anchorman is called into television action during a crisis in the Middle East.
As played by William Hurt, the anchorman is, intellectually, way over his head and completely unprepared for the demanding assignment.
Jane Craig, the producer of the newscast and the heroine of the movie - a brainy, feisty and extraordinarily self-possessed young woman - speaks to the anchorman through a hidden Telex earpiece, and, while he is on camera, force-feeds him questions, information and direction.


Group Cites Police Torture and Killings in Brazil
LEAD: A United States human rights organization said today that, while political repression has diminished since civilian rule returned to Brazil in 1985, the police in major cities still routinely use torture and executions in dealing with suspected criminals.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Nov. 30 from East Greenville, Pa., about an automobile fatality involving four teenagers on Halloween night, misstated the distance from East Greenville to the nearest McDonald's.
It is much less than 20 minutes by car.
A map with the article mislocated two communities.
The designations for East Greenville and Reading were reversed; East Greenville is east of Reading.

LEAD: JOHN ADAMS is very much the American composer of the moment.
Across the river in Brooklyn, his opera ''Nixon in China'' plays to large and approving audiences; his ''Harmonielehre'' is being taken up by many orchestras, and on a smaller scale, there is his ''Tromba Lontana'' - a five-minute fanfare written for the Houston Symphony in 1986.

Merc May Extend Daily Limits
LEAD: Despite vocal opposition from some institutional investors, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange is likely to set permanent daily price limits on its popular Standard &amp; Poor's 500-stock index futures and options contracts in coming weeks, officials said.


Bernard Barnett, 71; Headed Jewish Appeal
LEAD: Bernard H. Barnett, past national president of the charity organization United Jewish Appeal, died Thursday at University Hospital here.
He was 71 years old.


Chrysler's Jeep/Eagle In 'Big Bang' Debut
LEAD: Around the Chrysler Corporation the in-the-know set is calling introductory advertising for the new Jeep/ Eagle mid-size car the ''Big Bang'' because of the large amount being spent in a short period of time.
Trade sources said the 1988 budget is $50 million.


Music: Kahane and 2 Guests
LEAD: IN a gesture rare among recitalists today, Jeffrey Kahane invited two colleagues, Arleen Auger, the soprano, and Gary Hoffman, a cellist, to join him during his performance at the 92d Street Y on Saturday evening.
As it happened, the pianist found himself being upstaged at one moment by Ms.
Auger, who contributed the evening's only inspired passage - her still and gentle version of the opening lines from Brahms's ''Unbewegte, laue Luft'' (''Mild, unagitated air'').


Corrections
LEAD: The Advertising column in Business Day on Nov. 24 misidentified the parent company of Hanes Underwear.
It is the Sara Lee Corporation.


A Boot for Smooth Going
LEAD: SKI boots are probably the oddest footwear worn by modern man.
In some ways they're the man-made equivalent to webbed feet: they're not pretty nor particularly comfortable to walk around in, but they're not supposed to be.
They've been designed for function.
Ski boots have outer shells made of very stiff - almost rigid - plastic that come with buckles, knobs, dials and levers to make them fit tightly.


Warriors' Hopes Center On Sampson
LEAD: The trade that sent Ralph Sampson to the Golden State Warriors late Saturday night was the culmination of the three uneasy years that it took the Houston Rockets to decide that the 7-foot-4-inch Sampson was never meant to be a power forward but rather a center.


Business-Campus Ventures Grow
LEAD: Only four years ago, corporate efforts to enlist university researchers in the drive to make American industry more competitive seemed to face major difficulties.
But the problems - which mainly involved fears that these alliances would compromise basic academic freedoms - have proved relatively easy to resolve, and many research projects are not only flourishing but producing tangible results.

A 'Messiah' Cast of Thousands
LEAD: It is beyond Dolby.
It is beyond the best efforts of the audio engineers.
It is 3,000 people from top to bottom and side to side of a great auditorium, all lustily singing Handel's ''Messiah.'' The performers are the audience, making music together in total wraparound sound.

LEAD: THERE is an annual ritual among sailboat owners who face winter's onslaught of cold and snow.
They haul the boat out of the water, throw a canvas cloth across its deck, and store it somewhere until the next boating season.
But it doesn't have to be that way.

Winter Storm Sweeps Across the West
LEAD:  Katie Wolfe and her father, Fred, looking for a Christmas tree in Denver after two inches of snow fell there yesterday.
Up to 16 inches had fallen by last night in Colorado's southern mountains, and 18 more was forecast.
In New Mexico, where the storm caused the closing of Interstate 40 and other highways, 19 inches fell in Ruidoso and 18 inches at Escancia.


Eastern Utilities-Neco
LEAD: Eastern Utilities Associates said Friday that it had agreed to buy 52 percent of Neco Enterprises Inc. and will seek to buy the remainder of the company, which is the parent of the Newport Electric Company.
Eastern said it would buy the stake for $21 a share from David F. Larouche, Neco's largest investor who recently failed to win shareholder approval for a plan to liquidate the company.


Bacteria Test Is Delayed
LEAD: Tests of bacteria genetically altered to prevent frost damage to crops were postponed today because of gusty wind, a spokesman for Advanced Genetic Sciences said.
The experiment was tentatively rescheduled for Monday, said the spokesman.
The Oakland company wants to test the bacteria, which it calls Frostban, on an acre of strawberry plants near here to determine whether Frostban can prevent frost damage to fruit and nut crops.

Jesse Jackson, Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts and Senator Paul Simon of Illinois picking up most of the support.


Cello: Mihai Tetel in Debut
LEAD: MIHAI TETEL, a Rumanian cellist trained in Canada and now resident in New York, gave a debut recital of Haydn, Beethoven, Schumann, Debussy and Sarasate Saturday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall.
Mr.
Tetel is capable of making good musical sense, and he avoids many of the exaggerations of vibrato and phrasing that often cling to this repertory.

Light Streaks in Sky Caused by Breakup Of a Soviet Rocket
LEAD: People from Montana to Mississippi reported vivid streaks of light in the night sky Saturday after a disintegrating rocket that had been used to launch a Soviet satellite burned up in the atmosphere.
It put on a fireworks show with ''spectacular, beautiful colors.''

LEAD: Someone pushed over two decorative brick pillers in front of Gov.
Evan Mecham's home Tuesday evening, the police said.
Mr.
Mecham, who faces a drive to remove him from office, and his wife, Florence, were in Washington at the time.

Mecham was Governor-elect, prowlers entered through a hole they cut in the roof and walked about while the Mechams were asleep, the police said.

Market Place; 'January Effect' On Stock Prices
LEAD: WHAT is popularly known on Wall Street as the ''January effect'' has nothing to do with wintry weather.
It is a seasonal phenomenon in which stocks that have been hard hit by selling for tax purposes in December often stage a partial recovery the following month.

Bank Merger Approved
LEAD: The New York State Banking Board has approved a merger of Norstar Bancorp and the Fleet Financial Group of Providence, R.I.
The new company, to be called Fleet-Norstar Financial Group Inc., will have $25 billion in assets and will be among the 25 largest bank holding companies in the country.
Its headquarters will be in Albany and Providence.

Stage: 'Dummy Hoy'
LEAD: LARRY BAZZELL scores in ''The Signal Season of Dummy Hoy,'' but the play never makes it to first base.

They were devised, according to the script by Allen Meyer and Michael Nowak, to meet the needs of William Ellsworth (Dummy) Hoy, a good center fielder who could not hear or speak.

China-Taiwan Trade Up
LEAD: Indirect trade between China and Taiwan increased by 60 percent in the first half of the year and may reach a record $2 billion this year.
The China Daily, in a report on Sunday, attributed the increase in part to Taiwan's recent relaxation of a ban on all contacts with the mainland, and in part to rising protectionism in Taiwan's main market, the United States.

Steel Output Off 0.6%
LEAD: Steel production fell to 1.787 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, a decrease of six-tenths of 1 percent from the previous week's 1.798 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 82.8 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 83.3 percent in the previous week.

LEAD: A faint hope for progress on negotiating a cease-fire in Nicaragua faded today after the Sandinistas abruptly delayed a second round of talks here.

LEAD: Industrial output climbed a healthy four-tenths of 1 percent last month as American industry continued to show strong gains despite the October collapse of the stock market, the Government reported today.

Inventories Rise by 0.8% As Sales Drop Slightly
LEAD: Business inventories climbed a sharp eight-tenths of 1 percent in October, the biggest advance in five months, while total business sales dropped slightly during the month, the Commerce Department said today.


Brazil to Pay Interest Again
LEAD: Brazil, whose $113 billion debt is the largest in the developing world, will resume interest payments on its suspended foreign debt this month, a Finance Ministry spokesman said today.
Francisco Baker said by telephone from Brasilia that an agreement would be signed Tuesday in New York.

ARCO Withdraws
LEAD: ARCO, citing unfavorable market conditions, said it had withdrawn from a proposed pipeline project to transport natural gas from Alaska's North Slope.
The Los Angeles-based energy company said its decision would result in a $50 million charge against its fourth-quarter earnings.
The project began in 1977 and would bring natural gas to the continental United States through 4,800 miles of pipeline, including a 745-mile section to be built in Alaska.


Researcher Defends Theory on Early Tools
LEAD: A Canadian scientist, reacting to criticism of his research methods, said last week that his reported discovery of human blood on prehistoric stone tools was valid and based on ''very careful'' laboratory work using a ''very good'' analytical technique.

Opera: First 'Turandot' Of Metropolitan Season
LEAD: THE title role in ''Turandot'' requires at minimum a soprano voice able to give out the imperious cries of the cruel Chinese Princess with trumpet-like power.
If the two-dimensional character of Turandot can somehow, in addition, be projected with more than a bulldozer's nuances, all the better.
But penetrating power is the first requisite, the one upon which renowned Turandots of the past have built.

LEAD: Firefighters evacuated a Bronx elementary school for about an hour yesterday when a school employee became ill after inhaling carbon monoxide fumes, a Fire Department official said.
Students and faculty members of P.S. 19 in the Woodlawn section of the Bronx were evacuated as a precautionary measure.

One Good Piece of the Trade Bill
LEAD: Another year of battling over the Federal budget has pushed the foreign trade bill off until 1988.
Over all, that's fine; the protectionist legislation that might have passed is temporarily shelved.
But the delay also has a negative side effect, freezing the United States out of a global deal to harmonize trade regulation.

Uspci, a hazardous waste management company, has rejected the bid.

Space Probe Turns 20
LEAD: ONE of NASA's longest-lived space probes celebrated its 20th year of operation Sunday.
The craft, Pioneer 8, has traveled about 11 billion miles and has helped push back the frontiers of astrophysics by providing scientists with a stream of data on solar flares and how they interact with the Earth and its magnetic fields.

It is 24.

LEAD: A French espionage agent confined to a French atoll in the South Pacific for his role in the bombing of a Greenpeace ship in New Zealand was flown to Paris today for medical tests.

LEAD: As much as Americans treasure freedom of speech, they also treasure the freedom to hear.
But the freedom to hear dissent has been seriously compromised since passage of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act of 1952.
One provision allows the Government to exclude foreign visitors on the basis of public statements they might make in the United States.

LEAD: Henry Anatole Grunwald testified last Wednesday before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on his nomination to become the United States Ambassador to Austria and on the State Department's decision to bar the Austrian President, Kurt Waldheim, from entry into this country because of his record in World War II.


CONVENTIONAL ARMS ARE KEY IN NEXT ACCORD, REAGAN SAYS
LEAD: President Reagan, trying to reassure the European allies, said today that the United States intends to strengthen its conventional military forces in Europe and modernize its chemical weapons before it reaches any further arms control agreements with the Soviet Union.


Righetti's Situation Becomes Confusing
LEAD: Confusion erupted yesterday over the Japanese offer to Dave Righetti that his agent says is worth $10 million for two years.
The United States representative of the Tokyo Giants, the team that reportedly made the offer, denied that the Giants have made an offer.
But Bill Goodstein, the pitcher's agent, who has refused to identify the team, said that Righetti is ''seriously considering going to Japan'' and will make a decision in the next few days.

Kuwait Lifts B.P. Stake
LEAD: The Kuwaiti Government said today that it had raised its stake in the British Petroleum Company above 13 percent.
The Kuwait Investment Office, which invests the Persian Gulf state's petrodollars worldwide, began buying B.P. stock last month.
B.P. said the Kuwaiti agency now holds 13.07 percent.

LEAD: If the battle of Waterloo was won on the playing fields of Eton, it may be that the international trade wars of the 1990's and beyond will be decided at the 1988 Olympic Games in Calgary, Alberta, and Seoul, South Korea.


Volume Declines At Charles Schwab
LEAD: Charles Schwab &amp; Company disclosed that it had postponed the opening of a new branch office in London because of a sharp decline in the discount brokerage's trading volume since the market collapse in October.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Schwab said its trading volume for the last two weeks of November was ''significantly below the average for the first six months of 1987.

TCA is led by William P. Lyons, a professor of business at Yale

Denis Sanders Dies; Film Director Won 2 Academy Awards
LEAD: Denis Sanders, a film maker who directed the debut performances of Robert Redford and George Hamilton and who won an Academy Award for the short film that served as his master's degree thesis, died Thursday of an apparent heart attack at his home in San Diego.
He was 58 years old.

Louis Graeler, Violinist, 74
LEAD: Louis Graeler, a violinist and member of the Kroll Quartet for 20 years, died of cardiac arrest Dec. 8 in Tokyo, where he lived.

The Murder of Eleni
LEAD: On Aug. 28, 1948, Eleni Gatzoyiannis, a peasant woman 41 years old, was murdered in the tiny stone village of Lia in the Greek mountains.
She was shot by a firing squad, finished off with a bullet to the head.
Her body was thrown into a ravine.
Years passed.
Her son Nicholas grew to manhood in America.

Sports People; Pirates Hire Ward
LEAD: The Pittsburgh Pirates announced yesterday that Jay Ward, the Yankees' hitting instructor last season, has been named manager of the Salem Buccaneers, the Pirates' Class A farm club in the Carolina League.
Ward, 49 years old, managed minor league teams in the Cincinnati Reds' organization in 1985-86 and in the Philadelphia Phillies' organization in 1983-84.


Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. What is quicksand?
A.
Quicksand occurs when a mass of smooth, fine-grained sand is saturated with water.
Such sand yields readily to pressure and will engulf objects on its surface.


Dow Up 65.82 Points For 7th-Largest Gain
LEAD: Stock prices surged broadly higher yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 65.82 points, or 3.53 percent, to close at 1,932.86, extending last week's record 100.3-point advance.

Surviving in the Cold: Strategies Revealed in New Studies
LEAD: AS winter grips the fields and forests of the north, life seems to be put on hold.
The trees have lost their leaves, the food factories that nourish them and provide sustenance and shelter for birds and insects.
Adult insects die, leaving eggs and larvae in protected nooks and crannies to start the next generation.

Ms. Holtzman's Rush to Judgment
LEAD: Adjudicatory officials, not being wholly free to defend themselves, are entitled to receive the support of the bar against unjust criticism.
While a lawyer . . . has a right to criticize such officials publicly he should be certain of the merit of his complaint. - Canon 8 of the American Bar Association's Model Code of Professional Responsibility.

LEAD: THE New York City Ballet's annual run of George Balanchine's ''Nutcracker'' may now seem a tradition.

Biotechnology Merger Set
LEAD: Advanced Genetic Sciences Inc., which conducted the first outdoor experiment with genetically modified bacteria, has agreed to merge with the DNA Plant Technology Corporation, another biotechnology company.
Under a tentative agreement an- DNA Plant's stock gained 12.5 cents in over-the-counter trading today to close at $4.125 a share, giving the deal a value of about $37 million Advance
