LEAD: Wagner College players and students with their N.C.A.A.
Division III trophy yesterday outside Staten Island Borough Hall.
The football team received an official reception there after a motorcade from the Wagner College campus.
The Wagner team defeated Dayton, 19-3, in Phenix City, Ala., Saturday to capture the crown, the school's first national title.


Southmark, I.C.H. End Merger Plan
LEAD: The Southmark Corporation and the I.C.H.
Corporation said they had ended their plan to merge, which had been announced Nov. 15.
The merger would have created an insurance and financial services company with more than $20 billion in assets.
The companies said they were dropping the plan because ''we cannot ignore the dissatisfaction with the merger as registered by the securities' markets.


How Some Bacteria Outwit Body's Defenses
LEAD: UNDER a microscope, the three bacteria look exactly alike.
Yet one causes food poisoning, another causes typhoid fever, and the third causes a blood infection.


A Local Hero's Problems Cause Shock
LEAD: Lou Piccola has coached basketball at Xaverian High School in Brooklyn for 11 years.
In that time, he has worked with dozens of young athletes.
None of them, he said, impressed him as much as Chris Mullin did.


Youth Cleared in a Bias Attack
LEAD: A white youth accused of taking part in what the authorities said was a bias-related attack on two Hispanic teen-agers was found not guilty yesterday by a judge in Queens, who said that the defendant had been a victim of mistaken identity.

LEAD: A London newspaper quoted unidentified sources today as saying that Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian spiritual leader, was in a coma and that a foreign medical team had flown to Teheran to attend to him.

LEAD: The Western Union Corporation said yesterday that its shareholders had approved a restructuring plan intended to save the struggling telecommunications concern from a Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing.

LEAD: Two brothers who played on Troy State University's championship football team were among four people killed today when a car in which they were passengers collided with a tractor-trailer, authorities said.

Washington Talk: Briefing; Funderburk Is Back
LEAD: Back from the forgotten-but-not-gone category comes David B. Funderburk, who served the Reagan Administration as Ambassador to Rumania from 1981 to 1985, then left in a huff complaining of ''shocking collaboration'' between his superiors at the State Department and the Bucharest regime of President Nicolae Ceausescu.


Ray Malavasi Is Dead; Former Coach of Rams
LEAD: Ray Malavasi, who coached the Los Angeles Rams to their only Super Bowl appearance, died today of a heart attack, a spokesman for Western Medical Center said.
Mr.
Malavasi was 57 years old.


William L. Greene, 71; Figure in Court Rulings
LEAD: William Lewis Greene, an aeronautical and civil engineer whose security clearance was denied in the early 1950's, resulting in two important Supreme Court decisions, died of a heart attack Dec. 9 at his home in Bath, Me.
He was 71 years old.
Mr.
Greene was an executive with a Navy contractor until 1951 when, as a result of the denial of his security clearance by the Defense Department, he was forced to leave.


Western Union Note Offering
LEAD: The Western Union Telegraph Corporation has arranged a $500 million offering of five-year speculative grade notes through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., a Drexel official said late yesterday.


Sinai Reported To Weigh Shift
LEAD: Allen Sinai, the chief economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers, whose views have commanded a wide following, is considering a new position at Shearson that, some sources at the firm say, may resemble an independent consulting arrangement.


For Ben &amp; Jerry, A Frustrating Bid To Aid Subways
LEAD: Last spring Ben Cohen went to catch a train at 59th Street and Columbus Circle, heading for the Brooklyn Botanical Garden, and he was dumbstruck by ''the filth, the disrepair, the degrading effect on your sensibilities.''


Israeli Prices Up 1.6%
LEAD: Israel said today that the cost of living rose 1.6 percent in November, and experts forecast that the 1987 annual figure would drop to about 16 percent, from 19.7 percent in all of 1986.
Annual inflation has steadily declined since Israel initiated an emergency economic program in mid-1985 to halt runaway inflation, which topped 400 percent in all of 1984.


In Saigon '87, Ho, Ho, Ho, Ho Chi Minh
LEAD: At the Dong Khanh Bakery in Cholon the other day, the pastry chefs got to work on the first of the season's traditional French Christmas logs.


Mexico's Tough Economic Crisis
LEAD: The Mexican Government is struggling to regain control of an economic crisis that has unleashed a new round of record inflation, caused Mexicans to shun the peso and send their savings abroad, and stirred up labor discontent.


Happiness Is a Warm Dessert
LEAD: MOST of us are suckers for warm desserts.
Whether it's homemade apple pie, a sophisticated souffle or that seldom-seen classic crepes, we are almost powerless to resist a still-warm-from-the-oven or stove-top sweet at the end of a meal.

LEAD: The Yankees, who were one phone call and $35,000 away from solving a pressing need for a left-handed hitter, apparently procrastinated too long Monday afternoon.

Nicaragua to Keep Big Military Force, Its Leader Declares
LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that Nicaragua would continue to maintain a large standing army and a force of 600,000 or more men in reserve, even if it ''normalizes'' relations with the United States and its neighbors.


A Seven-Course Feast of Fish
LEAD: IT is a Christmas Eve ritual handed down from mother to son.
Every year, Ed Giobbi, the artist and cookbook author, serves a holiday feast of seven fish dishes (seven for the seven sacraments).
Each dish is cooked in a different manner -broiled, fried, baked and so on - or uses a different main ingredient.


Transit Scandal: Do Arrest Incentives Motivate the Police or Invite Abuse?
LEAD: The four New York City transit police officers accused of making scores of false or improper arrests worked for a commander who gave the best jobs to his most ''active'' officers, those who made the most arrests and issued the most summonses.

LEAD: Cuban troops started to patrol southern Angola this week with orders to engage South African troops in combat, Angolan authorities here say.

LEAD: Congressional leaders said today that a Nicaraguan defector's assertion that Managua intends to enlarge its military appeared to be turning Congress in favor of renewing non-arms aid for the contras.

LEAD: French and British military officials have made ''good progress'' with discussions on the possible joint development of a new air-launched nuclear missile that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher says is permissible under the new Soviet-American arms treaty.

LEAD: After a visit in a cold, driving rain to inspect ''Tilted Arc,'' the Richard Serra sculpture that sweeps across 26 Federal Plaza in downtown Manhattan, a committee of art experts and public officials from around the United States decided yesterday that the work could not be removed or relocated without destroying its artistic value.

LEAD: A Federal jury found the leader of the nation's largest Hare Krishna community not guilty of arson and fraud charges today but convicted a follower of burning an apartment building to collect $40,000 in insurance.


RESULTS
LEAD:  N.H.L.

The Flyers passed the Pittsburgh Penguins in the standings and are in third place in the Patrick Division.
Huffman broke a 2-2 tie at 8 minutes 48 seconds of the second period when he tapped in Pelle Eklund's pass for his second goal of the season.

LEAD: The Amoco Corporation's board approved a $3.8 billion capital and exploration budget for 1988, a 17 percent increase over the company's $3.25 billion budget in 1987.

LEAD: Judge M. W. Deo said today that he would announce on Thursday whether the Union Carbide Corporation should pay interim relief to victims of the Dec. 3, 1984, gas disaster at Bhopal, the world's worst industrial accident.

Joseph Mercy Hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich., said last night that Bo Schembechler's prognosis for recovery was good after the Michigan football coach had undergone his second quadruple heart bypass operation.
Schembechler, 58, was listed in satisfactory condition in the intensive-care unit, where he underwent the seven-hour procedure.

BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1987
LEAD:  International


Concert: I Cantori, Choir
LEAD: AMONG this city's many small choirs, the 19-member ensemble called I Cantori di New York is distinctly one of the best.
Its concert Monday at Merkin Concert Hall, under the direction of Bart Folse, was a display not just of well-chosen and well-blended voices (I especially liked hearing a tenor section with some juice in the tone) but of thoughtful preparation and carefully structured phrasing.


Film: 'Moonstruck,' With Italians in Love
LEAD: THE moon hits your eye like a big pizza pie in ''Moonstruck,'' and a lot of other things do too. ''Moonstruck'' is so heavily ethnic that it begins with Dean Martin's rendition of ''That's Amore,'' and there's plenty more where that came from.
With its accordion music, its bits of dialect and its love of opera (a key segment of the story unfolds at a Metropolitan Opera performance of ''La Boheme''), ''Moonstruck'' clearly means to celebrate all things Italian.


Nets Hold Off Spurs to End Streak
LEAD: With Buck Williams missing from the lineup for the first time in seven years and with Mike Gminski missing his beard for the first time in two years, the Nets ended their losing streak at 11 games tonight with a 104-98 victory over the San Antonio Spurs at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

LEAD: The broadest measure of the nation's foreign trade showed a record $43.4 billion quarterly deficit last summer, as the United States ran a deficit with the rest of the world in investment earnings for the first time in 29 years.

LEAD: An unusual independent human rights seminar ended today with some of its leaders, united by experience in Soviet prisons and labor camps, parting ways over how to coexist with the Government that imprisoned and freed them.

The move pushed the peso's value against the dollar down by 18 percent.

LEAD: Iranian war vessels raked the 102,088-ton Greek tanker Ariadne with grenades and machine-gun fire today, forcing most of the crew to abandon ship, and in a second attack tore it nearly in half with a missile.

Topics of The Times; Gift Gimmick, Hard to Bear
LEAD: 'Tis the season of gift-giving, a joyous thing - except when public-relations gimmicks come disguised as gifts.
The 1987 booby prize in this category goes to the YMCA of Greater New York.


Mura Dehn, Dancer, As Subject and Chronicler
FOR many dancegoers, Mura Dehn is known, a little vaguely, as a woman who had something to do with film and black dancers.
But the Film Forum is doing something about that, with a double feature consisting of ''In a Jazz Way,'' a short film on Miss Dehn by Louise Ghertler and Pamela Katz, and a two-hour excerpt from ''The Spirit Moves: A History of Black Social Dance on Film,'' a documentary by Miss Dehn.
The program opens today for a two-week run at Film Forum 1.
''In a Jazz Way,'' shot in 1985, offers a tantalizing look at Miss Dehn.
It has the look of a documentary that originally had more ambitious things on its mind, but Miss Ghertler and Miss Katz do give us an undiluted dose of Miss Dehn, who died in February.
We see her at her kitchen table, in her apartment in Washington Heights, reminiscing about her youth in Vienna and about her work recording and preserving the artistry of some of the great known and anonymous dancers of the Savoy Ballroom in Harlem.


26 Months In a Prison, Wrongly
LEAD: After being imprisoned 26 months as a convicted rapist, Marion Coakley heard himself declared an innocent man yesterday by a judge and prosecutors in a brief hearing in a Bronx courtroom.


Role of the Police Studied In Death of Bronx Woman
LEAD: Bronx prosecutors and at least three city agencies are investigating the death of a 28-year-old Bronx woman who, according to her companion and lawyers for her family, was severely beaten earlier this month in a confrontation with the police.
The police deny those allegations.


WINE TALK
LEAD: The great chefs of France share various faults, but excess modesty has never been one of them.
Eagerly do they lend their names to cookbooks, videotapes, canned foie gras, nonstick pans, Beaujolais and, in one extreme case, tennis togs.
And who is to say them nay?
After long years in the kitchen it's hard to resist a little easy money and fame, even if it does tend to look commercial.

U.S. Cutting Sugar Imports In Blow to Trading Partners
LEAD: The United States will cut its 1988 sugar imports by 25 percent, to the lowest level in more than 100 years, the Reagan Administration announced today.
The action is expected to increase prices for consumers and hurt the debt-burdened economies of some of America's trading partners among developing nations.

LEAD: Gold prices tumbled and the dollar firmed in foreign exchange trading yesterday in response to another sharp drop in oil prices.

Economic Scene; Markets Grope For Confidence
LEAD: TWO months after the stock market's deep dive, the economy is holding up remarkably well.
The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that American industry was operating at 81.7 percent of capacity in November, two-tenths of 1 percent higher than in October.
Output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities was up four-tenths in November, after a nine-tenths gain in October.

LEAD: Alabama must forfeit more than $250,000 in basketball receipts for using two ineligible players in the 1987 N.C.A.A.
Tournament, the National Collegiate Athletic Association announced today.


William E. Park, 78; Simmons College Head
LEAD: William Edgar Park, retired president of Simmons College, died Dec. 7 at Falmouth Hospital in Falmouth, Mass.
He was 78 years old.
Mr.
Park, who lived in Cotuit, Mass., was president of the Simmons from 1955 to 1970.
As president he oversaw a self-study curriculum that expanded the number of departments from 9 to 18 and changed the college into a predominantly residential campus by adding three dormitories.


Market Place; Banks' Reserves And Latin Loans
LEAD: AFTER the Bank of Boston's decision to write off 20 percent of its Latin American loans and to establish reserves equal to more than half its remaining Latin loans, many investors are wondering whether the other money-center banks will follow.

LEAD: The Wickes Companies said it planned to sell its lumber division to a group of former managers.

Terms were not disclosed, but an analyst estimated the price for Wickes Lumber at around $200 million.

LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it would allow continued use of the herbicide alachlor with some restrictions.
After four years of study, the agency has decided that the chemical does not pose an ''unreasonable'' risk of cancer in humans.

BASEBALL EXPANSION
LEAD: Baseball Commissioner Peter Ueberroth made no commitments on expansion at a meeting in Washington yesterday with a group of Senators interested in securing major league teams.
Following a meeting with 10 Senators representing Colorado, Arizona, Ohio, Indiana and Florida, as well as the delegate from the District of Columbia, Ueberroth said that baseball wanted to expand, but that it had no timetable and had made no commitments to any city.

Many of the so-called classics are not only popular, they're also cheap to rerun.

A New Use For Sludge: To Make Oil
LEAD: OVER the years, cities have tried all manner of methods to dispose of sludge, the end product of the typical sewage treatment plant.
They have burned it, buried it, dumped it in the ocean, spread it on farms and even made bricks of it.


HAITIAN GENERAL DISAVOWS KILLINGS
LEAD: Lieut.
Gen.
Henri Namphy, the head of the provisional Government, has disavowed all responsibility for the massacre that disrupted Haiti's presidential elections two weeks ago and disparaged the Roman Catholic Church, Haitian political leaders and the civilians who organized the election.


49ers Lose 2 Players
LEAD: The San Francisco 49ers' euphoria over a 41-0 victory Monday night against the Chicago Bears, gave way to mild depression yesterday when it was announced Joe Montana may miss the remaining two regular-season games and the top linebacker, Keena Turner, was undergoing knee surgery.
Montana has a torn hamstring that definitely will keep him out of Sunday's game against the Atlanta Falcons, and there's ''a good chance'' he'll miss the final game against the Los Angeles Rams, Coach Bill Walsh said.


Israeli Force Raids Guerrilla Bases in South Lebanon
LEAD: Israeli troops backed by tanks and helicopter gunships attacked guerrilla bases in southeast Lebanon today.


Van Ellis Huff, Inventor, 93
LEAD: Van Ellis Huff, inventor of the jalousie window, died at home here last Thursday.
He was 93 years old.


Mehta, With Buts, Talks of Leaving the Philharmonic in 1991
LEAD: Zubin Mehta said yesterday that he would retire as music director of the New York Philharmonic at the end of the 1990-91 season.
Then he said he couldn't entirely preclude the possibility that he might change his mind.
Then, after a nervous telephone call from Philharmonic officials, he said he really hadn't come to any decision at all.

LEAD: When Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev of the Soviet Union marched into the Pentagon last week to meet with Adm.
William J. Crowe Jr. and other members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, almost everything he said and did was shrouded in secrecy.

College Hockey Notebook; Little Man Is Big Again on Ice
LEAD: Although the typical college athlete in the last generation has grown about 3 inches and added 20 pounds, there is still a place for the smaller performer in hockey.


Youth Slain in Hiccup Cure
LEAD: A high school senior shot his friend to death in an attempt to cure his hiccups by scaring him, the police said Monday.
The 19-year-old senior, David E. Duquette, of Glocester, told the police the gun he was holding on Nicholas Lovell, 16, went off accidentally.
Mr.
Duquette was charged with murder.


SENATORS PREDICT FAST CONFIRMATION OF JUDGE KENNEDY
LEAD: Judge Anthony M. Kennedy completed his testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee today to the congratulations of both Democrats and Republicans who predicted that he would easily be confirmed to the Supreme Court.

LEAD: Six of the seven candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination debated tonight in one of the poorest areas of the country and agreed that a range of new Federal programs was needed to help the economy on both sides of the Mexican border.


A Brighter Future for American Orange Juice
LEAD: Three new varieties of oranges have been developed in a 25-year research project.
They should deliver brighter juice to American consumers and help domestic growers compete against imports, the Agriculture Department recently announced.


Citicorp's Auction Rates
LEAD: Interest rates rose for the third consecutive week at Citicorp's auction yesterday of new commercial paper.


Repairing the Big Board
LEAD: If one benefit has emerged from the stock market crash, it is that the inadequacy of the specialist system, long known to market insiders, is now out in the open.

LEAD: ''Kill us all!'' taunted the young Palestinians throwing rocks at the Israeli soldiers. ''Come and kill us all or get out!''

LEAD: Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company has agreed to acquire Pinstripes Petites, a women's specialty-store chain based in Minneapolis, for an undisclosed sum.
It is Sears's second specialty-store acquisition in recent months - the first was Eye-Care Centers of America Inc., a 41-store chain based in San Antonio.

The Beef and Gary Hart
LEAD: What did people do yesterday when they heard that Gary Hart had re-entered the Democratic Presidential race?
Again and again, they laughed.
Sometimes the laughter was nervous, incredulous: Is this some kind of practical joke?
Or it was cynical: He must be after Federal matching funds to reduce his campaign debt.


Sins of the Summit
LEAD: Among the best ways to sabotage the frail process of Soviet-American summitry is for participants to say one thing in private and another in public.
Another is to pass over tough subjects in private and then explode them publicly.
With Mikhail Gorbachev's jetstream barely dissipated, President Reagan has done both.


HART, IN SURPRISE, RESUMES CAMPAIGN FOR WHITE HOUSE
LEAD: Gary Hart resumed his Presidential campaign today, shocking Democratic leaders and the six others seeking the party's nomination.
He vowed to ''let the people decide'' on his candidacy.


Bridge: Nassau-Suffolk Event Ends In Time for the 1988 Version
LEAD: The final of the Nassau-Suffolk Double Knockout Team Championship was completed a week ago at the Grand Club in Franklin Square, L.I., with victory going to Alan Tucker of Great Neck, L.I., Harry Stappenbeck of Uniondale, L.I., and Jim Becker, Howard Chandross and Josh Parker, all of Manhattan.


South Korean Vote Reaches to Games
LEAD: When the citizens of South Korea vote to elect a new president today, they will also be starting a process that will determine whether the 1988 Seoul Olympics will be staged successfully or at all.

Dr.
Herbert Anderson.

It is a delightful development.

LEAD: In his first trip abroad since becoming Prime Minister of Japan, Noboru Takeshita told the heads of six Southeast Asian nations today that his Government would reject remilitarization and assist the region in greater economic development.

LEAD: The financier Carl C. Icahn said yesterday that he would oppose any reorganization plan that gives a committee of Texaco shareholders the authority to appoint members to the company's board.

Fay Accepts Match Race
LEAD: Michael Fay, a banker from New Zealand, gave up his demand for a multinational America's Cup regatta and agreed today to the San Diego Yacht Club's condition that it race only against Fay's boat for the cup next year.

Film: 'Broadcast News,' Comedy
LEAD: THERE once was a time when big news events had the power to stun and, sometimes, to cause a certain amount of anxiety.
Wars, earthquakes, airplane crashes, stock market busts, mass-murder sprees, kidnappings, duplicity in positions of public trust, political assassinations.
These things could upset daily routine.


Officer Found Guilty In Off-Duty Shooting
LEAD: A New York City transit police officer was convicted of misdemeanor charges yesterday in the off-duty shooting of a Brooklyn man last year, which prosecutors characterized as a racial incident.
However, the officer was acquitted of more serious felony assault charges.

LEAD: I. William Fishkind, an executive with the National Association of Securities Dealers in Washington, the regulatory organization for the securities industry, died of cancer Friday at his home in Burke, Va.
He was 53 years old.

LEAD: The Governors of Maryland, Pennsylvania and Virginia, along with the Mayor of Washington and the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, signed an agreement today on to a regional effort to clean up and protect the Chesapeake Bay, one of the largest and most polluted ecosystems in the country.

LEAD: One of Schembechler's foremost Big Ten rivals, former Ohio State coach Earle Bruce has turned down the head-coaching position at Kansas, university officials said yesterday.
The Kansas athletic director, Bob Frederick, said Bruce decided against accepting the offer to succeed Bob Valesente at the Big Eight Conference school because ''we could not resolve certain contractual issues surrounding Bruce's previous contract settlement and aren't able, therefore, to pursue the matter further.

LEAD: Marc Sullivan, a catcher for the Boston Red Sox the last three years, with more skill behind the plate than at it, has been traded to Houston.

Lonnie Smith, the veteran outfielder who returned to the team last season after failing to attract interest on the free-agent market, was released by the Kansas City Royals.

LEAD: The only gunman who survived the attack on the Rome airport two years ago in which 16 people were killed went on trial today at the Rebibbia maximum-security prison.


Music: Oratorio Society In Handel's 'Messiah'
LEAD: EVER since its founding in 1873, the Oratorio Society of New York has performed Handel's ''Messiah'' each holiday season, all but the first 18 of those years in Carnegie Hall.
The group sang the oratorio there on Monday evening, with Lyndon Woodside, its music director, conducting a version full of vigor and buoyed by the presence of several able soloists.

LEAD: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday in a seesaw session.
The Dow Jones industrial average ended 8.62 points higher at 1,941.48, bringing its advance in the last two days to nearly 75 points.

Celebrity Bake Sale
LEAD: Joanne Woodward will donate a cake, as will Liza Minnelli, Kathleen Turner, Woody Allen, Jerome Robbins and other celebrities who are to take part in a benefit bake sale tomorrow from 4 to 7 P.M. at the Martha Graham Center for Contemporary Dance, 316 East 63d Street.
Almost 100 cakes have been donated by individuals and restaurants for the sale, whose proceeds will benefit the Martha Graham Dance Company.


Panel Says New York Athletic Club Discriminates Against Women
LEAD: The New York City Human Rights Commission said yesterday that it has found that the New York Athletic Club discriminates against women in violation of a city law, and must develop a plan to end the discrimination or face a judge's order to do so.


ASIANS END TALKS IN MOOD OF RELIEF
LEAD: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia put into words today the relief felt at the uneventful end of a two-day meeting of six Southeast Asian leaders, a gathering held reluctantly and with unusually tight security in this volatile capital.

INVESTORS RETREATING FROM FOREIGN MARKETS
LEAD: The worldwide bull market made global securities dealing a hot investment concept in the 1980's.
But with the October collapse of markets worldwide, professional and individual investors are pulling back from what they now fear has become a ''globalization of insecurities.''


OPEC Pact Sends Oil Price Down
LEAD: Oil prices fell again on world markets yesterday after OPEC decided to extend its current production and pricing levels through the middle of next year.


The Indian 'War' Is Bitter; Can the Few Survive?
LEAD: Amid charges of conspiracy, forgery and espionage, a fierce battle has erupted between Brazil's Roman Catholic Church and powerful conservative groups that want commercial mining to be permitted on lands traditionally occupied by Indians.


Pinky Tomlin, Songwriter, 80
LEAD: Pinky Tomlin, who wrote the 1930's hit ''The Object of My Affection'' and dozens of other tunes, died of a heart attack at a medical center in North Hollywood Saturday.
He was 80 years old.


U.S. Weighs Turning Agency Into Private Health Institute
LEAD: Federal budget officials have drafted a proposal to convert the world-famous laboratories of the National Institutes of Health into a private research center financed with money from the Government, industry and foundations, according to confidential budget documents.

LEAD: In a warehouse of the District of Columbia Public Works Department on a small side street in the Northeast section of the capital, amid spare street lights, signs, posts and paint, is a giant steel cage containing thousands of flags from nations throughout the world.

LEAD: President Reagan today signed a five-year extension of the independent counsel law, despite what he said were ''my very strong doubts about its constitutionality.''

LEAD: Pravda does not carry cigarette advertising.
But last month it became a vehicle for America's largest tobacco company, Philip Morris U.S.A.


Light-Truck Sales Lead 7.1% Rise at Car Makers
LEAD: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks totaled 299,262 units in early December, up 7.1 percent from the corresponding period a year ago, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

LEAD: Treasury bond prices rose for the second consecutive day, following the lead set by declining oil prices.


A Christmas Goose at the Ready
LEAD:  FOR the traditional Christmas goose to be on the family table, orders should be placed with butchers now.
A new source is the branch of the Ottomanelli Brothers butcher shops at Macy's Herald Square.
Fresh geese, ranging from 8 to 12 pounds, are $3.49 a pound.
Macy's will also cook the bird for $15; call 212-967-4930 to order.

LEAD: Mildred S. Simon, a founder of a chain of self-service discount stores, died of lung cancer Monday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 88 years old.

LEAD: With the agreement of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, the former Progress Club at Central Park West and 88th Street, now a five-story wing of the Walden School, is to be torn down to make way for a 23-story apartment building.

LEAD: West Virginia officials said today that they hoped to have enough money by Wednesday to cover paychecks this week for 40,000 state workers.

LEAD: The Mellon Bank Corporation said yesterday that it expected to report a fourth-quarter loss of $220 million, which would bring its net loss to $830 million for the year.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that a strong nuclear arsenal was crucial for Western security after intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Europe are destroyed.


Opera: Dimitrova Makes Met Debut in 'Turandot'
LEAD: THE title role in ''Turandot'' requires at minimum a soprano voice able to give out the imperious cries of the cruel Chinese Princess with trumpet-like power.
If the two-dimensional character of Turandot can somehow, in addition, be projected with more than a bulldozer's nuances, all the better.
But penetrating power is the first requisite, the one upon which renowned Turandots of the past have built.


Ford-Soviet Link
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company is considering a joint automotive venture with the Soviet Union, but the proposals are at a very early stage, Ford's vice chairman, Harold A. Poling, said.
Soviet officials approached the second-largest United States auto maker four weeks ago and outlined a ''large range of possibilities,'' from components to full assembly of vehicles, Mr.


Doctors' Quandary: Picking Who Gets a Heart
LEAD: Every Friday morning at 7 o'clock, heart transplant surgeons at Presbyterian Hospital gather with other staff members in a small 14th-floor conference room to decide over coffee and doughnuts the fate of dozens of patients waiting for a transplanted heart.


Topics of The Times; Truth in Juice
LEAD: It tastes sweet and looks like juice, but a popular apple drink sold in supermarkets contains only 10 percent real fruit juice.
The rest is sugar and water.
Consumers have a right to accurate information about the content of diluted fruit ''punches,'' ''ades'' and ''cocktails'' that compete on store shelves with real juice.


Eating Well
LEAD: ''WHAT is this stuff,'' said a shopper to no one in particular - a fairly common occurence in the supermarket.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Sports Pages yesterday about the Giants' problems incorrectly named the team's next opponent.
The Giants play the Green Bay Packers on Saturday.


ROCK: RICHARD BARONE
LEAD: RICHARD BARONE'S performance at the Bottom Line on Monday was an impressive reminder that in pop music, as in other arts, talent has a way of surviving changes in fashion.


NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1987
LEAD:  International A3-17


Real Estate; A New Look For the Old White Castle
LEAD: Since 1932, a White Castle restaurant has been on the northwest corner of Northern and Bell Boulevards in the Bayside section of Queens.
Today, two of the restaurant chain's unmistakable white porcelain and notched-roof buildings are squeezed onto that site.


Sihanouk Plans to Talk With Cambodian Chief
LEAD: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the former leader of Cambodia, announced another about-face today and said he would meet with the Prime Minister of Cambodia's Vietnam-backed Government after all.


A User-Friendly Keyboard
LEAD: Hunt-and-peck typists who feel inadequate because they are not proficient at touch typing may now have something to be smug about.
After studying touch typists, who use all fingers instead of just one or two, a Tucson, Ariz., group has concluded that they must cock their left wrists slightly to type and could be damaging tendons and nerves.


Trump Wins Approval To Shift Resorts License
LEAD: The Casino Control Commission today unanimously approved Donald J. Trump's request for permission to close the Resorts International casino when he is ready to replace it with a much larger casino, the Taj Mahal.


Congressmen Delete Martha Graham Grant
LEAD: A joint Congressional panel voted today to delete a grant of more than $4 million for the Martha Graham Dance Company.


Slot Machines Seized At Indian Reservation
LEAD: About 200 state troopers raided six businesses on the St.
Regis Mohawk Indian Reservation early today and seized slot machines and other gambling devices, the state police said.

While other musicians are busily resurrecting forgotten works, young pianists remain on the whole unusually faithful to the mainstream.

Halliburton In Expansion
LEAD: The Halliburton Company agreed to acquire 60 percent of Geophysical Services Inc., a unit of Texas Instruments Inc., the two companies said today.
Both companies are based in Dallas.


Stage: 'Voice of Prairie,' Celebrating Radio Days
LEAD: ''The Voice of the Prairie'' celebrates a time of itinerant radio, when, before there were networks, sponsors and regulating agencies, a broadcaster could be a one-man road-show radio station.
Traveling from town to town, such an entrepreneur could discover banjo players and blues singers or, in the case of the hero of John Olive's new play, a farmer named Davey (Michael Countryman) telling shaggy stories about his boyhood adventures.

LEAD: Dennis A. Volman, a reporter for The Christian Science Monitor, died of cancer Monday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center.
He was 37 years old and lived in Washington.


Sugar Plan Advances
LEAD: Congressional negotiators tentatively approved a sugar re-export program today for Caribbean countries and the Philippines that could soften the blow of sharply lower United States sugar import quotas next year.


2 Divided Camps of Bishops Form Over Catholic AIDS Policy Paper
LEAD: In statements issued by Roman Catholic chanceries from Boston to Los Angeles in recent days, bishops have been lining up on either side of the controversy over a policy paper on AIDS released last week by the administrative board of the United States Catholic Conference.


Film: 'The Dead,' by Huston
LEAD: ''ONE by one we're all becoming shades,'' says Gabriel Conroy, looking out into Dublin's bleak winter dawn.
Gretta, the wife he loves and suddenly realizes he has never known, lies asleep on the bed nearby.
His own life now seems paltry: ''Better pass boldly into that other world, in the full glory of some passion, than fade and wither dismally with age.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A front-page picture caption yesterday about the lighting of a Hanukkah menorah near New York City misidentified the site.
It was the Solomon Schechter Day School of Suffolk County, not a day-care center.

LEAD: The Kean administration and Senate Democrats reached a compromise today in a money dispute that had threatened to kill the Governor's proposal that would give the state power to take over failing school districts.

LEAD: Septima Poinsette Clark, a teacher who had been active in civil rights activities since World War I, died Tuesday at a nursing home on John's Island.
She was 89 years old.
Born in Charleston, the daughter of a former slave, Mrs.
Clark was widely recognized for her work in civil rights.
In 1964 she accompanied the Rev.


Soviet Links Iran Embargo to U.N. Force
LEAD: The Reagan Administration said today that the Soviet Union had expressed a willingness to consider an arms embargo against Iran, provided it was enforced by a naval blockade under the United Nations flag.
The Administration expressed reservations but stopped short of rejecting the proposal outright.


Bridge: A Play by Edgar Kellerman Recalls the Marshal of France
LEAD: Whist was popular in Western Europe in the 18th century, and it takes only a small effort of anachronistic imagination to assume that the game was bridge.


Corrections
LEAD: An article from Manila yesterday about a Southeast Asian summit conference misstated the relative size of the Indonesian military.
It is the largest among the members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations; Vietnam's military is the largest in Southeast Asia.

LEAD: Judge Anthony M. Kennedy came across in Senate testimony this week as a man with a subtle mind who had no preconceived answers to the hardest questions he would face on the Supreme Court.

Peanut Quota Increases
LEAD: The national poundage quota for the 1988 peanut crop will be 1,402,200 tons, an increase of 46,700 tons from this year's level, Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng announced Tuesday.
By law, the annual quota is set at a level equal to the estimated quantity of peanuts that will be needed for edible uses, seed and related purposes in the coming year.


Trading Fair With Brazil
LEAD: Impatient with Brazil's fierce protectionism on computers and software, President Reagan last month ordered retaliation.
His response is not without risks, given Brazil's fragile politics and $100 billion foreign debt.
But thus far the response seems to have paid off: Brazil's more pragmatic leaders are forced to consider that the country is unlikely to realize its incredible economic potential unless it plays by the rules of fair trade.


Hidden Treasures of Small Nurseries
LEAD: FOR years and years now, I have carried on love affairs with a great many of America's small nurseries.
My wife is resigned to my habit of avoiding interstate highways whenever possible, to increase the chance of stumbling on some local nursery where I just might find some long-sought plant.


Stage: 'Trinity,' Three One-Acts
LEAD: ''BEING a failure ain't easy,'' one of the West Indians in Edgar White's ''Trinity'' says.
But once you have achieved it, he adds, ''the nice thing about failure is that people leave you to hell alone.'' Not in a play by Mr.
White, they won't.
All one of his characters has to do to set himself up for trouble is get a little overconfident.


23d Chess Game Adjourned
LEAD: The 23d game of the World Chess Championship between Gary Kasparov and his challenger, Anatoly Karpov, was adjourned today.
Karpov, playing white, sealed his 41st move.

Where is the Wetlands Board?
LEAD: New York State's Department of Environmental Conservation has designated as ''wetlands'' up to 2,000 acres of Staten Island, thereby severely limiting the way owners may use such acreage.
Dismayed at the extent of opposition to the department's designation methods, the Legislature has established a Freshwater Wetlands Appeals Board.

Brazil Moves to Ban Whaling
LEAD: The Senate today enacted a law to ban whale hunting in Brazil's 200-mile territorial waters.
The measure now needs only President Jose Sarney's signature to become law.
Violators face fines, the confiscation of their vessels and prison terms of two to five years.

Mr.

Textile Import Rise Cited
LEAD: The United States textile industry, a leading supporter of tough trade legislation, said today that 1987 would mark the seventh consecutive year of record textile and apparel imports.
The American Textile Manufacturers Institute, a trade organization, said in its year-end report that foreign shipments would raise the textile and apparel trade deficit by 20 percent, to $25.4 billion, by the end of December.

LEAD: IN Charles Ives's first string quartet, vernacular American elements (hymn tunes, mostly) are genially integrated with the Germanic procedures that the young composer was learning at Yale, rather than set in rugged opposition to them.
It's an assured and likable piece, a little collegiate in its freshness but already subtle in the blending of popular and composed elements.

That was my instinct too.

Mr.
Fifield, who won an O. Henry short-story prize in 1942, was the author of ''In Search of Genius,'' a collection of interviews with people he considered geniuses, including Picasso, Cocteau, Miro, Dali and Robert Graves.

EXPLODING STARS SHOWN TO YIELD LIFE ELEMENTS
LEAD: Instruments aboard an astronomical satellite and two scientific balloons have provided the first direct evidence that exploding stars create the heavy chemical elements that make up most things on Earth, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration reported yesterday.

LEAD: The last container of radium-contaminated soil being removed from a residential neighborhood in Montclair.

New Jersey officials said the residents of the houses should be able to return to them by the spring.

Chrysler Incentive
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation added several car and truck models to the buyer-incentive programs that it began in mid-November.
New 1987 Dodge Dakota pickups, except for the S-series, and Ramcharger pickups carry $770 rebates as well as 7.7 percent annual financing for four-year loans.
Either the rebate or the low-rate financing may be applied to the purchase of 1988 models of the Chrysler Fifth Avenue and E-Body New Yorker Turbo cars, the Dodge Daytona car and Dakota Ramcharger pickup, except for the S-series.

MEDICAL TECHNOLOGY: FINETUNING PACEMAKERS TO MATCH BODY'S NEEDS
LEAD: When the first artificial pacemakers for the human heart were developed about 30 years ago, the sole objective was to save the patient from unpredictable sudden death.
Today's devices, smaller, longer-lasting and, in some cases, able to alter the rate of heartbeat to match the body's needs, help restore the quality of life as well.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q.In winter, condensation forms and a mildew smell develops in our attic.
We also get a lot of moisture in the bathroom, and algae on the walls.
Do we need vents in the attic?
A fan in the bathroom?
A.It sounds as though you need both.
The vents should be at opposite ends of the attic, to insure cross ventilation.

LEAD: While many children occasionally play with fire, those who repeatedly start fires tend to have family trouble, recent studies indicate.

LEAD: The House ethics committee determined today that Representative Austin J. Murphy, Democrat of Pennsylvania, violated House rules by diverting Congressional property to his former law firm and twice allowing someone else to cast votes for him.


Sports People; Tar Heels Pick Brown
LEAD: After having led Tulane from a 1-10 record in 1985 to 6-5 this season, Mack Brown was not entirely surprised when he was selected yesterday by North Carolina to be its new football coach.
Brown has one game left at Tulane, Saturday night against Washington in the Independence Bowl, before starting his new duties the next day.

LEAD: The number of people seeking shelter and food assistance in major cities has grown steadily in the last year, straining resources so severely that many city shelters are now turning away an average 25 percent of those seeking help.

LEAD: The Pentagon conducted an experiment this week demonstrating for the first time that lasers and other high-powered electrical devices can be operated in space without heavy insulation to prevent short circuits, officials said Tuesday.

Sports People; Francis Is Waived
LEAD: Russ Francis, the 34-year-old tight end, was waived from the San Francisco 49ers' injured-reserve list yesterday.
Francis, who had 41 receptions for 505 yards for the 49ers in 1986, had 22 receptions for 202 yards this season before being placed on injured reserve with a back problem Dec. 4.

LEAD: Nuns of the Missionaries of Charity convent in the Bronx unloading fruit and vegetables from the Hunts Point Market that they were to distribute to needy families.
The delivery was part of a test project begun yesterday by the city and the Hunts Point Terminal Produce Cooperative Association to collect and distribute the surplus of the millions of pounds of produce that pass daily through the market.

LEAD: Gustav Husak, who dismantled a program of liberalization in Czechoslovakia two decades ago under the watchful eye of Soviet invasion forces, resigned today as head of the Czechoslovak Communist Party, the official press agency said.


Everyone Has Something to Say About Wright
LEAD: His admirers and his detractors tend to portray him in similar terms: the combatant, the partisan, the risk-taker.


Japan Outlook For Economy
LEAD: Government officials today painted a rosy economic picture for the Japanese economy next year, forecasting rapid growth and a falling trade surplus.
The officials, who declined to be identified, said domestic demand, not exports, would be the driving economic force in 1988.


Economic Scene; World Outlook: Warning Issued
LEAD: ALTHOUGH the securities markets have steadied in recent weeks, there are plenty of signs that the danger to the international economy is anything but over.
The dollar is continuing to fall.
The third world debt problem appears to be worsening.
Oil prices, in the wake of a flimsy price and production agreement by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, plunged below $16 a barrel - good news to consumers and financial markets, but alarming to producers from Indonesia to


Two Kims Elect a Roh
LEAD: South Korea's opposition fought a long, brave fight for direct elections in order to have the chance to vote an unpopular Government out of power.
Instead, because of its deep division, the opposition appears to have handed victory to Roh Tae Woo, the ruling party candidate whose official anointment last spring touched off national unrest.


New Technique May Create Decoy to Halt Spread of AIDS
LEAD: Scientists have developed a novel technique that, in theory at least, may prevent the AIDS virus from reaching the body cells that are its target.


Insiders See Texaco Near A Settlement
LEAD: A $3 billion settlement of the bitter four-year-old battle between Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company appeared imminent last night, several people involved in negotiations said.
The settlement would be the key part of a reorganization plan that would bring Texaco out of bankruptcy.

LEAD: The Mendelssohn String Quartet, with Lucy Shelton, a soprano, is to perform works by Janacek, Ginastera and Ravel tomorrow at 8 P.M. in Merkin Concert Hall, at 129 West 67th Street.
Tickets are $10.
Information: 362-8719.


Tax and Budget Revolt: A Backlash in California
LEAD: Eight years after California led a widespread revolt against taxes and government spending, Californians are growing unhappy with some of the consequences, and they soon will have the opportunity to relax those restrictions.
Today a million signatures were filed to place an amendment on next June's ballot that would ease the spending limit.

Tickets are $23.
Information: 570-3949.

LEAD: The name Schrafft's, which has a bright and shining image to a certain age group of New Yorkers, is barely known to the up-and-coming generation.


Money Fund Assets Off
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 412 money market mutual funds decreased $174.2 million, to $262.31 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 111 institutional funds were up $75.5 million, to $73.27 billion.
Assets of the 206 general purpose funds were down $87.6 million, to $79.81 billion.

New York's Revenues Are Up
LEAD: New York City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday that the city took in $5.4 billion in taxes in the first five months of fiscal 1988, 8.6 percent more than the same period last year.
The city's financial plan predicted a 6.1 percent increase for the year.
Mr.
Goldin said economically sensitive taxes - on sales, personal income, general and financial corporations and unincorporated businesses - rose 8.2 percent from July through November over that period last year.

LEAD: A 23-year-old New York man wanted for a double murder in Pennsylvania surrendered in Brooklyn yesterday, ending a week of freedom in which he was mistakenly freed twice by what Brooklyn prosecutors called a mixup in court papers.

LEAD: Street battles broke out here today as students and workers vented their anger at the electoral defeat of this city's favorite son, Kim Dae Jung.


Court Bars More Charges In Friedman Graft Case
LEAD: New York's highest court yesterday barred the state from prosecuting Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader, and a colleague on corruption charges, asserting that to do so after their Federal convictions would violate double-jeopardy laws.


Ford Ends Stock Buyback
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company flexed its financial muscle today by completing an old stock buyback program and announcing a new stamping plant.


Schumer Ties Homelessness To Cuts in U.S. Housing Aid
LEAD: Representative Charles E. Schumer of New York charged today that homelessness had ''skyrocketed'' in American cities largely because of cuts in Federal housing aid.

LEAD: It was bad enough that this city's Senator Q was indicted.

DISARRAY OF OPEC IS CALLED BENEFIT TO U.S. CONSUMERS
LEAD: American consumers will save billions of dollars next year and inflation will slow because of OPEC's inability to curb its members' crude oil production, oil industry analysts say.


Group of Seven Meeting on Dollar Delayed
LEAD: A seven-nation meeting to devise a way to stabilize the dollar, which some countries sought immediately after the mid-October fall of world stock markets, is still likely but probably not until February, officials of participating foreign countries said.

LEAD: Grande Bande, an original-instrument ensemble, is to present a program of 17th-century Christmas music tomorrow at 8 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall.
Tickets are $14 and $17.50.
Information: (212) 874-6770.


Panel Says Memo Calls Bush 'Solid' for Iran Arms Sale
LEAD: The Congressional Iran-contra committees made public a newly discovered White House memo today that describes Vice President Bush as being ''solid'' in his support of the arms shipments to Iran as of February 1986.


Niekro Declines Offer
LEAD: Phil Niekro, winner of 318 major-league games, has turned down offers to work in the Atlanta Braves minor-league system and will apparently enter private business.
Niekro spent 25 years in the Braves' organization and ended his pitching career with a farewell appearance in the last home game of the 1987 season.


Revised G.N.P. Growth Put at 4.3%
LEAD: The nation's economy was expanding at a robust annual rate of 4.3 percent immediately before the October stock market collapse, the Commerce Department said today.


A Lane on the Manhattan Bridge Is Closed
LEAD: One lane of the lower roadway of the 78-year-old Manhattan Bridge was closed to traffic yesterday afternoon after cracks were found in the floor beams by city and state inspectors, officials said.


Air Force Weighs Letting Pilots Fly Longer
LEAD: The Air Force has agreed to consider creating a career alternative for its pilots that emphasizes continuing to fly rather than taking on broader duties.


AT THE BAR
LEAD: In his heyday on Wall Street, Ivan Boesky was much admired for his uncanny sense of timing.
That talent, as it turns out, was largely illusory.
But in one sense, at least, the fallen arbitrageur's timing was indeed impeccable: if he had to commit crimes, he committed them at precisely the right moment.


ISRAELIS MAINTAIN GAZA CRACKDOWN
LEAD: Israeli troops kept a tight lid on the occupied Gaza Strip today, but scattered demonstrations broke out in Palestinian refugee districts and towns in the West Bank and the Arab sector of East Jerusalem.


732 Were Kept From Leaving Soviet in 11 Months of 1987
LEAD: During the first 11 months of 1987 7,007 citizens emigrated from the Soviet Union and 732 people were barred from leaving, most of them for state security reasons, Interior Minister Aleksandr V. Vlasov said today.


Righetti Says No to Japanese
LEAD: Dave Righetti, who seems to be the most aggressively pursued free agent in the last three years, last night rejected an offer to pitch in Japan.
But that decision did little to clarify his status.
With the Yankees, Los Angeles and California among the teams seeking his services, Righetti must take the next step by tomorrow midnight and decide if he will accept the Yankees' offer of salary arbitration.

LEAD: Jed Harris: the Movie Frederic Raphael, who won an Academy Award for the screenplay for ''Darling'' and dissected marriage to a fare-thee-well in ''Two for the Road,'' is turning his attention to the legendary Broadway producer Jed Harris.

LEAD: The Mets tied up a loose end yesterday when they signed Lee Mazzilli to a two-year contract, but negotiations with their two frontline pitchers -Dwight Gooden and Ron Darling -may not be so orderly.


Marine Bank Chief Named
LEAD: In a move that was expected by analysts, the Marine Midland Bank said that Geoffrey A. Thompson, its president, would take on the additional role of chief executive.
Mr.
Thompson, 47 years old, replaces John R. Petty, 57, who will continue as chairman of the bank and the chairman and chief executive of its holding company.

Bavaro Is Solid Amid Collapse
LEAD: For Mark Bavaro, this has been a season of mixed success.
The bad parts have been the Giants' 4-9 record and his painful toe injury.
The good parts have been his consistently strong games that have kept him ranked as pro football's best tight end.

LEAD: A world premiere of a cantata by Gunther Schuller is to be presented tonight at 8 at St.
Thomas More's Roman Catholic Church, 65 East 89th Street.
The work, ''Thou Art the Son of God,'' is to be performed by the Horace Mann Glee Club and the Amor Artis Orchestra, conducted by Johannes Somary.
Also on the program are Mozart's Coronation Mass and Britten's ''Ceremony of Carols.

LEAD: After a flurry of quick and dramatic moves that left chess analysts confused, Gary Kasparov shook hands with his challenger today in a gesture of resignation that left his hold on the world chess championship hanging by a thread.


Theater Grants
LEAD: More than 20 theatrical organizations, most of which are in the New York area, are the recipients this year of grants and scholarships from the American Theater Wing.
The grants, which total more than $30,000, were awarded at a luncheon yesterday.
Among the recipients are the AMAS Repertory Company, the Equity Library Theater, Negro Ensemble Company, Theaterwork-U.S.A., the Drama League of New York and the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center.

LEAD: The sentencing of Ivan F. Boesky, scheduled for this morning, may be one of the most important events in white-collar law enforcement in years, according to several lawyers, law enforcement officials and regulators.

LEAD: A House-Senate conference committee, making decisions affecting Japanese trade, aid to Pakistan and military planning, today moved toward approval of a $600 billion catch-all appropriation bill needed to put this year's budget agreement into effect.


Last Gargoyle Graces Cathedral
LEAD:  Youngsters watching yesterday as a gargoyle caricaturing a ''caveman,'' right, was hoisted to the top of the north tower at the National Cathedral.
The setting of the last gargoyle brought the cathedral one step closer to completion.
Only the pinnacles on the twin west towers remain to be raised.


Iran Attacks Maldivian Vessel
LEAD: ABOARD U.S.S.
LA SALLE, in the Persian Gulf, Dec. 17 - Iranian gunboats attacked and set afire a cargo ship flying the Maldivian flag in the Persian Gulf today.
An American warship nearby sent observation craft to the scene but did not otherwise become involved in the episode.


Art: Egyptian Antiquities
LEAD: THE title of the exhibition ''Antiquities From the Collection of Christos G. Bastis'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is displayed in letters at least a foot tall painted high on the wall in the first of the show's two galleries.
These letters threaten to dwarf the objects on view, most of which range from small to tiny, and create the momentary impression that the show's contents are being hyped.

LEAD: Within the next two years 882 free- market rental apartments will be created on an 8.5-acre waterfront tract on the northern portion of Roosevelt Island.

LEAD: The Devils scored more than three goals for the first time in seven games tonight, but it wasn't enough to prevent their fourth consecutive loss, their longest such streak this season.


4 Felled in Coast Apartment
LEAD: An 8-year-old girl was found dead Wednesday and her parents and young brother unconscious in the family's apartment, according to the authorities, who said they believed carbon monoxide from a heater was responsible.
The girl, Roseanne Keefe, was pronounced dead at the scene while her parents, David and Rosario Keefe, were reported in fair condition today in the hospital.

LEAD: A dispute over plans to build a $70 million conference center in Ethiopia is delaying the windup of the 42d United Nations General Assembly, delegates say.


Art: Sculptures by Nancy Graves at the Brooklyn Museum
LEAD: AT the entrance to ''Nancy Graves: A Sculpture Retrospective'' is the 1969 ''Mongolian Bactrian (To Harvey Brennan),'' a main character in the shaggy camel story that helped establish Ms.
Graves's reputation.
A camel is an eccentric animal, and this is an eccentric work.
It looks like an actual camel, but it was assembled, constructed and pieced together.


Dining Out Guide: For Wine Lovers
LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times.
Stars are followed by the date of original publication.
Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

New York Adds Hospital Beds To Treat AIDS
LEAD: Citing the rising number of AIDS patients crowding New York City hospitals, state health officials yesterday increased the overall capacity of hospital beds by as much as 500 beds.
The move reverses 10 years of reductions stemming from efforts to control costs.


Deaver Prosecutor Critical of Government Ethics
LEAD: Whitney North Seymour Jr., the special prosecutor in the Michael K. Deaver case, accused the Reagan Administration today of undermining public confidence in Government by condoning ''influence peddling'' by former senior Government officials.


British Jobless Rate Falls
LEAD: The unemployment rate in Britain fell to 9.5 percent in November, the 17th consecutive monthly decline, the Government said today.
The Employment Secretary, Norman Fowler, said 1987 had seen ''the largest sustained fall in unemployment on record.'' On a seasonally adjusted basis, the number of jobless in November was 2.69 million, down 63,500 from October, when the unemployment rate was 9.8 percent.


Dance: Murray Louis And Alwin Nikolais
LEAD: ALWIN NIKOLAIS and Murray Louis have combined forces for their current season but the second program, like the first, was dominated by one of the two choreographers rather than balanced as expected.


A Gremlin Greets I.B.M.
LEAD: Gremlins have invaded I.B.M.'s computers. Worse yet, they reproduce.


4 Haitians Press Namphy to Quit
LEAD: In an attempt to pressure Lieut.
Gen.
Henry Namphy to step down, four leading presidential candidates have announced agreement on a coalition government that would replace him if he yields.


House Ethics Committee's Counsel Recommends the Ouster of Biaggi
LEAD: The counsel to the House Ethics Committee recommended today that Represenative Mario Biaggi be expelled from Congress, while Mr.
Biaggi's lawyers recommended a reprimand, according to the committee's chairman.


NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 18, 1987
LEAD:  International A3-15


U.S. Preparing Shells To Spread a Fatal Gas
LEAD: The United States has ended an 18-year moratorium on producing chemical weapons and is filling canisters for an artillery shell that would spread toxic nerve gas, the Pentagon said today.


Bridge: Winter Regional to Include Unusual Open Pairs Event
LEAD: The Winter Regional Championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association begin today at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, at 36th Street and 11th Avenue in Manhattan, with this schedule:  Today - Men's pairs, women's pairs and senior pairs, 2 P.M. and 8 P.M.; knockout teams, 49er pairs and newcomer pairs, 8 P.M.


Congress Kills Grant For Martha Graham
LEAD: A special Federal grant of $4 million that was to have gone toward establishing a permanent record of the choreography of Martha Graham was killed today in Congress.


Korean Opposition, Declaring Extensive Fraud, Pledges to Keep Fighting
LEAD: Stunned by their decisive defeat in the presidential election, rival opposition leaders declared Thursday that the results were void because of what they called widespread fraud, and pledged to step up their anti-Government resistance.


Some Deft Help From Great Minds
LEAD: Under interrogation in Senate hearings this week on his nomination to the Supreme Court, Judge Anthony M. Kennedy demonstrated a knack for coming up with apt quotations to underscore his philosophical points.

10% RISE IS FOUND IN PRESCHOOLERS
LEAD: The Census Bureau reported today that the preschool population increased more than 10 percent in the 1980's, with the fastest growth in Sun Belt states and Alaska.


B.P. Raises Stake in Britoil to 24.9%
LEAD: With oil prices sliding again and stock markets around the world remaining fragile, it seems an unlikely time for a multibillion-dollar buying spree of oil company stock, but that is precisely what is unfolding in London.


Cuomo Plays Grinch for Media Crowd
LEAD: Governor Cuomo read ''A Visit From St.
Nicholas'' (''Twas the Night Before Christmas'') to 125 media-mobbed children yesterday, but when the press turned its attention to the Governor, there arose such a clatter that he gave, as a sort of encore, a fair impersonation of the Grinch.


Lost Collection
LEAD: A lifelong collection of basketball memorabilia was lost Wednesday when the four-bedroom house in Columbia, S.C., built 23 years ago for Frank McGuire, a Hall of Fame basketball coach, burned to the ground.
McGuire and his wife, Jane, barely escaped serious injury from a blaze that fire officials said probably had been caused by a gas leak ignited by a spark after Mrs.


Dukakis Begins a Quest For Presidential Stature
LEAD: As he rode across Iowa one recent wintry afternoon, Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts mused on the sources of President Kennedy's inspirational leadership.
Kennedy was not ''the greatest natural orator,'' Mr.
Dukakis said, nor was his Presidential stature apparent to everyone in the early days of his campaign.


Two Clubs for Women Are Charged With Bias
LEAD: Three men filed complaints yesterday with the New York State Division of Human Rights because they were refused admission to two Manhattan women's clubs.


McLaughlin Expects Scrutiny in Labor Post
LEAD: Ann Dore McLaughlin, sworn in today as Secretary of Labor, joins a select company with a high attrition rate.
In seven years in office, President Reagan has appointed 41 other Cabinet members; the three women in that group have all resigned.

ACCORD IS REACHED ON NUCLEAR DUMP
LEAD: House and Senate negotiators agreed today on a compromise that would designate Yucca Mountain in Nevada as the only site for disposal of the nation's most dangerous nuclear waste.


Heyman May Buy More GAF Shares
LEAD: Samuel J. Heyman, the chairman of the GAF Corporation, said he might increase his stake in GAF to 15 percent from 10.2 percent.


Estimate Board Defeats Koch Plan On East Harlem Homeless Shelter
LEAD: A Koch administration plan to turn an East Harlem school building into a shelter for homeless families was soundly defeated last night by the Board of Estimate.


Colonel in Dispute Retiring
LEAD: An Air Force colonel criticized as putting pressure on wives of senior officers at Grissom Air Force Base to quit work so they would be available for social activities will retire next month.
The colonel, Gary R. Ebert, 44 years old, wing commander of the 305th Air Refueling Wing, based at Grissom, was on leave and unavailable for comment, a base spokeswoman said.


Film: 'Ironweed,' From Hector Babenco
LEAD: EARLY in his novel ''Ironweed,'' William Kennedy describes a visit made to a cemetery by the aging derelict Francis Phelan, whose mother and father and infant son are buried there.
It is Halloween, and they are watching him, interested and bemused, from beyond the grave.

Brooklyn Judge Criticized in New Case
LEAD: The judge accused by the Brooklyn District Attorney of humiliating a complainant in a sexual-misconduct trial has been accused by jurors in another case of demeaning witnesses, of falling asleep on the bench and of intimidating the defense and prosecuting attorneys.


Investor Buys 7.3% of Showboat
LEAD: Paul W. Lowden, the investor who controls the Sahara Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, Nev., has purchased 7.3 percent of Showboat Inc. and has said he might seek control of the casino company.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr.
Lowden said he planned to discuss the acquisition of Showboat's Las Vegas Casino Hotel and other properties with the company.


3 'PRICELESS' PIECES FROM OMAN STOLEN FROM CASES AT U.N.
LEAD: A silver urn and two gold perfume bottles given to the United Nations by the sultanate of Oman as gifts were stolen Tuesday from display cases only yards from the Security Council chamber, United Nations officials said today.


Sampson Gets 24 In a Losing Debut
LEAD: Ralph Sampson made his debut as a Golden State Warrior tonight, and although the 7-foot-4-inch center could not halt the team's dismal decline, his performance kindled hope for brighter days.


Karpov's Rook Smashes Blunder by Kasparov
LEAD: Whether it was seductive wild hope or just a miscalculation, Gary Kasparov blundered yesterday with an incorrect combination and was smartly smashed by Anatoly Karpov in the adjournment session of their 23d world chess championship game in Seville, Spain.

Film: Cronyn in 'Batteries'
LEAD: ''NO, they're not toys.
You can't buy these things at Macy's!'' cries one of the characters in ''Batteries Not Included,'' describing the dinner-plate-size flying saucers that are the film's real stars.

LEAD: Congressional negotiators have decided to allow the Reagan Administration to proceed with tough new abortion restrictions on family planning groups, handing a victory to the White House and its anti-abortion allies.

Road Fatalities Soared as Limit For Speed Rose
LEAD: Traffic fatalities on rural interstate highways soared by more than 50 percent in states that increased their speed limit to 65 miles per hour last spring, according to Transportation Department figures.


NEW OFFER IS RECEIVED BY ROBINS
LEAD: The A. H. Robins Company said yesterday that it had received a takeover offer from Sanofi that included assurances the large French pharmaceutical company would provide the $2.48 billion that Robins needs to compensate women injured by its Dalkon Shield birth control device.


On Wall Street, Blues for a Blue-Chip Firm
LEAD: What is one of the nation's most prestigious law firms to do when a state appellate court chides it twice in six months for violations of the law, inexcusable breaches of ethics, specious legal arguments and hubris to boot?

Washington Talk: Briefing; Beer at the Bar
LEAD: In Washington, senders of holiday greeting cards often vy to combine the wittiest analysis of a current political situation, often cartoon-illustrated, with best wishes for the season.
A contemporary example, circulated by Nordlinger Associates, a public relations concern, may raise an eyebrow or two in the capital's large legal fraternity.


Cabot Offers 2 Issues of Notes
LEAD: The Cabot Corporation is offering two note issues totaling $250 million through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.


Democratic Chief Says Hart Put Own Goal Over Party's
LEAD: The national Democratic chairman said today that Gary Hart had placed personal goals above the good of his party by re-entering the Presidential race this week.


Like Son, Like Father
LEAD: Keith Asmussen, the block of the young chip, won his first race ever in New York yesterday, something his son, Cash, used to do regularly.
Cash Asmussen was New York's leading rider in 1979, then began riding in Europe in 1980 and has since become the only non-French jockey to win the French riding title, doing so in 1985 and 1986.


Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption on Tuesday, with an article about a speech by President Reagan on seeking conventional arms reductions in Europe, misidentified the head of the Center for Strategic and International Studies.


Accord Reported in Suit Involving Texas Shooting
LEAD: A $5 million settlement has been reached between T. Cullen Davis, the bankrupt oil heir, and his former wife, Priscilla Davis, in a suit stemming from a 1976 shooting at the Davis mansion, lawyers report.
A jury failed to reach a verdict in the case earlier this year.


Ex-Howard Beach Alternate Juror Discusses Case
LEAD: An alternate juror dismissed by the judge in the Howard Beach trial predicted yesterday that the jury would decide the case on the evidence presented and would disregard the broader racial and social questions that have been discussed again and again in the courtroom.


REAGANS TO AVOID LINKS WITH DEAVER
LEAD: Nancy Reagan said today that she and President Reagan had been advised by counsel to suspend their personal relationship with Michael K. Deaver as long as appeals of his conviction were pending.


Pritzker Group Has Ramada Stake
LEAD: An investment group led by the Pritzker family of Chicago said it had purchased a 6 percent stake in Ramada Inc., a hotel, casino and restaurant company based in Phoenix.
The Pritzker family controls the Hyatt Corporation and Braniff Airways Inc.

LEAD: Mox Arthur Weber, retired chairman of the department of physical education at Hamilton College in Clinton, N.Y., died Dec. 5 at the North Hill retirement home in Needham, Mass.
He was 85 years old and lived in Needham.

LEAD: A former employee of Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's military leader, has told Congressional investigators that the general authorized arms shipments to the Salvadoran rebels in the early 1980's when the Reagan Administration was trying to keep Nicaragua and other nations from arming them.

LEAD: It was on Veterans Day that Gaetano (Guy) Russo, a former assistant adjutant in the Connecticut National Guard, first learned that Jane Fonda was coming to town to make a movie.
Outraged, he wrote a letter to the local newspaper.
A few days later, he had 250 bumper stickers printed.
They read, ''I'm Not Fond'a Hanoi Jane.

It is at 26 East 78th Street in Manhattan.

Inquiry in Death In City Custody Faces Problems
LEAD: Prosecutors investigating the death in city custody of a 28-year-old Bronx woman are faced with conflicting reports from witnesses about her struggles with the police and with problems in determining the origin of a fatal blood clot in her leg.


College Basketball; SYRACUSE RESERVE LEADS ROUT
LEAD: Keith Hughes, a sophomore reserve forward, scored a career-high 19 points tonight as Syracuse took control early in a 111-68 victory over St.
Bonaventure.


Theater: 'A Most Secret War'
LEAD: WHILE Hugh Whitemore's ''Breaking the Code'' continues on Broadway, another play about Alan Turing, ''A Most Secret War'' by Kevin Patterson, opened this week at the Harold Clurman Theater.
Both plays focus on the same aspect of Turing's life - his homosexuality -and neither amply investigates the mathematician's breaking of the German secret code during World War II.


Deaths Increase Among Patients With Medicare
LEAD: Deaths of elderly Medicare patients in municipal hospitals in New York City exceeded statistical predictions in 1986, according to a new Federal survey.
At the same time, however, death rates for such patients in private nonprofit hospitals did not exceed the Federal predictions.


Revenue Bonds Set For Medical Center
LEAD: The New York State Medical Facilities Finance Agency is tentatively offering $131.5 million of revenue bonds for the Catholic Medical Center, with a maximum yield of 8.315 percent for an issue due in 2022, through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.


U.S. Orders Crews to Be Screened Before They Go Aboard Airliners
LEAD: Airport and airline employees, including flight crews, will have to go through security screening before boarding planes, the Government ordered yesterday.


Topics of The Times; Underground Literature
LEAD: Old images of New York's subways live, carried back to Boise and Biloxi: graffiti-plastered, urine-soaked, crime-infested and suffused with noise and danger.
Visiting friends are horrified at the idea of taking the train, either for convenience or to beat the street traffic.


Chief of Latin Lender May Quit in Protest
LEAD: The president of the Inter-American Development Bank, Antonio Ortiz Mena, said yesterday that he would quit rather than accept a Reagan Administration appointee as his No. 2, according to officials of the bank, a major lender to Latin America.

That would flagrantly violate the new Central American peace plan, which forbids all foreign aid to insurgents.
Then why not cut off all contra aid?

Apple Optimistic
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. said it expected record revenues and earnings for its first fiscal quarter, which ends Jan. 1.
Analysts have estimated the earnings at between 65 and 85 cents a share, with revenues between $925 million and $980 million.
In the comparable period last year, Apple earned 45.5 cents a share, after an adjustment for a 2-for-1 split, on revenues of $662.3 million.


Jordan Has 52, Season High
LEAD: Michael Jordan had a season-high 52 points and began a 12-0 spurt during a 2-minute-53-second span in the final quarter to give the Chicago Bulls a 111-100 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight.

LEAD: Ever since Mikhail S. Gorbachev left town a week ago, some White House officials have been practicing the Washington art of ''spin control,'' the technique of delivering information to the press and the public with just the right twist to suit the purposes of the purveyor.


Troubadours Carry Forth A Tradition
LEAD: THE troubadour, a wandering poet-musician, has long been a figure swathed in mystery and romance, and not only in Europe.
The tradition of the itinerant bard is well established in Africa and the Arab world as well.
Indeed, there is evidence that the celebrated troubadours of 12th-century Provence were substantially influenced by Moorish bards.

Counterbid Seen In Martell Case
LEAD: The London liquor and hotel group, Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., said it might bid for Martell S.A., the cognac concern that has agreed to be acquired by the Seagram Company of Canada.
Seagram said Wednesday that it would buy the 40 percent of Martell's stock owned by the company's founding family for 2,500 francs, or about $450, a share.

LEAD: Dick Schultz, the executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, said yesterday he expected a postseason playoff system to determine the national champion in Division I-A football to be rejected by a 2-1 ratio when members vote on the proposal next month.

Can't Wait for That Looser, Longer Look
LEAD: To the Editor:


Hart Misses the Point
LEAD: There is a common thread connecting many strong people who decide to seek psychiatric counsel.
It is the realization that they are acting repeatedly in a way harmful to them, without knowing quite why.
So they spend time, often painful time, with somebody who can make them see themselves more clearly, discover what it is that makes them act out the same mistake - and by knowing, change.


Sudan Is Said to Talk With Leaders of Rebels
LEAD: The Khartoum Government held secret peace talks in London this month with representatives of the rebel army fighting in the southern Sudan, officials said today.

LEAD: Pier A on the Battery, a century-old landmark that commands an uninterrupted, almost seaborne, vista of New York Harbor, would be turned into a high-priced restaurant - with a visitors' center and fast-food dining, too -under a new plan by the Koch administration.

That's a nice-sounding name.'' So Halas drafted Fortmann, who became a Hall of

LEAD: When the Maxwell Football Club in Philadelphia selected Don McPherson of Syracuse for its 1987 award yesterday, it marked the 27th time in 51 years and the fourth in the last 10 that the Heisman Trophy and the Maxwell Award honoring the outstanding college football player of the year went to different players.

And the other woman has fallen in love with him.

And then gangsters gave him a ticket and he became the most wanted man in the United States.

LEAD: Albert P. Morano, a Republican who represented the Fourth Congressional District of Connecticut from 1951 to 1959, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Wednesday at Greenwich Hospital.
