LEAD: Percussive Sounds


Corrections
LEAD: An obituary of Alan Mitosky yesterday listed his survivors incompletely.


Editors' Note
LEAD: An article on Monday about a Nicaraguan Army officer who defected in October said the proposed peace accord for Central America calls for limiting national armies in the region.


Qaddafi Foiled as an Ice Hockey Patron
LEAD: Unable to find any domestic sponsors for his bankrupt ice hockey club, Heinz Weifenbach went for broke.
He flew to Libya.


Music: New World Group
LEAD: FROM the very first notes of its concert Wednesday evening in Alice Tully Hall - a sweet, perfectly balanced, utterly graceful statement of the opening of Beethoven's F major Quartet (Op. 18, No. 1) - the New World String Quartet declared itself an ensemble of almost startling refinement.


G.M. Issuing a Recall of 203,000 Vehicles
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would recall 203,000 automobiles and light trucks to correct possible safety defects.
The company said it knew of no accidents related to the defects.


A Chance in Nicaragua
LEAD: There does seem to be a serious chance to end the war in Nicaragua and cut off all Soviet military support for the Sandinistas.
That was the message the Russians tried to deliver during the Gorbachev visit.


Film: 'September,' From Allen
LEAD: ''SEPTEMBER'' is Woody Allen's riskiest film yet.
It's a small, tightly disciplined drama about love, friendship and family, set entirely within a Vermont summer house at the end of the season.
People come and go to destinations elsewhere, but the movie remains inside the cottage, like a possibly hypochondriacal, invalid ghost.


BARKLEY BEATS KNICKS
LEAD: The play began last night where the endline and baseline meet near the Knick bench.
After giving Sidney Green, who was guarding him, a head fake, Charles Barkley made his move to the basket.
Patrick Ewing, coming over to cut off the Philadelphia 76ers' power forward, missed the block.
Barkley drove round him, dribbled the ball once, took a step and half and then jammed the ball through the basket - in the face of the Knick center.


Conferees, Upset by Trade Gap, Move to Limit Japanese Business
LEAD: Reflecting yearlong trade disputes and tensions over the trade deficit with Japan, House and Senate conferees agreed today to ban Japanese companies from participation in public works construction of airports, veterans' hospitals and other projects in the United States.


Treasury Bonds Retreat Slightly
LEAD: The rally in the bond market lost some momentum yesterday, as a rebound in oil prices from their intra-day low led to a slight decline in Treasury bond prices.


Report on Mortality: Guarded Praise
LEAD: The Government's report today on hospital mortality rates was praised by many, but flaws in the study show that measuring quality of care is a science still in its infancy.


Defense Dept. Aide Calls Defector's Nicaragua Data 'Speculative'
LEAD: A senior official in the Defense Department acknowledged today that evidence provided by a Sandinista defector of a Nicaraguan plan to invade other nations was ''speculative.''


Trial Leaves Old Questions For Palermo
LEAD: ''The Mafia organization continues to function punctually,'' Mimmo Signorino, a deputy prosecutor, said the morning after a jury returned 338 guilty verdicts in the most successful law enforcement effort ever undertaken against the Sicilian underworld.


Paxton at Bottom Line
LEAD: Tom Paxton, a songwriter, is to perform tonight and Sunday at the Bottom Line, 14 West Fourth Street (228-6300).
Tonight, the bill also includes Schooner Fare and John McCutcheon; on Sunday, Mr.
Paxton shares a double bill with the Carolling Carollers led by Suzzy Roche.
Shows begin at 7:30 and 10:30 P.M.

Ex-Massachusetts Aide Is Charged With Fraud
LEAD: Gerard T. Indelicato, a former education adviser for the state, was charged today with running a scheme to divert Federal education grants to himself and three other men.


CORRECTION
LEAD: The Hers column in The Home Section on Thursday misstated the nationality of the sculptor Clement Meadmore.
He is a naturalized American citizen.


Carlucci, in Budget Move, Orders Study of Military Command Staffs
LEAD: Secretary of Defense Frank C. Carlucci has told the top commanders of United States military forces around the world that he intends to make their headquarters more efficient and cut their staffs to help reduce the Pentagon budget.


The Myth of Pakistan as a Heroic U.S. Ally
LEAD: To the Editor:


RESULTS
LEAD:  Boxing  Foreman Stops Sekorski: George Foreman stopped Rocky Sekorski in the third round last night in Las Vegas, Nev., for his fifth straight knockout since starting a comeback last March at the age of 39.
Foreman, who held the heavyweight championship from January 1973 to October 1974, methodically pounded Sekorski with jabs and savage right hands before Referee Richard Steele stopped the bout at 2:48.

TEXACO REPORTED TO REACH ACCORD ON PENNZOIL SUIT
LEAD: A tumultuous four-year legal battle that pitted the Pennzoil Company against the giant Texaco Inc. was brought to a conclusion last night when Texaco agreed in principle to give Pennzoil $3 billion, a lawyer for Texaco said.

Trustees to Repay S.M.U.
LEAD: Members of Southern Methodist University board of trustees today voted to make individual contributions totalling $1.7 million to reimburse the school for expenses associated with its football scandal.


CORRECTION
LEAD: An article in The Home Section on Thursday about Steven McDonald, a disabled police officer, misstated his educational background in some editions.
He attended several colleges in the New York area but did not graduate; he did not attend Notre Dame.


Drug Seizure
LEAD: Robert Stutman, a special agent of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration, with two stacks of packages of heroin that were seized by the agency this week.
Three suspects were arrested in the seizure, which totaled 165 pounds of the drug. (The New York Times/Don Hogan Charles)


Jet Defense Taking Simpler Approach
LEAD: Are the Jets dimmer than players on other clubs?


U.S. and South Korea: Gamble for Administration
LEAD: In issuing a quick endorsement of the legitimacy of Wednesday's election results in South Korea, the Reagan Administration has taken a gamble, but one in which the odds appear heavily in Washington's favor.


Fed Had Doubts as It Eased Credit
LEAD: Federal Reserve policy makers agreed to loosen credit conditions in the weeks after the stock market collapse even though concerns were raised about the effect such policies would have on the strength of the dollar, according to official minutes released today.

Dance: Joffrey's 'Nutcracker'
LEAD: The Joffrey Ballet has come up with something to write home about - a Christmas-card version of ''The Nutcracker'' that has a distinct and original flavor of its own.


Ramada Defense
LEAD: Ramada Inc. said it had put in place a stockholder rights plan to deter an unfair takeover and adopted the measure before learning that an investor group led by the Pritzker family has bought a 6 percent interest in the company.
Ramada, a hotel, casino and restaurant operator based in Phoenix, has been a rumored takeover target for two years.


B.P. Forges Ahead With Bid for Britoil
LEAD: The British Petroleum Company announced this afternoon that it would go ahead with a multibillion-dollar takeover bid for Britoil P.L.C. despite the British Government's decision earlier today to invoke special powers to block British Petroleum from gaining control of Britoil.

Manhattan Bridge Closing Ties Up Traffic
LEAD: Manhattan-bound trucks inching their way off the Williamsburg Bridge.
Trucks were diverted from the Manhattan Bridge since Thursday, when officials closed a lane on the lower level of the bridge because inspectors found cracks in beams between the towers.
Manhattan-bound buses and trucks were banned, leading to the cancellation of service on one bus line.

Greenspan Plays Down Record Trade Deficit
LEAD: In his first comprehensive review of economic issues since taking office in August, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today that the record trade deficit reported last week was an aberration.


Patents; Method to Transmit Electronic Mail
LEAD: A method of transmitting electronic mail was patented this week for Express Communications Inc., a New York company.
Patent 4,713,780 was granted Thomas G. Schultz of Chicago and four co-inventors.


Crude Oil Falls a Fifth Day After an Early Rally Fizzles
LEAD: Crude oil cash and futures prices fell yesterday for the fifth day in a row after an early rally found little support.
Futures prices of heating oil and unleaded gasoline also declined.

Canadian Violinist Wins Contest at Carnegie
LEAD: Scott St.
John, an 18-year-old Canadian violin student at the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia, has won first prize in the first Alexander Schneider Competition for Violinists Playing Viola.


Colombo Figure Given 25 Years On '80 Charges
LEAD: Alphonse (Allie Boy) Persico, a former leader of the Colombo organized-crime family who had been a fugitive seven years, until his arrest last month, was sentenced yesterday to 25 years in prison for a 1980 conviction on extortion charges.


PATH Safety, Not Neighborhood Blight
LEAD: Five years ago an electrical fire broke out in the PATH tunnel under the Hudson River, through which 200,000 people commute each day from New Jersey to Lower Manhattan.
Four hundred managed to climb a narrow 60-foot spiral stairway to safety.
Firefighters had to lug hoses along the smoky track from a station entrance a quarter mile away.


Telex to Reduce Work Force by 5%
LEAD: The Telex Corporation said it would trim its worldwide work force by about 5 percent, partly through layoffs, as a result of its merger with Memorex International N.V., which began today.
While Telex's president, George Bragg, called the company's decision to eliminate 400 jobs ''unpleasant news,'' he said the successful completion of the $911 million merger with Memorex would keep layoffs to a minimum.


Transactions
LEAD:  BASEBALL


Agent's Suit Rejected
LEAD: A Federal judge in Atlanta threw out a $500,000 lawsuit by Norby Walters against Brent Fullwood, the former Auburn running back, ruling invalid a contract Fullwood signed with the agent before finishing his college career. ''We decline to serve as paymaster of the wages of crime, or referee between thieves,'' United States District Judge Charles Brieant wrote in his ruling, which was reported in the combined edition of The Atlanta Journal and The Atlanta Constitution today.


Ambulances Being Diverted In New York
LEAD: New York City hospitals, burdened by overcrowding, are increasingly closing their emergency rooms to patients and diverting ambulances to less crowded hospitals, city hospital and ambulance officials said yesterday.

A Franklin Bank Payout
LEAD: Nearly 14 years after the Franklin National Bank had to be bailed out in the largest bank failure ever, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said yesterday that certain preferred shareholders would receive accrued but unpaid dividends equal to $10.9 million.


A Marriage Raises Political Questions in Pakistan
LEAD: Benazir Bhutto, the opposition leader, with her husband, Asif Ali Zardari, after their wedding yesterday in Karachi.
Many wondered whether the marriage would help or hinder her political movement.
Page 4. (Agence France-Presse)


OIL WELL TO FURNACE, PRICES WANDER
LEAD: The nation is starting the winter with 20 percent less heating oil on hand than a year ago, and with many questions about why and what it means to consumers.


Massachusetts Reaches Accord on Health Bill
LEAD: All Massachusetts residents would be covered by health insurance by 1992 under a compromise plan announced today.


JAZZ: QUINTET WITH PREVITE AT VISIONES
LEAD: Over the last few years, Bobby Previte has become the drummer of choice for downtown new music, particularly if it has jazz connections.
He's also a composer, and he brought a quintet to Visiones for a two-night stand that opened Wednesday with music from his two albums, ''Bump the Renaissance'' and the new ''Pushing the Envelope.


With or Without Cake, 'Newsmakers' Survives
LEAD: There is a certain symbolism in Norman Kramer's coffeecake, or, more precisely, in its absence.
For more than two decades Mr.
Kramer, the producer, creator and driving force behind WCBS's ''Newsmakers,'' one of the best-known local public affairs programs on television, offered coffeecake to guests before each Sunday morning program.


Shuttle Rocket Test Today
LEAD: The country's manned space flight program faces another test today when Morton Thiokol conducts the second full-scale firing of its redesigned rocket booster for the space shuttle.


Paradyne Chief Resigns
LEAD: The Paradyne Corporation's president and chief executive of nine months has resigned after a dispute with the chairman, Paul J. Ferri, over operations of the data communications concern, which earlier this year pleaded guilty to fraud conspiracy.
Jerry T. Kendall, 44 years old , also resigned Thursday from Paradyne's board of directors.

Chambers Jury Is Selected
LEAD: A complete jury has been selected to hear the case of Robert Chambers Jr., who is charged with second-degree murder in the death of 18-year-old Jennifer Levin in Central Park in August 1986.
Eight men and four women are on the jury, which was selected from 486 people interviewed.

Correction
LEAD: A headline in some editions yesterday about a clash in southern Lebanon misstated the number of Lebanese guerrillas killed by Israeli troops.
It was six, not three.


Watch Your Handbag
LEAD: Shoulder bags can be open invitations to the professional thieves who blend into the crowds on New York City's shopping avenues, especially during the hectic holiday season.
They work alone, in pairs and in packs.
And every day they find victims, because busy people are often careless people.


Pennzoil-Texaco Fight Raised Key Questions
LEAD: The Pennzoil Company has called its battle with Texaco Inc. ''a true story of deceit and treachery.'' Texaco has sought to portray the bitter fight as a tale of justice gone awry.


Jazz: Ellis Marsalis, Pianist
LEAD: When Ellis Marsalis chose to stay in New Orleans 30 years ago to raise his family instead of pursuing a broader career as a jazz pianist, he laid the groundwork for what has turned out to be a second shot at jazz celebrity.
The family he raised has already produced two jazz stars - his sons Wynton, the trumpeter, and


Swedes Say Evidence Shows Incursions by Foreign Subs
LEAD: Sweden said today that it had clear evidence that foreign submarines repeatedly violated its territorial waters in the last six months.

Cavaliers Outshoot Nets at Finish
LEAD: The Cleveland Cavaliers scored 7 consecutive points in the final minute tonight to beat the Nets, 103-94.


Consumer Prices Rose By 0.3% in November
LEAD: The Consumer Price Index climbed by three-tenths of 1 percent in November as energy prices turned up, the Labor Department reported today.
Increases for housing, food and apparel slowed, however.

Contributors to the Neediest Aid Youths and the Elderly
LEAD: Mrs.
Frederick Brand of Manhattan has contributed to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund for more than half a century and hopes ''to go on for as long as I can.''


CPC International
LEAD: CPC International Inc., based in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., said that it had signed agreements to purchase three food companies in Europe and had recently completed two smaller acquisitions in Latin America.
The five businesses are being purchased for about $175 million and will be added to an array of food companies that include such brand names as Hellmann's, Skippy, Mazola and Knorr.


Manila Drops Jailed Rebel Officer From Army
LEAD: Col.
Gregorio Honasan, the charismatic leader of a series of coup attempts, now lives in confinement aboard a navy warship, charged with rebellion and no longer a member of the armed forces.


Bernward 8U. Kurtz, Architect, Dies at 51
LEAD: Bernward U. Kurtz, an architect and former partner and director in the Eggers Group Architects &amp; Planners in Manhattan, died of a lung ailment Monday in Tampa, Fla., where he lived.
He was 51 years old.
Mr.
Kurtz, a native of Neustadt, West Germany, came to the United States in 1965 after earning degrees in architecture and engineering in Mannheim.


BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Armstrong World Industries, Lancaster, Pa., said its Italian subsidiary had acquired the majority of shares of Euroflex of Trezzano Rosa, Italy.
Terms were not disclosed.


Bridge; New Rule Caused Error In Nassau-Suffolk Event
LEAD: When a team match ends, experts normally calculate the imp score accurately within a minute.
One of the rare errors occurred last week in the final playoffs of the Nassau-Suffolk Double Knockout Team Championship at the Grand Club in Franklin Square, L.I.
And it happened for a curious reason.

Key Jobs in Military Off Limits for AIDS-Infected
LEAD: Officials of the Defense Department said today that military personnel infected with the AIDS virus were being removed from sensitive, stressful jobs because of new evidence that the virus could impair mental function, even in people who show no overt symptoms of the disease.


PARAGUAY DECIDING FATE OF PRISONER
LEAD: Paraguay's longest-serving political prisoner completed a 25-year prison term today, but he was not immediately set free.


Parcells Planning Something Special
LEAD: The Giants' special teams have been anything but special this year.
So when the Giants meet the Green Bay Packers in Giants Stadium in a rare Saturday game, some of their special teams will have a new look.


Suddenly, Upheaval in Jersey Garbage Disposal
LEAD: More than 10 years after New Jersey set out to close its sprawling regional landfills and force its 21 counties to draft plans for disposing of their own trash, garbage collection is suddenly in upheaval in heavily populated northern New Jersey.


Bond Prices Advance as Oil Drops
LEAD: Bond prices rose in late trading yesterday, with the increases attributed to a moderate drop in oil prices.


Conferees Complete Bill For $23 Billion Tax Rise
LEAD: Congressional tax aides worked out the final details today of a $23 billion tax-increase package approved late Thursday night by House and Senate negotiators.

CORRECTION
LEAD: An article last Saturday about the kaolin industry in Georgia described the status of the Freeport-McMoran Company incorrectly.
It still exists; a subsidiary, Freeport Kaolin, was bought in 1984 by the Englehard Corporation.

Tulane Replaces Brown
LEAD: Wasting little time finding replacements for Mack Brown, the football coach and athletic director who announced last Wednesday that he was leaving to coach at North Carolina, a 10-member athletic committee at Tulane yesterday selected members of Brown's staff as his successors.
Dr.
Eamon M. Kelly, the university president, said that Greg Davis, the assistant head coach, would be put in charge of the football program and that Wright Waters, the associate athletic director, would serve as the interim athletic director.

Dr. Gordon Ekholm, 78, a Curator At the Museum of Natural History
LEAD: Dr.
Gordon F. Ekholm, curator emeritus of anthropology at the American Museum of Natural History and an authority on pre-Columbian archeology of Mexico and Central America, died Thursday at the Phelps Memorial Hospital Center in Tarrytown, N.Y., after undergoing minor surgery.
He was 78 years old and lived in Pleasantville, N


Tokyo to Play Beethoven
LEAD: A series of five concerts devoted to the Beethoven string quartets, featuring the Tokyo String Quartet, will begin Jan. 20 at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.
The first program includes the Opus 18 quartets.
Other concerts will be on Feb. 10, March 30, April 27 and May 11.
Single tickets range from $13 to $17.50; subscriptions are also available for $60 to $75.


Kenya Ousts 2 Uganda Aides As Gunfight Raises Tensions
LEAD: Kenya today ordered the two senior Ugandan diplomats in Nairobi to leave the country within 24 hours, four days after growing tensions between the East African neighbors erupted in a gun battle between Ugandan and Kenyan security forces along their border.

Bush Is Hoping To Cut Damage Of Arms Memo
LEAD: Vice President Bush today sought to limit the damage caused to his Presidential campaign by a White House memorandum showing that he supported secret arms sales to Iran last year.
He said the memorandum's political effect would be ''absolutely nothing.''


Mary Orkin, 93, Dies; Painter of Park Scenes
LEAD: Mary Ruby Orkin, who in her 60's became known for her primitive paintings of Central Park, died on Sunday at Kateri Residence, a nursing home in Manhattan.
She was 93 years old.


Editors' Note
LEAD: A headline on Thursday about Senator Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey said, ''Lautenberg: Well Liked but Vulnerable.'' The subheading said the Senator ''has not been identified with any major public issues.''


Comings and Goings
LEAD: When Chris Evert lost in two sets to Sylvia Hanika last Nov. 16 in the Virginia Slims championships at Madison Square Garden, there was speculation that she would not make the trip to the Australian Open Jan. 11-24.
But Evert, the two-time champion of that Grand Slam event, announced yesterday that she would play in the $1.9 million tournament.


Brazil's Finance Chief Quits
LEAD: Brazil's Finance Minister, Luiz Carlos Bresser Pereira, resigned today after President Jose Sarney vetoed his plan to cut the country's huge public deficit through sharp tax increases.

Did Dinosaurs Die a Dull Death?
LEAD: A striking theory proposed in 1980 ascribed the sudden demise of dinosaurs some 65 million years ago to the fiery impact of an outsize asteroid.
Another explanation, duller and less often discussed, rejects catastrophes from the heavens and points to gradual processes on earth, like changes in climate and sea level, as the likely agents of extinction.


RIGHETTI WEIGHS ARBITRATION OFFER
LEAD: A number of baseball's premier free agents face a midnight deadline tonight to decide whether they will accept their former teams' offers of salary arbitration.
They include Dave Righetti, the pitcher who is considering contract proposals from at least seven teams.


Deaver Prosecutor Asks Tougher Conflict Laws
LEAD: Whitney North Seymour Jr. today proposed to Congress a major overhaul of the nation's laws on conflict of interest as the White House assailed his criticism of the Administration's ethical standards.

It will reach The New York Times Book Review best-seller list at No. 15 in the Dec. 27 issue, and it is higher than that on several regional best-seller lists -No. 3, for example, in southern California, according to The Los Angeles Times.

LEAD: Josephine Scacciaferro, who taught Italian in New York City high schools for 22 years, died Tuesday at her home in Nutley, N.J.

Benjamin Taylor, assistant executive editor, has been named executive editor.
Both appointments were made Thursday and are effective Jan. 1.
The Globe has not had an editor since Michael C.

Double Bill at Planetarium
LEAD: A double bill of planetarium shows, narrated by Kirk Douglas and Harry Blackstone Jr., will begin an extended run on Jan. 5 at the Hayden Planetarium at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 81st Street.
The program lasts 45 minutes and consists of ''The Space Telescope: New Eyes on the Universe,'' narrated by Mr.


AIDS, the Cardinal and the Public
LEAD: Cardinal O'Connor says he won't allow AIDS education programs in the schools of the New York Archdiocese to include instruction about condoms.
A church's teaching is its own business, but doctrine that affects public policy invites public comment.
As public policy, the Cardinal's stand is dismaying.


'ARTHUR' ON SKID ROW IN SEQUEL
LEAD: In the temporary guise of a shelter for the homeless, the Washington Square United Methodist Church exchanged pews for rows of cots the other day, and accommodated an unlikely guest.


Joe Rosenfield Jr., 86, Radio Talk Show Host
LEAD: Joe Rosenfield Jr., who was the host of a radio talk show called ''The Happiness Exchange'' for many years, died on Nov. 22 at a nursing home in Falmouth, Me., after a long illness.
He was 86 years old.


Sampson 'Drafted'
LEAD: Saying he had ''a new attitude as though I was just drafted out of college,'' Ralph Sampson made his debut with the Golden State Warriors an emotional and statistical success despite the 113-106 loss to the Los Angeles Lakers at the Oakland Coliseum Arena Thursday night.
The 7-foot-4-inch center, who was traded by Houston with Steve Harris last weekend for Joe Barry Carroll and Eric (Sleepy) Floyd, had 24 points, 8 rebounds, 5 assists and 3 blocked shots.


House Votes to Reprimand Lawmaker for Misconduct
LEAD: The House of Representatives, imposing sanctions on a member for misconduct for the first time in three years, today reprimanded Austin J. Murphy, a Pennsylvania Democrat.

G.M. Orders New Layoffs
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would reduce car production even further and put an additional 2,025 workers on indefinite layoff, beginning on Jan. 25.


Jury Continues Its Deliberations Amid Tensions
LEAD: The jury in the Howard Beach murder case deliberated yesterday for a ninth day without reaching a verdict, amid mounting tensions at the Queens courthouse where four white teen-agers are on trial in the death of a black man.


Soviet Plans Mars Missions; U.S. Aid Sought
LEAD: Expanding on an ambitious drive to explore Mars, Soviet officials are planning to launch a spacecraft to the planet in 1992.
In addition, the Russians have formally asked the United States to modify an American spacecraft to help relay data from another Soviet mission to Mars set for launching in 1994.

Sinai Leaving For Boston Job
LEAD: Allen Sinai, one of Wall Street's best-known economists, is leaving as chief economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers to take a similar position at a Shearson subsidiary in Boston.
He will also become chairman and chief economist of a new economic consulting company.


Patents; A Bacterium to Treat Wood and Crop Wastes
LEAD: A bacterium genetically engineered to break down wood and other crop fibers has been invented by V. R. Srinivasan and two associates after research at Louisiana State University.
Patent 4,713,336, granted them this week, is assigned to Research Corporation Technologies Inc. of Tucson, Ariz., which is offering rights to industry.


Chess Title On the Line Today
LEAD: The world chess champion, Gary Kasparov, and the challenger, Anatoly Karpov, battled evenly tonight in the final game of their championship series, sending their duel into a second day Saturday.


The Dollar Moves Higher As Precious Metals Slump
LEAD: The dollar moved higher in fairly active trading yesterday, bolstered by widespread indications that a statement reaffirming the need for currency stability may come from seven leading industrial nations over the weekend.


Police Admit Surveillance Violated Pact
LEAD: Undercover officers of the New York City Police Department attended at least three meetings of a civil rights organization last summer, violating departmental guidelines requiring special approval for covert surveillance of political groups, the department has acknowledged.


In Praise of Wendell Willkie, a 'Womanizer'
LEAD: In 1940, Franklin D. Roosevelt, breaking precedent, chose to run for a third term.
Instinctively, rather than logically, the Republicans rejected their traditional isolationist leaders and turned to a lawyer-businessman who had never run for public office nor held a governmental post.


Cadbury Expands
LEAD: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. of London announced that it would purchase Chocolat Poulain, a French chocolate company, from Midial S.A. for a price of 950 million French francs, or about $170 million.
Cadbury Schweppes, which has a strong presence in the soft drink business in addition to confectioneries, said that Chocolat Poulain was a leading French maker of branded chocolate products, employing 760 people at two factories at Blois in southern France.

Two Broadway Producers Are Upheld in Fraud Suit
LEAD: A Federal jury Thursday found in favor of two Broadway producers who had been accused of fraud in a suit filed by investors in a 1985 Broadway show.
The verdict was seen by those involved and others in the theater industry as a cautionary tale to both investors and producers about the risky nature of commercial theater production.


'Eddie Murphy Raw'
At the Embassy 3, where ''Eddie Murphy Raw'' opened yesterday, even the ushers were laughing.
And they, like everyone else in the place, had good reasons not to.
The profanity is persistent, parts of Mr.
Murphy's act are filthier than anything Richard Pryor ever attempted (like his adolescent impression of Mr. Pryor doing bathroom jokes), and when it comes to women and homosexuals, Mr.
Murphy is clearly proud of his prejudices.
Nonetheless, this feature-length concert film is hilarious, putting Mr.
Murphy on a par with Mr.
Pryor at his best.
The generation between the two is readily apparent, both in the routine that has Mr.
Murphy mimicking his idol and in his long, scathing anecdote about a telephone call from Bill Cosby, who complained about the obscenity of Mr.
Murphy's show.
First of all, Mr.
Murphy is a terrific parodist, doing a lethal Cosby imitation complete with long pauses and sententious phrasings.
Second, he caps this brilliantly by reporting his own subsequent call to Mr.
Pryor, who said he himself had receivd a similar dressing down.
Do people like you?
Mr.
Pryor asked.
Do you get paid? ''Well, tell Bill I said have a Coke and a smile and shut up.''


Market Value Counts in Commercial Real Estate
LEAD: To the Editor:


David Rhinelander King, Rector, 58
LEAD: The Rev.
David Rhinelander King, rector of St.
John's Episcopal Church in Elizabeth, N.J., died of a heart attack Monday at St.
Elizabeth Hospital in Elizabeth, N.J.
He was 58 years old and lived in Hillside, N.J.
He was a Princeton University graduate and was ordained in 1954.
He is survived by his wife, Mary Sue Griffith; a son, Nicholas, of Hillside; two daughters, Elizabeth, of Dallas, and Melissa, of Hillside, and a twin, Canon Jonathan LeRoy King of Bergenfield, N.J.

A Crazy Way to Govern America
LEAD: Congress is about to send the President one gigantic, take-it-or-leave-it appropriations bill for fiscal 1988.
It's bad enough that the bill isn't even arriving until the fiscal year is almost three months gone.
Worse, it's loaded with trivia, fakery and irrelevant controversy, and forces on President Reagan a $600 billion choice: He must accept every detail of this bill, or, if he wants to block a single one, must veto the whole thing.

FIRST AID FOR SEA STINGS
LEAD: ONE really disagreeable way to ruin a vacation in the sun is to plunge into the surf and get stung, stuck or bitten by a sea creature.
In one case we know of, a vacationer had such an acute allergic reaction to sea urchin spines that he became ill and his traveling companions could not enjoy themselves for worry.

LEAD: PERHAPS you've heard of Mineola's Portuguese enclave, but there's also a Little Germany on Long Island, in Lindenhurst.

LEAD: THE comeback trail got a bit steep for George Foreman Friday night when the 39-year-old former heavyweight champion took on Rocky Sekorski in Las Vegas, Nev., and ran into something he had not encountered in four previous comeback fights, a real battle.
Unlike the four opponents who had succumbed without a scrap, Sekorski actually tried to make a fight of it.


Helping Poor Familes Take Charge of Life
LEAD: New York City enjoyed a phenomenal seven-year economic boom before the stock market collapse.
But these prosperous times did not benefit the people on the fringes of the economy.
The number of poor people increased dramatically from 1.3 million to 1.7 million during that period, including unprecedented numbers of families and children.


A FEAR OF LAWYERS
LEAD: In his article ''A Fear of Lawyers'' (About Men, Nov. 15), Morley L. Torgov has near-missed the point.
Because of the arcane and convoluted laws passed by legislators, most of whom are lawyers, his client and his client's opponent are at the mercy of their lawyers who do not always want their clients to ''compromise'' and ''settle.

LEAD: The United States and China, after a year of often contentious negotiations, concluded an agreement early today that will drastically curb China's shipments of textiles and apparel to the United States through 1991.
It starts Jan. 1.

REFLECT THE HOLIDAY SPIRIT THROUGH COLOR
LEAD: ADD a note of holiday cheer to food prepared for family and friends by paying attention to the color scheme.
Red and green are all it takes.
Peppers remain abundantly in the market in red and green.
Green herbs such as parsley and even greenhouse-grown fresh basil can be combined with red peppers for colorful accents.

LEAD: As the repeated Senate hearings on Supreme Court nominees have demonstrated, the Constitution lives.
Last week it was studied, argued over and even shaped by the Senate Judiciary Committee's dialogue with Judge Anthony Kennedy.
If confirmed, he will have much to say about what the Constitution means.

LEAD: IN the wake of the summit talks between President Reagan and the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, there is profit to be gained from examining East European economic reforms.
Most Soviet economic reforms are direct descendants of the earlier reforms in Hungary and Yugoslavia.
Seeing what happened in East Europe provides insights into what we might expect to see in the Soviet

LEAD: The success of Prime Minister Mohammad Khan Junejo's party in local elections last month is widely seen as an important step in his quest for political legitimacy.


Italy's Original Garlic Bread
LEAD: WHEREVER olive oil is produced in Italy, it's traditional to celebrate the olive harvest and the pungent new oil with a feast of bruschetta.
This is the original garlic bread, made with thick slices toasted over a fire, rubbed with fresh garlic and saturated with intense green olive oil.
This simple yet superb dish is known by various names all over Italy - bruschetta, fett'unta, soma d'aj - depending on the region.


A Warship's 'Eyes' Scan Gulf Region
LEAD: His fellow officers sometimes call Lieut.
Cmdr.
Dana N. Griffin the battleship Iowa's CAG, a naval acronym usually referring to the Commander, Air Group, the head of fighter-jet squadrons on an aircraft carrier.


MANDATORY RECYCLING: HABIT-FORMING
LEAD: AFTER several months of separating recyclable material from trash, people in counties where recycling is required are finding it has become more a habit than a chore - a daily ritual not unlike brushing one's teeth.

Jazz
LEAD: The Henry Threadgill Sextett is a minature orchestra, with strings (bass and cello), brass (trumpet and trombone), percussion (two drummers) and reed instruments (Mr. Threadgill, primarily on alto saxophone).
For much of the 1980's, the Sextett has delivered some of Mr.
Threadgill's wittiest, most boisterous music.

ON STEREOTYPES AND WOMEN ARTISTS
LEAD: To the Editor:


A FEAR OF LAWYERS
LEAD: Opinion polls consistently show that Americans not only fear, but despise lawyers -ranking them with used-car salesmen and politicians.
We don't trust lawyers because they have destroyed the nation's sense of right and wrong.
Most Americans are convinced that our courts do not find in favor of the innocent party, but of the better lawyer.


Europe Considers How to Take Up Arms
LEAD: THIS is a watershed moment of promise and peril in a Europe that for four decades has been the most heavily armed corner of this planet and, paradoxically, the most peaceful, too.


IT'S CATALOGUE TIME
LEAD: FILL large pine cones with a mixture of peanut butter and bird seed or use melted suet to hang on trees for the birds' Merry Christmas; fasten cones securely to ends of smaller limbs to discourage heavy squirrels.
Keep cyclamens and azaleas cool to prolong their lives; avoid drafty places for poinsettias.

LEAD:  IN LA-LA LAND WE TRUST, by Robert Campbell. (Mysterious Press, $3.95.) La-La Land is Los Angeles, where the discovery of a headless corpse helps a private investigator named Whistler uncover a pornography ring run by a seemingly respectable businessman with a voyeuristic taste for murder. ''Whistler is in many ways a very modern reincarnation of Hammett's Continental Op,'' Newgate Callendar said in The Book Review last year.

FROM CHINESE BRUSHES, MASTER STROKES
LEAD: ''IMAGES OF THE MIND'' IS AN exhibition of Chinese art with a great deal to say.

JESSE JACKSON AIMS FOR THE MAINSTREAM
LEAD: Jesse Jackson may ''aim for the mainstream,'' but he remains a divisive force in American life, in spite of all his new appeals and continued efforts to paint himself as a ''rainbow'' man.
His being a preacher makes me as uncomfortable with his candidacy as I am with Pat Robertson's.
Their respective backgrounds and activities as adults were both partisan and religiously oriented, and I question whether such personalities would serve the country's best interests.


A TREE FOR REMEMBRANCE
LEAD: EITHER way you look at it, a Christmas tree is an expense.
If a cut tree is chosen and trimmed with colorful trinkets and lights, its days of glory are brief.
All too soon, the tree is tossed on a trash heap to be carted away or cut up to protect a perennial border from spring frosts.

ARTICLE'S 'ESTHER' WAS REALLY 'RUTH'
LEAD: It came as a shock to read (''Tradition Inspires Illuminator,'' Dec. 6) that Queen Esther, heroine of the Purim story, was ''the only non-Jew revered in Hebraic history.'' If Esther (a descendant of King Saul) is not Jewish, the whole point of the story is lost: She is willing to lay her life on the line by revealing her religion to her husband to save her people.

LEAD: PAY raises for the state's top elected officials - including a 35 percent increase for the governor and an 80 percent increase for the treasurer - have been unanimously recommended by a state commission.

Dance: Japanese Legend, 'Himiko,' by Tomonaga
LEAD: AKIMITSU TOMONAGA had a good idea in ''Himiko: A Legendary Fantasy From Japan,'' which was presented on Friday at the Kampo Cultural Center, 31 Bond Street.
The hourlong spectacle told, through a blend of classical and modern techniques, the story of the shamanic Queen Himiko, who unified the Yamatai kingdom of ancient Japan.

Recital: Ilan Rechtman, Pianist, in Debut at Y
LEAD: ILAN RECHTMAN is a 24-year-old Israeli-born pianist and composer whose New York debut on Thursday evening at the 92d Street Y left one feeling more positive about his playing as the evening progressed.
His recital began with a version of Bach's G-major Partita that included moments of inventive playing - the slow opening to the minuet, for instance, and a buoyant gigue - but that failed to sustain interest over more than short stretches.

Mexico devalued its currency by 18 percent on Monday.

SHOCK THERAPY
LEAD: Susan Squire deserves congratulations for her clear article on electroconvulsive therapy (''Shock Therapy's Return to Respectability,'' Nov. 22).
ECT is the treatment of choice for certain severe forms of depression.
Like other treatments, it has potential side effects, and patients should explore with their physicians the risks and benefits of treatment alternatives.

Switzerland
LEAD: To the Editor: From a Manhattan-born U.S. and Swiss citizen, a first prize to Anthony Burgess for his fine article on Switzerland as viewed from Lugano.

IN SHORT: FICTION
LEAD: THE NEWSPAPER OF CLAREMONT STREET.
By Elizabeth Jolley. (Viking, $14.95.) In this small, richly peculiar novel, Elizabeth Jolley writes about money the way others write about love - lyrically, longingly, sensually.
Money is the obsession of Margarite Morris, known as ''the Newspaper of Claremont Street'' or ''Weekly'' because of the petty gossip she picks up and passes along on her rounds cleaning houses in a small Australian town.

Leniency for Ailing Speeder
LEAD: Leona B. Hann, who drove her car the wrong way at 90 to 100 miles an hour on Interstate 70 in March and crashed it into an unmarked police car has been found not criminally responsible because she was acutely depressed.
Judge Francis M. Arnold of Howard County District Court placed Ms.
Hann, 41 years old, of Warfordsburg, Pa., on probation Wednesday and ordered that she be given medical treatment.

A Theatrical Vision Endures
LEAD: ''OUR TOWN'' MAY BE the most misunderstood and misinterpreted of American plays.
It is not, as is often assumed, a hymn to small-town life at the turn of the century.
Nor is it the American equivalent of Dylan Thomas's ''Under Milk Wood,'' a poetic memory piece suffused with character and atmosphere.

LEAD: Oscar Schmidt, who led Brazil to a stunning upset of the United States by scoring 46 points in the Pan American Games basketball final last summer, said he is awed by the National Basketball Association but prefers to play in Italy.


Minority shift in the city's work force
LEAD: Minorities - blacks, Hispanics and Asians - are on the verge of becoming a majority in New York City's resident labor force, the United States Department of Labor announced last week.
The change reflects a shift in the city's population: the exodus of non-Hispanic whites and the influx of blacks, Hispanics and newer ethnic groups, such as Asians.

SHOCK THERAPY
LEAD: I had a course of ECT at a prestigious New York hospital in 1984.
Today, I struggle with a permanent loss of mental function.
I don't need to wonder whether ECT causes brain damage; I have the result of my own brain scan to prove that it does.
I doubt that the aging process could be blamed for this damage, because I am 27 years old.

Gadgets
LEAD: To the Editor: We enjoyed ''Gifts of Gear and Gadgets'' (Travel, Nov. 22).
As frequent travelers we have availed ourselves of most of them.
However, one item that might seem superfluous, in the United States and some parts of Europe, is not mentioned.
It is a traveling smoke detector.
It may be purchased with traveling case for between $10 and $15.

Woven Baskets From Ireland
LEAD: FOR centuries the common denominator of every household in Ireland - from a stone cottage perched on a Kerry cliff to a big house reigning over a Longford village - has been the daily use of baskets, especially to hold two staples of Irish life, potatoes and peat clods, or turf, for fuel.
Today, in an age dominated by plastics, professional basket makers supply a growing home and international market for willow and rush baskets made in the traditional way.

On Track in Morocco
LEAD: THERE'S a delicious scariness about skirting the fringes of a great desert.
The feeling has something in common with riding a roller coaster or making faces at a caged tiger: one can savor the proximity of danger without actually having to confront it.
When an unwary visitor or downed aviator is truly snared in the death grip of a major desert, of course, survival is no joke.

Gleaning Truth's From Yesteryear
LEAD: ''SORRELL AND SON,'' THE BRITISH period drama currently on public television's ''Masterpiece Theater'' (locally, on Channels 13 and 49 on Sunday evenings at 9), has a way of telling us something about ourselves today.
The mini-series stands as a refreshing reminder of what used to be called the eternal verities - kindness, compassion, self-sacrifice and the like - the very commodities employed so astutely by, among others, Thornton Wilder in ''Our Town'' and Sherwood Anderson in ''Winesburg, Ohio.

LEAD: Marie McBroom of Jersey City worked for years as a travel agent to interest other blacks in visiting Nigeria.

To the Top of Africa
LEAD: IT began as a pilgrimage, a sentimental voyage to Africa's northernmost cape to complement earlier voyages that had led to another cape, far to the south, at a continent's tip.
But it ended more as uncharted meandering along Tunisia's less beaten tracks, beach and forest and antiquity, a journey freckled with surprise and discovery: how, for instance, to prepare and cook a brik; or how they hunt wild boar in the winter with dogs, beaters and shotguns in the uplands back from the coast.

By W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $16.95.) This seventh volume of W. E. B. Griffin's ''Brotherhood of War'' series brings back many of the same characters whose military careers have been delineated in the first six.
The series is in the platoon-movie genre - one of everything.

CLASHING VIEWS RESHAPE ART HISTORY
LEAD: SOME CALL THEM ''RADICALS,'' ''REVISION-ists'' or simply troublemakers.
But to others -and to themselves - they are challenging the traditional insularity of art history.
Energetic, contentious and often controversial, they are a loose-knit community of scholars in universities throughout the country who use methods derived from outside the field to study the visual arts as more than a purely esthetic phenomenon.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.B.A.
Bullets 109, Bulls 96: Bernard King scored 28 points and Moses Malone added 20 for Washington last night.
King scored 8 points as the Bullets built an 89-78 lead 1 minute 45 seconds into the final quarter.
He then added two baskets in an 8-2 Washington run that gave the Bullets a 99-84 lead with 6:31 to play.

LEAD: Americas Watch, a human rights organization based in the United States, urged the Peruvian Government today to take stronger measures to prevent and punish abuses carried out by security forces in combating a Maoist guerrilla group.


Mayor to Pay for Inquiry
LEAD: Mayor Anthony Cucci will pay for a inquiry into the Jersey City Police Department out of his personal campaign fund after the City Council rejected financing the investigation, the Mayor's spokesman said today.
On Friday, the Mayor officially hired a former New York City Police Commissioner, Patrick Murphy, who began investigating the Police Department, which has been accused recently of insensitivity to complaints from city's Indian community.

Don't Forget to Dust the House
LEAD: IT may not be nice to fool Mother Nature but it can be profitable.
In 1986, the Weyerhaeuser Company of Tacoma, Wash., purchased the United States patent rights to a process invented in Sweden 10 years ago in which certain types of plants and trees are ''interiorized'' - that is, preserved in their natural state for many years.


GIANTS AWAKE AND WIN ONE
LEAD: The Giants snapped out of their lethargy today and beat a hard-playing team by playing harder.
Their offense was efficient and their defense was tough except for a few shaky moments late in the game, and the result was a 20-10 victory over the Green Bay Packers.

LEAVING HIS IMPRINT ON BROADWAY
LEAD: I do not question Lloyd Richards's esteemed place in the American theater (''Leaving His Imprint on Broadway,'' by Samuel G. Freedman, Nov. 22).
But he has left his imprint on Broadway at the expense of students of the Yale School of Drama.
As a student there, I knew Lloyd Richards to be a dean who was often absent from the school, a stranger to most students.

LONG LIVE BABE'S MOMENTS
LEAD: MORE than half a century after his last home run and nearly four decades after his death, Babe Ruth is still making headlines, still creating debate.
Just as his 714 homers and his 94-46 record with a 2.28 earned run average as a left-handed pitcher certify him as the best player in baseball history, his enduring esteem as a newsmaker is another reason why he remains the most celebrated baseball player in history.

Skiing Aspen's Quiet Side
LEAD: ALL around me at 9,500 feet that sunny winter morning were the spectacular snow-coated Rocky Mountains, with the Continental Divide looming like a thick band of vanilla ice cream across the horizon.
But I wasn't enjoying any of it, for my eyes were fixed on the silver tips of my skis, which were in midair, suspended over the side of a mountain.

SHOCK THERAPY
LEAD: As a social worker, I hesitate to call this process therapy, inasmuch as the patient undergoing ECT is totally passive and anesthetized.
I have witnessed the effect of this procedure on many patients and, admittedly, have seen positive short-term results.
I have also seen the same patients readmitted several weeks later.

BUSINESS FORUM: Congress, Taxes and the Arts; Treat the Artist and the Publisher Differently
LEAD: THERE is currently a tax issue that is causing significant alarm among the nation's creative artists.
The issue may be wholly attributable to a misinterpretation of the 1986 Tax Reform Act changes.
In my opinion, the misinterpretation of the Tax Reform Act results from confusing creative artists with the groups that produce and market their work - book and music publishers, art galleries, film and recording studios.

Broadcast TV
LEAD: Calling all VCR's - to tape ''A Christmas Carol'' (1951) for family enjoyment on Christmas Day.
This year the definitive British filming of Dickens is slotted late on Thursday - 12:30 A.M. on Channel 5 - with most children already tucked in bed awaiting Santa.
So a taped run-off should make perfect family fare for Christmas Day.


On Cigarette Ads
LEAD: 'Pravda does not carry cigarette advertising, or indeed any advertising.
Government control of information is typical of totalitarian regimes and dictatorships.
Those who favor such a ban hope to control the behavior of Americans by limiting their access to information.
Ad bans represent censorship and idea control.

IN SHORT: FICTION
LEAD: INDOCHINE.
By Christie Dickason. (Villard, $18.95.) A vivid sense of place and a thorough knowledge of Vietnamese culture distinguish this colorful if flawed first novel by an American-born director and choreographer who lived in Indochina in the 1950's.
Christie Dickason's heroine, Nina Luoc, is the daughter of a Frenchwoman and a wealthy Vietnamese who sees her privileged life shattered in 1954 when her mother is killed and her father disappears in the wake of an explosion at their home.

Opera: Mascagni's 'Amico Fritz' at Kennedy Center
LEAD: ''L'Amico Fritz'' is the second of Mascagni's 17 operas, and, as far as I know them, also the second best.
In some ways its craftsmanship and tangy harmonies may even make it preferable to ''Cavalleria Rusticana,'' which made the young composer's fame in 1890. ''Fritz'' is a treasurable piece, completely different from its predecessor: the trailblazer of verismo took Bellini's pastoral ''Sonnambula'' as his model here, and made something touching and memorable.

Two Alabama Officers Slain By Man Who Then Kills Self
LEAD: A man killed two police officers before apparently taking his own life Saturday, police officials said.

LEAD: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about new cookbooks misstated a title.
The book is ''Reading Between the Recipes,'' by Leslie Land (Yankee Books, $15.95).

LEAD: Gifts I would unwrap each Christmas are bound in twine I cannot always cut in time to join the caroling; twine tough as mindless dread - or wisteria that chokes the tree it climbs - it must be slashed away each season.

LEAD: It has survived one of the fiercest, most unpredictable and costly legal battles in history.
But Texaco Inc.'s problems are by no means over.

LEAD: The medical center that pioneered infant heart transplants has announced a policy to make sure anencephalic babies, those born with most of the brain missing, are brain-dead before they are used as organ donors.


2 Homeless Men Die In Separate Incidents In New York City
LEAD: Two homeless men died, one in a fire in a makeshift shanty in the South Bronx, and another on the steps of a storefront office on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, apparently of exposure to the cold weather, the police reported yesterday.

LEAD: The combined pressures of a superpower arms accord and maneuvering for a presidential campaign here have quickened the evolution of French strategic doctrine toward an automatic commitment to defend West Germany at its eastern frontiers in case of a Warsaw Pact attack.


A Remarkable Athlete
LEAD: By major college standards, Tony Dawson of Florida State is neither a particularly quick basketball player nor an impressive jumper.
But by any measure, Dawson is truly a remarkable athlete.


Dance: Rachel Harms's 'Blue Foxes'
LEAD: RACHEL HARMS has created some interesting dances that are memorable in part for their dramatic resonance.
But ''Blue Foxes,'' a new work presented by the Rachel Harms Dance Company on Saturday at St.
Mark's Church was surprisingly unevocative, despite the fact that the suite of dances was said to be an exploration of the charged atmosphere of nighttime and the behavior of people at night.


Experts Fault Democrats On Economic Platforms
LEAD: The Democratic Presidential candidates agree that the Federal budget deficit portends economic disaster, that President Reagan is to blame because of his tax cuts and increased military spending, and that among the pressing tasks for the next President will be to control the deficit.

LEAD: Long before the movie was even released, people were talking about Elaine Stritch's performance in Woody Allen's new film, ''September.''


Sotheby's Good Quarter
LEAD: Sotheby's auction house, which in November set the world record price of $53.9 million for a painting, with the sale of Vincent van Gogh's ''Irises,'' announced Friday its best-ever fourth-quarter results.
It reported worldwide auction sales of $:340 million, or about $622 million, for the latest three months, up 2.7 percent over the corresponding period last year.

LEAD: A new immigration law has failed to stem the flow of illegal aliens from El Salvador to the United States, according to a confidential cable from the American Embassy there.

A program devoted to it, presented by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater on Wednesday at City Center, suggested that the tradition or heritage is one of strong women and playfully spirited men, of profound suffering and equally profound hope - and of the capacity to celebrate each in vital, entertaining theater and dance.

Cinemette Theaters Sold
LEAD: The Cinemette Corporation has sold its 160 movie theaters for an undisclosed price to Cinema World Inc., a Cinemette vice president, George Stern, said.
Cinema World is owned by Matthew Bronfman of New York, son of the head of the Seagram Company; Robert Malina of Malina, Bodner &amp; Associates, the New York investment bankers, and Jeffrey Lewine, Cinema World's chairman and chief executive.


Paraguay's Most Famous Prisoner Is 'Free'
LEAD: Three days after completing a 25-year jail sentence, Paraguay's longest-serving political prisoner was freed from his cell in Asuncion today and ordered confined to a provincial town for 30 days.


Market Place; Lukewarm Views Of Oil Stocks
LEAD: SINKING oil prices customarily translate into a curb on inflation, and last week this interpretation sent stock and bond prices bounding ahead.
Wall Street took its cue from recent meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries after it became apparent that the group was unable to stem overproduction and price discounting.


Parts in 29 Cruise Missiles Did Not Have Proper Tests
LEAD: A study conducted for the House Armed Services Committee said today that at least 29 Air Force cruise missiles had guidance systems with an improperly tested component.


27 Vehicles in Pile-Up On Highway in Queens
LEAD: Twenty-seven vehicles piled up in a chain-reaction accident on the rain-soaked Whitestone Expressway in Queens early yesterday, but only minor injuries were reported, the police said.


One Craft Combines Two Popular Sports
LEAD: It is unlikely that Johann Klepper, a German who invented the folding sea kayak in 1907, could have imagined its future.
What would he think if he could see it with a sailing rig on a trans-Atlantic crossing nearly 50 years later?
Or as a sabotage craft during World War II?
Or in the 1980's as standard equipment for a weekend excursion on the water?

LEAD: TALLEY BEATTY took the title of ''The Stack-Up'' from a phrase that can mean freeway congestion.
Nevertheless, his work, which the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater performed Saturday afternoon at the City Center, 131 West 55th Street, and will repeat on Tuesday evening, concerns emotional, rather than highway, traffic.

LEAD: The veil of secrecy surrounding trading in the Treasury and agency securities market ought to be lifted, at least partly, according to a report to be published today by the General Accounting Office.

LEAD: The Singer Company said late last night that it had notified Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor, that he could complete his pending tender offer for the company if he could arrange the necessary financing and promptly complete the deal.

LEAD: Skip Novak remembers the incident clearly.
It was a day in August two years ago when the keel fell off the 77-foot maxi-yacht he was sailing near the southwestern coast of England.
Water came rushing through the hatches as the boat turned belly up.

LEAD: The E. F. Hutton Group's efforts in the last two years to turn around the fortunes of the battered investment house by hiring away talent from other companies have turned out to be an expensive gamble that failed.

LEAD: THE news spread quickly on that cool autumn evening in October 1976.
The New York Nets, as they were known then, were on the West Coast, beginning their first season in the National Basketball Association.
It was supposed to be a time for celebration for the team from a maligned league that played with a ball that critics said belonged on a beach, not a basketball court.

A Quirk of Fate?
LEAD: Here's a tale of the criminal justice system that begins in Maryland a quarter-century ago with a ''murder'' that may not even have been committed.
The shooting victim's insurance company was sure that he committed suicide - so sure that it refused to pay off on the dead man's policy until the murder conviction of Nick Donald Bagley, an 18-year-old black man, in October 1962.

Transit Agency Said to Waste Station Lighting in a Big Way
LEAD: The New York City Transit Authority wastes enough electricity in one year in lighting its 463 subway stations to light Shea Stadium until the middle of 1996 if all home games of the Mets were played at night, according to an audit report by City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin.

Press Strictures in Zanzibar
LEAD: The local government in Zanzibar will introduce a law to require journalists, newspapers and magazines to register with the Government, a local official said today.
Zanzibar, an autonomous Indian Ocean island which forms part of Tanzania, has no daily newspaper at present, but the official said the new law would oblige journalists visiting Zanzibar to obtain local accreditation before writing any news articles.

BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 22, 1987
LEAD:  Companies


Boy Who Nearly Drowned Goes Home From the Hospital
LEAD: Alvaro Garza Jr. leaving St.
Luke's Hospitals in Fargo, N.D., with mother, Mary Helen, and Dr.
William Norberg, his physician.
The 11-year-old had been there since Dec. 4 when he was rescued from the Red River.
He had been submerged for 45 minutes after falling through ice.
Doctors said that, altough he will need therapy, they are hopeful he will regain full control of his injured arms and legs.


PLANNERS REJECT A TOWER THAT IS 11 FEET TOO TALL
LEAD: The New York City Planning Commission refused yesterday to grant retroactive approval for additions to a mid-Manhattan skyscraper that have resulted in a building 11 feet taller than originally permitted by the planning body and the Board of Estimate.


Uncovered Short Sales Are Up 6.3% on Big Board
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the Big Board's ''short interest'' position - the number of shares sold short and not yet covered - in the month ended Dec. 15 rose by 29.1 million shares, or 6.3 percent, to 494.6 million shares.

LEAD: An official Soviet spokesman has written to The New York Times to take issue with Natan Sharansky, once a prominent leader of the Soviet human rights movement, over who attended a dinner in Moscow some 15 years ago and what was said there.

Mechanism for Muscle Contractions Is Found
LEAD: TO hold this newspaper, various muscles in your hand and arm must contract, a process that involves a flood of calcium into the fluid inside muscle cells.
To release your grip, those muscles must relax, which results when calcium flows back into storage in special sacs within the cells.


Deficit So Far Tops '87 Pace
LEAD: The Federal Government ran up a $25.77 billion budget deficit in November, and the shortfall in the first two months of the fiscal year has risen by 8 percent above last year's level, the Treasury Department reported today.


Rumanian Player Defects in Miami
LEAD: A 17-year-old Rumanian tennis player seeking political asylum defected today at Miami International Airport, the police said.

LEAD: Like the young republic whose founding it commemorates, the Commission on the Bicentennial of the United States Constitution is coming under attack.

Our Towns; Elderly Hands Help Brighten Holiday Season
LEAD: ''Miss Pearl, where did you put the wiggly worm?'' Jean Batcheller was sure Pearl Curran would know.
At 65, Miss Pearl Curran -the youngest worker at the Master Crafters shop here - knows every item's life story, not to mention where it's hidden.


Greenpeace Protests
LEAD: Amid growing concern that Japan will ignore opposition to research whaling, environmentalists today towed a 50-foot plastic humpback whale across the bow of a whaling ship docked here.


Piano: Aleksandra Romantic
LEAD: ALEKSANDRA ROMANIC, a Yugoslavian pianist who has played prominently on the Soviet and Eastern European circuit, opened her austere debut program at Alice Tully Hall Sunday evening with the massive Bach-Busoni Chaconne.
She played with a sense of the work's grandeur that did not quite amount to an embodiment of it, but gave evidence of some imagination in matters of textural shading.

Wertheim's Chairman Gets Key Job at Ames
LEAD: James A. Harmon, an investment banker who has served on the board of Ames Department Stores Inc. since 1967, was named chairman yesterday, succeeding Herbert Gilman, one of three brothers who founded the chain.


Nunn's Noel
LEAD: On the strength of Georgia peaches, peanuts and sand dollars, Senator Sam Nunn has emerged as the victor in a Congressional holiday decorating competition.
The contest, sponsored by Roll Call, a Capitol Hill newspaper, has been held annually for 32 years and is judged by the paper's editors.
This year it got more than 100 entries.

Critic's Book Assesses Fortunes of the Theater
LEAD: Garson Kanin says that Otis L. Guernsey Jr. is to the American theater ''as James Boswell is to Dr.
Johnson, pursuing his arduous task with charm and trenchancy.'' Like Boswell's, Mr.
Guernsey's copious jottings have a hot-from-the-griddle appeal.


Time to Act on Taxes
LEAD: YOU have seven working days left to do something about the tax consequences of buying or using a personal computer in 1987.
Here are some guidelines.
As always, check with your accountant or another qualified tax adviser before making a major tax decision.


Music: Chamber Group
LEAD: APPREHENSION of Ferruccio Busoni's music may eventually recapitulate the postwar ''discovery'' of Mahler.
Both composers belong to that exciting period around the turn of the 20th century when everything in music was coming to a boil; both won great fame as performers but found only a limited audience for their strange, ambiguous amalgam of old and new in their compositions.


Santa Hats Cause Flap at Jersey Factory
LEAD: Employees of the Okonite Company outside the plant in North Brunswick yesterday as they protested their suspensions last week for wearing Santa Claus hats on the job after being warned not to.
In addition to the 23 suspended last week, 100 employees were suspended yesterday when they wore Santa hats to work to show support for the employees previously suspended.


Amid Doubt, Bilzerian Extends Bid for Singer
LEAD: Amid growing uncertainty that he can raise the money, Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor, extended his offer yesterday to buy the Singer Company for $50 a share, or $1 billion in cash, until 5 P.M. tomorrow.


Leo Burnett Loses Mars Candy Business
LEAD: The Leo Burnett Company is losing all its Mars candy business because the pet foods it handles for the H. J. Heinz Company is upsetting Mars Inc. corporate management.


Fashion Director: Always an Elusive Job Description
LEAD: ''It's our responsibility to be the eyes and ears of the store,'' said Ellin Saltzman of Saks Fifth Avenue.


A GENERAL STRIKE BY ISRAEL'S ARABS DISRUPTS COUNTRY
LEAD: Hundreds of thousands of Arabs inside Israel joined others in the occupied territories today in a general strike protesting Israel's handling of a wave of protests.


Jacques Sigurd, 67, French Screenwriter For Young Signoret
LEAD: Jacques Sigurd, a French screenwriter whose films helped start the career of Simone Signoret, died of lung cancer Sunday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital.
He was 67 years old and lived in Paris and Manhattan.


Retired Chief to Head General Public Utilities
LEAD: William G. Kuhns, a longtime leader of the General Public Utilities Corporation, has come out of retirement to succeed John F. O'Leary as the utility's chairman and chief executive.
Mr.
O'Leary died Saturday.


Dole Scores Again
LEAD: Score another Presidential campaign point for Senator Bob Dole in his quest to upstage Vice President Bush.


Canada Backs Dome Merger
LEAD: The long takeover saga of Dome Petroleum Ltd. by the Amoco Corporation's Canadian subsidiary neared completion today after the Canadian Government approved the deal, worth $5.5 billion (Canadian), or about $4.2 billion in United States currency.


Chip Maker Reports Profit
LEAD: The National Semiconductor Corporation today reported its third consecutive quarter of profitability.
For the 13-week quarter ended Nov. 29, National had earnings of $11.1 million, or 8 cents a share, compared with a loss of $5.7 million in the 12-week quarter ended Dec. 14, 1986.
Sales rose 40 percent, to $640 million, from $456.8 million in the second quarter of the 1987 fiscal year.


ARCO Lifts Stake In Britoil to 14.7%
LEAD: ARCO, competing against the British Petroleum Company for control of Britoil P.L.C., said it had lifted its stake in Britoil to 14.7 percent, from 7.7 percent.
An ARCO spokesman, Al Greenstein, said the share purchases were made public in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.


G.M. Optimistic
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it had projected sales of 1.3 million Opel and Vauxhall cars in Europe in 1987.
The projections are 3 percent more than last year's sales of 1.2 million and equal to 10.7 percent of the market, compared with 10.9 percent in 1986.
John F. Smith Jr., the president of G.M.


3 Die and 2 Are Rescued in Blaze in Bronx
LEAD: Three people were killed early yesterday when a fire broke out in their fifth-floor apartment in the Bronx.
Two others were saved as they were about to jump from a window.


Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q.Cold air supposedly constricts the capillaries in the skin.
Why, then, do your nose and cheeks turn red on a nippy day?
A.Oxygen gives blood its bright red color, said Dr.
Barbara Gilchrest, chairman of dermatology at the Boston University School of Medicine.
Oxygenated blood flows in arteries from the heart to the capillaries, where it gives up oxygen to cells.


Pan Am Pilots Rebuff Offer
LEAD: The pilots' union of Pan American World Airways Inc. has concluded that Jay A. Pritzker's takeover proposal for the airline is not viable, thus ending an effort by a union coalition to find a buyer for the airline, union leaders said yesterday.


College Hockey Notebook; Sacrifice, Devotion and Enthusiasm
LEAD: At the Division III level, the so-called small college plateau in sports, the problems confronting a hockey team in the metropolitan area are monumental.


PRICES OF TREASURY BONDS RETREAT
LEAD: Treasury bond prices retreated yesterday after traders learned that Congressional leaders had agreed over the weekend to authorize the Treasury to sell another $20 billion of long-term issues with interest rates of more than 4 1/4 percent.


Steel Output Off 5.2%
LEAD: Steel production fell to 1.694 million tons in the week ended Saturday, a decrease of 5.2 percent from the previous week's 1.787 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 78.5 percent of capacity for the week, compared with 82.8 percent in the previous week.

LEAD: The State Senate today passed Governor Kean's plan to allow state takeovers of failing school districts, 29 to 5, over the objections of some legislators who said the bill appeared aimed at punishing their urban districts.


The Editorial Notebook; The Fire Tender and the Hungry
LEAD: Kalif Beacon is an itinerant musician and founder of the Temple of the Rainbow Food Kitchen.
He calls himself the Fire Tender.
The pots on his makeshift wood stove have simmered steadily since he began feeding homeless and hungry New Yorkers in September.
His sooty hands are as black as his beard; his eyes are a piercing blue; on his shaggy head sits a stovepipe hat.


Senate Finance Committee Hit Its Tax Targets; Pentagon Legerdemain
LEAD: To the Editor:


Izler Solomon, 77, an Orchestra Conductor
LEAD: Izler Solomon, music director of the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra from 1955 to 1975, years that saw significant expansion and enhanced status come to that ensemble, died of heart failure Dec. 6 in Fort Wayne, Ind., where he lived.
He was 77 years old.


SOVIET GIVES U.S. PHOTO OF MISSILE
LEAD: The Soviet Union has provided the United States with an original photograph of its SS-20 missile, Reagan Administration officials said today.

Comings and Goings
LEAD: Mario Lemieux of the Pittsburgh Penguins, who had five goals and seven assists in four games, was named player of the week in the National Hockey League. . . .
Larry Nance, the Phoenix Suns forward who averaged 32.7 points, 11.7 rebounds and three blocked shots last week, was named National Basketball Association player of the week.


Both Sides Report Heavy Fighting In Rebel Offensive in Nicaragua
LEAD: Both the Government and the contras reported heavy fighting today in a major guerrilla attack in northeastern Nicaragua, but otherwise the two sides offered conflicting accounts.


MIDEAST VIOLENCE ALARMS U.S. JEWS
LEAD: The head of a leading American Jewish group said yesterday that the violence between Israeli soldiers and Palestinian demonstrators should ''shock Israel's Government'' into aggressively negotiating an end to the Israeli occupation of some Arab lands.


U.N. Meeting Breaks Up Over Resolution on Israel
LEAD: A Security Council meeting on the violence in Israeli-occupied territories broke up in confusion tonight after the Palestine Liberation Organization and some Arab governments tried to toughen a draft resolution deploring Israel's handling of the disturbances.

Stage: 'Haddocks' Eyes,' Tom Hulce as Lewis Carroll
LEAD: DAVID DEL TREDICI is apparently making a rewarding life's work out of his musical interpretations of Lewis Carroll.
Lately he has been sidestepping into related performance areas - into dance with a Glen Tetley ballet, and into theater with ''Haddocks' Eyes.'' For the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer, the theatrical move seems effortless.


Pitchers Talking
LEAD: Jack Morris is getting closer to an agreement on a new contract with the Detroit Tigers and Charlie Leibrandt may soon break off negotiations with the Kansas City Royals, the agent for the pitchers said yesterday.


Official of Democratic Party In Kansas Is Shot to Death
LEAD: Charles W. Thompson, chairman of the Wyandotte County Democratic Party Central Committee and a two-time delegate to the party's national convention, was shot and killed today outside a restaurant, the police said.


Protest Against Racism Disrupts New York Rush Hour
LEAD: With surgical precision, a protest against racism by several hundred people severed critical subway and bridge links between Brooklyn and Manhattan late yesterday afternoon and disrupted the homebound rush of hundreds of thousands of commuters and holiday shoppers.

Korean Beetles Battle Plant Pest
LEAD: Two predatory beetles from South Korea have been enlisted as warriors to fight tiny sucking insects that threaten American shrubbery, the Agriculture Department said last week.


The Pace of Evolution: A Fossil Creature Moves to Center of Debate
LEAD: WHEN Peter Sheldon chipped his first fossil trilobite from some rocks in Wales a decade ago, two American scientists were transforming standard evolutionary theory with a radical idea.
Well-established species, they argued, tend to change little or not at all as the eons pass; most real evolution takes place in rapid bursts at the rare moments when new species are born.

LEAD: Despite reports of a rebel offensive that began in northeastern Nicaragua on Sunday, the war appears to be stalemated.


3 Recommended For Schools Chancellor
LEAD: Three candidates for New York City Schools Chancellor were formally recommended to the Board of Education yesterday, with the choice essentially between two of them, according to people involved in the search.

Fletcher D. Richards Sr. Advertising Executive
LEAD: Fletcher Doughitt Richards Sr., a retired advertising executive, died Friday at the Albany Medical Center Hospital after a brief illness.
He was 95 years old and lived in Clifton Park, N.Y., where he had moved from Greenwich, Conn.


Jacob Heller, Lawyer For Garage Group, 82
LEAD: Jacob R. Heller, an attorney who represented the Metropolitan Garage Owners Association for 40 years, died last Thursday at Wellington Regional Medical Center in Florida after a brief illness.
He was 82 years old and lived in Rockville Centre, L.I., and in Royal Palm Beach, Fla.


Arkady I. Raikin, 76, a Comedian Who Lampooned Soviet Life, Dies
LEAD: Arkady I. Raikin, who became the Soviet Union's most beloved comedian by deftly poking fun at the idiosyncracies of the Soviet system under a succession of rulers from Stalin to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, died over the weekend, the official press agency Tass reported today.
He was 76 years old.
Mr.
Raikin's humor, which mixed wicked satire with sentimental schmaltz and in his younger days physical slapstick, made him a favorite of several generations, and led many


New York's Medicaid Program Is Found to Be Among Best
LEAD: A report issued today by a consumer group says Minnesota, Wisconsin and New York have the best Medicaid programs in the country, in terms of what kinds of services are covered and how much the programs pay for, among other criteria.


Next Stop: the South Pole
LEAD: ACCORDING to the National Science Foundation, which logs the going and coming of travelers to the ultra-Deep South, about 7,200 paying tourists are visiting Antarctica this year, a mob that outnumbers the White Continent's normal complement of polar professionals by more than 2 to 1.


Asuncion Journal; In Autumn of the Patriarch, Murmurs Grow Loud
LEAD: Presidential elections are still eight weeks away and campaigning has not yet begun, but the winner, Gen.
Alfredo Stroessner, is already receiving the ''profound and sincere thanks'' of his acolytes for his ''inexhaustible vocation'' for serving Paraguay.


Estranged Husband Kills Family of 3 and Himself
LEAD: A Queens father, separated from his family and ''very, very depressed,'' fatally shot his wife, two daughters and himself yesterday, the police said.


John Francis O'Leary, Chairman Of a Utility and Ex-U.S. Official
LEAD: John Francis O'Leary, chairman of the General Public Utilities Corporation and deputy secretary of energy in the Carter Administration, died Saturday at Thomas Jefferson University in Philadelphia after a brief illness.
He was 61 years old and lived in Mendham, N.J.

European Telescope Will Be Biggest
LEAD: CONCLUDING a decade of debate over financing and technical details, a consortium of West European nations has at last committed itself to building a telescope so powerful that it is likely to dominate astronomical research well into the 21st century.


Banks Add Charges, Cut Jobs
LEAD: Seeking to bolster its profits, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company has begun charging a fee for withdrawals made through its cash machines and, according to banking industry officials, has planned to dismiss 2,500 employees by the end of March.

Yonkers Anguish: Black and White in 2 Worlds
LEAD: Bernadette McLaughlin lives on the east side of this city, Margaret Puryear on the west.
The two women share a deep nostalgia about a lost past and fears about the future.
But they inhabit separate worlds, divided by far more than the Saw Mill River Parkway, the concrete barrier that runs between them.


One Killed and 4 Wounded In Gunfire at a Haitian Mass
LEAD: One man was killed and at least four people were wounded today when three gunmen fired into a memorial march for the victims of last month's election day violence.


Market Place; Texaco, Pennzoil: Their Prospects
LEAD: TEXACO INC. and the Pennzoil Company have ridden Wall Street's roller coaster in recent years and now, with the proposed settlement of their mammoth legal dispute, some analysts see both stocks poised for possible further gains.


2 From Soviet Bloc in Games
LEAD: Hungary and East Germany became the first Soviet-bloc nations to announce that they will participate in the 1988 Summer Olympics in South Korea.


Back in Familiar Territory, Mullen Makes Himself at Home
LEAD: When the game was over, Brian Mullen finished his chores in the basement of Madison Square Garden and began the walk home.
He worked his way west through the dank streets for two blocks, then turned uptown for slightly more than a dozen.
At 49th Street, he took a seat on a stoop across the pavement from his apartment house and quietly began to hold court.


Disarmament Jitters
LEAD: The reason America's European allies have firmly endorsed the new treaty to destroy Soviet and American medium-range missiles is that it would be politically damaging to refuse.
Their own voters would be indignant.


Phototron Sues Kodak, 2 Others
LEAD: The Phototron Corporation, a wholesale photographic finishing company based in San Bernardino, Calif., has filed suit in Federal court seeking $300 million from the Eastman Kodak Company and two other photo companies claiming they violated Federal and state antitrust laws.


G.O.P. Candidates Agree That Deficit Is Dragon
LEAD: As he campaigns across the country, Senator Bob Dole maintains that ''the Federal budget deficit is the single greatest threat to a prosperous and dynamic America.''

Col.
