John Poindexter were among the guests last week at one of Vice President Bush's Christmas parties.


Soviet Launches Replacement Crew for Craft
LEAD: Three Soviet astronauts were launched into space today aboard a Soyuz TM-4 capsule in a mission to replace a space station crew that has been setting records for endurance in space.


After 2 Months, Larry Davis's Trial Starts in Bronx
LEAD: After more than two months of defense motions, protracted jury selection and a debate over where the defendant should be held, the trial of Larry Davis began yesterday in the Bronx.

The Year Congress Stopped
LEAD: The first session of the 100th Congress raises the real possibility that one of these years, the national legislature may not simply adjourn for Christmas but actually grind to a halt.
Consider the lawmakers' performance in the last few days.
They had to pass a law to keep the Government functioning while they battled one more day.


Allied and Siemens Set New Venture
LEAD: The Allied-Signal Corporation and Siemens A.G. said they had agreed to discuss establishing a venture to combine some of their automotive electronics operations and to develop new engine products.
A spokesman for Allied-Signal said the name, headquarters and management of the venture, and any financial transaction that might result from it, had not yet been outlined.


British Airways Buys 50.02% of Caledonian
LEAD: British Airways P.L.C. said today that it had acquired a controlling stake in the money-losing British Caledonian Airways, ending a six-month battle with Scandinavian Airlines System.


What Tact the Press Showed!
LEAD: We meet in the aftermath of the most traumatic economic event of our time.
That was the great stock market crash of October 1987, an occurrence rivaling and even exceeding in extent and associated disorder and fear the Great Crash of 1929.
It is your treatment of this drastic event that I wish to talk about and, in a manner of speaking, commend.


Signatures Held Sufficient to Force Arizona Vote
LEAD: More than enough petition signatures have been validated to force Gov.
Evan Mecham to face an election to recall him from office, county recorders said today.

Tall, slender and elegant, Mr.
Meek moves at the ballet barre as one who wears an inherited mantle but wears it with unassuming grace.


New Soviet Offer on Afghan Withdrawal Reported
LEAD: A senior State Department official disclosed today that during the summit meeting earlier this month, Mikhail S. Gorbachev made a new offer to have Soviet troops refrain from offensive combat operations during any period that is agreed upon for their withdrawal from Afghanistan.


Panel Urges Changes in New York Election Laws
LEAD: The State Commission on Integrity in Government recommended drastic changes yesterday in New York State's campaign finance reporting laws.


Trial Reactions: From Approval To a Letdown
LEAD: Reaction to the Howard Beach verdicts ranged from dismay to cautious approval last night among political and civil-rights figures, religious leaders and others.


14 Killed as a Helicopter Crashes Onto Oil Rig Off Louisiana Coast
LEAD: A helicopter carrying 13 offshore oil workers to begin a two-week shift in the Gulf of Mexico crashed and burned on the deck of an oil rig today, killing 12 of the workers and both pilots, the Coast Guard said.


Chinese Student Is Convicted For Role in Shanghai Protests
LEAD: An American-educated student was convicted in Shanghai today of conducting ''demagogical propaganda for counterrevolutionary ends,'' the Government-controlled New China News Agency announced.

LEAD: Dave Righetti and the Yankees are expected to announce today an agreement on a three-year contract worth a guaranteed $4.5 million, a source familiar with the negotiations said last night.


Cowboys End Bid By Rams
LEAD: Roger Ruzek kicked a team-record five field goals, and the Dallas defense slowed Charles White and the rejuvenated Rams tonight as the Cowboys ended a four-game losing streak with a 29-21 victory.
The defeat knocked Los Angeles out of the playoffs.

Curing Math Anxiety
LEAD: ONLY 362 Americans received doctorates in mathematics in the last academic year, out of 32,000 doctorates awarded, according to a report by the American Mathematical Society and the Mathematical Association of America.
This is the lowest number in 15 years, at a time when mathematics is a key to scientific, technological and industrial success.

LEAD: State archaeologists have found the ruins of a Spanish mission church that was burned to the ground in 1704, officials have announced.

LEAD: Fire killed five children early yesterday when flames raced through their home near Portland, Ore., the authorities said.


Airports Normal Under New Rule
LEAD: Most airports reported no delays yesterday as new safety procedures took effect requiring airline and airport employees to go through security checkpoints just like passengers, but some flight crew members grumbled.


Searchers Find No Trace of 1,500 From 2 Ships Sunk in Philippines
LEAD: Rescue ships and helicopters searched the sea south of Manila today but reported no trace of 1,500 people missing and presumed drowned after a passenger ferry and an oil tanker collided Sunday night.


Track and the Future
LEAD: Fatima Whitbread, the world champion in the women's javelin throw, called for the establishment of a disciplinary committee to fine or suspend British athletes and officials who bring track and field into disrepute.
Speaking in London yesterday, Whitbread, Britain's only world track and field champion in 1987, said she wanted to see an organization established with a top attorney as chairman that would help stamp out adverse publicity she believes is damaging to the sport.


Iran and Iraq Report Heavy Fighting in Gulf War
LEAD: Iran and Iraq both reported heavy fighting today on the south-central front in the Persian Gulf war, but they differed sharply on the outcome.

LEAD: Warner Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire Teldec Schallplatten G.m.b.H., a leading West German record company, for undisclosed terms.

Economic Scene; Japan Will Seek Balanced Growth
LEAD: JAPAN is starting to rejuggle its economy in an effort to attain faster domestic growth and slower external growth.
Prime Minister Noburo Takeshita and his Cabinet accepted a plan yesterday, prepared by the Economic Planning Agency, for transforming the country from a supercompetitive export machine to a more balanced and affluent society ready to play a larger role in stabilizing the world economy.

LEAD: ''METROLINE'' is of more than passing interest tonight.
Channel 13's weekly series on public affairs looks at private organizations in New York that feed the hungry.

The program, ''A Million Meals,'' at 8:30, is a model work.

LEAD: The authorities here said all five members of a family were killed early today when a lighted Christmas tree was ignited by an electrical short, destroying their home.
The Eatonton Police Chief, Kent Lawrence, identified the victims as Floyd Paynter, 30 years old, his wife, Pamela Sue, 24, and their children, Shawn, 5, Brandon, 3, and Kristen, 1.


LIFE IN THE 30'S
LEAD: MY most enduring and exalted memory of Christmas is an odd one, tied to neither home nor family.
It is the memory of singing in the elementary school Christmas concert each year.
We were rehearsed mercilessly from Halloween on, our consonants honed to a cutting edge, our tight little mouths coaxed into generous ovals.

Japan-Citibank Tie
LEAD: The New York-based Citibank and Japan's Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank said they would link their automatic teller machine systems beginning in January, allowing customers to use the automatic tellers of both banks.
Citibank is the largest commercial bank in the United States, while Dai-Ichi Kangyo is the largest in the world in terms of assets.

Pacific Telesis
LEAD: The California Public Utilities Commission ordered the Pacific Telesis Group, the holding company for Pacific Bell and Nevada Bell, to decrease its rates by $194.5 million.

The remaining $86.5 million was ordered for the upcoming year.

Clearing the Air for Nonsmokers
LEAD: A smoker feels harassed when asked to put out a cigarette.
But nonsmokers feel harassed, and subjected to health risk, by having to breathe in the smoker's smoke.
How, then, to keep both happy?
By making it very clear where smoking will and will not be allowed.

To a Californian, seltzer is salt-free carbonated water or flavored salt-free carbonated water or sweetened and flavored salt-free carbonated water.

Brownsville Journal; In Texas, It's the Season For the Humble Tamale
LEAD: Bing Crosby never warbled a holiday season tune in their honor.
You wouldn't want one in your Christmas stocking.
It's a little hard to picture Santa eating one.


Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q. Some years ago during a water shortage I reduced water used by my flush toilets by twisting the bowl refill tube to one side so that instead of directing water through the overflow tube and into the bowl it sent the water into the tank.
I have operated two toilets this way for years with no noticeable decrease in flushing efficiency.


College Basketball; Rutgers Falls, 72-46
LEAD: Max Blank, a junior center, scored a career-high 27 points as George Washington defeated Rutgers, 72-46, tonight in an Atlantic 10 Conference game.


3d Year Was Key for Righetti
LEAD: The implications of Dave Righetti's three-year, $4.3 million deal with the Yankees are potentially so far reaching that General Manager Lou Piniella didn't think he could make the official announcement yesterday without making sure he added a quick disclaimer.


Correction
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Tuesday, about the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, misstated the arrangement under which banks make payments in the New York Cash Exchange system, a network of automatic tellers.
When the cash machine used does not belong to the customer's own bank, the customer's bank pays the owning bank a fee of 20 cents for a balance inquiry or 38 cents for a cash withdrawal; another fee of 13 to 19 cents is paid to the exchange.


FLYERS UNBEATEN OVER 13 STRAIGHT
LEAD: Dave Poulin scored two goals tonight as the Flyers extended their unbeaten streak to 13 games by defeating the Minnesota North Stars, 5-3.
Philadelphia also moved past the Islanders into first place in the Patrick Division.


Olympians Investigated
LEAD: Jurgen Hingsen of West Germany, who was a silver medalist at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics in the decathalon, is under investigation for suspected purchases of cocaine, a prosecutor in Essen, West Germany, said yesterday.
The prosecutor, Hermann Kerl, said an investigation was opened against Hingsen and Rolf Milser, an Olympic weight lifting champion.


Carson Is Selected For Ninth Pro Bowl
LEAD: Harry Carson made National Football League history today when he was voted a Pro Bowl linebacker for the ninth time.
Lawrence Taylor made history of sorts when he failed to be named a Pro Bowl starter, although he did make the team.


Francis Rejoins Patriots
LEAD: Russ Francis, a former first-round draft choice of New England, has agreed to rejoin the Patriots for the remainder of the season and may sign a contract for next year, team officials said.
Francis, who was waived by the San Francisco 49ers last week, made the decision to rejoin the Patriots Tuesday after being told by Coach Bill Walsh of San Francisco that the 49ers had no intention of re-signing him.


Correction
LEAD: An article in some editions yesterday about indictments involving the Wedtech Corporation misstated the activity of W. Franklyn Chinn, one of those indicted.
Mr.
Chinn managed investments for Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, but there is no evidence the investments included Wedtech.

Homeless Children: Looking for Compassion as Well as Shelter
LEAD: The West Women's Hotel, a run-down building on Skid Row here, is an outpost in the difficult battle being waged around the country to save the spirits of homeless children.
It is a place where it can take a month of cuddling and comfort in a locked playroom to coax a 3-year-old girl to smile at her own reflection in a mirror.

Bol Speaks on Report
LEAD: Manute Bol, the Washington Bullet center, said that Kevin Mackey, the Cleveland State basketball coach, never did him any favors.

PARENT &amp; CHILD
LEAD: THE holiday guests inwardly cringe as the 6-year-old scratches his way through a tune on his new violin.
They keep a watchful eye on the living-room furniture as his younger sister demonstrates her skill at indoor cartwheels.
They smile at the pure tones of the 10-year-old singing a Christmas carol and are impressed as the 13-year-old demonstrates the computer program she just wrote.


'88 Growth Forecast Cut to 2.4%
LEAD: The Reagan Administration today substantially lowered its forecast for economic growth next year but predicted that 1988 would become the sixth consecutive year without a recession.


For Child With AIDS, Hospital Is Home
LEAD: He was born on Christmas Day 1984 in a New York City hospital, and although no one knew it at the time, he was infected with the AIDS virus.


To Mars, Via Moscow
LEAD: America's space agency keeps looking at the heavens through bizarre bifocals.
At a time when the paramount need is to reduce the Federal deficit, NASA's top goal is to build a $32 billion space station that has no clear purpose.
Congress knows that, yet is willing only to cut in half NASA's request for $770 million in start-up funds.


Lincoln Center Drops Play
LEAD: Lincoln Center Theater has halted rehearsals of ''Ron Giovanni,'' a satirical musical that was to begin performances Jan. 22 at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater.
The show will be replaced by a comedy, ''Boy's Life,'' the artistic director of the company, Gregory Mosher, said yesterday.


Israeli Rebuts U.S. Charges That It Used Excessive Force
LEAD: Israeli officials today rejected the Reagan Administration's assertion that Israeli troops had used excessive force in quelling Palestinian riots.

LEAD: The Beard Company announced it intends to resume merger talks with the Union Pacific Corporation as soon as Union Pacific's tender offer for Uspci Inc. is consummated.

LEAD: Libya is building a plant that Reagan Administration officials strongly suspect will be used to make chemical weapons.

There are parties.
There are bonuses.
But the frivolity is tempered by fear.

LEAD: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation is offering three- and six-month bonds totaling $2.38 billion through various securities dealers.


The Clearer Message
LEAD: Some may think the meaning of the Howard Beach trial is that racial violence no longer will be tolerated.
Others may think the manslaughter convictions of three young white men demonstrate the power of black political pressures.
But the clearer ''message'' comes not from the verdict - reached only after 12 days of jury deliberation - but in the reaction of all too many blacks and whites.


NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1987
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL/A2-9


South African Blacks Moving to White Areas
LEAD: The view from Rose Malakeng's balcony, across Wanderers Street to the railroad station, is not the stuff of which postcards are made.
But it is special to Mrs.
Malakeng, who has the kind of home that many blacks in South Africa have hankered after for a lifetime.


Advertising; Carter-Wallace to Offer College Health Message
LEAD: Carter-Wallace, whose product line includes Trojan condoms, will be sponsoring two- to three-minute public service video messages reaching college campuses, intended to inform students on the diseases that threaten them, from AIDS to anorexia, according to the announcement.


Turks Answer the Met In Suit Over Artifacts
LEAD: The Turkish Government has filed legal papers responding to a motion by the Metropolitan Museum of Art to dismiss a suit in which Turkey has demanded the return of artifacts it contends were illegally exported in the 1960's, Harry I. Rand, an attorney representing Turkey, said yesterday.


South Africa Gold Plant
LEAD: South Africa, the world's biggest gold producer, will spend 77.9 million rand, or about $40 million, to build a gold refinery capable of processing about 800 metric tons of bullion a year.
The new plant will be built on the high-security site of the existing refinery at Germiston, near Johannesburg.


2,636 Entrants For Westminster
LEAD: Entries for the 112th annual Westminster Kennel Club show at Madison Square Garden Feb. 8-9 have closed with 2,636 dogs, representing 140 breeds or varieties. ''It's the earliest close in the long history of Westminster,'' said Chet Collier, the show chairman.


U.S. Vehicle Sales Fell 11.7% in Mid-December
LEAD: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks fell 11.7 percent in the second 10 days of December from the comparable period a year ago, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

Aliens Are Paying a Price for Honesty
LEAD: If Mohsen Moharerzadeh, a 26-year-old Iranian photographer, had secretly waded across the Rio Grande into the United States, he would probably be free, working here and pursuing an application for political asylum.


General Haig's Joke
LEAD: That uproar between Alexander M. Haig Jr. and the United States Marines over a joke that the Republican Presidential contender made at the expense of The Few and The Proud is not over yet, despite his insistence that the joke be treated as a joke.


Wiggins Banned Again
LEAD: Mitchell Wiggins, who was banned from the N.B.A. for cocaine use, has been dismissed from the Continental Basketball Association for failing a drug test.
Wiggins, who played for the Houston Rockets until he and Lewis Lloyd were banned on Jan. 13, 1987, was playing for the Quad City Thunder. ''This is an extremely unfortunate situation,'' Mike Storen, the C.B.A.


Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a rollcall listing yesterday on the Senate's vote on a $600 billion spending bill misidentified Senator Albert Gore of Tennessee.
He is a Democrat.


Wurlitzer Sale To Baldwin
LEAD: The Wurlitzer Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its musical keyboard business to the Baldwin Piano and Organ Company of Loveland, Ohio, combining two of the oldest and best-known names in musical instruments.

LEAD: President Reagan has signed legislation that will prevent immigration officials from barring foreigners because of their political beliefs for at least the next 14 months.

Soviet Reports on Afghan Battle
LEAD: Soviet and Government troops have killed or wounded more than 1,500 Afghan guerrillas in the first two days of a drive to lift the siege of Khost, a major garrison city southeast of Kabul, the Kremlin said today.

LEAD: Secrecy in government has a thousand fathers: a thousand excuses.
But Frank Carlucci, the new Secretary of Defense, came up with a particular gem last week.
He testified that the President should not have to inform the Congressional intelligence committees promptly about covert operations because foreign countries whose help we need do not like the idea.

LEAD: Bond prices rebounded yesterday after finance ministers of seven major industrialized Western countries stated that they opposed further declines in the dollar's value.

LEAD: The first 25 homeless families moved this week into an imaginative prefabricated housing project in Brooklyn called Help I. If you don't own any power tools, or are confused by the variations available, here are some basic choices to consider.

I.R.S. Ruling Seen On Carter Payout
LEAD: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. said that the Internal Revenue Service intends to rule that most of the $320 million in cash distributed to its shareholders in a restructuring this year will be taxed as a dividend.
The percentage of the cash payout that will be considered taxable depends on the year-end earnings and retained profits of the Los Angeles-based retailer, a spokesman said.

LEAD: The lawyer for a convicted teen-ager in the Howard Beach case said yesterday that he would ask the judge for a hearing to determine if, before the verdict, the jury foreman had authorized a television news producer to try to sell her story to newspapers.

Faster Move by Penney
LEAD: The J. C. Penney Company expects to complete its move from New York by July 1, several months ahead of schedule.
The retailing company's chairman, William Howell, said on Tuesday that he expected about 60 percent of Penney's 2,200 top managers and a smaller percentage of the 1,600 New York-based non-managers to move in the headquarters shift to the Dallas suburb of Plano.


Mob Figure Is Offered A Deal for His Release
LEAD: In a highly unusual move, a Federal judge yesterday offered to release Joseph Armone, the reputed underboss of the Gambino crime family, on $1 million bond pending his sentencing if he publicly renounced any connection he might have had with the organization and resigned any position he might hold.

It estimated that the G.N.P. would rise by 2.4 percent after adjusting for inflation - more than a full percentage point lower than the 3.5 percent projection for next year that it made in August.

The Editorial Notebook; Surrender in Chicago
LEAD: Chicago has surrendered its public housing projects to heavily armed street gangs.
Their bloody encounters terrorize the dilapidated high-rise communities that are home to thousands of poor families.
Children are particularly at risk.
Some, even while in grade school, are dragooned by the gangs for training in drug dealing.

LEAD: Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor, announced yesterday that he had raised most of the money for his $1 billion cash offer to buy the Singer Company.

LEAD: After years of effort, the New York City Council yesterday overwhelmingly approved the city's first comprehensive anti-smoking bill.

It's Kathleen Sullivan and old Harry whosis.
Stay with it a while, though, and Harry takes on substance.
In fact, he wears quite well.
There are worse ways to start the day than by watching ''CBS This Morning,'' with Ms.
Sullivan and Harry Smith as co-anchors.


200 Mourners Recall Woman Who Died After Her Arrest
LEAD: More than 200 people crowded into a tiny Bronx funeral home where a 28-year-old black woman was mourned yesterday by public officials and ministers as a symbol of what they termed the continuing struggle to stamp out racism in New York City.


New Robins Bid by American Home
LEAD: The American Home Products Corporation yesterday joined a fast-developing bidding war for the troubled A. H. Robins Company, offering stock valued at $550 million and a commitment to provide $2.48 billion in cash over seven years to compensate women who say they suffered injuries from Robins's Dalkon Shield birth control device.


Blake Stern, Singer and Teacher, 70
LEAD: Blake Stern, an oratorio singer and a professor emeritus of music at Yale University, died Tuesday in Logan, Iowa.
He was 70 years old.


Dance: At City Ballet, 2 Sugar Plum Fairies
LEAD: THE role of the Sugar Plum Fairy in ''The Nutcracker'' is a peculiar one.
The part, a focal point of the ballet, is usually danced by a ballerina of artistic stature, but she appears for a very short time on the stage and then only at the end in the ballet's culminating pas de deux.
Almost everything in the fairy-tale ballet - Christmas parties, warring mice and toy soldiers and dancing sweets and snowflakes - upstages those final moments of pure classicism.


Jane E. Brody
LEAD: When a semitropical animal chooses to live in a cold climate, keeping warm is a primary concern.
We are such animals, but when it comes to protecting our relatively hairless bodies against the onslaught of frigid winter air and winds, we often don't do as well as less intelligent animals.


Correction
LEAD: An article yesterday about the adjournment of Congress misstated the amount of aid voted for rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government.
It is $8.1 million, not $8.1 billion.


Advertising; Unusual Commercial For Barney's New York
LEAD: A TV commercial will start running in the New York market tomorrow that will confuse many a viewer at first.
It looks more like the last few minutes of ''Sunday Morning'' on CBS than a commercial.
It's almost all mood, with the camera starting out with a winter country scene that goes to black and is followed by a different winter scene, and so on.


I.B.M. Signals Big Shift In Designing Computers
LEAD: A radical new computer design that only a few years ago was routinely dismissed as unworkable suddenly appears ready for broad acceptance after an about-face by I.B.M. that gratified the Federal Government and stunned the computer industry.

LEAD: BACH'S ''Christmas Oratorio,'' all six cantatas of it, was performed with lightness, precision and some virtuosity Tuesday evening in Alice Tully Hall by the 26-voice choir and 39-member orchestra (modern instruments) of Thomas Wikman's Music of the Baroque ensemble from Chicago.

LEAD: An article on Dec. 16 reported that Boston Properties, developer of the skyscraper proposed for the site of the New York Coliseum, had replaced Moshe Safdie, the building's architect, with David Childs of the firm of Skidmore, Owings &amp; Merrill, and asked him to design a smaller building.

LEAD: The Boys Choir of Harlem has sung to critical acclaim all over the United States, in Japan and in major cathedrals and churches of Europe, including St.
Paul's in London and St.
Germain des Pres in Paris.
Yet, says the director, the group has an image problem.


Drugs Mar Christmas on a Harlem Street
LEAD: On winter nights 119th Street between Fifth and Lenox Avenues looks much like a turn-of-the-century photograph, with its low buildings and brownstone facades.
Bathed in the amber of the street lamps, the street is sepia-toned, serene.
The doorway of one of the grander homes is draped with wreaths and the tiny white lights that mark the holiday season.

LEAD: Lakeside Pharmaceuticals is switching advertising responsibility for its Nicorette gum to Gross Townsend Frank Hoffman, from Medicus Consumer.
The chewing gum, sold by prescription only, contains nicotine that is said to help people break the smoking habit.

Cangialosi had been taking a fertility drug. (NYT/Sara Krulwich)

LEAD: As one of its final acts before adjourning, the Senate has passed and sent to President Reagan a bill to restore civilian control over the standards for safeguarding information stored in the nation's computers.

LEAD: Now that President Reagan has signed the two huge bills that Congress passed in the final hours of the 1987 session, Government officials are holding their breath, hoping there will not be a repetition of last year's debacle.


Paris Is Cool To Pere Noel: Is He Passe?
LEAD: Ferdinand Bachmann, a 30-year veteran of the Salvation Army, had an insider's explanation for why the Christmas shoppers sliding by him in front of Galeries Lafayette were plunking fewer francs into his metal drum this year.
It was too warm. ''The colder it is,'' he said, an idle bell dangling in his left hand, ''the more they give.

LEAD: In reassuming the positions of president and chief executive, Fred M. Gibbons, the co-founder of the Software Publishing Corporation, said he hoped to lead the company through two transitions.

LEAD: A judge in Manhattan has been charged by state disciplinary officials with misusing his judicial powers in a series of cases involving a friend, according to state officials and court records.

A Reagan Cabinet Memoir.

Europe Inflation Slows
LEAD: Consumer prices in the European Community edged up two-tenths of a percent in November, a much smaller increase than October's five-tenths of a percent, the community's statistics office, Eurostat, said today.
It said the community's inflation rate for the year should come to a modest 3.4 percent, up from last year's 2.9 percent.

LEAD: On St.
Patrick's Day 1982, two men moving a dining room set into a sixth-floor apartment in Elmurst, Queens, decided to take a break.
They sat down on a landing to drink a few beers.


Music: Moyse Leads Bach
LEAD: AS they say, better late than never.
At the august age of 78, Blanche Moyse finally made her Carnegie Hall debut Monday evening, leading the Orchestra of St.
Luke's and the Blanche Moyse Chorale in an absolutely glorious rendition of Bach's ''Christmas Oratorio.'' Even after three hours on stage the conductor seemed vigorous enough to start over again.


Pan Am Seeks Concessions
LEAD: The board of the Pan Am Corporation has asked two of its five unions, those representing the pilots and the flight engineers, to give them about the same level of concessions that they had been willing to give to Jay A. Pritzker, the financier who controls Braniff Airways Inc., in his unsuccessful bid to purchase the airline.

LEAD: A Taiwan citizen who is an American resident has been ordered to leave China for belonging to a ''reactionary organization,'' Chinese newspapers reported today.

LEAD: FREQUENTLY in the land of television, the line between an entertainment and a commercial can get curiously thin.
Next week, for instance, on Wednesday, CBS will be offering an hourlong ''documentary'' entitled ''China Odyssey: Empire of the Sun,'' which is less about China than about Steven Spielberg's new movie.

LEAD: The Educational Testing Service has reached a $52,000 settlement of a suit in which it charged a leading test coaching company with copyright infringement of questions from the service's Scholastic Aptitude Test.

LEAD: The Transamerica Occidental Life Insurance Company said it had agreed to provide part of the financing in a $10 million laboratory and plans to enter the growing market for AIDS testing by insurers.

LEAD: A judge today ordered the Georgia Bar to halt disciplinary proceedings against the State Attorney General on charges that he violated an ethics code by suing a state agency over a closed meeting.

LEAD: Robert Paige, an Emmy Award-winning actor who starred in such movies as ''Bye Bye Birdie'' with Janet Leigh and ''Can't Help Singing'' with Deanna Durbin, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack.
The Orange County Coroner's office listed his age as 76, but biographies put his age at 77.

LEAD: Navy engineers are checking 300 jet engines throughout the world after discovering that an error-prone mechanic was incorrectly assembling gearboxes, a Navy spokesman said today.

Von Bulow Says He Will Drop Claim to Money
LEAD: Claus von Bulow, the Danish-born aristocrat who was convicted and then, in a retrial, acquitted of twice trying to murder his wife with insulin injections, confirmed yesterday that he has agreed to renounce all claims to his wife's fortune, to divorce her and to leave the country.

15-Year-Old Hijacks KLM Plane; Incident Ends With Boy's Capture
LEAD: An unarmed teen-ager who said he had a bomb hijacked a KLM airliner with 97 people aboard today, forced it to land in Rome and demanded $1 million, airline officials said.
The police overpowered him four hours later, and all hostages were released unharmed.

LEAD: A former army colonel whose allegations of high-level corruption touched off a summer of unrest has been sentenced to five years in prison for crimes against state security, a court official said today.

LEAD: Cronyism and conflicts of interest on local school boards are depriving New York City schoolchildren of good educations, while the Board of Education, ''an isolated fortress,'' looks the other way, a report issued yesterday by the Manhattan Borough President, David N. Dinkins, charged.


Advertising; Dailies' Ads Rise
LEAD: According to the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, advertising spending in the nation's dailies in October rose 5.5 percent over the same month in 1986, to $2.66 billion.
The biggest category gainer was classified, which was up 14.7 percent, to $969 million, while retail rose 1.7 percent, to $1.37 billion.

Edward Scott Valentine of Manhattan had assumed that taxes took care of the poor people. ''The increasing numbers of homeless and destitute that I see every day on the streets indicate how thoughtless I have been,'' Dr.
Valentine wrote.


O.K., an Educator. Where's the Clout?
LEAD: Should New York City's next schools chancellor be more an educator or an administrator?
A search committee finally presents New York's Board of Education with an answer: three candidates, all accomplished educators now serving in other cities.
It's a defensible choice but more needs to be said.
In New York, effectiveness depends heavily on the ability to understand a gritty political system and make it respond.

LEAD: THAT was a nice gesture on the part of Dave Righetti, giving himself to George Steinbrenner for the holidays.

In a big business like baseball, some may say that Righetti was foolish to let sentiment override the profit motive.

LEAD: The parents of the West German pilot Mathias Rust, who was sentenced to four years in a Soviet labor camp after a flight from Finland to Red Square last May, visited him in Lefortovo prison today.

HERS
LEAD: WHEN we say we can't make love without love, I think, it's intimacy that we mean we can't make love, can't make out, can't live very well without.
Intimacy, I think, is what those who live alone in their beds, and those who live with someone without the habitual touch of flesh or mind want to weep for the lack of.

He can no longer study or write for 12 hours at a stretch without a break.

Louis will be his last in a Dallas Cowboys uniform. ''The only way I can see being here,'' said Dorsett, ''is if no other team in the league was interested in me.'' WEEKENDER GUIDE
LEAD: Friday  AILEY AT CITY CENTER


Courage at Christmas
LEAD: A chill wind swirls through the rubble-strewn empty lots.
A block away stand some gutted brick tenements, hollow as skulls.
Across 160th Street, a forlorn little branch library sticks up out of the desolation.
But here, in the old public school now called Argus Community, there is life.


Lockbaum In Blue-Gray
LEAD: College football resumes today with two bowl games and an All-Star matchup.


Japan Vehicle Exports
LEAD: The Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today that its exports in November totaled 483,254 cars, trucks and buses, down 9.4 percent from the previous month.
The figure was off 6.4 percent from a year earlier.
In addition, it said, a total of 104,359 motorcycles were exported in November, up 6.7 percent from the previous month, but down 29.0 percent from a year earlier.


Burlington Industries Plans to Sell 2 Units
LEAD: Burlington Industries said today that it would sell the apparel fabrics portion of its Burlington Blended Fabrics division and the Burlington Prints division for about $150 million.
The operations are being acquired by a group consisting of Citicorp Venture Capital Ltd. and the management of the divisions.


Yonkers Rejects A Judge's Order In Housing Case
LEAD: The City of Yonkers has rejected as unconstitutional a Federal judge's order that it buy private land through eminent domain to build public housing.

LEAD: India's leading ethnic Tamil politician died today, introducing a new element of uncertainty in India's efforts to enforce an accord intended to end the fighting in Sri Lanka.

Pop/Jazz; Yomo Toro Blends Latin And Cuban
LEAD: WHEN Latin music aficionados are discussing players like Yomo Toro, the Puerto Rican virtuoso of the 10-stringed mini-guitar called the cuatro, they often resort to a term that sounds out-of-place amid the streams of voluble, rapid-fire Spanish: hillbilly.
The ''jibaro'' music that is Mr.
Toro's specialty actually is folk music from the Puerto Rican hill country - buoyant, driving string-band music that can be compared to American hillbilly and bluegrass styles without stretching the point.

Consortium To Acquire SCI Cable
LEAD: SCI Holdings Inc., a major player in the nation's cable television industry, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by a consortium of leading cable operators.
An executive familiar with the deal estimated the price at $2.9 billion.


Christmas Day
LEAD:  NEW YORK  Parking: Sunday rules.
Sanitation: No collections or street cleaning.
Government offices: Closed.
Post offices: Closed; special delivery and Express Mail delivery only.
Banks: Closed.
Financial markets: Closed.
Transportation: Subways and buses, Sunday service; Long Island Rail Road, holiday service; Metro-North, Sunday service.


The Jordan Solution
LEAD: The young Palestinians throwing stones in Gaza and the Arabs of Israel clanging down their shop shutters have made a political statement and attention will be paid.
They want a Palestinian homeland and will not rest until they have it.

Private Behavior, Public Responsibility
LEAD: There is obviously still a lot of confusion in the country about the proper role of public officials.
The new idea this Christmas (the gospel according to Gary Hart) is that an official's public and private lives - his policies and morals - can be separate, that his personal monkey business is nobody's business and that all the folly and mischief are caused by the snooping scoundrels of the press.


Robins Gets an Extension for Filing
LEAD: The A. H. Robins Company has been given until Jan. 6 to file an amended bankruptcy reorganization plan in order to allow it to study competing takeover bids.

Clinton Sundberg, Actor, 81
LEAD: Clinton Sundberg, a character actor in dozens of films in the 1940's and 50's, died of heart failure on Dec. 14.
He was 81 years old.

Southland to Sell Chief Auto Unit
LEAD: The Southland Corporation will sell its Chief Auto Parts division to members of the unit's management and Shearson Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. for $130 million and the assumption of some debt.
The sale is part of a plan to repay some of the $4 billion needed for a recent leveraged buyout by Southland, which operates the 7


France Simplifies Donation of Organs
LEAD: To the Editor:


PLANNED DEMOLITION OF 3 BUILDINGS THREATENS OLD MERCHANT'S HOUSE
LEAD: On its 155th Christmas, the Old Merchant's House - a vivid Greek Revival vestige on East Fourth Street, an embellished and ornamented world of pale silver, crimson silk and richly veined mahogany - faces demolition only inches away.


Children and Space
LEAD: The spirit of cooperation proclaimed by President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev at their recent summit appears to be shared by American schoolchildren who, in a recent informal survey, overwhelming supported the idea of a joint Soviet-United States space mission to Mars.

Sports People; Slaney Sidelined
LEAD: Mary Decker Slaney, the nation's top female middle-distance runner but also the most injury-prone, will miss the 1988 indoor track season because of an injured right calf, her coach said yesterday.
The coach, Luiz de Oliveira, said Slaney, who has not competed since last Feb. 28, when she set a course record of 32 minutes 3 seconds, in winning the Continental Homes 10-kilometer (6.2 miles) race at Phoenix, would ''take off the next 15 days and see how she reacts to the injury.

LEAD: To the Editor:


ATTAINING SUCCESS WITH DEVOTION TO LEARNING
LEAD: The quality of the New York City school system has been attacked by business leaders, politicians and educators recently.
As they express their concerns, the Board of Education is preparing to pick a new chancellor.
Among the challenges he will face are a high dropout rate, overcrowding and deteriorating buildings.

Loans Spur Christmas Sales in Rural Town
LEAD: A program that provides low-interest loans to people who agree to do their shopping in local stores has made it a profitable Christmas for merchants in this farming and ranching town.


Command Post Plane Is Grounded by Geese
LEAD: A $149 million jet aircraft designed to serve as a Presidential command post in a nuclear war has been grounded by geese, the Air Force said Wednesday.


Palestinians And Unrest; Neither Side Appears Nearer to a Solution
LEAD: Despite two weeks of Palestinian rioting in Israeli-occupied territories and despite the deaths of at least 21 Palestinian youths, neither Israelis nor Palestinians appear to have learned anything about each other that might bring their conflict closer to a resolution.

U.S., Citing Worker Rights, Revokes Chile Trade Benefit
LEAD: The United States has withdrawn Chile's privileges to sell certain products in the United States duty free, citing violations of internationally accepted standards of worker rights.


Ralph Nelson, Early TV Director; Made 'Requiem for Heavyweight'
LEAD: Ralph Nelson, who directed some of television's most memorable dramas in the 1950's, including ''Requiem for a Heavyweight,'' and the Academy Award-winning film ''Lilies of the Field,'' died of cancer Monday in Santa Monica, Calif.
He was 71 years old.

Officers Were Not at Posts, Ship Disaster Survivor Says
LEAD: The coast guard said today that its initial inquiry indicated that some of the officers of the ferry Dona Paz were watching television or drinking beer when she collided with an oil tanker, killing at least 1,600 people.


Leo Berger Dies at 69; A Chemical Researcher
LEAD: Leo Berger, the associate director of chemical research of Hoffmann-LaRoche Inc., the pharmaceutical concern, from 1980 to 1985, died of a heart attack at his home in Montclair, N.J., on Dec. 13.
He was 69 years old.

The Unknown No. 1 Team
LEAD: Even during winter, baseball usually dominates the conversation when sports are discussed in this corner of the Sonoran Desert, just 65 miles north of the Mexican border.
This week's Associated Press college basketball poll has changed the topic of conversation for now.


Celebrations for a Bright, Bubbly New Year
LEAD: If New Year's Eve seems just a tad longer than usual this year, it's no illusion.
During the final countdown to the penultimate year of the penultimate decade of the 20th century, the last minute of 1987 will actually have 61 seconds.


Bonds Are Flat on Shortened Day
LEAD: Prices of Treasury issues were essentially unchanged yesterday in an abbreviated trading session.
Although this market has no fixed hours, dealers agreed to close at 2 P.M., New York time, on Christmas and New Year's Eves.


COMMUTER TRAINS COLLIDE IN FRANCE, KILLING ONE PASSENGER
LEAD: The wreckage of two trains that collided yesterday in Issy-les-Moulineaux, a suburb of Paris, killing one person and injuring 38.
Train at right was full of commuters while the train at left wasempty.


COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: Argus Energy L.P., Stamford, Conn., has acquired 9.17 percent of the Tosco Corp., Santa Monica, Calif.
Terms were not disclosed.


Diner's Journal
LEAD: MEZZALUNA, the much-imitated Italilan trattoria on Third Avenue near 74th Street, has quietly opened a new, considerably larger establishment in SoHo called Mezzogiorno (195 Spring Street).
It probably won't be quiet for long.
The menu is similar to that of the original: excellent carpaccios, (try the warm version speckled with oregano, diced tomato and olives and sprinkled with pepper-infused olive oil, $12), brick-oven pizzas ($10 to $12), pastas ($10 to $12) and salads ($8.50 to $12).


Henry Cotton, Former Golfer, 80
LEAD: Henry Cotton, the most distinguished British golfer of his generation, died Tuesday.
He was 80 years old.
Cotton, who turned professional in 1924, won the British Open in 1934, ending a long run of American victories and again in 1937 and 1948.
He played many times in the United States and was captain of the Ryder Cup team in 1939, 1947 and 1953.


Brazil Debt Negotiator Set
LEAD: Brazil appointed its new central bank governor, Fernando Milliet, to be its chief foreign debt negotiator after the resignation of several top finance officials, officials said today.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: Chase Manhattan Bank appointed Thomas C. Lynch and Robert G. Murphy executive vice presidents.


Suspect in Wife's Slaying Faces Child Custody Suit
LEAD: Two months after he was arrested in the murder of his wife, a Manhattan man is embroiled in a lawsuit brought by relatives of the slain woman, who are seeking custody of the couple's two children.


Board May Favor Black For Schools Chancellor
LEAD: As the New York City Board of Education enters the final phase of selecting a new schools chancellor, a board member said a black will most likely be chosen unless the lone white candidate is seen as better than the two black contenders.


Sports People; Bulls Waive Gilmore
LEAD: Artis Gilmore was placed on waivers yesterday by the Chicago Bulls, a team official said. ''Artis is debating retirement and has asked us to waive him, thus keeping his options open for a possible return to the National Basketball Association at a later date if he should decide not to retire,'' said Jerry Krause, the team's vice president for operations.

LEAD: In the photographs that grace most public places here, King Hassan II seems to have two sides: a religious pose for his countrymen and a secular one for everybody else.

LEAD: In this village of well-tended homes, architectural changes are as closely scrutinized as the Dow Jones industrial average.


The Environment As a Diplomatic Issue
LEAD: Just after an international protocol to protect the earth's ozone shield was signed in Montreal in September, Secretary of State George P. Shultz telephoned Assistant Secretary John D. Negroponte to compliment him on ''an important diplomatic triumph for the United States.''


'For the Public Good,' A Call to All Lawyers
LEAD: The American Bar Association Journal, joining a growing number of legal groups that are leaning on their own profession, is asking lawyers to do more for people who cannot afford them.
An editorial in this month's issue calls on every lawyer to devote 50 hours a year to work ''for the public good.

Copper Hits $1.40 a Pound, Highest in Over 7 Years
LEAD: Strong demand for tight supplies of copper yesterday pushed the price for future delivery of the metal to $1.40 a pound, its highest price in more than seven years.

Doctors' Attitudes on Cholesterol Are Studied
LEAD: Lay people are more likely than doctors to believe that lowering blood cholesterol levels helps fight heart disease, according to a new survey.

LEAD: The vote by Congress to deny tax credits to American companies for taxes paid by their subsidiaries in South Africa is being viewed here as potentially one of the most damaging economic measures taken by the United States against apartheid.

Sports People; Miami Suspends Two
LEAD: Two starters on the University of Miami football team, the linebacker George Mira Jr. and the offensive tackle John O'Neill, were suspended yesterday by Coach Jimmy Johnson and won't play against Oklahoma in the Orange Bowl Jan. 1. ''Both George and John violated team policy,'' Johnson said in a statement released last night.

School Is Given Roach Traps
LEAD: A West Springfield, Mass., company has given two cases of cockroach traps to Conard High School to help it get rid of the bugs.
Local officials said the school has had a cockroach problem for more than a year and a half.
Students boycotted the hot-lunch program last week after a student found a cockroach on a sandwich roll.


At the Movies
LEAD: New Brezner Comedy


Pueblo Chain Gets Buyout Offer
LEAD: Pueblo International Inc., an operator of supermarkets in Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands and Florida, has received a leveraged buyout offer of $24.50 a share in cash for its outstanding shares.
The offer by First Boston Inc. and Harold Toppel, Pueblo's chairman, includes the assumption of Pueblo debt and values the company at $185 million.

IN BETHLEHEM, CHRISTMAS IS MARKED BY TENSION
LEAD: A priest walking through a metal detector manned by Israeli troops yesterday in Bethlehem, in the occupied West Bank.
An uneasy quiet reigned in the occupied territories after two weeks of rioting.

3 IN C.I.A EXPECTED TO APPEAL ON JOBS
LEAD: At least three of the five Central Intelligence Agency officials dismissed or disciplined as a result of the Iran-contra affair are planning to appeal the action taken against them, Reagan Administration officials said today.


God's Portfolio
LEAD: The Christmas story begins, ''There went out a decree from Caesar Augustus that all the world should be taxed.'' Caesar had a global economic problem because of his greed, his lust for power and his need to impose his will upon the world - and so do we.
That was the Pax Romana.
Our power of arms is Pax


Art: A Joint Gallery Show of Miro and Rothko
LEAD: WE know that Joan Miro had a formative impact on the most venturesome American painters from the 1930's and 40's.
Many of them looked to his work, as they did to Picasso's and the paintings of a handful of other leading European artists, for inspiration in creating their own brand of Surrealism, one that borrowed heavily from the conventions of so-called automatic drawing.


Two Quartets
LEAD: Jane Ira Bloom, a soprano saxo-phonist, and Perry Robinson, a clari-netist, will lead quartets tonight through Sunday at Fat Tuesday's 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902).
Sets begin at 8 and 10 P.M., plus there is a $10 cover and a $7.50 mini-mum.


Rehnquist Postpones Effect Of Ruling in Gay Rights Case
LEAD: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist today gave Georgetown University a temporary postponement from having to comply with a request to provide two gay rights groups equal access to campus facilities.

Bank Deposit That Wasn't
LEAD: A thief covered the night deposit box at a Comerica bank branch with an out-of-order sign, set up a substitute box and then made off with $11,000 in store receipts deposited by an unwitting customer.
Police Officer Gary Conat said the bogus night deposit box was set up at the Northland Center mall branch last Saturday.

NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 25, 1987
LEAD:  International A2-11


Barrier for White House
LEAD: The concrete barrier lining Pennsylvania Avenue in front of the White House to prevent a terrorist attack will be replaced with permanent crash-resistant fixtures, it was disclosed today.
A White House notice said construction of new crash-resistant bollards is expected to take about six months, beginning after the first of the year.


On Black Employment
LEAD: At a forum on economic recovery held at the Labor Department last fall, President Reagan declared that in August the percentage of blacks employed was the highest on record.
The data showed that 56.7 percent of blacks of working age in the population were working.


Doctors Report AIDS Virus In the Retinas of 2 Patients
LEAD: Doctors have found the AIDS virus in the retinas of people with the disease and say it may contribute to blindness in AIDS victims.


Peru Settles With 2 Firms
LEAD: Two of Wall Street's biggest brokerage houses have paid Peru's leading mineral company, Minpeco S.A., $34 million to settle a lawsuit contending that they helped the Hunt brothers of Texas illegally fix silver prices, Minpeco said this week.

LEAD: Christmas comes to New York City in many ways, in the paiper-mache wings of a young Greek Orthodox girl preparing for her first Nativity pageant, in the spicy holiday pasteles of a Puerto Rican family, in the bright Lucia crowns of a Swedish boy, in the carols sung heartily in a Korean church.

LEAD: To the Editor:


PINTER'S 'ROOM' AND DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM
LEAD: IF this is Harold Pinter and the Dance Theater of Harlem on commercial television, it must be Christmas week, when television viewing levels are low and the networks rush to get rid of the kinds of programs - the arts projects or news documentaries - that might win prestige awards but not competitive ratings.


Wedding Bells, and Bucks
LEAD: If the bells of St.
Stephen's Cathedral seem to chime more often this season, it is Vienna celebrating the Government's new budget.
Like other governments that come to mind, Austria's is curtailing its generosity.
Among other things, on New Year's Day it will abolish the national award to newlyweds - 7,500 schillings, or $650, per couple.

News From Bethlehem
LEAD: The Christmas story is always present, always news.
It is the story of joy and renewal of life, of eternal yearning for hope.

Mets, Darling Agree On Pact
LEAD: Baseball hasn't even reached the filing period for salary arbitration, and Ron Darling knows what he will earn next season.
Darling, the Mets said yesterday, has agreed to a one-year contract for $1 million, which is $50,000 less than his 1987 salary.


Cigarette Fire Study Urged
LEAD: A Federal study group called Wednesday for more research into ways to improve the fire safety of cigarettes.
The group, the Interagency Committee on Cigarette and Little Cigar Fire Safety, proposed a two-year, $500,000 project to study ways of producing cigarettes that are less likely to set fire to mattresses.

Pakistan Jail Riot Put Down
LEAD: The police quelled a mutiny by about 2,000 prisoners today at Karachi's central jail, the authorities said.
The police said more than 1,000 police officers and paramilitary forces used gunfire and tear gas to put down the 10-hour mutiny.
They said about 90 prisoners and staff members were hurt.
The Karachi police chief, Iftikhar Rasheed, said the insurrection came after three political groups asserted that the death of a prisoner Monday resulted from torture.


Two Who Make a Difference in New York City's Schools; 'A Good Teacher' Extends 'Herself Beyond the Requirements'
LEAD: The quality of the New York City school system has been attacked by business leaders, politicians and educators recently.
As they express their concerns, the Board of Education is preparing to pick a new chancellor.
Among the challenges he will face are a high dropout rate, overcrowding and deteriorating buildings.

From the Pakistanis
LEAD: Perhaps the Pakistanis have adapted to life in Washington the adage of ''when in Rome, do as the Romans do.'' Money Fund Assets Off
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 413 money market mutual funds decreased $907.6 million, to $261.40 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 112 institutional funds were down $178.2 million, to $73.09 billion.
Assets of the 206 general purpose funds were down $581.8 million, to $79.22 billion.


New Zealand Brokerage
LEAD: A leading New Zealand brokerage house announced today that it could not meet its obligations as a result of the October stock market collapse.
Paine Belcher, described by the New Zealand Stock Exchange as a ''medium to large'' broker, ceased trading and said it was considering liquidation.
Investors are worried other companies and brokerage houses may follow suit and go under in the new year as New Zealand's market has stubbornly failed to recover from the

Ms.
Rey is no stranger to the restaurant business.

Turkish Silver Mine
LEAD: Turkey has opened its first silver mine and expects to earn about $30 million a year from exporting silver, the state radio said Thursday.
It added that a unit of the state company, Etibank, would process one million metric tons of ore a year and produce 122 tons of pure silver, most of which will be sold outside the country.

Rolando Fernandez, 37 years old, left Cuba as a young boy, grew up in Miami's Cuban community and then moved on to seek his fortune in Washington and New York.

LEAD: Despite bad news from Wall Street and reports of drought in prime growing regions, 1987 turned out to be a banner year for Christmas tree sales, industry officials said Thursday.

This year he has 13 goals and 24 assists, which places him third on the Rangers in scoring.

Saudi Princess Dies of Burns
LEAD: Shoaa Al-Farhan, a Saudi princess and cousin of the late King Faisal, died Thursday night at a Baltimore hospital where she was being treated for severe burns sustained in a house fire in Riyadh.
She was 43 years old.
The Princess was admitted to the Baltimore Regional Burn Center on Nov. 25 with third-degree burns covering 93 percent of her body.


Hurdling Rivalry
LEAD: Greg Foster and Renaldo Nehemiah will resume their longtime rivalry Feb. 5 when they meet in the 55-meter high hurdles in the Panasonic Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden.
Foster has won five Millrose titles and Nehemiah has won four.
Nehemiah holds a 28-7 margin over Foster, with one dead heat, since their first meeting in 1978.

LEAD: A Federal judge has awarded the surviving children of William Saroyan the rights to one of his plays, an action that some fear may threaten a scholarship foundation financed by royalties from his works.

LEAD: The Sandinista rest camp on the shores of Lake Apanas is primitive by American standards.
A concrete volleyball court and a wooden guard shack are the only signs of permanence.
The rest of the camp is made up of makeshift canvas and plastic lean-tos and tents hastily erected in a muddy field.

LEAD: A law firm that served as special counsel to the Washington Public Power Supply System has agreed to a $7.25 million settlement with the buyers of bonds issued by the system to build two nuclear power plants that have been abandoned.

Blast Rips Greek Army Camp; Leftists Take Responsibility
LEAD: An explosion tore through a major Greek Army camp and ammunition dump early today, and a little-known far-left group took responsibility for the blast.

Music: 'H.M.S. Pinafore' Headed by John Reed
LEAD: With its production of ''H.M.S.
Pinafore'' at Symphony Space, the New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players has set a winner to sail.
By enlisting the very funny John Reed, a D'Oyly Carte veteran, to portray the First Lord of the Admiralty, and then surrounding him with a cast of unusually able singers and nimble comic actors, the New York company laid the groundwork for a success.


Iranian Warns U.N. Against Further Steps
LEAD: Iran today condemned a United Nations Security Council statement on the Iran-Iraq war, saying it was the wrong way to end the seven-year-long conflict.

CHINA SEES TRADE SURPLUS FOR '87, THE FIRST IN 4 YEARS
LEAD: China in 1987 achieved its first trade surplus in four years thanks to a crackdown on imports and to new incentives to companies to export their products, the trade minister said today.


Seabrook Utility Formulating Plan
LEAD: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire is formulating a capital restructuring plan that would give the majority of its common stock to the holders of unsecured debt, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The company said it could not predict that the restructuring could be achieved ''on a timely basis'' or before it might be forced into bankruptcy.

To Them, It's Tea Time
After centuries of efforts to grow tea in the United States, two entrepreneurs in South Carolina are now raising the nation's only crop.


Indonesia Acts To Lift Exports
LEAD: The Government said Thursday that it would abolish nearly all export regulations under a new economic plan intended to increase production and raise exports of a wide range of non-oil products.

A Severely Burned Boy Goes Home for a Visit
LEAD: A 13-year-old boy who survived a 13,500-volt shock last fall went home from the hospital for a Christmas visit and is looking forward to riding his bicycle again.

LEAD: The United States and the Soviet Union both suffered setbacks on matters of importance to them at the United Nations during the General Assembly session that ended this week, diplomats say.

LEAD: The number of Palestinian youths arrested by Israel for suspected involvement in the recent wave of riots in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip has risen to nearly 1,000, Israeli newspapers and military personnel said today.

It's a key scene, providing the audience with a good look at Mr.
Biko's convictions, charisma and eloquence.

Trump on Resorts
LEAD: Donald J. Trump, the New York investor, said Thursday that, although he had made a written proposal to take Resorts International Inc. private, no tender offer had been made for the class A common stock of the resort and casino company.
Mr.
Trump, the chairman of Resorts, said the proposal must be reviewed by a special committee of the company's board before a tender offer can be made.


U.S. Youth Gains
LEAD: Jim Courier of the United States and Andrei Cherkosov of the Soviet Union advanced yesterday to the semifinals in the boys' 18 division of the Orange Bowl International Tennis Championships in Miami Beach.
The top-seeded Courier, of Dade City, Fla., advanced with a 6-2, 6-1 victory over unseeded Francisco Michelotti of Italy.


Markets Closed
LEAD: Stock and commodity markets in the United States and most other countries were closed yesterday in observance of Christmas.
Banks, government offices and most businesses were also closed.
On Jan. 1 the stock market will be closed in observance of New Year's Day.

LEAD: A senior Soviet sports official said yesterday that he expected Moscow to send a team to the 1988 Summer Olympic games in Seoul, South Korea, according to the Yugoslav news agency, Tanjug.

LEAD: On Christmas Eve, 1985, the people of this south-central Nebraska community mourned a stranger, a boy found dead on the side of a road.
This year they finally know who he was, but they do not know why he died.

'ARMS AND THE MAN' IN FAIRFIELD
LEAD: STAGING ''Arms and the Man'' is a tricky thing.
All excess and extravagance on the surface, it is filled with more operetta-like outbursts than the musical it inspired, ''The Chocolate Soldier'' with its signature song, ''My Hero.'' It is, after all, a play by George Bernard Shaw - and that isn't romantic.

LEAD: About 20 members of Poland's draft resistance group huddled in a small flat in the Polish capital this week, in the middle of a hunger strike to protest the detention of about 100 youths who they say were jailed for refusing military service.

LEAD: WITH the new year just before us, it seems appropriate to reminisce about the pleasures of dining out in Connecticut in 1987.

LEAD: A Federal judge has rejected motions to dismiss the charges against Anthony (Fat Tony) Salerno and 10 other defendants in a trial involving the Genovese crime family.

LEAD: IF someone was going to spend $20 million to redo the Rainbow Room, New York's tastiest Art Deco confection, it seemed a safe bet that the city's well-dressed women would go to some lenghts to make a grand entrance in that sparkling setting.
And so they did.

LEAD: A Rumanian woman arrested in Bucharest after an interview for a French television documentary was released Thursday, the League for the Defense of Human Rights in Rumania said Friday.

6 U.S. Sailors Hurt in U.S.O. Attack in Spain
LEAD: Six sailors from the United States Navy were wounded, one seriously, today in a grenade attack that wrecked a U.S.O. club, officials said.
Catalan separatist groups claimed responsibility for the blast, according to the Spanish state radio.

LEAD: Ten human rights monitors were killed, two disappeared and hundreds more were abused in the last year, according to a report issued today by Human Rights Watch, a coalition of Americas Watch, Asia Watch and Helsinki Watch, three rights groups.

CRIME
LEAD: Joseph Hansen's Dave Brandstetter novels, starting with ''Fadeout'' in 1970, have been probing studies of the homosexual culture.
Brandstetter is an independently wealthy claims investigator for an insurance company and a homosexual.
A man of deep feeling, he can give the impression of being cold because he is 100 percent rational.

WILLIAM SIMON'S FACIFIC OVERTURES
LEAD: THE BUILDING ON SANTA MONICA BOULEVARD in Beverly Hills, just over the Los Angeles city line, bears no resemblance to the West Coast headquarters of a world-class tycoon with bold new plans of conquest in the Pacific.
A scant three stories tall, muted post-modern in design, set in a row of nondescript shops facing the Hilton and the back of Robertson's department store, the World Trade Bank resembles the showroom of a moderately prosperous Chevrolet dealer.

AFTER HOWARD BEACH: A NEW MILITANCY?
LEAD: THE conviction last week of three white teen-agers for manslaughter, nearly a year to the day after they chased a black man to his death in Howard Beach, Queens, seemed to relieve, for a moment, an extended period of racial tension in New York City.
There were cries of ''murderers'' from some people in the courtroom, but the verdicts were widely regarded as fair.

The choices range from the sites of ancient ruins along the Nile to New Caledonia, a Gallicized group of islands in the South Pacific.

About Men; A Joyful Noise
LEAD: I ONCE LEANED BACK against the railing of the second-floor balcony of the Women's National Republican Club, just off Fifth Avenue, and realized there were other men in this world every bit as insane as I. This was not immediate cause for alarm.
To the contrary, what was happening was that a crucial problem that had plagued me since college was being resolved before my ears.

DID PICTURES JOIN, voices mingle and stories swoosh round in a blender?

There was no other way.
Ollie North gave way to Presidential candidates, who disappeared in the Persian Gulf, which evaporated when the stock market tumbled.
Red neckties - Washington correspondents now favor solid scarlet - remained the only constant.

PENZOIL PONDERS $3 BILLION QUESTION
LEAD: What to do with $3 billion was the question Penzoil was pondering as a settlement plan was filed in its historic feud with Texaco.
Texaco's plan to emerge from bankruptcy calls for a $3 billion payment to settle Pennzoil's claim that Texaco' acquisition of Getty Oil wrongfully interfered with a Pennzoil takeover of the company.


USING GENETIC ENGINEERING TO MAKE TOMATOES TASE LIKE TOMATOES AGAIN
LEAD: THE tomato is a symbol of the triumphs and disappointments of American agriculture.
Over the last 50 years, breeders have crossed one variety with another to produce hybrids with large yields, long shelf lives and the ruggedness to survive a long trek to market.
At the same time, the store-bought tomato has become pale, hard, thick-skinned and increasingly tasteless.


Leslie Carothers Is a Ballerina Ablaze With Passion
LEAD: THIS HAS BEEN CALLED an age of dancers.
Virtuoso whiz kids dart, spin and soar through choreography whose challenges would once have been considered almost impossible.
Then there are the performers who fill the stage with their very presence.
Every so often, however, a dancer is endowed with both superb technical facilities and a commanding stage personality.

MUSIC
LEAD:  Celebrating Bird: The Triumph of Charlie Parker  Sony Video Software Company. 58 minutes. $29.95.
So many audio recordings of Charlie (Bird) Parker exist, legal and surreptitious, that it's astonishing that he survives on movie film in only two clips, one of them without a sound track.
Despite such a handicap, this documentary of a meteoric jazz figure could hardly be bettered.


Food Without Foam
LEAD: The Styrofoam box with two compartments keeps the burger hot while the lettuce and tomato stay cool and crisp.
But at what cost to the environment?
The white plastic packages create hazardous waste.
Tons of nonbiodegradable boxes and cups strain the nation's overflowing landfills.
Burning can generate toxic emissions.


WHAT WERE THE YEAR'S BEST SPORTS STORIES?
LEAD: This year's top sports story is, and continues to be, the pollution of the athletic environment by moneyed interests.
Big-time college campuses have been infected by agents offering illegal financial assistance, coaches motivated by personal avarice rather than the desire to educate, administrations dedicated to the pursuit of television revenues, and athletes hoping to use school as a way station to the pros.

Caracas
LEAD: To the Editor: A friend and I visited Caracas in July.
We agreed with Anthony Austin's observation (Travel, Oct. 25) that instead of providing architecture, Venezuelean money could have eased the plight of the poor.
As prominent as the modern skyscrapers are, the shanties spilling down three sides of the surrounding mountains paint a rusty stain that ends flush against the high-rise fences.

By LESLIE BENNETTS

LEAD: THE FACE OF ROCK, 1987, WAS the face of U2's lead singer, Bono Vox.

It is the face of popular music feeling its power and its global reach, and taking them very seriously.

NEW PLANT MAP IS PROPOSED
LEAD: HARDY is a word often used in defining how well a plant grows, but it is a relative term.
A plant that is considered hardy in a certain area should survive cold weather and not be subject to frost damage.
But the word is not completely accurate, because it does not take into account many factors that affect growth: drought/rainfall, exposure/radiation, soils, summer heat and other environmental constraints.

Stationery on Bond Street

Then the 2,215-ton ferry collided with the 629-ton tanker Victor, with a crew of 13.

WHEN JUDGES MUST KNOW MORE THAN LAW
LEAD: AFTER a four-year jury trial, probably the longest in United States history, a court in Belleville, Ill., decided in October that 65 citizens of a small Missouri town had not been harmed when a chemical used as a wood preservative was spilled in a 1979 railroad accident.
Nevertheless, the jurors awarded the plaintiffs $16 million in punitive damages against the manufacturer, the Monsanto Company, for not ridding its product of dioxin, a potentially dangerous contaminant, and failing to warn the public about it.

The Year DAT Was Put on Hold
LEAD: THE PASSING YEAR, AS concerns audio, was marked by a non-event.
DAT didn't happen.
As most audio fans know, DAT stands for Digital Audio Tape.
It is a system of recording and playback that brings digital techniques to tape cassettes and makes them sound just as good as CD's.
Listeners accustomed to the latter's sonic excellence had long been hoping for cassettes to catch up and were eagerly expecting DAT's American debut.

LEAD: WE HAVE AN image of downhill racers.
Downhill racers are wild men.

From Euphoria to Glory to Grand Scope
LEAD: WAS IT ALWAYS SO EASY TO find great performers as it is today?
They are all over the landscape, helpfully labeled for us by arts packagers.
Here they come, armies of great singers, great violinists, great pianists, great conductors, great computer programmers.
Others fall into old but strangely new categories marked designer or stage director, whose most celebrated celebrities now invite us to enjoy the odd sensation of experiencing music as primarily a visual art to which aimless sounds are added, generally quite unobtrusively, though occasionally with the wit and subtlety of a laugh track

John D. Rich of Wilton, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs.
Martin J. Weiner of Scarsdale, N.Y.
The couple plan to marry in July.
Miss Weiner, a graduate of Hamilton College, is an assistant vice president in the treasury sales group at the National Westminster Bank USA in New York.


Julia Arnsten to Marry Adam R. Spilka in June
LEAD: Julia Hope Arnsten, a second-year medical student at New York University, and Adam R. Spilka, an associate in the New York law firm of Debevoise &amp; Plimpton, plan to be married in June, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs.
Lawrence Arnsten of New York, have announced.


JORDAN HELD TO 17 AS BULLS LOSE
LEAD: Vern Fleming scored 10 of his 22 points in the third period as the Indiana Pacers opened a 20-point lead and then handed the Chicago Bulls their sixth consecutive road loss, 106-92, today.


FICTION
LEAD:  THE FLOOD.
By John Broderick. (Marion Boyars/ Kampmann, $22.95.) Forget about plot.
John Broderick's latest novel, ''The Flood,'' which is set during the 1930's in Bridgeford, Ireland (population 8,767), boasts such a colorful jumble of characters and voices one barely notices that its story is thin and inconsequential.

Blast at Ammunition Depot Kills Greek Explosives Expert
LEAD: An army bomb disposal expert was killed and four others were injured today in the second explosion in two days at an army ammunition depot near Athens, the Defense Ministry said.


After Abduction, Queens Teen-Ager Is Found Safe
LEAD: A 13-year-old girl from Forest Hills, Queens, kidnapped and held by captors demanding $15,000 in ransom, was found unharmed Christmas night by detectives who tracked her kidnappers to their Brooklyn home, the police said yesterday.


The Best Christmas Present of All
LEAD: Deborah Edmonds with her 20-month-old son Stephen at Washoe Medical Center in Reno on Friday.
The child was trapped under water for 24 minutes Monday when a car he was in skidded off a road and into a lake.
On Christmas Day the child recognized his mother for the first time since the accident.
The child is still listed in serious condition.


Pop Music
LEAD: For Marti Stevens the year 1987, which began with her return to New York after an absence of many years, is ending in a special glow.

Photography
LEAD: Humor and art are not always allies, especially when it comes to photographs of dogs.
But William Wegman's new color pictures at Pace/ MacGill Gallery (11 East 57th Street, through Jan. 16) manage to make us laugh and think at the same time.
In ''Hatched,'' for example, we see the artist's new pet Weimaraner, Fay Ray, wrapped in red-faced aluminum foil, looking somewhat like a Christmas gift and somewhat like a half-opened bonbon.


Redskins Stymie Vikings
LEAD: Ali Haji-Sheikh, who missed a 33-yard field goal with 46 seconds left in regulation, kicked a 26-yarder at 2 minutes 9 seconds into overtime today, as the Washington Redskins temporarily prevented the Minnesota Vikings from earning the final National Football Conference wild-card spot with a 27-24 victory.


Japan Acts in Technology Sale
LEAD: An Osaka trading company was indicted today on charges of selling sophisticated electronic machinery to North Korea, the Kyodo News Service said.

Trip Insurance
LEAD: To the Editor: The Practical Traveler column on Oct. 25 discussed trip cancellation insurance.
No mention was made of the cancellation policy of Saga International Holidays of Boston.
Providing group packages for people 60 and older, Saga offers a complete refund for cancellations for medical reasons.


Headliners; Out of Russia
LEAD: Like many other Jewish scientists in the Soviet Union, Aleksandr Lerner was long denied permission to emigrate because, officials said, he knew too much.
Mr.
Lerner, a leader in the campaign for Jewish emigration, is a specialist in cybernetics, and Soviet authorities for 17 years denied him an exit visa on the ground that his research had given him access to state secrets.


Cracking Down On Sweets
LEAD: IT WAS the best and worst of news for schoolchildren in New York State, uplifting for their health but a blow to their morale.


O'Neill Reflects on 'Gratifying' Year
LEAD: TAKING stock at the end of his seventh year as the 84th Governor of Connecticut, William A. O'Neill generally likes what he sees.


Thailand Facing Unexpected Refugee Influx
LEAD: Thailand, through which hundreds of thousands of Indochinese refugees have passed since Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos were taken over by Communist Governments in 1975, is facing unexpected new influxes of asylum-seekers, according to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.


Syracuse Arrives For Sugar Bowl
LEAD: Syracuse (11-0) arrived here today to begin on-site preparations for Friday's Sugar Bowl game with Auburn (9-1-1), and Coach Dick MacPherson said that he expected his players to enjoy their stay.

LEAD: An unusual partnership of private and public concerns is creating a day care center for 100 children in an inner-city neighborhood here.

THE DOLLAR'S DROP
LEAD: To the Editor:


Chemical Cleanup
LEAD: IT'S A CHILLING SUMMARY.
After 40 years of manufacturing waterproofing materials for the textiles industry, the Arkansas Chemical Company went bankrupt in 1983 and abandoned its facilities in Newark, N.J.
Under the provisions of the so-called Superfund Act of 1980, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency was ultimately called in to begin a cleanup.


Just the Right Note on New Year's Day
LEAD: WHETHER they constitute a late supper on New Year's Eve or brunch on New Year's Day, certain dishes always hit the spot.
Blinis, Russian buckwheat pancakes, served with red or black caviar, melted butter and sour cream, are one of my favorites, especially with a glass of champagne or iced vodka.


New Kind of Criminal Is Stealing the Trash
LEAD: Rhode Island's new mandatory recycling program has created a new crime: theft of garbage.


NONFICTION
LEAD:  ALEXIS LICHINE'S NEW ENCYCLOPEDIA OF WINES &amp; SPIRITS.
Fifth Edition, Revised.
By Alexis Lichine with William Fifield. (Knopf, $45.) New Year's Eve celebrants who seek Alexis Lichine's advice on serving Champagne will also learn that Art Buchwald likes bubbly ''because it always tastes as though my foot's asleep.


LIKE A HOLLYWOOD PREMIERE
LEAD: THE 1987 razzle-dazzle award goes to Caffe Spasso in Carle Place.
Even at holiday time with the overkill of glitter and glow from nearby Fortunoff and Roosevelt Field, this restaurant stands out.
Saturday night at the pink neon-edged, Art Deco-style building resembles a 1930's Hollywood premiere.
The parking lot is jammed; the crowd is out the door.

LEAD: JOHN THEODORACOPULOS, a 22-year-old apprentice with a merchant bank, was talking about New Year's Eve recently with a group of friends and, he said, they all agreed.
It is a hyped-up evening, anticlimactic, and one that often ends with everyone a bit depressed.

When the Tide Turned on Rampant Growth
LEAD: THE EXTRAORDINARY EVENT in architecture in 1987 was surely the building that collapsed before it was ever built: the tower designed by Moshe Safdie for the site of the New York Coliseum at Columbus Circle.
What was extraordinary was not the actual design for this building, which was a wretched piece of architecture, but the circumstances surrounding its demise.


EARLY MUSIC AND THE OFFBEAT SET THE PACE
LEAD: EVER SINCE THE ADVENT OF the compact disk, the record companies' release lists have been filling up with reissues of back catalogue.
But their activities heretofore in this regard paled beside the reissue onslaught of 1987.
Not that it's surprising, or even bad: the CD has become the format of choice among classical-music record buyers, and naturally one wants as many valuable recordings as possible from the analogue era to remain readily available.


4 Die in Dutch Fire
LEAD: Two prisoners and two firefighters died in a fire at police headquarters Friday, and officials said today that the fire may have been set by a burglary suspect in his cell.
Twelve prisoners, police officers, firefighters and jail guards were hospitalized for injuries suffered in the fire, but all but one have been released.


New &amp; Noteworthy
LEAD:  THE LEOPARD, by Giuseppe di Lampedusa.
Translated by Archibald Colquhoun. (Pantheon, $7.95.) Set in the late 19th century, when the kingdom of Sicily was losing its independence to Italy, Giuseppe di Lampedusa's novel describes how an enlightened monarch adjusts to a situation he is powerless to change.
