FILM'S FAR EAST CONNECTION: Janet Yang; Bringing Hollywood Hits to China's Moviegoers
LEAD: JANET YANG remembers clearly the first time she saw an American movie in China.
It was called ''Nightmare in Badham County,'' and it was about the horrors and injustices heaped upon two women trapped in a backwoods town in the American South.


13 CANDIDATES REACH 1988, WITH PLENTY TO FRET OVER
LEAD: In 1987, amid all the talk of things like adultery and politicians' stealing speeches, it has been easy to lose sight of what the American people will be deciding in the election of 1988.


To Improve Medicaid's Bad Deal
LEAD: A new study finds that New York State's Medicaid program is one of the best in the country, but it costs New York City plenty.
The city's share of the health insurance for the poor now comes to $1.4 billion annually, a figure that has been increasing 11 percent per year, well above the national average.


Dervishes
LEAD: To the Editor: I am writing about an oversight in the article entitled ''A Flourishing of Whirling Dervishes'' (Travel, Dec. 6).
My translation of a quatrain by Rumi appeared without crediting the book in which it was originally published and without mentioning my name.
The translation first appeared in the book entitled ''Mevlana Celaleddin Rumi and the Whirling Dervishes'' by Talat Sait Halman and Metin And (published in Istanbul in 1983 by Dost).

LEAD: THE concert season runs from fall through spring and so, naturally enough, do most subscription series.

LEAD: WHEN the Candlewood Playhouse canceled its revival of the musical ''Annie,'' which was scheduled to been seen in October, there was talk that New Fairfield's summer theater was not going to be a year-round showplace, as its three producers had hoped, but that it was going under.

A Starting Place for Black Musicians
LEAD: In 1973, fresh from the Manhattan School of Music with a master's degree, Hal Archer scoured Manhattan for a job as a classical flutist.
He had anticipated a difficult search, but he never dreamed of the barriers facing a black classical musician in the early 1970's.
Through the next decade, his one steady job, and his best reviews, came when he played with the New York City Housing Authority Symphony

FOUR-WHEEL DRIVE IS THERE WHEN YOU NEED IT
LEAD: THEY are part mechanized cow pony, part military personnel carrier.
You see them hauling groceries in Hastings-on-Hudson, toting Turf Builder in Tuckahoe, riding high above the station traffic in Rye.
They are not exactly trucks, but they sure aren't cars; they're the new Family Four-by-Fours.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Track and Field  Two Golds for Foderingham: Winsome Foderingham captured two gold medals yesterday in women's events at the Reebok Christmas Classic track and field meet in the West Point field house in West Point, N.Y.
The meet was conducted by the Metropolitan Athletics Congress.
Foderingham, a Jamaican representing the Bronx International Express Track Club, won the 55-meter dash in 7.14 seconds and the 55-meter hurdles in 8.12 seconds.

LEAD: Israel's crackdown on Palestinian protesters has sharpened the quandaries and frustrations facing Egypt, the only Arab nation to have made peace with Israel, according to analysts and officials here.

Westport, Conn.


5 Deaths Reported in South African Unrest
LEAD: Four black men were killed Friday and the police twice fired at crowds in a district where more than 230 people have died in factional fighting this year, the police said today.


Japanese Textiles Reveal Subtle Beauty
LEAD: FOR many years, the arts of Japan have exerted a strong influence on Western taste.
Ever since the mid-19th century, the Oriental esthetic of simple, elegant design has found increasing favor in the United States, where Japanese prints, pottery and textiles have become ever more popular.


Broadcast TV
LEAD: Hallelujah!
Here comes the entire ''Thin Man'' series, all six features on Channel 5, to round out the old year and ease in 1988.
Home viewers won't find better nightly company this week than Nick and Nora Charles - the charming William Powell and Myrna Loy - in the durably popular sleuthing series derived from Dashiell Hammett's novel.


Moose's Love Takes a Place In Literature
LEAD: It's been almost a year since the 700-pound moose who courted a Hereford cow named Jessica in Shrewsbury, Vt., lost his antlers and walked away from the 76-day love affair, but the story of their romance is now popular in hardcover.


Ruth Bonner, Stalin Purge Victim
LEAD: Ruth G. Bonner, mother-in-law of the Soviet physicist Andrei D. Sakharov and a victim of Stalin's purges in the late 1930's, died Friday at the age of 87, her daughter Yelena G. Bonner said today.


NEW YORK REACHES ACCORD ON HOUSING
LEAD: Battery Park City plans to contribute $1 billion to develop housing in New York City, $600 million more than originally agreed to.
That means the development is to finance one-quarter of Mayor Koch's 10-year plan to build low- and middle-income housing.

THE YEAR'S BEST INNOVATIONS
LEAD: THE past year was full of innovations in photographic technology, in terms of both cameras and film.
We have yet to arrive at a camera so intelligent that it knows where to aim itself, or a film that can switch from color to black-and-white at the press of a button.
But photography is definitely marching to the beat of more automation and less fuss.

LEAD: UNAUTHORIZED markings on United States stamps, made by the engravers of the dyes, prompted smiles in the world of philately but frowns in the Treasury Department's Bureau of Engraving and Printing earlier this year.


LEGISLATORS ADOPT A BUDGET FOR 1988
LEAD: THE County Board of Legislators approved an $846.9 million budget for 1988 last week, trimming $3.4 million from the proposed spending plan presented in mid-November by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke.
The final version will require a 15 percent increase in the county tax levy, or the amount raised from real estate taxes.

KEAN'S STAR RISING IN G.O.P.
LEAD: SOME of Governor Kean's aides gave their boss a sweatshirt for Christmas with his picture on a map of the United States captioned ''Tom Kean's '86-'87 North American Tour.'' Like a memento of a rock star's itinerary, the back of the shirt lists the 36 cities the New Jersey Republican has visited since his landslide re-election victory in 1985.

FICTION
LEAD:  NIGHT WITHOUT DAY.
By Raphaele Billetdoux.
Translated by Derek Mahon. (Viking, $14.95.) In this chronicle of a torturous three-day affair, the lovers' first meeting summons up ''the memory of a bruised pear . . . demanding anew to be eaten or thrown away.'' The burden of their first embrace ''was heavy, but they took the weight of it in their legs, they clung to each other, they concentrated harder, their clenched fingers hurting.


INCREASINGLY, THOSE WHO HAVE JOBS ARE POOR, TOO
LEAD: IN 1981, President Reagan persuaded Congress to adopt many of his proposals tightening eligibility and limiting benefits in the main welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children.
Emphasizing the importance of the work ethic, Administration officials said A.F.D.C. should be restricted to those who could not work because they were old or disabled or had to care for young children.


BILL OF RIGHTS PROVIDES SCANT REFUGE FOR IMMIGRANTS STOPPED AT HE BORDER
LEAD: EARLY next year, the Justice Department will make good on a promise that helped end last month's prison riots in Atlanta and Oakdale, La., when it begins holding special administrative proceedings for Cubans who have been in legal limbo for more than seven years.
In the eyes of the law, they and some others who came to the United States with the Mariel boatlift never actually entered the country.


Dispute Blocks Home for Elite School
LEAD: Almost four years after Queens College won a fierce political battle to recreate a famous high school for intellectually gifted youngsters, the college finds itself in a dispute over where the elite school should be housed.


Campaign for Egg Eating Stirs Storm in India
LEAD: When hundreds of runners turned up for a marathon race in the western city of Pune last month, they were handed free boiled eggs by members of a movement seeking to promote the egg-eating habit in india.

Howard Beach Juror Cites Victim's Fear
LEAD: A member of the jury in the Howard Beach trial said yesterday that the jurors had reached a verdict of manslaughter rather than murder last week because they believed that Michael Griffith's death was caused by fear that resulted from the mob attack and chase.


Bull Market for Movies and Screens
LEAD: THE MOST IMPORTANT MOVIE news this year wasn't movies but business.
More movies than ever went into release this year than at any time in recent memory.
Distributors of video cassettes became an important source of production money.
Box offices boomed, but often with movies that were interchangeable (''Robocop,'' ''Stakeout,'' ''Lethal Weapon,'' ''Extreme Prejudice'').

TAX SHELTERS

STABILIZING THE CURRENCY: Peg the Dollar's Value to Commodities
LEAD: MAINTAINING the stable purchasing power of a currency is the key policy objective of any central bank.
Recently, Secretary of the Treasury James A. Baker 3d called for the use of a broad commodity basket, including gold, as an indicator to be used in the monetary policy formulation process.


Developer Buys Church Land: Gothic Details for an Office Building
LEAD: When the Rev.
Peter Larom, pastor of the Grace Episcopal Church in White Plains, heard that Harry A. Halpern planned an office project on the same block as his church building, he briefly considered fighting it.
Instead, he decided upon an option being exercised by an increasing number of nonprofit institutions that are situated on valuable, downtown property: He agreed to sell church land to the developer.

Girl Survives Alligator Attack By Grabbing Beast by Jaws
LEAD: A 12-year-old girl survived an attack by an alligator by grabbing its jaws after it had grabbed her legs, officials said today.


CONGRESS BATS UNDER .500
LEAD: The 100th Congress, the Democrats in charge after they recaptured the Senate in the 1986 elections, began 1987 with heady expectations for redirecting the Reagan Administration's domestic agenda and reshaping the President's foreign policy.
It adjourned last week, three months later than planned, not so much defeated as deflated.


JUST THE RIGHT NOTE ON NEW YEAR'S DAY
LEAD: WHETHER they constitute a late supper on New Year's Eve or brunch on New Year's Day, certain dishes always hit the spot.
Blinis, Russian buckwheat pancakes, served with red or black caviar, melted butter and sour cream, are one of my favorites, especially with a glass of champagne or iced vodka.


TWO SHOWS FEATURE LANDSCAPE PHOTOGRAPHY BY KETCHUM
LEAD: ROBERT GLENN KETCHUM emerged with a master's degree in fine arts from the California Institute of the Arts in 1974.
Since then, apparently, he has been working nonstop - as a curator, consultant, lecturer and, most of all, as a landscape photographer.
At the Hudson River Museum it is Mr.
Ketchum the photographer and heartfelt environmentalist who is the center of attention.

Skiing the Uncrowded Colorado
LEAD: BEAVER CREEK is a refuge for hawks, elk, whistle pigs (groundhogs), eagles, deer, beaver and skiers fleeing the winter carnival of Vail.
Vail, just up the road, is a dazzling place to ski.
The Colorado snow is abundant, the temperature rarely cold enough to be uncomfortable, the air dry, the lifts fast; the runs, lined with spruce and aspen, are varied and seemingly endless.


AN ANIMATED '88 AWAITS ON THE DRAWING BOARD
LEAD: TELEVISION'S CRAVING FOR animation continues to be as ravenous as the appetites of those sinister cats on the film maker Ralph Bakshi's ''Mighty Mouse: The New Adventures,'' Saturday mornings on CBS.
While just about all program schedules have currently been offering a cornucopia of animated holiday fare, animators are already busy at their drawing boards crafting colorful fantasies for 1988 and '89.

War's Toll in Angola
Twelve years of civil war in Angola has reduced Government-controlled areas to an archipelago of urban islands strung over a nation twice the size of France.

The Editorial Notebook; Chile's Unburied Past
LEAD: Fourteen years of relentless dictatorship have done little to concentrate Chilean democrats' minds on the future.
A recent visit showed the opposition to be as divided today as it was in September 1973.
That's when a military coup, supported by centrist and right-wing civilian parties, ended the elected Socialist presidency of Salvador Allende and with it, Chile's democratic political life.

The pocket-size guide lists 740 dining establishments, from Abyssinia to Zucchini, the overwhelming majority of them in Manhattan.
Each is rated on food, decor, service and cost.


Israelis Defend Protest Tactics
LEAD: Israeli officials said today that Israeli soldiers had resorted to using live ammunition against Palestinian demonstrators when their own lives were endangered.


F.D.I.C. Could See First Yearly Loss
LEAD: The Government agency that insures almost $2 trillion in deposits at the nation's commercial banks could record the first annual loss in its 54-year history, its chairman says.


Anthony West, Critic and Author; Wrote Essays for The New Yorker
LEAD: Anthony West, the critic and novelist, died yesterday at his home in Stonington, Conn., after suffering a stroke.
He was 73 years old and also kept a home on Fisher's Island, N.Y.


Search Ends for Plane In Hawaii After 4 Days
LEAD: The search for a twin-engine commuter plane missing since Wednesday night with eight people aboard was called off today, and a newspaper reported that the pilot had been having trouble with his door before the plane vanished.

LEAD: In Pasadena, Calif., it's the DooDa Parade.

LEAD: Travelers who hauled large, heavy bags aboard planes when they left for their holiday trips may find a surprise on return flights as tighter restrictions on carry-on luggage take effect on New Year's Day.

LEAD: The Government of Singapore this weekend restricted the circulation of one of Asia's most influential publications, the weekly Far Eastern Economic Review.

LEAD: Sport fishing has come a long way since the days of bamboo poles and twine.
Now comes a touch of technological wizardry that may leave even the most tournament-crazed angler wanting.


Soviet-Egyptian Trade
LEAD: The Soviet Union and Egypt plan to double their trade over the next three years, Soviet Deputy Trade Minister Vladimir Burmistov said in Cairo today. ''I will sign a new trade protocol raising the volume of trade from $900 million, to $1.8 billion, during this visit,'' he told reporters after arriving for talks on a new 1988-1990 agreement.

LEAD: For months, the Y-shaped concrete pillars flanking the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in lower Manhattan resembled a latter-day Stonehenge, akin to the original monoliths in their apparent futility but distinguished by their spray-painted graffiti.

LEAD: The Communist Party newspaper Pravda warned today that some of the unofficial political clubs spreading through the country were violating the law by promoting anti-Soviet views.


Amex Seeks New Network
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission is reviewing a proposal from the American Stock Exchange that would make it easier for sophisticated investors in the United States to trade securities issued by foreign corporations that do not register with the commission.


The Detroit Advantage in Trucks
LEAD: Parking lots at schools are crowded with mothers in mini-vans picking up their children.
Young executives park their BMW's and Volvos on weekends to drive their Jeeps to the country club or their vacation homes.
The payload in a pickup these days is as likely to be a surfboard as a sheet of plywood.

LEAD: Not long ago, Joseph R. Canion recalls, every time the International Business Machines Corporation brought out a new personal computer, reporters, colleagues, even friends ''all wanted to know when we were going to board up the windows at Compaq and go away.''

LEAD: Intense competition among ship and submarine builders is prompting many contractors to submit unrealistically low bids for Navy contracts, leading to huge cost overruns that the Navy must help absorb, a General Accounting Office report concludes.

Alexander G. Barmine, 88, Dies; Early High-Level Soviet Defector
LEAD: Alexander G. Barmine, a brigadier general in the Soviet Army who defected in 1937 and became an influential journalist and a United States Government official, died Friday at a nursing home in Rockville, Md.
He died of complications resulting from a stroke.

LEAD: Despite more than two decades of intensive Federal and state assistance, the depressed coal counties of southwestern Virginia are making little progress in catching up economically with the rest of the state, a major study has found.

LEAD: NOBODY knows what 1988 will bring for the stock and bond markets, but James S. Riepe, director of the mutual fund division of T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore, seems sure of one thing. ''It's going to be harder to sell mutual funds than it has been in recent years,'' he said.


Welfare Allowance Going Up But Homeless Worries Persist
LEAD: New York State will increase the housing allowances of welfare families by an average of 13 percent on Jan. 1.
But public officials, community leaders, housing specialists, welfare recipients and landlords assert that the allowances, less than most rents in New York City, will be inadequate to stop an increase in homeless families.

LEAD: After almost two years as one of the Federal authorities' most wanted fugitives, former New Jersey State Senator David J. Friedland was snared last week by his own success as an operator of a chain of scuba diving shops on an island in the Indian Ocean, a Federal marshal said yesterday.

Enact a Gasoline Tax, to Begin With
LEAD: For many years, the Federal Government has emulated New York City's pre-1975 spending and borrowing practices.
Since 1980, the Government has outdone New York's most financially irresponsible conduct.
It has borrowed recklessly, first from ourselves, then from the rest of the world, to finance a huge defense program, significant tax cuts and continuously growing social programs such as Social Security.

LEAD: The beginning was simple enough: on Sept. 12, 1983, a Wells Fargo guard robbed a depot in West Hartford.
Getting to the end, however, has turned into what some lawyers are calling one of the lengthiest and most complex criminal cases in Federal court history.


News Lurks on the Crime Blotter in Moscow
LEAD: Every Wednesday at one of Moscow's most fearsome addresses, 38 Petrovka St., the local police meet the Soviet press to report the latest incidents of exploding television sets, snatchings of fur hats, vodka moonshining and other constabulary notes from all over Moscow.


Chemical Cars Derail And Water Is Checked
LEAD: A chemical-laden freight train derailed Saturday near this east Texas city and burned through the night, causing Federal and state environmental officials to monitor water in the area today for possible contamination.


Near-Perfect Conditions Can Be Found Indoors
LEAD: THE United States Davis Cup team has played five of its last six home matches indoors, even in the middle of summer when the rest of the tennis-playing world is competing outside.
Why?
Because indoor tennis removes the natural elements as factors in determining the outcome of a match, and there have been instances in which the United States Tennis Association felt that Mother Nature contributed as much to an American defeat as the opposition.


Dole and Bush Leading In an Iowa G.O.P. Poll
LEAD: A poll indicated today that the Iowa race between Senator Bob Dole and Vice President Bush remains close six weeks before the state's precinct caucuses, a key test of the Republican Presidential campaign.

LEAD: Over the centuries, Christian clerics have offered their blessings to everything from the hounds before the hunt to battleships going off to war.

LEAD: An American sailor died today from wounds received Saturday in a bomb attack on a U.S.O. club, the fourth against American targets in Barcelona this year.
Rival Catalan separatist groups took responsibility for the bombing, in which nine other sailors were wounded.

LEAD: MAYBE you won't need a program to tell one character from another in ''Us,'' but it can't hurt.
Although there are only two actors in Karen Malpede's play at the Theater for the New City, they take six parts, and the action occurs in three countries over an unchronological period of about 40 years.

LEAD: The team bus is a crowded van.
The pre-game meal takes place at McDonald's.
The coach does not receive a paycheck.
And the cheerleaders, locker room and big crowds do not exist.
Welcome to the world of junior varsity college basketball.


BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, DECEMBER 28, 1987
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  Holiday sales disappointed retailers across the nation.
Although results averaged about 3 percent more than last year, most merchants suffered declines in real terms.
A telephone survey indicated that sales varied among types of stores, with those catering to the affluent showing the biggest rises.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Friday about an increase in the number of ''bias incidents'' reported to the New York City Police Department included some erroneous statistics, provided by the police, for some months of 1987.
In the first three months of the year, 161 racial or ethnic incidents were reported, more than three times the number reported in the same period last year.

Catalyst Energy
LEAD: The Catalyst Energy Corporation, a New York-based company involved in developing alternative energy systems, said its board had received a offer of $10 a share for its 16 million shares outstanding.
The proposal from the Karibu Corporation, a concern being formed by members of Catalyst's management, sent Catalyst's stock up $3 a share yesterday, to $9.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

Man Found in Lobby Slain With Crossbow
LEAD: A 20-year-old man was found shot dead in a Brooklyn building lobby yesterday with a bolt apparently fired from a crossbow.
The building is known as a drug-dealing spot, and the police said the killing appeared to be drug-related.


Jaguar Output Up 16%
LEAD: Jaguar P.L.C., the luxury-car maker, produced 16 percent more cars this year than in 1986 but fell just short of its production target of 49,000, the British national news agency Press Association said today.
The agency, quoting a company spokesman, said the record total of 48,020 produced in 1987 included a rise of 24 percent in the number of six-cylinder sedan cars and 8 percent in XJS sports cars.

LEAD: Alfredo Viazzi, a Greenwich Village restaurateur and an authority on the preparation of pasta dishes, died of a heart attack last night at St.
Vincent's Hospital.
He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: REM sleep, a paradoxical and mysterious state characterized by rapid eye movements, is leading scientists to new insights about the chemistry of the brain.

LEAD: Two tax attorneys were indicted by a Federal grand jury in Manhattan yesterday, charged with scheming to generate more than $890 million in fictitious investment losses so that taxpayers could deduct more than $200 million on their tax returns.

Japan Video Output Off
LEAD: Japanese output of video cassette recorders and color televisions fell 6.8 percent and 2.1 percent, respectively, in November from a year earlier because of slow exports, the Electronic Industries Association of Japan said today.
November's production of 2.3 million video recorders marked the 12th straight monthly decline from the previous year and was down 6.6 percent from October, a spokesman said.

87's Mixed Report Card
LEAD: IF you want to file away education's key topics for 1987, consider the headings of ''poverty'' and ''reform.'' Regrettably, poverty was real, while reforms still remained largely in blueprints.
Yet, the two are closely connected: reforms in education were supposed to reduce the damage poverty does to children.

H. H. Robertson
LEAD: The H. H. Robertson Company, based in Pittsburgh, said that it had agreed to sell its Freeman chemical units.
The transactions are part of Robertson's plan, announced earlier this year, to concentrate on its building-products units.
Robertson said that it would sell Freeman Chemicals Ltd., based in Ellesmere Port, England, to Naamloze Vennootschap D.S.M of the Netherlands, and that it would sell the Freeman Chemical Corporation, in Port Washington, Wis., to the Georgia Gulf Corporation of Atlanta.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. Many people get a pain below the ribcage when they run.
What causes this pain?
A.
Several things can cause such a ''stitch'' or cramp, said Dr.
Averil Ma, a gastroenterology fellow at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center.
For example, he said, if someone ate a heavy meal and then ''started doing something else that demands blood flow, there would be relative ischemia,'' or a reduction of blood supply to the intestines; this would produce a cramp.

AIDS: The End of the Beginning
LEAD: The AIDS epidemic in America is nearing the end of its first phase.
The virus is firmly established among homosexual and bisexual men and intravenous drug abusers, and among their regular sexual partners.
If, next, it should leak substantially from these groups into the population at large, the epidemic could become self-sustaining.

LEAD: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company's Canadian unit will shut its Hamilton, Ontario, plant next month and lay off 1,300 workers because of a shrinking market for its model of tires.

If there's any single characteristic that would justify describing a Philadelphia ''school,'' it's the combination of a formidable technical fluency with the tendency for each player to work out his own system of interval permutations - the improviser as comprehensive music theorist.

LEAD: The junta that destroyed an independent election at gunpoint a month ago hopes to legitimize dictatorship in an electoral travesty scheduled for Jan. 17.
Gen.
Henri Namphy now demands that voters hand their ballots directly to his soldiers.
Candidates representing some 90 percent of the electorate have properly declined to participate under these circumstances, refusing to lend legitimacy to a cynical exercise.

Mike Jones, Auburn's leading scorer and rebounder this season with averages of 21.9 and 10.0, has been declared academically inelgible and will concentrate on a pro career in Europe, according to Coach Sonny Smith.

9 Bodies Found in Arkansas, Lifting Slaying Toll to 16
LEAD: The police discovered nine bodies in a shallow grave and in abandoned cars today outside the rural home of a man who was arrested after a shooting spree here Monday.
The bodies brought to 16 the number of slayings linked to the man.


Hopes Fall for Oil-Rig Suppliers
LEAD: After three years of staggering losses, executives in the oilfield service industry thought that the worst was finally over last summer.
Oil prices went as high as $22 a barrel and exploration for new oil in the United States began to accelerate, increasing the demand for the drilling rigs, casing, pipe and other equipment and services needed to find and produce new reserves.

LEAD: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the leading Cambodian rebel figure, said today that he would hold peace talks only in North Korea.

Advertising; P.&amp; G. Picks Grey
LEAD: As was expected, Procter &amp; Gamble is switching its Pantene line of hair-care products from FCB/Leber Katz Partners to Grey Advertising, a P.&amp; G. agency.
Billings are more than $10 million.
The move was expected because FCB/L.K.P. is also the agency for a bunch of Colgate-Palmolive products.
One doesn't have Colgate and Procter under the same roof; the same goes for Lever Brothers.

Rover Builds More Cars
LEAD: Britain's state-controlled Rover Group P.L.C. says it has built 14.5 percent more cars this year than last, mainly because of demand abroad.
Production rose to more than 468,000, from 408,677 in 1986.
Last month Rover (once called British Leyland) said it would show a pretax profit for 1987, its first since 1983.

Woody Allen Flirts With Chekhov
LEAD: Long before he reaches those sobering final words in the end credits - ''Filmed entirely at Kaufman Astoria Studios in New York'' - Woody Allen abandons any pretense that his new film, ''September,'' is anything other than a one-set play performed before the camera.
The play is Chekhovian.
We know this because the characters drink only vodka - until the final fade-out, at which point the more mournful women in the household switch to tea.

New Zealand Broker Fails
LEAD: A large New Zealand stockbroker has defaulted and ceased trading, according to an announcement today.
It was the second significant failure in a week.


Freedom To Disagree
LEAD: On the evening of Aug. 22, 1918, copies of two thin leaflets were thrown from the roof of a building on New York's Lower East Side.
Unsigned, one printed in English and one in Yiddish, they attacked President Wilson for sending U.S. troops to intervene in revolutionary Russia.


Police Say Man Wielded Knife And Was Shot
LEAD: A Queens man who was shot and killed by two police officers Tuesday evening was four to five feet away from one and was lunging with a knife when they fired 11 shots at him, the police said The man, Alfred Sanders, 39 years old, of 122-08 Farmers Boulevard, was pronounced dead about an hour later at Mary Immaculate Hospital of multiple gunshot wounds to the stomach region.

Mr.

LEAD: A judge issued an injunction today halting an election to pick the first government since 1933 for this tiny rural town, and proponents of the election vowed to appeal.


Alfred W. Roberts, Lawyer, 76

He was 76 years old.

Arab Lawyers Boycott the Israeli Military Trials
LEAD: Arab lawyers announced today that they would boycott hundreds of military trials of Palestinians rounded up on the West Bank after two weeks of widespread disorders.


No Time for Raised Voices on Race
LEAD: In recent days, New Yorkers have heard racially tainted thrusting, parrying and thrusting.


Electric Service Extended by L.I.R.R.
LEAD: After decades of dealing with diesel, thousands of Suffolk County commuters are switching to electric this week.
Electric trains, that is.
As part of the first major extension of its electrified rail system since 1970, the Long Island Rail Road on Monday began replacing diesel-powered trains with faster, quieter electric trains on 18 miles of its Main Line.


Market Place; Favorable Views Of the Railroads
LEAD: RAILROAD traffic has been strong this year, reflecting improvement in the industrial and manufacturing sectors, and further improvement is expected in 1988.

Metro Matters; Looking Back And Forward In a Leap Second
LEAD: Some of the metro matters that were subjects of this column in 1987 continued to unfold after they were first reported.
Today's leap second offers an opportunity to catch up on a few of them.


Advertising; 50-Plus Set Is New Focus Of Research
LEAD: A THIRD of the United States population is over 50 years of age, the 65-plus group is the nation's fastest growing and the leading edge of the Baby Boom will hit the big five-o in 1996.


Morgan Bank Outlines Its Mexican Debt Plan
LEAD: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company yesterday began sending to other banks that have loans to Mexico details of a proposal under which the banks would forgive part of their Mexican debt in return for 20-year Mexican bonds backed by United States Government securities.


Texaco Filing Due
LEAD: Texaco Inc. plans to file a disclosure statement today that is expected to detail how the company will finance its reorganization and how it will affect its shareholders.
The statement, to be filed in Federal Bankruptcy Court in White Plains, must be approved by Judge Howard Schwartzberg.
The document will accompany the ballots sent to shareholders, who must approve Texaco's reorganization plan.


Charles Murphy, Biographer, Is Dead at 83
LEAD: Charles J. V. Murphy, a biographer of the Duke and Dutchess of Windsor and Winston Churchill and a longtime journalist, died of lung cancer Tuesday at his home in Grafton, Vt.
He was 83 years old and moved to Grafton in 1980 from Washington, where he had lived for many years.


Advertising; Partnership to Revive New Home Magazine
LEAD: Robert J. Krefting's Park Avenue Publishing has entered into a partnership with Salls-Wright Publishing Group, Gilford, N.H., to bring back New Home magazine as a six-a-year publication, starting with the May/ June issue.


News Carriers in Olden Days
LEAD: Each New Year's Day in the 19th century, an appeal was made on behalf of newspaper delivery boys for a few coppers or even dollars as a reward for carrying the papers from hometown printing offices to the doorsteps of subscribers during the year just ended.
The newspaper carriers received little or no remuneration for their rounds.


Mutual Fund Sales Fall 20%
LEAD: Sales of mutual funds declined 20 percent in November from the previous month but still exceeded redemptions, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.


After Feud, Chicago City Ballet Dies
LEAD: Chicago's only resident ballet troupe has disbanded after a feud that drove out financial backers and prompted the resignation of its founder, Maria Tallchief, a former prima ballerina and former wife of George Balanchine.


The Kabuki Fraternity Gives a Bow to the Past
LEAD: Amid the roaring traffic and the Western glitter of the Ginza, the Kabukiza forms a graceful bridge between the traditions of Japan's feudal past and the startling social changes that built a modern economic giant.

Adrift and Divided, Philadelphia Transit Searches for Leader
LEAD: Even before he took the job as general manager of metropolitan Philadelphia's mass transit system last month, William G. Stead of San Francisco was warned that he was entering a political jungle where he might be eaten alive.
That is just about how it turned out.
And in the aftermath of the messy affair, the reputation of the oft-maligned Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority, owner and operator of the nation's fourth-largest transit system, appears to have sunk to a new low.

Washington Talk: Lobbyists; Inducements on a Major Scale
LEAD: Maria Fisher is an unusual Washington lobbyist.
She lobbies for music.
And she can be very persuasive.
She sweet-talked Malcolm S. Forbes, the magazine publisher and hot-air balloon enthusiast, into lending her his Beethoven balloon, a seven-story-high representation of a bust of the composer.
She will use it in Washington's Cherry Blossom Parade next spring.

BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 31, 1987
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  The index of leading indicators fell 1.7 percent in November as stock prices, a component, dropped for the second straight month, the Commerce Department reported.
The drop in the index has not been exceeded in more than six years, but most analysts remained confident that the economy would continue to expand, though probably at a slower pace than in the last several months.

He was 65 years old.

Judge Clears 2 Bond Raters
LEAD: The nation's two largest bond-rating agencies - the Standard &amp; Poor's Corporation and Moody's Investors Service - have been dismissed as defendants in a securities fraud lawsuit.
The suit was filed by investors after a group of utilities defaulted on $2.25 billion worth of bonds.


Army Coup in South African Homeland
LEAD: A 32-year-old officer with the rank of general in the tiny army of nominally independent Transkei, the largest of South Africa's black homelands, staged his second coup today in less than four months and installed himself in power.

LEAD: An administrative law judge today rejected the application of Detroit's two daily newspapers to combine their business operations, saying that losses at the smaller of the two papers did not prove that it was failing.

British Aerospace Orders
LEAD: British Aerospace P.L.C. said today that it had received orders worth $80 million for two BAe 146 jetliners and six more of its BAe 125-800 business jets.
The orders for the 100-seat BAe 146 were from Air U.K. and Druk Air, the national airline of Bhutan, and bring the total orders for the short-haul aircraft to 109.

LEAD: Concerned by an Alaskan commuter airline's 10 accidents in three years, including the fatal crash of an overloaded plane last month, the Government yesterday ordered a special inspection team to look into the the company's qualifications to continue carrying passengers.

Washington Talk: Briefing; Names to Know
LEAD: A lobbyist undoubtedly has a better shot at getting the ear of a member of Congress if he knows how to pronounce the member's name.
To that end, a combination desk calendar and handbook for the next session of Congress, just published by the LTV Corporation, a major military contractor, is likely to come in somewhat handy.


Dyncorp Board Accepts Bid
LEAD: The board of Dyncorp has accepted a new offer made by its chairman, Jorge E. Carnicero, to purchase the military contractor, based in McLean, Va., for cash and securities he valued at $23.25 a share, or $246 million.


James B. Carsky, Publishing Executive, 58
LEAD: James B. Carsky, senior vice president of Scholastic Inc., the publishing company, died of lung cancer Saturday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y.
He was 58 years old.

LEAD: BASEBALL


Senator Inouye's Christmas Tree Bauble
LEAD: The United States will provide $8 million of its scarce refugee funds for the year to build parochial schools in France for North African Jews.
Only they aren't refugees.
Except to Congress and Senator Daniel Inouye, that is, who so labeled them in the pre-adjournment rush to finish the gigantic appropriations bill.


Head Rabbi Made Lord In Britain's Honors List
LEAD: The New Year's honor list, which confers on a handful of people the traditional appellations of entry into the English aristocracy, includes a rather striking new life peer: Rabbi Immanuel Jakobovits.


Army Would Burn Chemical Shells at 8 Sites
LEAD: The Army said today that the best way to dispose of its aging stockpile of chemical weapons was to burn them in closed incinerators at the eight sites around the country where they are stored.


Punishment Sought by V.A. In Death After Test Mix-Up
LEAD: Veterans Administration officials recommended disciplinary action today against 11 hospital workers in the death of a man given the wrong test.


Congress Adds Apparent Barrier To Murdoch's Ownership of Post
LEAD: In a little-noticed action before adjournment, Congress has erected an apparent barrier to Rupert Murdoch's continued ownership of The New York Post and The Boston Herald while he owns television stations in the same cities.

Broad Advance Sends Dow Up 23.21
LEAD: The stock market bounced back yesterday, with a broad advance on sharply higher volume.
As measured by the 30-share Dow Jones industrial average, the market climbed 23.21 points, to 1,950.10, ending a three-session slide.


Neighbor Is Held in Deaths of 2 Rhode Island Boys
LEAD: A man who neighbors say often dressed in fatigues and wielded a knife was arraigned today in the killings of two boys and ordered held in a state mental hospital.


Candles for Elegance
LEAD: CANDLES as big as wine jugs or as thin as slivers; candles that resemble stained glass or look like Little Orphan Annie: these are among hundreds at the Candle Shop in Greenwich Village.
Now that elegance is back, incense is out and candles are in.

LEAD: As one of the most respected and effective nose guards in college football, Ted Gregory had become expert at clogging things up.


Debt Policy in Transition
LEAD: Under the plan to sell bonds to Mexico to help it reduce its debt burden, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d has effectively become a partner in debt relief with commercial banks and the Mexican Government.


Farmers' Descendant Saving 95 Acres and 145 Years of History
LEAD: In the great gray barn up the hill, a 100-year-old steam-powered wheat thresher, as big as a stage coach, rests beneath a loft filled with hay.
Across the muddy path, handmade hay rakes, oak wagon wheel hubs, unused hickory axe handles and homemade leather shoes are piled in a tool shed.

LEAD: BASEBOARD molding, the molding at floor level around the perimeter of a room, is prone to damage.
Repairing it is not too difficult for beginners.
The key is to work slowly and precisely, using the right tools.

The winner finished a head in front of Notebook in the Kentucky Jockey Club Stakes at Churchill Downs Nov.


Martell Counterbid From Grand Met
LEAD: The British hotel and liquor group Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. announced a counterbid in its quest against a Canadian rival, the Seagram Company, for control of Martell S.A., the French cognac maker.
Grand Met, which makes Smirnoff vodka and other spirits, said it would offer 2,675 francs, or about $495, a share for Martell.

LEAD: Spurred by the news that Gary Hart had been awarded 1988 Federal matching funds for his reborn Presidential campaign, the Xerox Corporation, one of his numerous unpaid creditors, tried but apparently failed to attach some of the new money to pay bills from 1984.

LEAD: A 23-year-old Bronx man has been charged with second-degree murder in the Christmas Day death of a 5-year-old neighbor who was killed when a bullet ripped through a window frame of the child's home, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: A state appeals court upheld today a ruling that the Long Island Lighting Company cannot charge customers $635 million to cover cost overruns at its Shoreham nuclear power plant and questioned whether customers should have to pay any part of an additional $1.5 billion in overruns.

Hialeah Park Not Ready to Be Scratched
LEAD: There have been recent afternoons at Hialeah Park when it seemed that the flamingos in the infield outnumbered the railbirds in the grandstand.
Flamingos and railbirds are both endangered species in Florida these days, as is Hialeah Park itself.
All of them, though, look like good bets to escape extinction.

LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, money market mutual funds and bank money market accounts were mixed for the week ended yesterday, with short-term rates ending 1987 about one and a half percentage points higher than they finished in 1986.

The team announced that it did not expect Welp, who averaged 4.8 points in 10 games, to be in uniform again until the middle of next year.

PARENT &amp; CHILD
LEAD: MAKING the jump from child to adult is no simple task.
Late adolescence is marked by vacillations between self-assurance and dependency.
It is a bit like learning to walk, making tentative steps into adulthood while still holding onto your parents for support.


The Editorial Notobook; The Soviet Inflation Challenge
LEAD: These days, the mere mention of the U-word - unemployment -sends shivers through the ranks of Moscow's economic reformers.
A guaranteed job is viewed as the signal triumph of the Soviet system.
Any streamlining that leads to unemployment could derail support for the whole reform movement.

Plane Carrrying 100 Skids Into Field at Detroit Airport
LEAD: A Pan Am jetliner arriving from London skidded off a runway while taxiing at Detroit Metropolitan Airport and became mired in a snow-covered field Tuesday evening.
The authorities said none of the 100 people on board was injured.


Saudis Plan To Borrow
LEAD: Saudi Arabia, hampered by shrinking oil revenues, said today that it was planning to borrow money to finance its 1988 budget.


New-Home Sales Off 1.2% In November
LEAD: Sales of new homes edged down 1.2 percent in November as a huge jump in demand in the Northeast was insufficient to offset weakness in the rest of the country, the Government reported today.


Bank Provision Set
LEAD: The Bank of New England Corporation said it would make a special $90 million provision in the fourth quarter for its loans to troubled developing countries, including Mexico, Brazil and Venezuela.
The company said the action should result in a fourth-quarter net income of about $13 million, or 18 cents a share, compared with about $68 million, or 98 cents a share, if the provision were not made.

Blacks in Brooklyn Plan Rally to Protest Beatings
LEAD: In a high-spirited gathering in a Brooklyn church late yesterday evening that was a defiant political rally and a heart-warming commemoration, several ministers, leaders of social service organizations and prominent black lawyers called for a march Saturday morning in Brooklyn to protest the beating of two black men this week by a group of white youths.

LEAD: A New York City police officer has been suspended without pay after an argument with other officers in front of her home in Brooklyn early Christmas morning, the police said yesterday.


Reiser, a Comic, Stars In 'Out on a Whim'
LEAD: THE beginning doesn't work; the ending suffers from a failure of imagination.
That aside, however, ''Paul Reiser: Out on a Whim'' is a pleasantly entertaining hour.
It will be seen on Home Box Office, the pay-cable channel, at 10 o'clock tonight.
It doesn't have to be centerpiece of your New Year's Eve revelry, but if you are watching television, you could do a lot worse.

LEAD: A novel proposal to help Mexico reduce its $105 billion foreign debt burden by more than $10 billion was greeted throughout Latin America today as a significant step toward easing the region's six-year debt crisis.

LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration has allowed two drug companies to market a new medicine for treating high blood pressure that may be taken only once a day.
Merck Sharp &amp; Dohme, a subsidiary of Merck &amp; Company, developed the drug, to be sold under the brand name Prinivil.

So you throw a cocktail party.

LEAD: YOU can toss your Christmas tree unceremoniously onto the curb once the holidays are over.

LEAD: The Manhattan District Attorney's office said yesterday that there was ''absolutely'' no evidence that an attack last week on a white taxicab driver by a group of black men in Washington Heights was racially motivated, despite initial police reports that suggested this.
